Adsorption per Gram

Effective sorbents exhibit high uptake capacity and rapid uptake kinetics. To determine the maximum ReO4 - capacity of NU-1000 and examine the associated kinetics, MOF samples (5 mg) were exposed to aqueous sodium perrhenate solutions (15 mL) with Re concentrations corresponding to 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, and 3 ions per MOF node (28, 43, 57, 71, and 85 ppm). The amount adsorbed q in mg of perrhenate per gram of NU-1000 was determined using   1    q =    (   C   i   -   C   f   )  V   m     where C i = initial concentration (mg/L), C f = final concentration (mg/L), V = volume of solution exposed to NU-1000 (L), and m = mass of NU-1000 (g). Adsorption isotherms were constructed by monitoring q as a function of time () and indicate that NU-1000 reaches maximum uptake within 5 min of exposure, which can be attributed to the rapid diffusion of solvent through the large pores (30 Å) of NU-1000. The maximum adsorption capacity of NU-1000 for perrhenate was determined to be 210 mg/g using the Langmuir eq () making NU-1000 among the best sorbents reported to date (). 

Post-Adsorption Characterization

Full postadsorption characterization of NU-1000 was performed to confirm the retention of both crystallinity and porosity. From powder X-ray diffraction patterns, it is apparent that NU-1000 remains crystalline throughout adsorption (). Zirconium concentrations were monitored in all ICP-OES experiments and indicate no leaching, further verifying the stability of NU-1000. Additionally, N2 isotherms before and after adsorption are nearly identical in shape with Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of 2140 ± 5 m2 g-1 (1010 ± 5 m2 cm-3) and 1640 ± 5 m2 g-1 (1040 ± 5 m2 cm-3), respectively (). The decrease in surface area is consistent with the increase in mass due to adding perrhenate to the framework and is in agreement with surface area reductions we have seen when capturing sulfate and selenate in NU-1000 and when installing catalysts in NU-1000 via postsynthetic modification. The associated pore size distribution further corroborates the existence of binding motifs within both pores as shown by the SCXRD data (). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) further elucidates the binding motifs of perrhenate within NU-1000. Neat NU-1000 exhibits a strong peak at 3674 cm-1 corresponding to non-H-bonding -OH stretches and this peak is diminished after perrhenate capture confirming the exchange of hydroxyl groups on the node for perrhenate anions ().

Conclusion

In summary, the water-stable, Zr6-MOF NU-1000 was evaluated as a sorbent for aqueous perrhenate and found to have an adsorption capacity for ReO4 - of 210 mg/g. Over a range of concentrations, NU-1000 was found to reach its maximum capacity within 5 min of exposure, presumably due to its large pores that facilitate diffusion and easy access to the nodes that contain substitutionally labile Zr-OH sites. Importantly, screening with pertechnetate further indicates NU-1000 is an effective sorbent and confirms that perrhenate is a suitable simulant for pertechnetate. Additionally, the presence of competing anions including chloride, bromide, iodide, and nitrate did not inhibit the adsorption of ReO4 -; whereas sulfate only slightly reduced ReO4 - adsorption. Furthermore, NU-1000 can be regenerated after ReO4 - adsorption by washing with dilute HCl and the MOF consistently adsorbs 1.8 ReO4 - ions per node through 5 cycles of exposure and washing. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was used to elucidate the ReO4 - binding motifs which include a unique chelating mode in both the small pore and the mesopore, and two additional unique nonchelating modes in each pore. The facile, large-scale preparation of NU-1000, large pores, and high concentration of accessible nodes, and our recently garnered understanding of perrhenate binding at the node, make this material a promising candidate for pertechnetate remediation.

PXRD and TGA

The experimental PXRD patterns of 1-3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated ones (Figure S6, Supporting Information), indicating the phase purity. TGA was performed under N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1-3 (Figure S7, Supporting Information). For 1, no weight loss was found before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at around 290 °C. For 2, it shows a weight loss of 4.19% before 94 °C, which due to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.14%). There is no weight loss or obvious heat change observed in the temperature range of 94-295 °C, and then the samples start to decompose at approximately 295 °C. For 3, the phase remains stable up to 376 °C until the organic ligands start to be released, exhibiting higher thermal stability than 1 and 2, and the reason should be due to the interpenetrating structure of 3.

Magnetic Properties

Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for complexes 1-3 was measured for the polycrystalline samples in the range of 1.9-300 K under 1000 Oe of an external field. As shown in a-c, the χM T value at 300 K of 1 is 2.50 cm3 K mol-1, 2 is 2.95 cm3 K mol-1, and 3 is 3.25 cm3 K mol-1, which are larger than the spin-only value of 1.88 cm3 K mol-1 (S = 3/2, g = 2) state based on one Co(II) ion. The larger values are the result of contributions to the susceptibility from the orbital angular momentum at high temperature. Then they abruptly decreased to 1.50 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, 1.75 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, and 1.81 cm3 K mol-1 for 3 at 1.90 K, and this can be assigned to a large zero-field splitting (ZFS). In accordance with the Curie-Weiss law, χM = C/(T - θ), the data in the range of 1.9-300 K show a good linear relationship between χM -1 and T, with a Curie constant of C = 2.14 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant of θ = -10.41 K for 1, C = 2.13 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -10.34 K for 2, C = 2.34 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -10.34 K for 3. The moderate negative θ values of the Weiss constants indicate antiferromagnetic behavior of 1-3. In addition, the large separation between the neighboring Co(II) cores is most probably the main reason for the weaker magnetic interaction.

Luminescent Properties

Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The luminescent properties of zinc carboxylate compounds have been investigated. The photoluminescent spectra of free neutral ligands L1-L2 and ODPTA measured at room temperature show the emission maxima at 423 (λex = 255) for L1, 420 (λex = 340) for L2, and 406 (λex = 354) nm for ODPTA, respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 based on L1 and L2 show the emission maxima at 383 (λex = 336) and 402 (λex = 340) nm, respectively. The emission of the ODPTA and L1-L2 ligands may be assigned to π* → n and π* → π transitions of the intraligands. In comparison with the N-donor ligands and multicarboxylate ligand, the emission maxima of compounds 1 and 2 have changed and show blue shifts (Figure ). It is possible that a combination of several factors together, including a change in the highest occupied molecular orbital and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energy levels of deprotonated ODPT4- anions and neutral ligands coordinating to metal centers, the charge-transfer transition between N-donor ligands and metal centers, N-donor ligands coordinating to the metal centers, which effectively increase the rigidities of the ligands and reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay, and π* → n and π* → π transitions of the intraligands. In comparison with 1 and 2, the emission differences between them may be caused by different neutral ligands.

For compound 1, the weight loss in the range of 17-165 °C corresponds to the departure of lattice water molecules (observed, 5.6%; calculated, 5.5%), the weight losses in the range of 273-512 °C correspond to the removal of the corresponding organic components, and the remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (observed, 16.8%; calculated, 16.2%). The anhydrous compound 2 begins to decompose at 202 °C and ends above 484 °C. The weight loss (found, 84.5%) corresponds to the loss of organic components (calculated, 85.2%). The remaining weight of 15.5% corresponds to the percentage (14.8%) of ZnO.

A novel guest-free metal organic framework (GFMMOF) is synthesized and structurally characterized. It contains one-dimensional close-packed open channels with a pore diameter of 4.5 Å. It demonstrates a remarkable thermal stability, a unique ability to separate methanol from dimethyl ether or water, and is among the microporous MOFs having the highest adsorbed hydrogen density (0.054 g/cm3 at 77 K and 1 atm). 

There has been some concern on practical utility of porous metal organic materials due to their thermal instability. Many of these compounds being investigated are incapable of withstanding prolonged and repeated heating, even at relatively mild temperatures. However, as an exception, GFMMOFs can possess exceptionally high thermal stability. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of 1 showed that no weight loss occurred during a prolonged heating at 350 °C (over 24 h). The structure retained its crystallinity fully. This was verified by PXRD analysis immediately after TGA. This remarkable feature demonstrates that MMOFs of this type may indeed be suitable for applications that require frequent adsorption-desorption cycles over long time periods, such as on-board hydrogen storage. 

The pore characteristics and hydrogen adsorption capabilities of 1 were characterized by gas sorption study using a previously described procedure. The DA (Dubinin-Astakhov)2q pore volume of 1 was calculated to be 0.14 and 0.15 cm3/g based on the N2 and Ar sorption data collected at 77 and 87 K, respectively (Figure a). Both follow a typical Type I isotherm. A gravimetric density of 0.75 and 0.52 wt % of hydrogen was achieved at 77 and 87 K and 1 atm, respectively (Figure b). The density of adsorbed H2 at 77 K and 1 atm, calculated to be 0.054 g/cm3, is as high as that of our previously reported value, 0.053 g/cm3, which is one of the highest values among the porous metal organic frameworks reported to date. This high hydrogen density was achieved with relatively small multipoint BET surface area, 256 m2/g, from N2  adsorption data at 77 K, and smaller pores compared to [M3(bpdc)3bpy]⋅4DMF⋅H2O (M = Co or Zn). In addition, the isosteric heats of hydrogen adsorption Q st of 1 were calculated to be 6.7-6.4 kJ/mol (coverage 0.02-0.5 wt %). These values are similar to those of [Co3(bpdc)3bpy]⋅4DMF⋅H2O, suggesting a relatively strong adsorbent-adsorbate interaction. It leads us to believe this high density is a result of suitable pore diameter (comparable to H2 kinetic diameter) and effective pore structure (close-packed 1D channels).  

The new MMOF material is also of great interest because of its potential for unique applications in gas separation. The effective cross-section of the 1D channels in 1 is ~4.5 Å, allowing it to adsorb normal paraffins, methanol (MeOH), and dimethyl ether (DME) but to exclude aromatics. The intimate relationship between MeOH and DME in important reactions such methanol to olefins and methanol to gasoline made them prime candidates for our gas sorption study. Compound 1 has the property of being very hydrophobic, exhibiting essentially zero water adsorption (<~1 mg/g at P/P 0 = 0.65) but adsorbing high volumes of methanol, 110 mg/g at 24.5 °C and 90 Torr MeOH (P/P 0 = 0.73). The shape of the MeOH adsorption isotherms (Figure ) is typical for an adsorbent that exhibits relatively weak interactions with the adsorbate, adsorbing less than ~3 mg/g up to 40 Torr followed by a very sharp increase in adsorption as capillary condensation fills the pores with MeOH. The condensation point shifts ~4.7 Torr/1 °C, indicating that at ~15 °C capillary condensation should occur at very low pressure (e.g. 1 Torr MeOH). The Zn(tbip)/MeOH system also exhibits hysteresis (Supporting Information). The adsorption properties of 1 may be compared with those of pure silica ZSM-5 (4 ppm Al, silicalite), which is hydrophobic but adsorbs as much as 7 mg/g of water at P/P 0 = 0.65 and shows moderate affinity for MeOH (Supporting Information). Its MeOH adsorption isotherms are fitted reasonably by the Langmuir equation, with adsorption beginning at low pressures but not exhibiting the sharp increase associated with capillary condensation.  

Zn(tbip) also exhibits potential for the separation of DME from MeOH. The adsorption of DME, followed by MeOH, is illustrated in Figure . At 30 °C, 650 Torr (P/P 0 = 0.13), 30 mg/g of DME is rapidly adsorbed on 1. After 30 min, simultaneously, the pressure of DME is set to zero and MeOH is introduced at 85 Torr. As DME desorbs (P = 0) it is replaced by MeOH and quickly reaches the 105 mg/g adsorption level. Several separation schemes are possible. For example, at conditions of T and P below the MeOH capillary condensation point, DME will selectively adsorb for facile separation from MeOH. In a second case, T is chosen to maximize the difference between DME and MeOH adsorption, and after adsorption of the binary gases, a few degrees increase in temperature will result in desorption of a majority of the MeOH and a relatively small amount of DME. The isosteric heat of adsorption of DME computed from adsorption isotherms (Supporting Information), at Q = 10 mg/g loading, is 51 kJ/mol and is similar to that of MeOH (Q = 60 mg/g loading points of Figure ), 53 kJ/mol. Note the latter heats include substantial adsorbate-adsorbate contributions.

Abstract

Two new Co(II) metal-organic frameworks, namely [Co2(bpm)(H2O)3(L)] n  (1) and {[Co(bpe)(H2O)(H2L)]⋅(bpe)0.5⋅(H2O)} n  (2), (H4L=1,1':2',1"-terphenyl-3,3",4',5'-tetracarboxylic acid, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene), have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both complexes 1 and 2 have been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Complexes 1 and 2 consist of 1D Co(II) chains bridging by carboxylate groups in syn-anti fashion. 1 shows a novel 3D tri-nodal (4,6,10)-connected net with a (3.43.52)2(32.414.512.612.74.8)(32.42.55.64.72) topology. While 2 exhibits a 2D sql layer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that both 1 and 2 show weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions in 300-8K for 1 and 300-16K for 2, respectively, and then 2 also displays ferromagnetic coupling at lower temperatures.

The TGA curves of the two compounds are shown in . For complex 1, the first weight lost of 6.6% was observed from 200°C to 270°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 7.2%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 270 to ~562°C. The final residue of 23.8% is close to the calculated 23.6% based on CoO. For complex 2, the pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 230 to 540°C.

Magnetic properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 at 1000Oe in the range of 2-300K in  . For complexes 1 and 2, The value of χ M T at 300K is 2.78 and 3.47cm3 mol-1 K, respectively, which is much larger than the spin-only value (1.875cm3 mol-1 K) for one spin only Co(II) (S=3/2) ion, indicating the important orbital contribution arising from the high-spin octahedral Co(II) . Upon cooling, χ M T decreases to minimum value of 1.62cm3 mol-1 K at 3K for 1 and minimum value of 2.35cm3 mol-1 K at 12K for 2, and then increases to 1.70cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 1 and 3.87cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 2. Upon cooling, the decrease of χ M T at high temperature is a typical manner of spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) ions. The increases in χ M T under 12K for 2 are clearly indicative of ferromagnetism between neighboring Co ions . The temperature dependence of 1/χ M obeys the Curie-Weiss law with C=2.87cm3 Kmol-1 and θ=-12.80K above 12K for 1 and C=3.62cm3 Kmol-1 and θ=-13.80K above 25K for 2, revealing the presence of strong spin-orbit couplings.

In this equation,   x = λ / k T  , ( λ  is the spin-coupling parameter and A is a measure of the crystal field strength due to the inter-electronic repulsions). The best fits gave the parameters λ=-135cm-1, A=1.03 and θ=0.19K for 1 and λ=-134cm-1, A=1.46 and θ=4.30K for 2. The positive θ values confirm the presence of ferromagnetic interactions.

The data were fitted as the noncritical-scaling theory with the following simple phenomenological Eq. :  (2)     Χ M   T = A exp  ( -   E 1   / k T )  + B exp  ( -   E 2   / k T )     where A+B is the high-temperature Curie constant, E 1/k for the effects of both spin-orbit coupling and site distortion, and the value E 1/k corresponding to spin coupling between Co(II) ions  The best fits gave the parameters A=1.26cm3 mol-1 K, E 1/k=46.64K, B=1.65cm3 mol-1 K, and E 2/k=-0.005K for 1 and A=1.66cm3 mol-1 K, E 1/k=72.12K, B=2.13cm3 mol-1 K, and E 2/k=-1.09K for 2.

The solid-state photoluminescence spectra of 1 and the free H3CAM ligand at room temperature were given in  . Complex 1 exhibits blue luminescence with the maximum emission at 469nm upon excitation at 370nm, while the free H3CAM ligand exhibits green luminescence with the maximum emission at 526nm upon excitation at 365nm. Compared to the free H3CAM ligand, complex 1 results in much higher emission energy with a large blue shift of 57nm. This indicates that the emission of 1 may be originated from charge transition between the ligand and the metal ions. The luminescent properties show that 1 may be a good blue light-emitted material. The diffuse reflectance spectra of 1 reveal the presence of an optical gap of 3.45eV (Fig. S3, Supporting Information).

In summary, we have obtained the third new 3D coordination polymer {Cd2.5(CAM)(HCAM)(H2O)7⋅1.5H2O}n (1) based on the H3CAM ligand, presenting an interesting (4,6)-connected framework. The structural analyses show that the coordination of hydroxyl group with metal centers plays an important role in governing the multidimensional MOFs for H3CAM ligand. Compared with the free H3CAM ligand, polymer 1 displays a strong blue photoluminescence with large blue shift of 57nm.

Crystal data for 1: C28H44N4O37Cd5, Mr =1590.67, colorless crystal, triclinic, space group P-1, a =10.2240(17)Å, b =11.2172(18)Å, c =11.3302(19)Å, α =69.059(2), β =76.930(2), γ =88.666(2) º, V =1179.8(3)Å3, Z =1, T =293(2)K, D calcd. =2.239gcm-3, μ =2.334mm-1, R (wR)=0.0413 (0.1161) and GOF=1.046 for 4290 reflections with I >2.00 σ(I). The crystal structure of 1 was solved by direct methods using the Siemens SHELXTL version 5 package of crystallographic software and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. Non-hydrogen atoms were located by difference Fourier maps and subjected to anisotropic refinement. All hydrogen atoms of carbon atoms were calculated in idealized positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located in difference Fourier syntheses and refined with O-H distances restrained to a target value of 0.85Å and Uiso (H)=1.5Ueq (O), and hydrogen atoms of lattice water molecules were not included for 1.

Description of X-ray crystal structure of complex 1 

A structural view of the trinuclear unit of complex 1 with the atom numbering scheme is shown in  . The complex crystallizes in the hexagonal P63/m space group with the refined formula [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1). In the unit cell four anionic [Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]- trinuclear units, six Na+ and six ClO4 - counter ions along with three water molecules of crystallization and additionally, to balance the total charge, four hydronium ions (formally O11 or O11B and O12) are present. The anionic cluster is constituted by three [Cu(cbal)] subunits in which each copper(II) ion is coordinated to a deprotonated tridentate ligand, cbal2-. The [Cu(cbal)] subunits are held together by two distinct bridging systems: (i) one μ3-hydroxo group (O5) which is coordinated to each of the three copper centers  and (ii) the three bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen atoms, each coming from different ligand unit. The resulting trinuclear species can be viewed as either a partial cubane or a cubane with one missing corner of the [Cu3O4] core. In the trinuclear unit, the three copper(II) ions assemble at the corners of an equilateral triangle with ~3.202(2)Å edges ( ). Each copper(II) ion is in a Jahn-Teller distorted octahedral geometry with the bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen of the ligand and an exogenous H2O molecule occupying the elongated axial positions. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around each copper(II) center is defined by the O1, N1, O3' and O5 atoms, the axial positions are taken by O3 and O10 atoms. The average Cu-O(bridging hydroxo) and Cu-O(bridging carboxylate) bond distances are 2.017 and 2.137Å, respectively. The Cu-O(hydroxo)-Cu and Cu-O(carboxylate)-Cu bridging angles are 105.1(2)° and 96.77(18)°, respectively. The μ3-O5 atom is located at 0.807Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This induces a relatively bigger Cu-O(hydroxo)-Cu bridging bond angle of 105.1(2)° on the structure when compared to the smaller Cu-O(carboxylate)-Cu bridging angle of 96.77(18)°. The observed Cu---Cu inter-metallic distance at 3.202(2)Å in the complex is comparable to the values reported in the literature . The crystal structure of complex 1 features several modes of carboxylate binding involved in a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu3 units are inter-linked through the Na+ ions (). The plentiful hydrogen bonding interactions among the coordinated water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of the ligand contribute towards the stabilization of the crystal lattice.

Description of X-ray crystal structure of complex 2 

A structural view of the trinuclear body of complex 2 with the atom numbering scheme is shown in  . The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group with the refined formula [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O. Unlike to complex 1, each metal center of the Cu3 unit poses different coordination geometries. The coordination geometry around the Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers is best described as distorted octahedral, square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometry, respectively. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around the Cu1 center is defined by the O1, O14, O3 and N1 atoms, the axial positions are occupied by the O11 and O13 atoms. The square base of the square pyramidal geometry around the Cu2 center is described by the O5, O14, O7 and N2 atoms, whereas the axial position is occupied by the O3 atom. The trigonal bipyramidal geometry around Cu3 center is defined by the O5, O11 and O7 atoms at the equatorial position, and N3 and O14 atoms at the axial position. The coordination environment of the counter cation K+ is best described by the distorted octahedral geometry, with four carboxylate and two water oxygens. The Cu1-O11 bond distance of 2.377(7)Å is slightly longer when compared to the 2.217(6) and 2.233(6)Å values for Cu2-O3 and Cu3-O7, respectively. The Cu-O(bridging carboxylate)-Cu bond angles are 97.6(2)°, 96.5(3)° and 94.2(3)° for Cu1-O3-Cu2, Cu2-O7-Cu3 and Cu3-O11-Cu1, respectively. The Cu1-O14 and Cu2-O14 bond length values between the copper(II) ions and the central μ3-OH oxygen atom are almost identical at 2.069(6) and 2.002(6)Å, respectively, while the Cu3-O14 distance is 1.966(6)Å. The μ3-O14 atom is located at 0.842Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This opens the Cu-Ohydroxo-Cu bond angle to an average value of 103.69°. Unlike to complex 1, the Cu3 triangle in complex 2 is not equilateral as the Cu---Cu edges are at 3.115(2), 3.174(3) and 3.204(3)Å distances ( ). Again, the average Cu---Cu separation of 3.164Å is comparable to the values reported in the literature for similar complexes . Similar to complex 1, the crystal structure of complex 2 displays a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu3 units are connected to each other through K+ ions (). The complex 2 also shows an intricate hydrogen bonding among the coordinated water molecule, secondary amine and carboxylate groups of the ligand, contributing to the stabilization of the crystal structure.

Solution UV-Vis and MS studies

The solution behavior of complexes 1 and 2 was analyzed using UV-Vis and mass spectrometric techniques. UV-Vis spectra were obtained on aqueous solutions (pH~7.5) of the complexes. The spectrum of complex 1 displays a broad absorption band at 705nm (ε, 231lmol-1 cm-1) due to the d-d transition. The spectrum also shows two distinct metal ion bound ligand-based π→π∗ transitions at 272nm (ε, 7955lmol-1 cm-1) and 228nm (ε, 27523lmol-1 cm-1). Similarly, the spectrum of complex 2 shows a broad absorption band at 719nm (ε, 86lmol-1 cm-1) due to the d-d transition. The spectrum also indicates two distinct metal ion bound ligand-based π→π∗ transitions at 274nm (ε, 2074lmol-1 cm-1) and 225nm (ε, 6771lmol-1 cm-1). No significant changes were observed in UV-Vis spectra when complexes 1 and 2 were measured in aqueous solutions (pH~7.5) after ~24h. The representative UV-Vis spectra for complex 1 are shown in the . Indeed, the solution stability of the cluster species has been authenticated previously using the spectrophotometric method . Thus, the stability of complexes in solution is established.

Luminescence properties of 2 and 3 

In view of the potential application in the photochemistry area, we endeavored to study the luminescent properties of these coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of 2-3 and free Hpytza ligand were investigated in powder at room temperature ( ). Compounds 2 and 3 exhibit photoluminescence with emission maximum at 380 nm and 372 nm upon excitations at 328 nm, respectively. These fluorescent emissions could be tentatively assigned to the intraligand (π-π*) fluorescences emission , because a similar emission at 376 nm upon excitation at 328 nm was also observed for the free ligand Hpytza. Compound 1 does not exhibit detectable emission. The reason is complex 1 contains Co(II) metal with low energy d-d transitions . These transitions quench luminescence. It is extremely rare that such complexes are luminescent.

Thermal stabilities of 1-3 

To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-3 were carried out in the temperature range of 30-800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere ( ). The TG curves for 1-3 show the initial weight loss of 7.20% from 190 to 250 °C for 1, 7.61% from 220 to 280 °C for 2, and 7.48% from 140 to 280 °C for 3, respectively, which can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calculated, 7.15% for 1; 7.68% for 2; 7.43% for 3). Further weight loss are probably caused by the decomposition of the pytza ligands beginning at about 250 °C for 1, 280 °C for 2 and 3, leading to the collapse of the frameworks.

The TG curve of compound 1 ( ) exhibits two steps of weight losses. The first weight loss is 3.98% (calc. 3.71%) in the range of 340-380 °C, corresponding to the release of coordination water. The second weight loss is 61.72% (calc. 62.89%) in the temperature range of 390-480 °C, corresponding to the release of piperazine and btec ligands. The sample does not lose weight at temperatures higher than 480 °C. The residue is ZnO.
Fluorescent property

The luminescent spectra of 1 and the free H4btec ligand in the solid state at room temperature are shown in   and  . The emissions of 1 [λ max=489.00 nm, (τ=0.016 ms)] (τ=lifetime; the short lifetime suggests that luminescence should be assigned to fluorescence) can be observed upon photoexcitation at 442.00 nm, while emission of the free H4btec (λ max=342.00 nm) is upon photoexcitation at 308.00 nm. Thus, the blue fluorescence may be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . A similar emission band has also been observed in other zinc-organic polymer compounds . Compound 1 may be used as an advanced material for blue-light emitting diode devices because of the blue fluorescence emission. This condensed polymeric material may be an excellent candidate for highly thermally stable and solvent-resistant blue fluorescent material because 1 is highly thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and non-polar solvents such as ethanol, chloroform, acetone, and water .

Thermal studies

The thermal decomposition of complexes 1-3 was studied by TGA under an atmosphere of oxygen (Fig. S9). Compound 1 is thermally stable up to 97°C. Between 97°C and 601°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule (Fig. S9-A). No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further. A plateau in the decomposition of 1 is reached at 601°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

Compound 2 is thermally stable up to 35°C. Between 35°C and 491°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-B). A plateau in the decomposition of 2 is reached at 491°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

Compound 3 is thermally stable up to 175°C. Between 175°C and 512°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-C). A plateau in the decomposition of 3 is reached at 512°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

Cytotoxicity results

V(V) cell toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes

In an effort to examine whether V(V) ions (non-complexed inorganic vanadium) affect cell survival, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with 1, 10, 100, or 200μΜ of KVO3 for 24h (A). The results show that V(V) affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<0.05). Specifically, reduction in cell survival is not affected at low concentrations (1, 10μΜ) compared to the control, whereas reduction in cell survival amounts to 40% at 100μΜ and almost 50% at 200μΜ (p<0.05). Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control, exhibiting full reduction of cell survival under the employed experimental conditions.

Ligand toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes

To investigate the cytotoxic potential of the organic ligands-substrates LiH (i=1-3) on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, the cells were treated with 1, 10, 100, 200μΜ of L1H, L2H and L3H, respectively, for 24h ( B-1 through B-3). The results show that L3H affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<0.05). Ιn particular, L3H causes reduction in cell survival amounting to 28% at 1μΜ, 35% at 10μΜ, 70% at 100μΜ and >90% at 200μΜ (p<0.05). Ligand L1H reduces cell survival only at the highest concentration (200μΜ). Ligand L2H is not cytotoxic at all concentrations tested (p>0.05).

Photoluminescence properties

Coordination polymers involving d10 metal centers and aromatic organic spacers have current been a promising class of candidates for functional crystalline materials with good photoluminescent properties . Thus, solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-3 and the free L434  ligand were studied at ambient conditions, as depicted in  . Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of 1-3 at 280nm leads to visible fluorescence emissions with the peak maxima occurring at 392nm for 1, 390nm for 2, and 392nm for 3. The fluorescent spectrum of the free L434  displays the maximum emission peak at 354nm (λ ex =320nm). The obvious red shift of the maximum emissions of 1-3 compared with that of L434  ligand can be attributed to the coordination interactions of Cd(II) centers with L434  ligands. Significantly, complexes 1-3 show different emission intensities, which should be mainly caused by the halide anions therein as well as the effect of water molecule as ligand in 3.

Thermal study

Thermal stability of complexes 1-3 was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments (see  ). For complexes 1 and 2, the coordination patterns are solvent-free and the TG traces reveal a relatively higher thermal stability (both stable up to ca. 345°C). Decomposition supervenes with several different and consecutive steps of weight loss upon further heating, which does not stop at ca. 800°C. The TGA curve of 3 shows the first loss of 2.33% in the range of 78-248°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules. Pyrolysis of the residual sample is observed upon heating to 407°C with a very sharp weight lose, which does not end until 800°C.

Results and discussion

Structure description

In the previous work, we had reported a 2D energetic MOF [Cd(H2O)2(AFT)2] n  (3) , which of each two Cd(II) cations can mutual connect through bidentate coordination tetrazole-ring of AFT group, and form #-shape structure (). The crystal structure of 1 belongs to monoclinic, pertains to P21/c space group, a=7.857(3)Å, b=9.409(3)Å, c=9.046(3)Å, β=93.560(4)° and D c=2.252g⋅cm-3 . The purpose is to verify that we can design and synthesis the more complex structures by adding energetic bidentate or multidentate ligands, such as hydrazine and ODH, to replace two coordination water molecules of 3.

In 1, the crystal structure belongs to monoclinic, pertains to C2/c space group, a=28.359(8)Å, b=7.8563(16)Å, c=15.790(3)Å, β=120.72(2)° and D c=2.026g⋅cm-3 (). There are one cadmium(II) cation, four AFT ligands and two hydrazine molecules from  . Furazan-ring is not take part in coordination. Moreover, tetrazole-rings and hydrazine molecules present typical bidentate coordination modes, and connect with two cadmium cations, featuring a one-dimensional chain structure ( ). The six basically equivalent CdN bonds are approximately equal about 2.33-2.45Å from the  . The bond angles of two contraposition hydrazine molecules and Cd(II) cation are close to 180° (<N12-Cd1-N11=179.3°), but the bond angles of two N atoms of contraposition AFT groups and Cd(II) cation are close to 157° (<N1A-Cd1-N2=156.8° and <N13-Cd1-N8=157.2°). The nitrogen atoms from two border upon ligands and Cd(II) cation's bond angles are all departure from 90°. Therefore, all above data demonstrate that the each Cd(II) cations of 1 exhibit appreciably distorted-octahedral configuration. In addition, the distance of two Cd(II) cations (4.08Å) for 1 is more shorter than 3 (6.53Å), owing to shortening the distance of two cadmium ions by hydrazine molecule. But 1has zero point seven crystal waters compared with 3, which is one reason of lower density. From the packing diagram ( ), intermolecular hydrogen bonds make an important contribution to extend the structure into a 3D supramolecule and enhance the thermal stability.

In 1, a melting point could not be observed in the DSC curves, in spite of the presence of coordination water molecules. The peaks of exothermic decomposition stages were observed at 306.3°C, 320.5°C, 327.0°C and 340.2°C, and onset temperatures were observed at 302.5°C, 308.5°C, 315.7°C and 339.9°C, respectively, corresponding to the linear heating rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C⋅min-1. Compared with 3, compound 1 has only one exothermic process, and is one of the few thermally stable energetic materials at temperature higher than 300°C.

In 2, there were two endothermic peaks in the temperature ranges of 50-100°C and 180-200°C, which are coincident with the loss of all lattice water molecules. Then, the cleavage of amino- and ODH groups and the breaking of tetrazole and furazan rings are destroyed, so it gets unstable and begins to decompose. It can be seen from the DSC curve, the decomposition occurs in the temperature range of 220-400°C with one endothermic and two exothermic steps. The peaks of first exothermic decomposition stages were observed at 271.3°C, 287.8°C, 300.0°C and 308.5°C, respectively, corresponding to the linear heating rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C⋅min-1. Therefore, 2 was more unstable than that of 1.

Magnetic measurement

Variable-temperature magnetic measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL-5-type) at a magnetic field of 0.5Tesla over the temperature range 1.8-300K. Correction are based on subtracting the sample-holder signal, contribution χ Dia estimated from Pascal constants  and equals -298, -269 and -312×10-6 cm3 mole-1 for 1, 2 and 3, respectively. The effective magnetic moment was calculated from the equation:     μ   eff   = 2.83 (   χ   M   T   )   1 / 2   ( B.M. )  .

EPR spectra and magnetic properties

The EPR parameters of powder spectra of compounds 1, 2 and 3 are presented in the  . These spectra indicated rhombic line for complex 1 and axial lines for 2 and 3 complexes.

The values χMT of complexes 1, 2 and 3 in the temperature range 10-300K are near constant. At 300K they are equal 4.22cm3 mol-1 K (μ eff =5.82 B.M.) for 1, 4.30cm3 mol-1 K ( μ  eff =5.87 B.M.) for 2 and 4.18cm3 mol-1 K (μ eff =5.79 B.M.) for 3, as expected for an uncoupled manganese d5 electron configuration center. Calculated Weiss constants indicate values Θ=-0.2K for complex 1, Θ=-0.2K for complex 2, Θ=-0.3K for complex 3.

The variation of the magnetization M versus the magnetic field H have been measured for all complexes at 2K indicates linear relation to ~1Tesla and than continues Brillouin function ( ). Value of magnetizations at 5 Tesla equals 4.74 B.M., 4.86 B.M. and 4.72 B.M. for complexes 1, 2 and 3, respectively. All these data confirms presence of spin S = 5/2 and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese (II) centers.

The least-squares fit of the experimental data using these equations were limited to the temperature range from 1.8 up to 300K and leads zJ' =-0.02cm-1and g =1.97 with the agreement factor R equal 1.74×10-4 for complex 1, zJ' =-0.03cm-1, g =1.99 and R =1.93×10-4 for complex 2, zJ' =-0.03cm-1, g =1.96 and R =1.75×10-4 for complex 3.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P‾1 and features a 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional oxo-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy2(3,4-qldc)2(H2O)4]n and ox2- pillars. Its asymmetrical unit is composed of one dysprosium ion, one independent 3,4-qldc2- ligand, one-half oxalate ligand and two coordinated water molecules. As shown in  , each Dy3+ ion is nine-coordinated in a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry with five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3a, O3b and O4b) from three 3,4-qldc ligands, two oxygen atom (O5, O6) from one oxalate ligand and two oxygen atom (O7, O8) from two coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Dy-O bond distances range from 2.346(7) to 2.708(6) Å. The bond angles of O-Dy-O are in the range of 50.1(2)-155.2(6)° comparable to those in other Ln carboxylate complexes observed in our previous papers . In present case, the 3,4-H2qldc was completely deprotonated and each 3,4-qldc2- ligand via μ 3-η 1:η 1:η 1:η 2 coordination manner links two Dy(III) centers ( ) to generate a 14-membered ring. On the basis of the coordination mode I and conformation of ligand 3,4-qldc2-, two neighboring rings are connected in parrallel into a 1-D zigzag chain along a axis via two μ 2-O3 bridges (a). And then by means of the coordination mode μ 2-κ 4-O of ox2- ligand (viewing as pillars), these one-dimensional chains are constructed to form two-dimensional layers as depicted in b. In order to identify the connectivity in the ligands and metals, the topology of the whole framework is investigated. While considering the dinuclear motif [Dy2(μ 2-O)2] constructed by two μ 2-O3 from two 3,4-qldc2- ligands of two adjacent 14-membered rings as a node (a), the C2O4 2- (b) and 3,4-qldc2- (c) as linkers, the simplified topological representation of the compound 1 is described in , which exhibits a 4-connected 44 topology (d). Moreover, through interlayer π...π stacking interactions, a 3-D network is assembled as shown in Figure S2.

The XPRD pattern of compound 1 reveals that the title compound is pure single phase and is also of completely identical molecular structures, corresponding to the simulated results from the single-crystal X-ray data (Figure S3). The thermal stability of the title compound was examined and its TGA curve was shown in Figure S4. The experiment was performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of the compound under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The crystals of 1 showed the first endothermic weight loss of 7.97% around 260°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.87%) from one formula unit. And then the weight loss of 8.94% (calc. 9.5%) between 254 and 355°C ascribes to the loss of half oxalate ligand from one formula unit, and the residue weight corresponds to Dy(3,4-qldc). Another major weight loss occurred in the range of 350-800°C, Dy2O3 was assumed to be the residual product in 40.91%, supported by the expected value of 40.71%.

The solid-state luminescence property of this compound was investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of the compound 1 (Figure S5), obtained with excitation wavelength of 365nm, are composed of emission lines typical for Dysprosium (III). The emission at 479, 577, and 658nm is attributed to the characteristic emission of 4F9/2, and 6HJ (J =15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transitions of the Dy3+ ion. The relative intensity ratio for the emission lines at 479 and 573nm is indicative of the larger probability for the 4F9/2 → 6HJ (J =15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transition of the Dy3+ ion.

Abstract

A novel three dimensional (3D) coordination polymer [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  (pydc=pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate, Hpic=picolinic acid) (1) has been synthesized hydrothermally and characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, TG/DTA, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). This compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with cell parameters a =9.3041(13)Å, b =14.216(2)Å, c =10.5401(15)Å, V =1387.72(30)Å3 and Z =4. Complex 1 has a distinct 3D open-framework architecture due to the presence of picolinic ligands, which are converted from 2,5-pydc ligands by in-situ decarboxylation under the hydrothermal conditions. The compound exhibits strong luminescent emissions because of the f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion at room temperature. According to TGA/DTA analysis, the coordination polymer is thermally stable up to ~300°C.

IR spectra

In the FT-infrared spectra, the ligand 2,5-pydc shows stretching bands attributed to ν(OH), ν(CO), ν(CN) and ν(CH) at 3473, 1737, 1598 and 1120cm-1, respectively (). FT-IR spectrum of the complex displays a broad absorption band at about 3478cm-1 for the stretching vibrations of ν(OH) groups  engaged in hydrogen bonds (O-H vibrations of water molecules). The CO stretching frequency of the ligand appeared at 1737cm-1 as the strongest absorption in the IR spectrum. After coordination, the CO stretching frequency of the complex shifted to 1660cm-1, indicating that the oxygen atoms in the carbonyl group were also coordinated to samarium ions . The remarkable changes observed in the 900-400cm-1 region for the complex are attributed to the coordination of the ligands to the metal. The appearance of ν(SmO) bands at 722-650 and 526-592cm-1 can be attributed to the carbonyl and carboxylate oxygen atoms , respectively. These bands support the chelation through the O atoms. A new band, having very strong intensity at 505cm-1, can be assigned to the ν(SmN)  stretching vibration. This band supports chelation through the N atoms of the 2,5-pydc ligands ().

Thermal stability

It is well known that lanthanide ions have a high coordination number, and this feature may cause structural flexibility and increase thermodynamic stability . TG analysis supported the thermal stability of the coordination polymer ( ). It was performed in the temperature range 50-800°C under a N2 atmosphere at 1atm with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 on a Perkin Elmer Diamond TG/DTA. The compound is thermally stable up to ~300°C. Above this temperature, the TG curve exhibits two weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 4.08%, between 298 and 340°C, is attributable to the loss of a coordinating water molecule in the formula unit (calculated: 3.95%). The next significant weight loss of 62.96%, which occurred from 350 to 545°C, corresponds to the decomposition of the 2,5-pydc and picolinic ligands (calculated: 63.37%). The remaining weight of 32.96% corresponds to the final product, Sm2O3 percentage (32.68%). The thermal results fundamentally agree with the structure of 1, and the observed thermal behavior reflects the structural features.

Magnetic study

The coordination polymers consisting of dinuclear or polynuclear Co(II) units may serve as promising magnetic materials, the Co(II)⋯Co(II) distance in the dinuclear unit of complex 7 is 4.619Å, suggesting the existence of magnetic exchange interaction in the dinuclear Co(II) ions. However, Co(II) ions in complexes 3 and 5 are well separated by AcAIP and bis(imidazolyl) ligands, magnetic exchange between Co(II) ions can be neglected, their magnetic behavior is similar to mononuclear metal ions. As a result, the magnetic susceptibilities of only complex 7 were measured at 2-300K in an applied field of 1000 Oe. The temperature dependence of χ m T is depicted in  , χmT value at 300K is 3.460cm3 mol-1 K, which is much higher than the spin-only value of 1.875cm3 Kmol-1 based on single Co(II) ion (g =2 and s =3/2) due to the spin-orbital coupling. The χ m T value is almost constant above 70°C, but it goes down quickly to 0.160cm3 mol-1 K at 2K. These results suggest the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions within dinuclear Co(II) ions. The reciprocal value of magnetic susceptibility follows Curie-Weiss law over full temperature range, Curie constant and Weiss constant are C =3.6477cm3 Kmol-1 and θ =-11.7038K, respectively. Considering crystal structure of complex 7, the dinuclear cobalt(II) units are well separated from each other, magnetic exchange between dinuclear Co(II) units can be neglected, as a result, the dinuclear unit may be assumed to make up the basic magnetic unit. The magnetic data can be fitted using MagSaki Software . The best fit to the experimental data give J =-2.262±0.04cm-1 and g =2.763. The negative J value further confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions.

Luminescent properties

Taking into account of the excellent luminescent properties of Zn(II), the solid-state luminescent spectrum of 2 has been studied at room temperature. As shown in  , compound 2 shows the emission maxima at 420 nm (λ ex = 320 nm). In order to understand the nature of the emission, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of free organic ligand and found that the strongest emission peak of H2ndd is at 474 nm (λ ex = 363 nm). It can be seen that the maximum emission peak of compound 2 displays remarkable blue-shift, which can be assigned to π∗ → n and π∗ → π transitions of the ligand-to-metal (LMCT) .

Thermal properties

To study the thermal stability of the complexes, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (). The TG curve of 1 shows that the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 311-567 °C, corresponding to the release of organic components. The remaining weight of 13.97% corresponds to the percentage (calcd. 12.93%) of Ni and O components, indicating that the final product may be NiO. The TG curve of 2 shows one main weight loss. No weight losses were observed for the complex up to 342 °C; above 342 °C, significant weight losses occurred and ended at 675 °C, indicating the removal of the corresponding organic components. The remaining weight may correspond to the final product of ZnO (obsd. 18.87%, calcd. 22.15%).

The magnetic properties of the compounds 1 and 2 have been investigated at a field of 2KOe in the temperature range 1.8-300K. The overall magnetic behaviors of the compounds 1 and 2 correspond to paramagnetic systems with antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. For the compound 1, the χ m T value of 1.09emumol-1 K at 300K is significantly less than that of a spin-only value per formula unit ( ). With decreasing temperature, the χ m T value first decreases gradually till reaching 0.65emumol-1 K at 50K, and then decreases rapidly below this temperature till reaching zero at 5K. For the compound 2, the χ m T value at 300K is 1.13emumol-1 K and decreases gradually with decreasing temperature at the range of 300-30K. Below 30K, the χ m T value is closed to zero.

Abstract

The in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN3 and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile leads to a new three-dimensional pillared-layer Cu(I)-MOF, [Cu2(μ 3-I)(μ  5 -IPT)]n (1) (HIPT=5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate). Interestingly, the structure of 1 exhibits an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional self-penetrating framework first constructed from [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters as 8-connected nodes and in situ generated IPT ligands as 4-connected nodes. Moreover, 1 is strongly luminescent with green emission (λ em =545nm) in the solid-state.

The luminescent metal-organic frameworks bearing the closed d 10 shell structure have been widely investigated for their potential applications as functional luminescent materials . We here studied the solid-state luminescent property of 1 at room temperature. As depicted in  , an intense broad green emission band was observed at 545nm (λ ex =290nm) for 1. The reported solid free HIPT ligand has three intense broad fluorescent emission bands centered at around 416, 436, and 466nm (λ ex =367nm), which can be assigned to the ligand-centered π*→ n and π*→ π emissions []. Nevertheless, the conformation of IPT ligand in 1 abruptly changes owing to the coordination interaction. The dihedral angles between the N-heterocycles and benzene ring are 27.57° for tetrazole ring, 30.13° for imidazole ring, respectively, so the significant red shift emission peak of 1 should not be assigned to ligand-centered emission. In comparison with the reported luminescence properties of Cu-I cluster-based complexes bearing N-heterocyclic ligands, the emission peak of 1 should be tentatively assigned to the combined consequences of the LLCT (ligand to ligand charge transfer) transition and MLCT (metal to ligand charge transfer) transition .

Crystallographic data for 1: C10H7N6ICu2, Mr=465.20, Orthorhombic Pbca with a =8.714(6) Å, b=13.480(10) Å, c=20.447(15) Å, V=2402(3) Å3, Z=8, D calcd.= 2.573mg⋅m-3, Rint =0.0477, F(000)=1760, GOF =1.006, R 1 [I > 2σ (I)]=0.0350, wR 2 (all data)=0.0867. The structure was solved via direct method and refined using the full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2 with the SHELXTL program package . CCDC: 1062912.

Crystal structure of 3 

Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/c space group. There are one Cu(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one H2dpd and one bpy ligand in the asymmetric unit ( a). The coordination geometry of Cu(II) atom is completed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligand, one oxygen from one H2dpd ligand and two nitrogen atoms from one bpy ligand. The Cu-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.9095-1.9576Å and Cu-N bond lengths are 1.984 and 2.001Å. One type of dpd2- ligand is completely deprotonated, exhibiting both chelating and monodentate coordination modes (c). The other type of H2dpd ligand doesn't deprotonated in order to reach the charge conservation, exhibiting a monodentate coordination mode (d). Adjacent Cu(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into an infinite 1D chain (b). These chains are further connected by the hydrogen bonding interactions between the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O⋯O distance of 2.6297Å) and weak π⋯π stacking interactions existing between phenyl rings of dpd2- ligands (distances of 3.8010-3.9407Å) into a 2D supromolecular layer (c).

Crystal structure of 5 

Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/n space group. As shown in  a, there are one Co(II) atoms, one dpd2- ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. The Co(II) atom in 5 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry formed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands, one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand. The Co-O bond lengths range from 2.056-2.244Å, and the Co-N bond lengths are 2.082 and 2.133Å. The dpd2- ligand in complex 5 adopts the same coordination mode as it in complex 3 (c). Adjacent Co(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into an infinite 1D linear chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.718Å (b). Then, these 1D chains are held together through the hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 2D supramolecular layer (c). Finally, π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5299-3.8667Å connect the adjacent 2D layer to a 3D supramolecular structure along c axis (d).

Crystal structure of 6 

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 6 is a zigzag 1D chain which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of complex 6, there are one Co(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule ( a). The Co(II) atom is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands, two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligands and one oxygen atom from one water molecule. In 6, dpd2- ligand shows the same coordination mode as it in complex 3 (c), Co(II) atoms are linked by dpd2- ligands into a zigzag chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.7353Å. The phen planes are coordinated with Co(II) atoms in a chelating fashion. The Co-O distances are in the range of 2.058-2.248Å, and the Co-N distances are 2.084 and 2.144Å. In addition, the 1D chains in 6 are linked together by hydrogen bonding interactions which are caused by the coordinated water molecule into a 2D layer supramolecular structure. Finally, the π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5324-3.8742Å connect the adjacent 2D layers to a 3D supramolecular structure along b axis (d).

Then the thermal stabilities of complexes 1-6 have been studied, their thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature of 30-600°C (). For complex 1, the weight loss is from 30 to 123°C which is corresponded to the removal of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.71%, found: 3.45%). The residual framework begins to decompose at 227°C and the retention weight is 14.73% (calculated: 14.62%), corresponding to MnO powder. Complex 2 and 3 remain stable up to 322°C and 300°C, respectively, then start to decompose. The remaining weight can be attributed to the formation of Co2O3 (calculated: 17.60%, found: 17.55%) and CuO (calculated: 10.85%, found: 11.06%). The TGA curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 2.91% occurring in the range of 30-120°C corresponding to the removal of one water molecule (calculated: 2.61%). After the loss of the coordinated water molecule, the residue is stable up to 308°C and begins to decompose upon further heating. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of MnO (calculated: 10.29%, found: 10.79%). In the cases of 5 and 6, weight losses of 4.02% and 3.92% were observed in the temperature ranges of 30-126°C and 30-112°C, respectively, corresponding to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.51% and 3.51%, respectively). The residual complexes begin to decompose at 282 and 270°C leading to the Co2O3 (calculated: 16.15%, found: 15.05%) and Co2O3 (calculated: 16.15%, found:16.70%), respectively.

UV-Vis spectra

The UV-Vis absorption spectra were carried out in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in  . The free ligand H2dpd showed an intense peak ascribed to the π∗-π or π∗-n transition at ca. 257nm . And the broad absorption peaks of complexes 1-4 and 6 are centered at 250 and 296nm (for 1); 250, 296 and 536nm (for 2); 245, 303 and 660nm (for 3); 239, 283 and 397nm (for 4); 237, 270 and 512nm (for 6), respectively, which might probably attributed to the intraligand charge-transfer .

Fluorescence properties

The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-6 with free H2dpd and auxiliary ligands have been investigated at room temperature. As shown in  , the main emission peaks of the H2dpd, bpy and phen ligands are at 361, 390, 379nm (λ ex =250nm), respectively, which may be attributed to the π∗-π or π∗-n transitions of the intraligands . Upon excitation of solid samples of 1-6 at 300nm, these complexes show emissions bands with maximum at 392nm for 1, 386nm for 2, 389nm for 3, 369nm for 4, 394nm for 5 and 390nm for 6, respectively. The emissions of 1-6 may be assigned to intraligand transition upon the combination of the mixed ligands with metal ions . The different red shifts and intensities of the emission peaks of these complexes were observed compared with the emission of the free ligands, which may be assigned to the differences of the coordination environment and the different structures because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the coordinated ligands and metal ions . Complexes 1-6 may be good candidates for optical materials.

Abstract

A novel 3D metal-organic framework of zinc(II) imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate, [Zn5(L)2(HL)2(DMF)4] n  (1) (H3 L =4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid), was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. This compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with the space group Pbca and cell parameters a =14.1613(8)Å, b =15.6764(9)Å, c =16.1345(9), V =3581.8(4)Å3 and Z =4. The crystal structure presents a novel 3D framework with the rare four-fold helical structure and open channels, exhibiting guest-coordination sites at channel walls and strong fluorescent emission.

Thermal properties of 1 

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stability of 1, which is an important aspect for metal-organic frameworks. As shown in  , the first weight loss of 1 starts at 60°C and does not end until 330°C, which is mainly attributed to the strong interactions of DMF with metal ions. The consecutive weight loss from 330 to 600°C is probably caused by the decomposition of ligand, resulting in the collapse of host framework. For confirming that the host framework remains intact accompanying with the loss of DMF molecules, the PXRD measurements were performed, which indicate that the solid after removal of DMF by heating 1 to 330°C retains the initial framework which is consistent with the simulated one ( ).

Exchange of guest molecules of 1 

Due to the strong interaction of DMF with metal ions, which makes it difficult to remove DMF from the open channels, a primary experiment immersing 1 in CH3CN solution for 3 days has been done to investigate whether DMF can be exchanged by CH3CN . The IR spectra exhibit that the strong CO stretching bands of DMF in 1662cm-1 disappear after immersing in CH3CN [IR (KBr, cm-1): υ =3449m, 2398s, 1574vs, 1469s, 1388s, 1242m, 1097s, 1016m, 814w, 660m], implying that DMF have been exchanged by CH3CN. The compound after guest exchange shows high crystallinity as indicated by sharp peaks observed in the PXRD pattern (). This observation shows that the cavity of 1 is so flexible that CH3CN molecules may be incorporated instead of DMF molecules without collapse or decomposition. From TG curve of the DMF-CH3CN exchanged product 1a, it can be clearly seen that 1a completely loses guest molecules below 300°C and the decomposition of ligand accompanying with the collapse of host framework occurs between 330 and 600°C. It should be noted that 1a shows a two-step desolventized process, in which the first one may be attributed to the loss of uncoordinated guest molecules included in the channels after guest exchange  and the second one is the loss of exchanged guest molecules coordinated to Zn atoms. Furthermore, the BET surface area measurement shows that the desolventized 1a possesses a surface area of 56.3m2/g, implying the permanent porosity of 1a.

Emission property of 1 

The photoluminescence spectrum of 1 was measured in the solid state at room temperature ( ). Upon excitation at 310nm, complex 1 shows stronger fluorescent emission than that of the free H3 L ligand at 420nm. This may be attributed to the deprotonation of the ligand and the rigidity of framework . The strong fluorescence emission of 1 makes it the potentially useful photoactive material because it is thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.

Results and discussion

Crystal structure of compound 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallized in monoclinic P21/c space group with the asymmetric unit containing one Cd(II) ion, one Htci2- ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in  a, the Cd(II) ion is seven-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N8 and N4a) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O8, O9, O6c, O7b and O7b) from three different Htci2- ligands, affording a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The CdO and CdN distances are in the range of 2.302(3)-2.544(3) Å, 2.266(3)-2.270(3) Å, respectively. In the self-assemble process, the H3tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci2-, and the Htci2- ligand adopts a cis-cis-trans conformation linking three different Cd(II) ions in μ 3-(η 2-O,O'), (η 2-O",O‴), O‴ coordination mode ( a). Two symmetry-related Cd(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups into a dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 3.897Å. Under the synergetic bridging effect of Htci2- and biimpy ligands, the dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits are bridged together into a 2D layer (b). In this 2D layer, each dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunit is connected to six adjacent identical ones via four biimpy ligands and four Htci2- ligands (each two Htci2- ligands links two dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits). Topologically speaking, the dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, so this 2D layer represents a 6-connected 2D hxl plane topological network with the point symbol of {36,46,53} (c). Notably, there exist abundant hydrogen bonds between CH groups and O donors, which not only further consolidate the 2D layer but also extend the 2D layer into 3D supramolecular framework. The detailed hydrogen bond parameters are listed in .

Crystal structure of compound 2 

 Via tuning the pH value of reaction mixture, another new compound 2 was obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 2 crystallized in the triclinic P-1 space group, and contains one and half Cd(II) ions, one tci3- ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in  b, the Cd1 ion is coordinated by two nitrogen donors (N4 and N8b) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen donors (O8, O9, O6b, O7b and O8c) from three different tci3- ligands, adopting a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, and the Cd2 ion is four-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen donors (O4, O5 and O7a) from two independent tci3- ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O1w), displaying a rare tetrahedral geometry. The CdO and CdN distances locate in the range of 2.087(7)-2.619(5) Å, 2.253(5)-2.296(4) Å, respectively. Different from compound 1, the H3tci ligand deprotonated three protons into tci3-, and the tci3- ligand adopts a cis-cis-cis conformation and exhibits a μ 5-(η 2-O,O'),O', (η 2-O",O‴), O", (η 2-O‴',O‴") coordination mode (b). The tci3- ligand using its carboxylate groups links the Cd(II) ions to form a 2D layer (b). These adjacent 2D layers are further pillared by the biimpy ligands, giving rise to a 3D pillar-layered framework (c).

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermogravimetric analyses

In order to confirm the phase purities of the synthesized two compounds, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were performed. As shown in , the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns, which suggest that the as-synthesized samples are in single pure phase. In addition, thermal stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30-800°C. For compound 1, it can be stable up to 267°C, and after that, obvious weight loss was observed owing to the decomposition of the organic ligand. The final residue of 19.95% may be powder CdO (Calcd: 198.28%) (). For compound 2, the first weight loss of 2.38% occurred in the temperature range of 125-150°C was resulted by the departure of the coordinated water molecule, and then, the skeleton can be stable up to 300°C. When heating above 300°C, continuous weight loss occurred until 450°C, leading to the formation of powder CdO (Obsd: 25.02%, Calcd: 26.02%) ().

Photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 

The solid-state luminescent properties of compound 1 and 2 as well as free organic ligands (H3tci and biimpy) were investigated at room temperature. As shown in  , the free H3tci ligand shows an emission peak at 425 nm upon excitation of 310 nm, which originates from π*→n or π* → π electronic transitions, and the free biimpy ligand is non-fluorescent in the visible range. Compared with that of the free ligand, compound 1 shows a luminescent emission band at 438nm (λ ex=325nm), and compound 2 shows a luminescent emission band at 455nm (λ ex=325nm) (). It can be observed that the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 have obvious red-shifts (13nm for 1 and 30nm for 2)with respect to the free H3tci ligand. Thus, the luminescent emissions of compounds 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer. The red-shifts of emission spectra for compounds 1 and 2 were caused by the deprotonation of H3tci ligand and coordination effects to metal centers, which can effectively enhance the rigidity of organic ligand. In addition, the difference of emission peaks between 1 and 2 may be caused by the different deprotonated existent forms (Htci2- for 1 and tci3- for 2), different coordination environments for metal ions and different spatial frameworks [,].

The structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the phase purity of the material in bulk amount was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies reveal that 1 gradually loses the free DEF and coordinated water molecules (obsd. 32.8%, calcd. 33.2%) in the temperature range 25-250°C to form the desolvated framework 1a. Typically, the free solvent molecules were lost first followed by the coordinated solvent molecules. However, because DEF has much higher boiling point (153°C) than water, DEF and coordinated water molecules might be released simultaneously from 1, so we cannot specifically assign the weight loss steps for these two types of solvent molecules from the TGA data. The temperature dependent PXRD patterns further confirm that desolvated framework keeps crystalline nature until 250°C, though the diffraction peaks were slightly broaden and shifted. After gas sorption, 1a still exhibits a moderately high crystalline nature, indicating that 1a displays a permanent porous structure.

To check the selective adsorption properties of 1a, hydrogen and nitrogen adsorptions were carried out at 77K; carbon dioxide, methane, and acetylene adsorptions were carried out at 273K and 296K, respectively. As shown in  , 1a can take up a relatively significant amount of hydrogen (24.4cm3/g) but a negligible amount of nitrogen (2.3cm3/g) at 77K and 1atm, underlying a good capacity of 1a for H2/N2 separation . 1a can also absorb 23.3cm3/g acetylene and 23.0cm3/g carbon dioxide, but a very limited amount of methane (7.3cm3/g) at 273K and 1atm ( ). Their adsorption isotherms at 296K (Fig. S6) further confirmed the different gas uptakes of 1a for these examined gas molecules, underlining the potential of these new MOFs for the selective gas separation of C2H2/CH4, CO2/CH4.

The coverage-dependent adsorption enthalpies of 1a to carbon dioxide, acetylene, and methane were calculated based on the virial method, a well-established and reliable methodology from fits of their adsorption isotherms at 273K and 296K (Fig. S7) . The enthalpies at zero coverage of gas were calculated to give the values of 38.3, 34.7, and 28.6kJ/mol for C2H2, CO2, and CH4 respectively. The adsorption enthalpies for C2H2, CO2, and CH4 in 1a are moderately higher than those reported values . The relatively high Qst  of this compound may be due to the pore size and open metal sites in the activated framework, which favors the selective gas separation for these large gas molecules. Henry's law selectivities (Sij ) for C2H2/CH4, CO2/CH4 calculated respectively based on the equation Sij  = KHi /KHj , are also shown in Table S1, which are moderately high .

The X-ray diffraction data was collected using synchrotron radiation, λ=0.40663Å, at Advanced Photon Source on beamline 15ID-C. Indexing was performed using APEX2 (difference vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by multi-scan method implemented in SADABS. The structure was solved using SHELXL-2014 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-2014 (full-matrix least-squares on F2) contained packages. Despite of using synchrotron source and trying several crystals from different batches, diffraction experiment resulted in low quality diffraction data. This can be attributed to the presence of the solvent disorder and to the presence of bad quality, multiply twinned crystals. All non-H atoms were found in the difference Fourier map and were refined using the distance restraints. Hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and included in the refinement process using riding model with isotropic thermal parameters: Uiso(H)=1.2Ueq(-CH). The DEF solvents could not be located. Contributions to scattering from all solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; the structure was then refined again using the data. Crystal data for 1: CuC17H11O5, Mr=358.80, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a=17.714(7) Å, b=12.567(5) Å, c=25.643(9) Å, α=90° β=93.440(6) γ=90° V=5698(4) Å3, Z=8, Dc=0.836gcm-3, μ=0.412mm-1, T=100(2) K, 33107 reflections measured, 2465 independent reflections, final R1[I>2σ(I)]=0.1194, wR(F2)=0.2953, GOF=1.074.

Compound 2 exhibits a one-dimensional mixed-valence helical chain along b-axis, as seen from (a). Within the chain, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The oxidation states of Cu ions are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS spectrum of 2 (Fig. S1) shows the evident peaks of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 at 932.08eV and 952.08eV, respectively, which means the presence of Cu(I) in the compound. The satellite peaks at 942.08eV and 961.08eV indicate that 2 may also contain Cu(II) ions . In addition, the appearance of black crystals of 2 is the typical color of mixed-valence oxide state containing Cu(I)/Cu(II) ions . The coexistence of Cu(I) and Cu(II) is due to the partly reduction of Cu(II) under basic hydrothermal conditions , and methanol in this reaction may act as the reducing agent .

The thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) are performed on the single crystal samples of 1 and 2 with a heating rate of 10°C⋅min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere, as shown in Figs. S2 and S3. The TGA curves of the two compounds show the similar process of thermal decomposition with three stages. For 1, the first mass loss stage from 60 to 125°C is confirmed as the loss of uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules with residual weight of 10.55% (cal: 10.32%). The second stage occurs between 125 and 190°C and is attributed to the loss of Hatrz ligand with 66.10% (cal: 65.86%). The third stage from 310 to 370°C is considered as the break of pda ligand and then the compound is completely converted to CuO with residual weight of 22.25%, which is in good agreement with calculated value 22.81%. For 2, the first stage is confirmed as the loss of coordinated water molecules with 5.10% (cal: 4.58%) during 30-90°C. The second and third stages in the range of 155 to 380°C are considered as loss of atrz and pda ligands, respectively, with residual weights of 74.00% (cal: 74.30%) and 40.80% (cal: 40.45%). Also, compound 2 is converted to CuO. Two remainders after thermal decompositions are evidenced by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (Fig. S4).

HMX is a typical highly energetic material which has been widely used in the main component of solid rocket propellant. The performance of HMX can be enhanced by reduce the peak temperature of decomposition and increase the heat release . To check the effects of thermal decomposition of HMX after adding the as-synthesized compounds, 1, 2 and HMX are mixed at a mass ratio of 1:30 to prepare the target samples. The study is investigated by DSC measurement with a heating rate of 10°C⋅min-1 in N2 atmosphere in the range of 100-500°C with Al2O3 as reference. The Kissiger's method is used to investigate the activation energy (E a) and pre-exponential factor (A) of thermal decomposition for HMX and HMX with additives by DSC measurement with four different heat rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C⋅min-1 .   shows the DSC curves of HMX and HMX with 1 and 2. In a, the endothermic and exothermic peaks at 197°C and 289°C of HMX are attributed to the phase transformation and decomposition temperatures, respectively, and the heat release of exothermic process is 1200J⋅g-1. From b and c, we can see that the mixtures have no significant impact on the phase transition of HMX. The peak temperature of HMX containing 1 decrease from 289°C to 280°C and the heat release up to 1410J⋅g-1 while that of HMX containing 2 reach to 272°C and 1550J⋅g-1. It can be inferred that the compounds decompose and release much heat itself, as well as the formation of metal and oxide at molecular level on propellant surface may contribute toward their catalytic effects .

The single-crystal X-ray data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at room temperature. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structure was solved with direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located at the calculated sites and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystal data for 1: crystal dimensions 0.28×0.19×0.10mm3, formula C9H11CuN5O6, Mr =348.77, monoclinic, space group P21/c, with a =9.408(3), b =18.253(6), c =7.245(2), α =90.00°, β =101.57°, γ =90.00°, Z =4, ρ calcd =1.901gcm-3, μ =1.832mm-1, the final R 1 =0.0441, wR 2 =0.0816, and S =1.009. Crystal data for 2: crystal dimensions 0.27×0.20×0.09mm3, formula C9H8Cu2N5O5, Mr =393.28, monoclinic, space group P21/n, with a =12.148(3), b =6.629(2), c =15.023(4), α =90.00°, β =91.93°, γ =90.00°, Z =4, ρ calcd =2.161gcm-3, μ =3.549mm-1, the final R 1 =0.0377, wR 2 =0.0777, and S =1.008.

Luminescence

The solid state photoluminescence properties of 1, 2, 3 and the free btx ligand were investigated at room temperature. The btx displays the emission band at 432nm upon excitation at 370nm, which can probably be assigned to the π-π∗ transitions . 1 shows emission maximum at 415nm emission upon excitation at 333nm ( ). No emission of 2 was observed at the same experimental condition. 3 exhibit the emission bands maximum at 394nm and a shoulder peak at 454nm, upon excitation at 345nm. The free 1,2-H2bdc, 1,3-H2bdc and 1,4-H2bdc exhibit emissions at 375, 370 and 390nm, respectively, according to the literature . Because the Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . The emission at 415nm for 1 can be attributed to the emission of btx and 1,2-bdc combination. The emissions at 394 and 454nm can be tentatively attributed to the intra-ligand charge transition for 1,4-bdc and btx, respectively , because the emission at 394nm for 3 is near to that of 1,4-bdc (390nm) . The emission at 454nm for 3 shows the obvious red shift 22nm compare to free btx ligand.

Thermal analysis

In the TG curve of 1 ( ), the lattice water molecules were lost from 45 to 124°C (Calcd.: 5.99%, found: 5.86%). The anhydrous substance is stable upon heating to 300°C. Then the weight decrease continuously happened and did not end until to 600°C. The lattice water and DMF molecules of 2 were continuously lost from 45 to 184°C (Calcd.: 19.81%, found: 19.94%). The anhydrous substance is stable upon heating to 303°C. Then the weight decrease continuously happened and did not end until to 600°C. The lattice water molecules of 3 were lost from 45 to 180°C (Calcd.: 10.90%, found: 10.76%). The anhydrous substance is stable upon heating to 335°C. Then the weight decrease continuously happened and did not end until to 600°C.

Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Eu3+ ion, the luminescences of 1 was investigated at room temperature. Excitation of solid 1 at 394nm reveals that 1 displays intense red luminescence ( ) and exhibits the characteristic transition of a Eu3+ ion. The transitions are attributed to 5D0 → 7F J  (J =0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transition, i.e. the weak intensities of emission at 537nm and 653nm are respectively 5D0 → 7F0 and 5D0 → 7F3 transition. It is well know that 5D0 → 7F0 transition is strictly forbidden in a field of symmetry and, therefore, the Eu(III) in 1 should occupy sites with a low symmetry. These results are in excellent agreement with the crystal structure analysis. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition at 592nm and 5D0 → 7F4 transition at 702nm corresponds to a magnetic dipole transition both with medium-strong intensities. The most intensive emission in the luminescent spectra is the 5D0 → 7F2 transition at 612nm, which is the so-called hypersensitive transition responsible for the brilliant-red emission of this complex .
