Results and discussion

Description of the structures

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that in spite of their different metal centers, complexes 1 and 2 are isostructural; hence, only the structure of complex 1 is discussed here. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P2(1)/c. As shown in Fig. 1, the Zn atom has a six-coordinate mode, provided by three oxygen atoms from different imip ligands plus a further two oxygen atoms from two coordinated water ligands. The remaining coordination site is occupied by a nitrogen atom from the third imip ligand. The relevant bond lengths are Zn-O3 = 2.027(7) Å, Zn-O5 = 2.147(7) Å, Zn-O6 = 2.461(8) Å, Zn-O1(W) = 2.075(6) Å, Zn-O2(W) = 2.051(6) Å, and Zn-N2 = 2.036(7) Å. The O1W-Zn-N2, O1W-Zn-O3, O1W-Zn-O2W, and O1W-Zn-O5 bond angles are 96.4(3)°, 88.7(3)°, 168.7(2)°, and 90.7(3)°, respectively. The two water ligands occupy the axial positions, in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry overall.   In complex 2, the relevant bond lengths are Co-O3 = 2.077(5) Å, Co-O5 = 2.159(5) Å, Co-O6 = 2.341(5) Å, Co-O1(W) = 2.098(6) Å, and Co-O2(W) = 2.098(6) Å, while the O1W-Co-N2, O1W-Co-O3, O1W-Co-O2W, and O1W-Co-O5 band angles are 94.6(2)°, 88.3(2)°, 169(2)°, and 89.7(2)°, respectively (Figs. 2, 3).

In view of the excellent luminescence properties of coordination polymers with d10 metal centers and their potential applications in chemical sensors and photochemistry displays, the luminescence properties of the free H2imip ligand and complexes 1 and 3 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 10, an emission peak was observed at 359 nm for H2imip (λex = 274 nm), which can be ascribed to ligand-centered transitions [32]. Under the same excitation conditions, emission peaks were observed at 363 nm for complex 1 (λex = 268 nm), and 365 nm for complex 3 (λex = 294 nm). Thus, compared to H2imip, the emission maxima of 1 and 3 are redshifted. The most likely emission mechanism is ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [33], given the similar emission bands observed for the free ligand and its complexes. The enhanced luminescence in the complexes can be attributed to the ligand coordination to the metal center, which enhances its rigidity and thus reduces the loss of energy through radiationless pathways [34].

Thermogravimetric analyses

Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed in air on freshly grown air-dried crystals of the complexes, and the resulting TG curves are shown in Fig. 12. The first stage indicates that complexes 1 and 2 lose 16.2 and 17.1 % of their respective total weights at temperatures ranging from room temperature to 115 °C for 1 and 131 °C for 2. These weight losses are related to the loss of five water molecules (Calcd. 13.2, 13.5 %, respectively). The second stage occurs between 400 and 560 °C for both complexes 1 and 2 and corresponds to the release of the imip ligand. The corresponding weight losses are 60.7 and 60.1 % (Calcd. 62.9 and 64.1 % for 1 and 2, respectively). After 560 °C, there is no further weight loss. The residues (23.9, 22.0 %) are identified as ZnO and CoO, respectively (Calcd. 23.1 and 22.4 %, respectively). As for complex 3, the host framework was stable up to ca. 91 °C. The first weight loss of 6.4 % occurred between 91 and 160 °C, which is related to the removal of the three coordinated water ligands (Calcd. 7.3 %). The second stage came between 363 and 560 °C, corresponding to the release of the imip ligand; the observed weight loss was 60.7 % (Calcd. 58.0 %). No further weight loss was observed above 560 °C. The residue (obs. 32.9 %) is assigned to CdO (calcd. 34.7 %).

By contrast, in 2, the Ba ions are bridged by the 2,6-PDCO ligand to generate a 2D porous layer structure in the ab plane (Fig. 3b). This structure retains an effective void volume of 97.5 Å3 per unit cell, which is 19.5% of the crystal volume [36]. Free water molecules are located at the cavities and are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the host network [O⋅⋅⋅O 2.962(5)-2.970(5) Å]. Similar to 1, the simplified structure of 2 is presented in Fig. 4b. There exist three types of dinuclear    units with Ba⋅⋅⋅Ba distances of 5.033 Å (bridged by two symmetry-related O1 atoms), 4.449 Å (bridged by O2 and O5 atoms) and 4.999 Å (bridged by two symmetry-related O4 atoms), respectively. The dinuclear units are connected by Ba atoms to form the final framework.

Thermal Stability and Powder XRD

Compound 1 is stable up to 400 °C at which point the framework structure begins to collapse. For compound 2, the first weight-loss is 5.42% (calcd: 5.35%) 20-76 °C and corresponds to the loss of one free water molecules per formula unit. A plateau is observed from 80 to 370 °C indicating no further weight loss. Above 370 °C the framework starts to decompose rapidly.

TGA

To study the thermal stability of 1, TGA was performed (Fig. S3). There are two weight-loss steps from 25 to 800 °C. The first weight-loss (5.4 %) from 60 to 250 °C corresponds to the release of one coordinated water (calcd. 5.69 %). The second weight-loss step (58.82 %) from 400 to 800 °C is attributed to the loss of a tzba ligand (calcd. 58.80 %).

Fluorescent Property

The solid-state luminescence for 1 was carried out at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the 1 is depicted in Fig. S5. Polymer 1 exhibits a strong blue photoluminescence with emission maxima at 428 nm upon excitations at 376 nm. This is a red shift with respect to the free ligand, H2tzba (λem = 327 nm with excitation at 300 nm [27]). Other tetrazolate-based complexes, such as [Mn(4-TZBA2-)(H2O)2] and [Mn4(4-TZBA2-)4(μ2-H2O)2(H2O) (py)], are bathochromically shifted to 434 nm (excitation at 361 nm) and 425 nm (excitation at 358 nm), respectively. The photoluminescent mechanism is attributed to a ligand-centered π-π* excitation mainly through the aromatic rings of tbza2-, which is characteristic of fluorescent emissions for Cd(II) complexes with other heterocyclic aromatic ligands [24]. The results suggest that the polymer may be used as a blue light-emitting material [1].

Sorption Properties

The porosity of 1 was estimated by methanol, ethanol and water gas adsorption isotherms at 298 K. As shown in Fig. 6, 1 exhibits Type-I behavior with a small hysteresis to water and methanol. The amount of water and methanol uptake increases with an increase in P/P0 and reaches 165 cm3 g-1 at P/P0 = 0.86. The saturated sorption amount of water is equivalent to the adsorption of about 5.8 mmol g-1. The sorption amount reaches 120 cm3 g-1 at P/P0 = 0.9, which is equivalent to the adsorption of about 4.4 mmol g-1. In contrast, the amount of ethanol sorption (2.3 cm3 g-1 at P/P0 = 0.9) is close to the surface adsorption and is negligible, which indicates that methanol cannot easily enter the channel. Polymer 1 can adsorb water and methanol molecules, but excludes the larger ethanol molecules. The above adsorption studies show that 1 is a promising material for separating methanol and water from bioethanol. Significant hysteresis between adsorption and desorption traces indicates a microporous material [1].

Abstract

The 2D coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n(H2dpa = 2,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of NaOH and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, FTIR spectra, element analysis and thermal analysis. The crystal structure determination reveals that the carboxylate groups of 2,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid are acting as bridging ligands and adopt two coordination modes; bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating. The network consists of a 2D (6,3)-connected architecture. At room temperature the solid-state luminescence spectrum of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n shows a blue emission at about 354 nm upon excitation at 333 nm.

TGA

To investigate the thermal stability of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, TGA was performed (Fig. 3). [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is stable to 280 °C. Upon further heating, decomposition begins and the total weight loss at 600 °C is 84.37%, which corresponds to complete removal of the organic component. The final residue is ZnO (observed 15.63%, calcd. 16.15%).

Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n and the H2dpa ligand at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 4. [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n exhibits an intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 354 nm on excitation at 333 nm. Free H2dpa and bpp display intense fluorescent properties in the solid state at room temperature with emission maxima at 354 and 523 nm [28], respectively.

It is noteworthy to mention that the neighboring 2D layers of 3 are stacked along the c axis in an ABAB sequence (Fig. 1d, e). As presented in Fig. 1f, the distance between two adjacent layers B is 22.894(4) Å, suggesting that the vertical distance between layer A and layer B is 11.447(2) Å. On the other hand, the shortest Sm…Sm distance between layer A and layer B is 11.5167(21) Å. Therefore, a slippage distance of 1.2654(4) Å between layer A and layer B in compound 3 can be achieved. Such a small slippage distance between the neighboring 2D layers leads to the formation of small 1D channels running along c direction, which are occupied by guest water molecules (Fig. 1d). If only the uncoordinated water molecules are removed, compound 3 has a 1100.5-Å3 potential solvent volume (20 %) as calculated by PLATON [43].

Thermal stability analyses

To determine the thermal stabilities of the two types of CPs, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of the representative compounds 3 and 5 were measured under an air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30-800 °C. As illustrated in Fig. 3, compound 3 has two steps of weight loss. The first weight loss of 3.7 % from 30 °C to about 130 °C can be attributed to the loss of one guest water molecule (calculated 2.7 %) in the asymmetric unit, and then this compound is stable up to 200 °C. The major weight loss occurred in the next step above 200 °C is probably caused by the gradual decomposition of the coordinated DMA and HTFMIDC2- ligands, leading to the collapse of the coordination framework. Seen from the TG curve of 5, an initial weight loss of 5.6 % between 30 and 200 °C may correspond to the release of a half DMA guest molecule per formula unit (calculated 6.9 %). Further weight loss between 200 and 600 °C also can be ascribed to the decomposition of the whole coordination structure.

Photoluminescent properties

Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of the Eu(III) ions in the visible region, the photoluminescence of compounds 4 and 5 in the solid state was measured at room temperature. In order to well compare the luminescence intensity, all of the spectra are measured with the same voltage of 400 V and identical pass width of 5.0 nm. When the emission wavelengths were fixed at 614 nm for 4 and 615 nm for 5, both the excitation spectra of 4 and 5 display a broadband roughly covering from 230 to 300 nm, as well as four sharp peaks in the range of 350-420 nm, giving the maximum peaks at 394 and 395 nm for 4 and 5, respectively (Figs. S11 and S12). As presented in Fig. 4, compound 4 exhibits intensity red luminescence and shows the characteristic f-f transition of a Eu(III) ion upon excitation at 394 nm. The strong intense emission at 614 nm is assigned to electric-dipolar 5D0 → 7F2 transition, while the medium strong intensity of emission at 592 nm is attributed to magnetic-dipolar 5D0 → 7F1. Three weak peaks at 579, 652 and 701 nm can be ascribed to the 5D0 → 7F0, 5D0 → 7F3 and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions, respectively [45, 46]. Compound 5 emits red light upon excitation at 395 nm (Fig. 4), and it also exhibits a typical Eu(III) emission spectrum as compared to compound 4. The characteristic peaks at 580, 593, 615, 655 and 704 can be assigned to the characteristic emissions of Eu(III) corresponding to electronic transitions from the excited state 5D0 to the multiplets 7FJ (J = 0 → 4), respectively [45, 46]. The intensity ratios of 5D0 → 7F2/5D0 → 7F1 for 4 and 5 are calculated to be 5.4 and 5.1, respectively, indicating that the Eu(III) ions in both 4 and 5 adopt noncentrosymmetric coordination environments without inversion centers. These results are in agreement with the X-ray single-crystal structure of compounds 4 and 5. In addition, the luminescence intensity of 4 is relatively stronger than that of 5, which may be assigned to the quenching effect of the water molecule coordinated with Eu(III) center in 5 [47].

Photoluminescence properties

It is well known that Cd(II) complexes can exhibit interesting luminescence properties [8, 24]. The solid-state luminescence of the free Na2mtms ligand and complexes 1 and 2 was investigated at room temperature and is shown in Fig. 5†. Na2mtms shows an emission peak at 460 nm when excited at 301 nm. Upon excitation at 304 nm, complexes 1 and 2 display emission maxima at 353 and 362 nm, respectively, which are both greatly blue-shifted compared to the free Na2mtms ligand. Since the Cd(II) center has d10 electronic configuration, the emissions of complexes 1 and 2 can be tentatively assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [26-28]. These complexes may be suitable as blue-light-emitting materials, since they show luminescence in the blue region [29].

Cyclic voltammetry

The cyclic voltammogram of 3 was measured with a conventional three-electrode cell in aqueous solution with complex concentration of 1.0 × 10-5 mol L-1, as shown in Fig. 6†. Measurements were carried out at room temperature by scanning from -0.600 to +1.400 V at different scan rates. The CV shows an oxidation peak at 0.444 V with the scan rate of 50 mV s-1, while there is no corresponding reduction wave. As the scan rate is increased to 80 and 100 mV s-1, the anodic peak appears at 0.479 and 0.567 V, respectively. Again, no corresponding cathodic wave was observed, showing that the electrochemical behavior of the Zn(II)/Zn(I) redox couple is irreversible [30].

Abstract

Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2⋅H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene), have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 35.504(4) Å, b = 7.6014(9) Å, c = 19.894(2) Å, β = 121.607(2)°, V = 4,572.6(9) Å3, Z = 8, R1 = 0.0461 and wR2 = 0.1193. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 21.623(2) Å, b = 13.9245(15) Å, c = 19.743(3) Å, β = 119.2360(10)°, V = 5,187.2(12) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0399 and wR2 = 0.1034. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). A careful structural comparison reveals the similarity of the Ni(II) coordination geometry and ligand binding mode. The significant discrepancy of their network structures may be attributed to the fluorinated substituent group.

Thermal property

To characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270-600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermogram of 1 shows three degradation steps. The first and the second steps are at 100-200 °C and at 450-540 °C, respectively, and correspond to the release of the EIN ligand (M.W = 63%). The first step involves removal of the carboethoxy group (COOC2H5); Δm% obser. (calc.) 30.5 (30.3). The second step is due to the release of the pyridyl moiety of the EIN ligand; Δm% obser. (calc.) 32.5 (32.4). At 850-900 °C the weight loss is due to the decomposition of the cyanide group; Δm% obser. (calc.) 10.5 (10.8). The molecular weight of the residue obtained after complete thermolysis of 1 under nitrogen atmosphere is coincident with metallic copper, Δm% obser. (calc.) 26.8 (26.4).

Electronic Absorption and Emission Spectra of 1

The electronic absorption spectra of EIN as a liquid in absence and presence of HCl reveal three and two bands, respectively, between 220 and 320 nm (Table 7). The high intensity band at 220 nm corresponds to 1La ← 1A transition while that at 275 nm is due to 1Lb ← 1A transition [27]. These bands resemble those of benzene, which exhibit a red shift upon substitution [27]. The long wavelength band at 320 nm may be assigned to a n-π* transition, which disappears in presence of HCl (Fig. 6).

Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on both complexes in air, with heating to 780 °C at a rate of 1 °C min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different thermal behaviors, but the TG curve of 2 is similar to that of 1 (from 228 to 780 °C, Fig. 3). In 1, the TGA displays two obvious steps of weight loss. The first corresponds to the loss of both lattice and coordinated water (at the range of 85-264 °C, the weight loss observed is 19.16%; theoretical 19.04%). The second weight loss above 250 °C is attributable to decomposition of the organic ligand. The TGA of compound 2 demonstrates that compound 2 has an excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 250 °C.

The magnetic behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 are illustrated in Fig. 4 in the form of μeff versus T plots. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.72 μB for compound 1, which is as expected for the spin-only value of 1.73 μB for one Cu(II) atom. Upon cooling, this value remains constant before rapidly decreasing at low temperature. This magnetic behavior reveals a weak antiferromagnetic interaction as expected. In 1, large Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances of and absence of effective overlap make the possible interactions weak [15, 16]. For complex 2, the value of μeff at 300 K is 2.2 μB per two Cu(II) atoms which is slightly less than that of two non-interacting Cu(II) atoms. The value gradually rises as the temperature decreases, to reach 2.91 μB at around 20 K. This behavior is typical of ferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) dinuclear compounds [14, 17, 18]. Below that temperature, μeff decreases to 2.56 μB at about 3 K, which may originate from intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions or from zero-field splitting of the S = 1 state of the dinuclear species. This overall ferromagnetic behavior has been observed earlier for many other oxo-bridged compounds. For Cu-O-Cu dinuclear compounds, a ferromagnetic interaction was found when the Cu-O-Cu angle was smaller than 97.5°, but when the angle is larger than 97.5°, an antiferromagnetic interaction would be expected [19]. In compound 2, the Cu-O-Cu is 80.12(1)° (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu 2.821(8) Å), which suggests the presence of ferromagnetic interactions involving the dimeric units.

Abstract

Coordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O having  three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO-) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.

The specific surface area determined from multipoint BET plot (see Fig. S3, Supplementary Material) is 45.37 m2/g with a slope 70.95, Y-intercept 5.80, correlation coefficient 0.998,725, and BET C constant 13.23. The value of BET C constant suggests a low heat of adsorption. The Langmuir surface area is found somewhat higher (98.62 m2/g) with a slope of 35.31, Y-intercept 8.814, correlation coefficient 0.999781, and Langmuir constant 4.0064.

A t-method micropore analysis (de Boer) of polymer (see Fig. S4, Supplementary Material) gives a linear V-t-plot with Y-intercept 15.02 cm3/g and slope 1.946. The linear plot along with the non-zero intercept suggests that [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O is mesoporous. Both the micropore volume and micropore surface area are 0.023 cm3/g and 15.27 m2/g, whereas the external surface area is 30.10 m2/g with a correlation coefficient of 1.000. This is almost the same as the BET surface area. The pore size distribution pattern was obtained from desorption branch by employing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model (see Fig. S5, Supplementary Material). The plot shows that there is a wide distribution of pores in the polymer with diameters ranging from 3 nm to more than 13 nm with an average of 5.6 nm. The total pore volume is 0.06357 cm3/g for pores smaller than 21.57 nm at P/P0 = 0.90386.

Photoluminescence studies

Figure 6 shows the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O. The excitation spectrum shows an excitation peak at about 390 nm which is assigned to 5I8 → 5G5 electronic transition in Ho3+ ion. The emission spectrum for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm shows three emission bands peaking at ~460, ~490, and ~545 nm corresponding to 5F2 → 5I8, 5F3 → 5I8, 5F4 → 5I8 transitions. Similar emission bands (not shown here) were observed with 430 nm excited wavelength. In general, purity in color of substance can be recognized by means of color coordinates. Hence, in our present work, the chromaticity coordinates of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O have been calculated from the emission spectrum using the commission international De I'Eclairage (CIE) system. The CIE chromaticity diagram for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm is shown in Fig. 7. The CIE coordinate is found to be (0.28, 0.38) which lies within the blue/hue region. Therefore, it may be concluded that the developed polymer could serve as a blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

Thermal analysis

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of coordination polymer [Ho2(PDA)3 H2O]n⋅2nH2O are shown in Fig. 8. The thermal decomposition was investigated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 293 to 1,273 K at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The coordination polymer network is stable up to 373 K. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve shows that decomposition of the polymer takes place in three steps. The first step starts at 373 K and ends at 463 K. The residual weight at 463 K is 88 % (calculated weight loss = 88.55 %) corresponding to loss of three water molecules and two molecules of carbon monoxide. The DTA curve has a sharp endothermic peak at 453 K, indicating the loss of three water molecules. The second step of thermal decomposition has onset at 463 K and ends at 793 K. The residual weight at 793 K is 72 % (calculated weight loss = 72.3 %) indicating the loss of four molecules of carbon monoxide and one molecule of acetaldehyde. The third step has onset from 793 K with gradual weight loss up to 1,250 K, this step involves the loss of two molecules of phenyl acetaldehyde. Sharp DTA curve at 683 K and broad DTA curve at 963 K indicate decomposition of organic ligand. The residual weight at 1,267 K is 47.5 % (calculated weight loss = 46.5 %) corresponding to formation of Ho2O3 and carbon as end product.

The electronic spectra of the copper(II) polymer were recorded in the UV-Visible. The copper(II) polymer shows three absorption bands with varied intensities. The intense band at 203 nm is assigned to intra-ligand (π-π*) transition associated to tpa ligand. While the less intense band at 275 nm corresponds to the charge transfer transition from tpa ligand to the metals. Besides, the broad band observed at the lower frequency of 645 nm in the spectrum matches well with the reported d-d transition of five-coordinated copper(II) in the square-pyramidal geometry [42]. The spectroscopic data of the copper(II) polymer are in agreement with the determination of the crystal structure (vide infra).

Cytotoxic Activity of the Polymeric Copper(II) Complex

The cytotoxicity assays of the polymeric copper(II) complex and cis-platin against two cancer cell lines human hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC-7721 and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 were conducted in our study. It is noteworthy that the IC50 values of the polymeric copper(II) complex are 19.0 ± 0.3 and 11.0 ± 0.4 μM for SMMC-7721 and A549, respectively, which are much higher than those of cis-platin (5.4 ± 0.2 μM for SMMC-7721 and 7.6 ± 0.4 μM for A549), indicating that the cytotoxic activity of the polymeric copper(II) complex is less than that of cis-platin. However, the inhibition of cell proliferation produced by the polymeric copper(II) complex on the same batch of cell lines is still rather active. The polymeric copper(II) complex possessing cytotoxic activity may be attributed to the extended planar structure induced by the p-π* conjugation from the chelation of the metal ion with the ligands. These findings of cytotoxic activities in vitro prompt us to explore the DNA-binding studies on the polymeric copper(II) complex.

In order to quantitatively evaluate the binding strength of the copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, the intrinsic binding constant Kb was determined by monitoring the changes in absorbance at 203 nm using the following equation [51]:1\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ \left[ {\text{DNA}} \right]/\left( {\varepsilon_{\text{a}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) = \left[ {\text{DNA}} \right]/\left( {\varepsilon_{\text{b}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) + 1/K_{\text{b}} \left( {\varepsilon_{\text{b}} - \varepsilon_{\text{f}} } \right) $$\end{document}where [DNA] is the concentration of DNA, εf, εa and εb correspond to the extinction coefficient, respectively, for the free polymeric copper(II) complex, for each addition of DNA to the polymeric copper(II) complex and for the polymeric copper(II) complex in the fully bound form. As shown in Fig. 3b, in the plot of [DNA]/(εa-εf) versus [DNA], the binding constant Kb for the polymeric copper(II) complex was estimated to be 1.07 × 104 M-1, (R = 0.9911 for nine points), lower than those of typical intercalators (e.g., EB-DNA, ~106 M-1) [52], and has the same level as those of well-established intercalation agents [53].

The Ethidium Bromide Fluorescence Displacement Experiments

To further investigate the interaction mode between the polymeric copper(II) complex and HS-DNA, the EB fluorescence displacement experiments were used. In general, the intrinsic fluorescence intensity of DNA is very low, and that of EB in Tris-HCl buffer is also not high due to quenching by the solvent molecules. However, on addition of DNA, the fluorescence intensity of EB will be enhanced because of its intercalation into the DNA. Thus, EB can be used to probe the interaction of complexes with DNA. If the complexes can intercalate into DNA, the binding sites of DNA available for EB will be decreased, and hence the fluorescence intensity of EB will be quenched [54]. In our experiment, it has been used to monitor the interaction of the polymeric copper(II) complex with HS-DNA, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, the fluorescence intensity of EB at 584 nm shows an obvious decreasing trend with the increasing concentration of the polymeric copper(II) complex, suggesting that the polymeric copper(II) complex binds strongly with HS-DNA. The quenching of EB bound to DNA by polymeric copper(II) complex is in agreement with the linear Stern-Volmer equation [55]:2\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ I_{0} /I = 1+ K_{\text{sv}} \left[ {\text{Q}} \right] $$\end{document}where I0 and I represent the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quencher, respectively. Ksv is a linear Stern-Volmer quenching constant, Q is the concentration of quencher. In the quenching plot (see inset in Fig. 4b) of I0/I versus (complex), Ksv is given by the ratio of the slope to intercept. The Ksv value for the polymeric copper(II) complex is 6.14 × 104 (R = 0.9927 for 14 points).

Cyclic Voltammetric Studies

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) has been widely employed to study DNA-binding properties for complexes with electronic activity, whether the electrochemical processes are reversible [56], quasi-reversible [57], or irreversible [58, 59]. In order to get a deeper insight into the mutual donor-acceptor electronic influence, we have undertaken CV studies of the copper(II) polymer. The cyclic voltammograms of the polymer (1.0 × 10-5 mol L-1) at different scan rates (from 0.06 to 0.24 V/s) were investigated (Supporting information, Fig. S1). The results indicated that the oxidation and reduction peak currents (ipa and ipc) both exhibit the linear relationship versus the scan rate (ipc = 3.4436 × 10-6 + 7.198 × 10-7 v, R = 0.9663; ipa = -2.966 × 10-7-7.835 × 10-7 v, R = 0.9707). These relationships indicate that the electrode processes in Tris-HCl buffer solution are absorption controlled [60].

Abstract

A new Zn(II)-btc coordination polymer 1 (H3btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) containing protonated acridines was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction at 165 °C for 3 days and characterized by FT-IR, UV-Vis, Fluorescence, TGA measurements and single-crystal/powder X-ray crystallography. The crystallographic data for 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a = 11.0100(5), b = 16.7104(7), c = 11.7492(5) Å, β = 98.735(2), V = 2136.56(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 130(2) K, Dc = 1.572 g cm-3, F(000) = 1036, μ(Mo Kα) = 1.205 mm-1, GOF = 1.005. R1 = 0.0427, wR2 = 0.1410 [I > 2σ(I)]. Structural analysis also revealed that the btc3- ligands bridge four-coordinate Zn(II) centres to form a 2-D grid-like layer network on the bc plane. The protonated acridines fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers and combine the 2-D layers to generate a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework through the hydrogen bondings and π⋅⋅⋅π packing interactions. The fluorescence investigation disclosed that 1 shows multiband emissions over a wide range.

Thermal Analysis

TGA analysis was carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the first thermal decomposition stage occurred in the range of 76-130 °C with a corresponding weight loss 10.31 %, which was assigned to two lattice water and one coordinating water molecules (calc. 10.69 %). The second weight loss was 35.20 % in the temperature range of 200-350 °C and was consistent with the decomposition of protonated acridines (calc. 35.43 %). The third decomposition stage continued with a weight loss of 30 % up to 500 °C. This process suggested the thermal decomposition of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate.

UV-Vis Spectrum

The UV-Vis spectrum of 1 in DMSO (c = 5 × 10-5 mol L-1) is shown in Fig. 6, which exhibits a series of bands in the UV range of 250-400 nm. A strong absorbance band centred at 260 nm with high molar extinction coefficient could be attributed to π-π* type transition within protonated acridines. A series of bands centered at 347, 357, 379 and 397 nm could be attributed to the π→π* transitions within the btc3- ligands [27]. The maxima of absorption wavelengths with the molar extinction coefficients as well as the assignment of the absorption spectra are summarized in Table 3.

Fluorescence Emission

A number of polynuclear d10 transition metal complexes, such as Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers, exhibit interesting luminescence properties [28-30]. Fluorescent investigation of 1 was carried out in the solution and the solid phase at room temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, upon a single-wavelength photo-excitation at 274 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 1 in the solution phase shows three overlapping emission bands in the range of 380-650 nm (peak at 407, 431 and 455 nm), which is similar to the emission property of original acridine ligand in Fig. 7b. So the multiband emission of 1 could be assigned to the emission of the pure organic component [19]. Study of the photoluminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7c. Excitation at λex = 270 nm leads to a broad emission from 350 to 500 nm compared with the emission of 1 in the solution phase. This is presumably due to the combination of ion electronic state induced by strong face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between protonated cations and btc3- ligands as well as strong hydrogen bonding interactions in the solid phase [31, 32]. The multiband emissions are expected to be useful in designing luminescent devices.

To examine the thermal stability of these frameworks, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA; Fig. 5). Compound 1 was stable up to 380 °C; then, it shows a weight loss of about 82.8 % between 380 and 640 °C suggesting the decomposition of the organic framework, and the remaining weight is assigned to zinc oxide (17.2 %). Compound 2 shows an initial weight loss of 9 % below 101 °C, corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules; then, we have three steps of weight loss between 101 and 387 °C to obtain the final residue (15.2 %) which may be assigned to nickel oxide. Compound 3 was stable up to 328 °C then began to decompose upon further heating. The first continuous weight loss of 43 % happened in temperature range of 328-390 °C, and this weight loss can be attributed to the release of (1,10-phen) ligand; the second weight loss of 57 % between 390 and 489 °C was assigned to the release L ligand; the third weight loss of 43.6 % between 489 and 650 °C was of sulfate anions; and the remaining weight is assigned to cadmium oxide 13.4 %.

To investigate magnetic properties for 2, magnetic susceptibility was measured with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe from 2 to 300 K. The comparison structural of these polymers were done by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (XRD). Figure 6a shows the XRD graph for the typical sample of this polymer was prepared by sonochemical process (1). Figure 6b shows the XRD graph from single crystal 2 and this pattern obtained using Mercury software. Figures indicate that the structure obtained by sonochemical process is identical to structure was obtained by single crystal owing to, as shown in Fig. 6 in these XRD graphs number of pages are match to gather in these structures. For comparison the thermal stability of polymer structures synthesized by sonochemistry and reflux methods, thermal gravimetric (TG) was performed between 25 and 1000 °C under a flow of dry air. The TGA curves show that the decomposition of polymer is a multiple step process and the final fragment weight corresponds to the metal oxide. The TGA graph for single crystal indicates three peaks. The first peak at around 60-80 °C corresponds to the removal of lattice water molecule. The second peak at around 110-130 °C is due to the loss of coordinated water molecules. The final peak at 427 °C is related to decomposition of whole structure (Fig. 7). Polymer was prepared by sonochemistry is minor stable and started to decomposition at 40 °C. Decomposition of polymer 1 achieved earlier than of its single crystal 2, maybe due to the much higher surface to volume ratio of this structure is needed to the less of heat for destruction of its structure [25]. The polymer was prepared by sonochemistry has a higher surface than reflux and the result of SEM images illustrated, the particles size of polymer 1 is smaller than of polymer 2.

The BET surface area and pore volume for polymer 2 are 76.54 m2/gr and 0.328 cm3/gr, respectively these parameters for polymer 1 are 143.27 m2/gr and 0.523 cm3/gr because of, the particles size outcome of 2 are smaller than of 1. Figure 8 shows magnetization curves at room temperature for 1 and 2. Both of these polymer exhibit paramagnetic behavior.

Physicochemical Characterizations of Catalysts

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared Ni x Cu y -BTC shown in Figure S1 are consistent with the simulated XRD patterns of Cu-BTC, indicating the successful synthesis of the isomorphic structure with different metal ions. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Figure S2a) reveal that the Ni-BTC presents a spherical-shaped structure and Cu-BTC possesses a typical octahedral structure (Figure S2e). For the bimetallic NiCu-MOFs, with the increasing of Cu content, the structure turned to be a more obvious octahedral-like shape, indicating the successful incorporation of Cu in the bimetallic MOFs. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis (Figure S3) confirms the bond formation process. The peak positions of the three MOFs precursors are very similar. The strong and wide adsorption peak at 3400 cm-1 results from the stretching vibration of the O-H group from water molecules. The peaks around the range of 1370 cm-1 can be attributed to the symmetrical bending vibration of -CH2. All these bands were red-shifted compared with typical -CH2 bonds, illustrating that the -CH2 groups were replaced by electron-donating groups. The peaks around 730 cm-1 might be assigned to the Cu-O stretching vibration. The corresponding infrared absorption peaks also confirmed the successful synthesis of bimetallic MOFs. The thermal stability of materials was investigated by thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA), and the results are revealed in Figure S4a-e. Apart from the weight loss (~8 to 9 wt % in general) of the physically adsorbed water around 100-120 °C, the broad exothermic peaks from 300 to 500 °C could be attributed to the decomposition of organic matter. At this stage, 37.6 wt % of weight loss in the Ni1Cu2-BTC precursor is observed. 

Furthermore, the porous information of Ni x Cu y /C500 catalysts was investigated with the N2 adsorption/desorption test. All of the five N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms confirmed the type IV curves according to the results of a. The values of the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and the pore diameter are listed in Table S3, suggesting that the surface area of bimetallic catalysts increased sharply compared to that of homometallic Ni/C500 and Cu/C500 catalysts. The maximum specific surface area of 225.3 m2 g-1 is obtained when the molar ratio of Ni/Cu is 1:1. The pore diameter distribution is shown in b, mainly distributed from 1 to 6 nm. Combined with the SEM characterization results of precursors, the collapse of the MOF structure may also cause the decrease of the pore volume after calcination.

The sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) cathode is the focal point of recent research in lithium-sulfur batteries due to its efficient polysulfide shuttle effect and boosting battery efficiency. However, the SPAN cathode needs to be enhanced to demonstrate more excellent electrochemical performance and kinetic characteristics encouraged by the chemical makeup of the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their effectiveness in the redox reactions of the battery. ZIF67 nanoparticles are grown in situ onto the fiber networks of a high-density glass fiber (GF) separator. They are dynamically activated in a vacuum oven. The open metal sites created after ZIF67 activation can effectively trap anions and improve Li+ transport properties. The transference number (t Li+ ) was predicted to be 0.49, thereby improving the electrochemical performances of the Li-SPAN battery. The anode and cathode exhibited better compatibility with the separator. The Li//Li symmetrical cells based on the ZIF67@GF separator exhibited low polarization and were stable for up to 600 h. A Li/ZIF67@GF/SPAN full cell also showed a small voltage polarization effect and had a starting capacity of 1590 mAh g-1 at 0.1C rate. The improved high-rate capability (ca. 714 mAh g-1 at 10C) of Li/ZIF@GF/SPAN cells was better than that of the Li/bare GF/SPAN cells. The long-term cycling performance was improved significantly, with a decay rate of 0.05% per cycle at 2C over 600 cycles and the ability to perform 1000 cycles at a rate of 5C with 75.3% capacity retention. Thus, our findings support that the Li-SPAN cell equipped with a GF separator with in situ grown ZIF67 nanoparticles substantially improved the electrochemical performance.

In this study, we generated ZIF-67 nanoparticles in situ onto a GF and then employed the ZIF67@GF as a separator for a cell containing a SPAN cathode and a Li metal anode. Here, we chose a GF separator because of its excellent wettability and good electrolyte uptake. One discharge plateau was found while employing the SPAN cathode, and the dissolving of the polysulfide was inhibited completely. Our modified ZIF67@GF separators to the system increased the transference number to 0.49 because the active sites in the ZIF67 particles interacted with the anions in the electrolyte, thereby decreasing cell polarization. The analysis of symmetrical cells demonstrated that the catalytic activity and stable morphology of the ZIF67 nanoparticles inhibited the growth of Li dendrites and limited the buildup of dead Li. Our Li//Li symmetrical cells equipped with the ZIF67@GF separator survived for more than 600 h without undergoing shorting. Compared with cells featuring bare GF separators, the cells with ZIF67@GF separators have displayed superior high-rate capabilities (notably at higher rates of 36.5% at 2C and 36.8% at 5C) and more excellent discharge capacity retention. Furthermore, the ZIF-67@GF separator-equipped cells had discharge capacities of 961.2 mAh g-1 after the first cycle and 670.71 mAh g-1 after 600 cycles at 2C; the capacity attenuation was approximately 0.05% per cycle. Finally, our Li-SPAN batteries incorporating ZIF67@GF separators markedly improved the transport and kinetic characteristics, enhanced the electrochemical operation, and protected the Li anode.

Thermal Behavior of Separators

GF separators are known for their excellent thermal stability. c presents the TGA profiles of the GF separator and ZIF67@GF separators. From the TGA curves, it is obvious that the GF separator is stable up to 800 °C. The ZIF67 particles are thermally stable up to 200 °C. The initial 3.5% weight loss at nearly 130 °C was caused by the complete evaporation of tiny water crystals and moisture captured by the glass fiber separator. Eliminating excess particles from the fillers and unreacted linker species generated a steady weight loss from 150 to 450 °C. After 450 °C, the ZIF67 particles begin to decompose. The framework started to disintegrate due to the disappearance of 2-methyilimidazole after 450 °C.

The total weight loss of the ZIF67 particles is estimated to be 15%, which is also the mass loading of ZIF67 in the glass fiber separator. The TGA results show that ZIF-67 particles are relatively thermally stable; thus, these particles will improve the thermal characteristics by adsorbing thermal energy. Hence, it prevents thermal assault and makes the battery system more stable. These findings suggested that operating our Li-SPAN corresponding batteries at elevated temperatures would be possible.

Ionic Conductivity and Separator Compatibility

Ionic Conductivity

Ionic conductivity is a crucial parameter when estimating the ion regulating properties of ZIF67 nanoparticles. Here, the ionic conductivities were measured with the help of AC impedance spectroscopy by sandwiching the separators between stainless-steel electrodes, followed by the addition of the liquid electrolyte inside the glovebox. The ionic conductivity value was analyzed at 25-60 °C to obtain the Arrhenius plot, displayed in a. The ionic conductivities and the activation energies of bare and ZIF67@GF separators are given in Table S2. At room temperature (25 °C), the ionic conductivities of bare and ZIF67@GF separators are ca. 9 × 10-3 S cm-1 and 1.08 × 10-2 S cm-1, respectively. When the temperature is increased to 60 °C, there seems to be an improvement in the ionic conductivity of both separators. For the bare separator, the conductivity is ca. 1.36 × 10-2 S cm-1, and for the ZIF67@GF, it is ca. 1.78 × 10-2 S cm-1. The slight improvement of ionic conductivities of the ZIF67@GF separators is attributed to the abundant porosity of ZIF67, and the compact nature of the as-grown ZIF67 particles supplies handfuls of ion transport channels with shorter ion diffusion lengths. The activation energy (E a) was not affected by the presence of ZIF67 particles. The E a values are ca. 3.8 and 5.0 kJ mol-1 for bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators, respectively. The difference is not that much between both cases. A lower activation energy means a lower energy barrier for the Li+ ion transport, which eventually increases the ionic mass transport rate and reduces the overpotential.

Wettability and Electrolyte Uptake

The wettability of the separator is a notable parameter for maintaining the electrolyte during the charge/discharge process. The contact angle measurements were conducted to examine the wettability of the separator. A drop of the liquid electrolyte is added to the separator surface, and the angle that the drop formed with the surface is measured. The contact angles of the bare GF separator and the ZIF67@GF separator are almost zero (Figure S3), which means that it can immediately uptake the electrolyte, hold a large amount of the electrolyte, and keep the separator wet for a prolonged time. The perfect wettability of the glass fiber separator generated a well-distributed lithium-ion flux, which lowered the increasing lithium-ion concentration polarization locally and contributed to the lithium dendrite suppression. Moreover, it reduces the surface tension, causing a smooth separator/electrolyte interface. The wettability of a separator is related to its electrolyte uptake tendency. The electrolyte uptake was calculated by . The electrolyte uptake of the bare glass fiber and ZIF67@GF separators is calculated to be 87 and 89%, respectively, proving a good interaction between the ZIF67 particles in the separator with the liquid electrolyte.

Electrochemical Performance Studies

The galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) profiles of the Li/SPAN cells with the bare GF and ZIF67-modified separators are demonstrated in a,b, characterized at 0.1C between the voltages in the range of 1-3 V (vs Li/Li+). The upper potential is decreased to 2.5 V for the second and third cycles for the cells containing both the bare GF and ZIF-grown GF separators, with the lithiation process starting at 1.8 V in the first discharge step. The Li/SPAN cell displayed considerable voltage hysteresis (polarization) during the initial discharge, resulting in a significant buildup of irreversible capacity loss. This voltage hysteresis may be due to the inadequate electrical contact at the original grain boundaries between the SPAN and the conducting carbon particles. The discharging and charging profile of the Li/SPAN cell, in contrast to typical Li/S batteries, exhibited only a single voltage plateau. This behavior suggested that the SPAN underwent a single-phase direct solid-to-solid reaction without forming any soluble polysulfides. The initial discharge capacity of the Li/SPAN cell assembled with the ZIF67@GF separator was ca. 1591 mAh g-1, and for the cell with the bare glass fiber separator, the capacity was ca. 1469 mAh g-1 at 0.1C at room temperature. It is noted that the initial discharge capacity of the full cell was increased by 8% and the overpotential (η) was reduced from 0.45 to 0.37 V after incorporating ZIF67 nanoparticles on the GF separator. This is because the active sites in the ZIF67 particles strongly regulated the Li+ ion transport flux at the electrolyte-separator interface and markedly reduced the overpotential. The high Li+ ion transfer number permits fast reaction kinetics throughout the Li nucleation and lithium growth processes at the Li anode; it may be responsible for the decreased overpotential. It should be emphasized that the increased overpotential in the cells with bare glass fiber separators is also caused by ongoing SEI generation. The higher capacities of the cells associated with the SPAN cathode may be due to the rough and porous nature of the electrode surface, which has more room for the Li+ ion interaction. 

The oxidation peak potential was noted at approximately 2.31 V. The single reduction and oxidation peaks resembled the single voltage plateau in the GCD profile, suggesting the direct conversion of S to Li2S without forming any of the soluble intermediate polysulfides responsible for the shuttle reaction. In the Li/SPAN cells incorporating the ZIF67@GF separator, the sharp and highly intense oxidation and reduction peaks appeared with an enhanced peak current. This is due to the redox nature of ZIF67 nanoparticles and their compatibility with the electrolyte interface. Notably, the overpotential in the first scan significantly drops from 1.01 to 0.75 V when ZIF67 nanoparticles are present. The extended cycle performance of the cell would be favored by the rapid reaction kinetics resulting from the lower peak potential difference (ΔE).

To explain the Li insertion behavior, the reaction mechanism involves producing Li2S and a lithiated polymer backbone through the cleavage of the S-S bonds and the formation of Li-C-N-Li bonding. Because of the existence of the S2 and S3 chains, no polysulfide production occurred. Nevertheless, the complete desulfurization of SPAN during the discharging has not been proven and is still disputed. It has been proposed that the lithiated polymeric backbone would resist delithiation and stay lithiated after recharging. Following the initial discharging, it has been suggested that Li-SPAN and Li2S would undergo a reversible redox reaction. The Li+ diffusion coefficient trend was found to be higher in the cells with the ZIF67@GF separator, as shown in b. As a result of the conversion of the lithiated SPAN into desulfurized SPAN, there is an increase in electronic conductivity, which is consistent with the electronic structure of SPAN during the discharging/charging process. The Li+ ion diffusion coefficient of the Li/SPAN cells incorporating the ZIF@67-modified GF separators increased; it is ca. 1.64 × 10-8 cm2 s-1 from initial SOC(%). We assumed that the effective active sites, high surface area, and nanoscale size of the ZIF-67 particles shortened the Li+ ion diffusion length and immobilized most large anions (PF6 -) in the liquid electrolyte to improve the Li+ ion transport rate. In comparison, the Li+ ion diffusion coefficients of the Li/SPAN cell featuring the bare GF separator were calculated to be ca. 5.82 × 10-9 cm2 s-1 from initial SOC(%).

Li Metal Anode Stability Analysis

The Li//Li symmetrical cells offered a crucial platform for quantitatively evaluating Li metal's electrochemical performance. They also help understand the polarization degree on the surface of the lithium foil. The stability and the short-circuit failure are frequently and qualitatively correlated with the Li plating/stripping voltage shape. These voltage changes are significantly influenced by the electrolyte composition, depth of charge/discharge, and current density. Symmetrical cells were made with bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators to examine the electrochemical capabilities of the bare glass fiber and ZIF67@GF separators with lithium metal anodes. 1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) in ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) was used as the electrolyte. Each cell was treated with an optimized amount (100 μL) of the electrolyte. As shown in a-d, the comparisons were made between the cells with ZIF67@GF and bare GF separators regarding their rate performance, plating/stripping voltage profiles, and current density. To measure the consistency and endurance of the electrolyte/electrode stability, the symmetrical cells operated at an extremely high current density, namely, the critical current density (CCD). The CCD profiles of the Li//SPAN cells with the bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators are displayed in a,c, respectively. In contrast to the spike-like voltage profiles of the cell with the bare glass fiber separators, the voltage plateau formed by the symmetry cells containing ZIF67@GF separators is flat and stable and features a slight polarization. The polarization difference completely diminished when the current density reached 2 and 5 mA cm-2. However, the symmetrical cells with the bare GF separator showed overpotentials of ca. 41, 66, and 171 mV at 0.2, 0.5, and 1 mA cm-2, respectively. In contrast, the overpotential of symmetrical cells with ZIF67@GF separators displayed approximately 36, 60, and 123 mV for 0.2, 0.5, and 1 mA cm-2, respectively. The cells were instructed to return to the lowest current density of 0.2 mA cm-2 after the highest current density of 5 mA cm-2. In both cases, the voltage profiles were accurately reproduced, and the bare one's voltage profile became smoother after a high current rate. The presence of ZIF67 nanoparticles on the GF separator is responsible for the reduced overpotential and smooth voltage profiles, which effectively enable the substantial amount of lithium to get fully utilized during the stripping and plating and prevent the formation of Li dendrites and dead lithium. b,d shows the voltage profiles of the symmetry cell at 1 mA cm-2 with an areal capacity of 1 mAh cm-2 for the bare GF and the ZIF67@GF separators. The plating/stripping profile shows no difference in cells with the bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators. A marked difference arose, however, at 500 h. Even the symmetrical cells with bare glass fiber separators underwent a short circuit at 547 h, revealing a trend of increasing polarization. In contrast, the symmetrical cell with the ZIF67@GF separator prevented the cell from undergoing a short circuit. Notably, around 300 h, a sharp voltage drop is observed at the cells containing bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators. This happened due to the unstable power supply/shutdown during the measurement.

The enlarged voltage profiles are shown in Figure S4. The calculated values of polarizations are ca. 577 and 300 mV for the cells with the bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators, respectively. During the final hours of cycling, the cells provided spiking or arcing voltage profiles. However, the arcing behavior of the cells with a bare GF separator is severe. This arcing profile featured a distinctive arc that plateaued at the halfway point of the half cycle. This change in the voltage curve suggested that its voltage shape, following prolonged cycling, could not be captured fully by morphology-driven reaction kinetics, implying that the dead Li layer continued to accumulate and that the diffusion length through the dead Li layer continued to increase. Thus, during cell cycling, this buildup of dead Li resulted in restricted mass transport. The interfacial stability of the symmetry cells incorporating the bare GF separators and the ZIF67@GF separators is investigated using the EIS measurements. In Figure S5, the AC impedance spectra are illustrated. The AC impedance was measured for the fresh Li//Li symmetry cells and cells that had undergone five cycles of polarization at 1 mA cm-2 with an areal plating capacity of 1 mAh cm-2. In the higher frequency region, one semicircle was observed with charge transfer resistance (R ct) and conductance (C 1). For the cells with the bare GF separator and the ZIF67@GF separator, the R ct values are around 138 and 96.2 Ω, respectively, before cycling, and they drop to 97.8 and 73.6 Ω after five cycles. The ZIF67 particles with a high surface area provided more free void or space for better lithium mass transport. They decreased the interfacial polarization, which resulted in lower charge transfer resistance for the cells using ZIF67@GF separators.

Rate Capability and Electrochemical Performance

The GCD measurements at various current densities ranging from 0.2C to 10C were used to study the rate capabilities for the cells with two separators. a displays the GCD profiles of the rate capabilities. The cells are generally activated for 2 to 3 cycles prior to performing the rate capability test to form some stable SEI layer. At rates of 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C, 5C, and 10C, the Li/SPAN cell assembled with the ZIF-67@GF separator offered high initial capacities of 1420, 1375, 1278, 1192, 960, and 714 mAh g-1, respectively. A high reversible capacity of 1395 mAh g-1 occurred when we switched the current density from 10C to 0.2C. At 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C, 5C, and 10C, the cells built with the bare GF separators had capacities of 1293, 1188, 1102, 874, 702, and 297 mAh g-1, respectively. When we reversed the current density to 0.2C from 10C, the discharge capacity returned to 1273 mAh g-1. At low current densities, the cells assembled with the ZIF-67@GF separator produced 9.8% (0.2C) and 16.7% (0.5C) more capacity than that of the cell with the bare GF counterpart. When the current density was much higher, however, the situation was more drastic, with the cells containing ZIF-67@GF separators achieving 36.5% (2C) and 36.8% (5C) more capacity than that of the cell with the bare GF separators. The lower overpotential and enhanced ionic conductivity that arose after modifying the GF with the ZIF-67 particles were primarily responsible for the increased discharge capacity and more reversibility after applying the high current density. The overpotential or polarization has the most detrimental effect at higher current densities. The use of GF separators in SPAN systems, capable of adapting to temperature variations inside the cell and withstanding even higher current densities, is noteworthy.

We used EIS to analyze the interfacial stability; b shows the Nyquist plots. A depressed semicircle in the medium- to high-frequency range and an inclined line in the low-frequency range make up each Nyquist plot before cycling. The former is related to the charge transfer resistance (R ct) at the electrode-electrolyte interface as well as the bulk resistance (R b) from the electrolyte, with the latter being the Warburg diffusion impedance (Wo) of lithium-ion diffusion in the bulk of the electrode. In this case, the charge transfer resistance of the cell prepared with ZIF67@GF (ca. 23.6 Ω) was slightly lower than that of the cell with the bare GF (ca. 27.8 Ω). Here, we can state conclusively that the separator prepared with the in situ grown ZIF-67 nanoparticles did not increase the impedance and enabled fast charge transfer kinetics. The interfacial contact between the electrode-electrolyte and the separator was also increased by the higher wettability of the separator, thereby promoting the ionic conductivity and increasing the discharge capacity.

The cells were evaluated at 0.5C and 2C at room temperature, as shown in c,d, to examine the electrochemical performance of the separators at various current densities. The cells incorporating the bare glass fiber separator had an initial capacity of 1283 mAh g-1 at 0.5C; after 200 cycles, its capacity was ca. 921 mAh g-1. Here, the capacity retention was ca. 82% and the capacity attenuation was 0.08% per cycle (from the second cycle). The ZIF67@GF separator-equipped cell delivered a high initial capacity of 1414 mAh g-1; after 200 cycles, its capacity was ca. 1019 mAh g-1 again, with a capacity retention of 82% and a capacity decay per cycle of 0.08%. The cells fabricated with the bare GF and ZIF67@GF separators had initial coulombic efficiencies of 86 and 97.9%, respectively. In both cases, the coulombic efficiencies reached a stable value of 100% throughout the cycles. The cell with the ZIF67@GF separator had a high initial coulombic efficiency because the catalytic activity of the ZIF67 nanoparticles increased the sulfur conversion efficiency, starting from the first cycle. The cell with the bare GF delivered an initial capacity of 821.6 mAh g-1 at a high current density 2C; after 600 cycles, it attenuated by 0.05% per cycle, resulting in 567.6 mAh g-1. Furthermore, the ZIF67@GF separator-equipped cell had a higher initial capacity of 961.2 mAh g-1 and a capacity of 674.71 mAh g-1 after 600 cycles, giving a capacity attenuation of 0.05% per cycle.

Higher Current Density and Long-Term Cycling Examination

As shown in Figure S7, the cells were evaluated at 5C for 1000 cycles. After 669 cycles at this rate, the cell with the bare GF separator no longer functioned. The cell with the ZIF67@GF separator, on the other hand, completed 1000 cycles successfully; its initial capacity of 394 mAh g-1 decreased to 297 mAh g-1 at the 1000th cycle, with a capacity retention of 75.3%. The survival of the cells with the ZIF67@GF was due to the distinctive porous structure of the GF separator, leading to a high ionic conductivity when placed in the electrolyte and facilitated rapid ionic transport; furthermore, the SPAN cathode, in which S atoms were covalently attached to the polymeric backbone of the PAN, prevented the shuttle mechanism. This rationale also explains why the cells containing the bare GF separators also functioned well. Most significantly, the long-range order and high porosity of the ZIF-67 particles facilitated directional Li+ ion conduction, which resulted in faster reaction kinetics and stable long cycle life.

A dual-emissive optical sensor based on the fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) technique has been demonstrated to have significant advantages of high sensitivity and reliability. Here, we designed and successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent thermometer of CsPbBr3 quantum dot (QD) encapsulated lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Eu-BTC), and their phase compositions and luminescence properties have been characterized. Different thermo-response luminescence behaviors originating from the photoluminescence of CsPbBr3 QDs at 528 nm and the 5D0-7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20-100 °C, in which the dual-emissive temperature-dependent emissions can serve as a ratiometric thermometer for accurate temperature monitoring applications. Significantly, the as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibited a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C in the measured temperature range, indicating its superiority as a ratiometric luminescent thermometer for temperature sensing. The related luminescent sensing mechanism of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC is also discussed, and this work provides an effective strategy for the rational design of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

Herein, a novel dual-emissive CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-MOF material has been successfully prepared through a simple liquid-phase synthetic route with expected FIR self-calibrated temperature sensing activities, in which the CsPbBr3 QDs display a thermo-quenching response, while the Eu3+ ions in the Eu-MOF show an opposite thermo-enhancing luminescence property when the temperature is increased. Accordingly, it is demonstrated that the thermo-response luminescence intensity ratio of CsPbBr3 QDs to Eu3+ emitters shows an exponential function versus temperature changes, which can effectively serve as an ultrastable self-calibrating temperature sensor. The as-obtained novel CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC thermometer shows a very high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and excellent cyclic sensing stability.

 a illustrates the chromaticity diagram of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC at different temperatures. It can be found that with an increase in temperature, the emissive colors evolved from green (0.275, 0.674) to orange (0.536, 0.423) (inset in a). b illustrates the relative luminescent intensity ratio of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm) versus temperature, and the results can be well fitted by the exponential function equation (a)         I   618  nm       I   528  nm     = - 0.536 + 1.422 ×   e   0.031 T     1 where I 618nm and I 528nm denote the emission intensities of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively, and T is the temperature. Such a fitting result with R 2 = 0.995 demonstrated that the luminescent emission intensity ratio I 618nm/I 528nm from CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF nanoparticles can be intrinsically used for temperature monitoring, showing an excellent ratiometric temperature-sensing ability.

In addition, we also calculated the absolute sensitivity (S a) and relative sensitivity (S r) to quantitatively evaluate the ratiometric temperature-sensing activity of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanothermometer. S a and S r can be calculated by the equations       S   a   =  |   ∂Δ   ∂ T   |    2        S   r   =  |     S   a     Δ   |    3 where Δ is used to represent the PL intensity ratio I 618nm/I 528nm, and T is the temperature. As a result, b shows the calculated S a and S r values as a function of temperature. It can be easily observed that the maximum value of S r is 3.9% °C-1 measured at 20 °C, which is higher than those of most of the reported MOF-based ratiometric thermometers (). In addition, the temperature resolution (δT), another crucial parameter for evaluating the thermometer, can be estimated from the equation 4    δ T =   1     S   r       ∂Δ   Δ     where δΔ/Δ denotes the relative error in the thermometric parameter measurements defined by the experimental detection equipment. The fluorescence spectrometer used has a signal to noise ratio of 16000:1, which means that the value of δΔ/Δ is about 0.0125%. The calculated δT curve of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC versus temperature is shown in c, which also indicates that δT is better than 0.004 °C across the entire measured temperature range. To evaluate the reversibility of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite toward temperature switching operations, the luminescent intensities of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC upon heating/cooling at 20 and 65 °C were recorded. The cycling experimental results are shown in d and indicate that the luminescent switching operation can be repeated for at least six consecutive cycles without significant change, illustrating its excellent reversibility and reliability as an optical sensor for thermometer applications. The above results demonstrate that the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite can serve as an optical ratiometric nanothermometer with high relative sensitivity and temperature resolution for potential temperature-sensing applications.

Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent nanothermometer of CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Eu-BTC). The different thermo-response luminescence behaviors of CsPbBr3 QD emission at 528 nm and 5D0-7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20-100 °C. The as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibits excellent FIR ratiometric temperature-sensing properties with a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and an excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C, indicating its superiority to serve as a nanothermometer for optical temperature sensing. This work provides an effective strategy for the rational design and synthesis of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

Ozone Decomposition by ZZU-281

The catalytic activities of ZZU-281 for O3 decomposition were evaluated with a dynamic test at room temperature in a fixed-bed continuous reactor at an initial O3 concentration of 50 ppm (Figure S9). We optimized the catalyst loading by adjusting the ZZU-281 amount with 5, 10, 20, 30, and 50 mg, respectively (Figure S10). With the increase of the catalyst amount, the removal efficiency gradually enhanced and achieved nearly 100% at 20 mg under both dry (RH ≤ 5%) and wet (RH = 90%) humidity conditions. When the catalyst loading was further increased to 30 and 50 mg, ZZU-281 still maintained 100% O3 decomposition efficiency. Therefore, a catalyst dosage of 20 mg was used in this reaction system. a and Figure S11 show that ZZU-281 achieved nearly 100% persistent O3 decomposition efficiency at ≤5%, 20%, 40%, 60%, 80%, and 90% RH, and the efficiency remained stable even after continuous reaction for 70 h. These results verified that ZZU-281 not only is an excellent humidity-resistant O3 elimination catalyst but also performs efficiently under dry conditions. The catalytic turnover frequency (TOF) for this catalytic reaction was determined to be 10 min-1 after 70 h test. This catalyst with such remarkable and stable O3 decomposition performance under different humidity levels thus significantly outperformed other reported catalysts (Table S2) and met the demands of practical application under various environmental conditions. We hypothesized that the high O3 removal efficiency of ZZU-281 under both low and high-RH conditions may correlate with the intrinsically abundant coordination water molecules in ZZU-281. To determine the role of coordination water molecules in the O3 decomposition process, we carried out an O3 removal experiment with dehydrated ZZU-281, which was obtained by heating the sample at 200 °C for 2 h. The TGA curve indicated that the water molecules in ZZU-281 were removed (Figure S6). All intense PXRD peaks of dehydrated ZZU-281 reproduced the pristine ones, indicating that the framework was basically maintained. A new tiny PXRD signal at 9.6° may have been caused by the loss of abundant coordinated water molecules around the Mn nodes. (Figure S12). The O3 decomposition efficiency of dehydrated ZZU-281 was much lower (50%) than that of pristine ZZU-281 at RH ≤ 5%, while the O3 conversion increased to 70% when the RH was increased to 90%. When the sample was switched again to dry conditions (RH ≤ 5%), the O3 conversion was obviously enhanced compared to that of the pristine dehydrated sample (Figure S13). Moreover, we found that the O3 conversion performance was increased each time the catalyst was treated with a high RH. After four consecutive dry-wet cycles, the O3 decomposition performance returned to nearly 100% at 90% RH, revealing that water indeed helped to improve the O3 conversion efficiency. We inferred that the water molecule recoordinated to the Mn nodes under high RH and recovered the original structure as evidenced by TGA (Figure S14), thus endowing the recycled sample with enhanced O3 conversion efficiency. These results confirmed the potential of using ZZU-281 to degrade O3 under dry conditions by using the water present in the pores, circumventing the need for added water. Importantly, as evidenced by PXRD and FT-IR, the structural integrity of ZZU-281 was fully retained after the 70 h O3 decomposition experiment (c and Figure S16).

Further, we investigated the catalytic performance of ZZU-281 for O3 decomposition in the presence of other gases at room temperature, including CO, CO2, NO, and NO2. The inlet concentration of these gases was maintained at 100 ppm by controlling the gas flow. When CO or CO2 were introduced, ZZU-281 still showed excellent performance (nearly 100% O3 decomposition efficiency) at a moderate RH of 30% within a 12 h test (a). For NO and NO2, a slight performance decay from 100% to 96% was observed during the first 5 h and was maintained at 95% after 12 h. This was probably caused by competitive adsorption between O3 and NO x  on the active sites, which eventually blocked the catalytic activity. Moreover, the outlet concentrations of CO, CO2, NO, or NO2 after catalytic reaction were consistent with the inlet one, confirming that these gases were not involved in the O3 conversion reaction. In addition, ZZU-281-catalyzed O3 conversion under different temperatures was studied (b). At 0 °C, the O3 conversion performance (~94%) is slightly lower than that at room temperature (25 °C, ~100%). When the temperature was further increased to 50 and 80 °C, the O3 removal efficiency remained nearly 100%. Overall, ZZU-281 showed great potential for O3 elimination in various environments.

The CD spectrum of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L is shown in Figure S9, indicating two intense CD signals at 440 and 530 nm, whereas the UCNP-PVP and UCNP@ZIF displayed a silent CD response. These results indicated that the chirality of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was from the chiral NiSx-L NPs. To confirm this assumption, dispersed chiral NiSx-L NPs were prepared. The TEM image in Figure S10 shows that the diameter of the chiral NiSx-L NPs was about 3.5 nm. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was conducted to analyze the changes in mercapto groups (-SH). As shown in Figure S11, FTIR of the chiral L-pen showed a peak at 2586 cm-1, which was assigned to the stretching and vibration of the S-H bond. After formation of the chiral NiSx-L NPs, the peak completely disappeared, indicating cleavage of the S-H bond by the strong covalent binding of thiol groups to Ni atoms on the surface of the NiSx-L NPs. The CD spectrum of the chiral NiSx-L NPs (Figure S12) showed a similar CD response to UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L, further confirming the existence of chiral NiSx-L NPs in the nanoassemblies. Notably, the NiSx-L and NiSx-D NPs which were induced by the chiral L-pen and D-pen displayed mirror image CD lines (Figure S12). Absorption spectra were carried out to characterize the optical activity of the prepared nanomaterials. As displayed in Figure S13, chiral NiSx NPs showed absorption peaks at 415 and 535 nm, and the absorption of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was in accordance with chiral NiSx-L, demonstrating that NiSx-L NPs were assembled into UCNP@ZIF successfully. Concurrently, the UCL of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L at 540 nm was dramatically quenched by NiSx-L NPs (Figure S14).

More importantly, the change of CD signal exhibited a perfect linear relationship with the H2O2 concentration ranging from 0.05 to 20 μM, and the LOD was 0.032 μM. (A and S20). We next tested the feasibility of this probe for its ability to detect H2O2 using a luminescent signal. As shown in Figure S21, the absorption of the probe spectrally overlaps with the green emission (540 nm) of the UCNPs. Reaction of H2O2 with the probe caused a decrease in probe absorption at 660 nm, which will then increase the I 660/I 540 ratio of the probe (B). A plot of I 660/I 540 ratio versus H2O2 concentration in the range of 0.05 to 20 μM shows a linear response, and LOD was calculated to be 0.037 μM (Figure S22). Next, the selectivity of this probe was tested. In the presence of ROS, the CD signal disappeared, and the luminescent signal was restored, whereas no obvious changes in the CD or luminescent signals were observed with possible interfering components. This suggested that this detection probe had a perfect specificity (C,D and S23, S24). Therefore, the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx probe had adequate sensitivity and excellent selectivity for the detection of ROS under physiological conditions.

To confirm general applicability of this probe, the detection of intracellular ROS levels was also carried out in human epithelial cancer cells (HeLa cells) and human melanoma SK-MEL-2 cells (A and S28). For HeLa cells, the intracellular H2O2 level was calculated to be 2.29 ± 0.21 μM and 2.43 ± 0.17 μM from the CD mode and UCL mode, respectively. For SK-MEL-2 cells, the CD and UCL detection results were 1.33 ± 0.23 μM and 1.37 ± 0.18 μM, respectively. All the results were consistent and comparable to those found using the H2O2 Kit, demonstrating that the nanoassemblies displayed excellent versatility among various cell lines. For the HeLa cells treated with NAC, the intensity of the CD response was much higher than that of the original untreated cells, whereas after treatment with lipopolysaccharide (LPS, an upregulator of ROS), the CD signal intensity was much weaker than that of untreated cells (Figure S29), suggesting that this probe could be applied to detect changes of intracellular H2O2 levels. It was found that the sensitivity of UCL detection was lower than that of CD detection which could be attributed to the high sensitivity and responsiveness of chiral NiSx NPs to the H2O2 analytes.
