The SEM image of CPP-16⋅Cu2+ revealed that the original multidomain-crystallized morphology was maintained well after reaction with Cu2+ (Figure a). Change in optical property of fluorescent chemosensor CPP-16 was easily recognized by FM image (Figure b), with the initial green emission (Figure b) of CPP-16 almost absent after interaction with Cu2+. A photograph image obtained after the addition of Cu2+ solution (after 10 s.) revealed the disappearance of the initial emission (). Incorporation of Cu2+ ions within CPP-16 was further verified by EDX spectrum analysis, as Cu atoms were detected, in addition to Zn, C, N, and O atoms (Figure c). CO2 sorption isotherms of CPP-16 and CPP-16⋅Cu2+ were measured at 195 K. CO2 uptake abilities of CPP-16 (70 cm3g-1) decreased after the incorporation of Cu2+ within CPP-16 to 51 cm3g-1 for CPP-16⋅Cu2+ ().

Selective sensing of CPP-16 on Cu2+ has been validated by thorough observation of parallel relations using a variety of other metal ions in place of Cu2+ (Figures  and ). Specifically, CPP-16 was immersed in several different kinds of MeCN solutions, which contained different kinds of metal ions, such as Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Ag+, and Cd2+ (10 mM). Fluorescence intensity changes of CPP-16 following immersion in the various metal ion solutions were dependent on the specific identity of the metal ions (Figures a and ). Alkaline-earth metal ions such as Mg2+ and Ca2+ had nearly no effect on the fluorescence intensity of the initial CPP-16. Moreover, little effect was found for transition metal ions such as Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Ag+, and Cd2+. The only considerable quenching effect on CPP-16 fluorescence intensity was found for Cu2+. Specifically, the quenching effect of metal ions was quantified by the Stern-Volmer equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M]), where I 0 and I are emission intensity of CPP-16 before and after reactions with metal ions, K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of the metal ions, and [M] is the concentration of the metal ions. As shown in Table , the largest and distinguishable K sv value was obtained for Cu2+ at 7846.7 M-1. The selectivity on Cu2+ was confirmed again by photograph showing the response of CPP-16 to various metal ions (Figure b). In addition, the selective response to metal ions was visualized by FM (Figure c). The influence of interrupting Cu2+ sensing by other metal ions was studied by conducting Cu2+ sensing in the presence of many other metal ions. Emission spectra () described no disturbance on selective Cu2+ sensing by any of the other metal ions. Lastly, the green emission of the particles was recovered when they were washed using NaCN solution ().

To validate the ethanol oxidation reaction mechanism on R2dtoaCu, we experimentally examined its electrochemical characteristics. We investigated the ethanol sorption properties and EER activity of R2dtoaCu. We analyzed the ethanol sorption isotherms of the (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu at 298 K as shown in Figure ; 0.6 mol of ethanol per 1 mol of Cu dimer was adsorbed on the (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu at P/P 0 = 0.95 where P 0 is the saturated vapor pressure of ethanol, while the ethanol uptake of (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu was about 0.8 mol ethanol per mol of Cu dimer. Furthermore, (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu gives smaller hysteresis than (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu. This lower ethanol adsorption amount and the smaller hysteresis of (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu compared with (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu coincide with the theoretical calculations showing the smaller adsorption energy of ethanol on (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu than that on (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu.

Figure  shows the cyclic voltammogram (CV) of (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu in an aqueous solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 with different concentrations of ethanol. From the CV curve without ethanol in Figure , a quasireversible oxidation couple was observed with a half-wave potential of 0.30 V vs Ag/AgCl (Peak I) (E pa = 0.35 V and E pc = 0.25 V) and an irreversible wave with E p = 0.95 V (Peak II). Here, E pa and E pc are the anodic and cathodic peak potentials, respectively. The peaks I and II were assigned to the CuI/CuII and CuII/CuIII oxidation couples, respectively. These characters are similar to that of (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu. Two characteristics were observed when the ethanol was added to the electrolyte. One is the considerable increase in the current density of both peaks. The other is that the potential in peak I was almost constant while the shape of peak II changed and the current became almost constant at a higher potential than peak II. These results suggest the occurrence of a catalytic EER reaction. The current density for the (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu is about 2.7 mA/cm2 when the ethanol concentration is 2.0 M.

We further conducted a controlled-potential (0.37 V) electrolysis experiment combined with gas chromatography analysis to identify the oxidation products. It was found that acetaldehyde is the sole oxidation product and no acetic acid was detected, which was the same as for (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu under 0.39 V. The maximum conversion ratio of 4.6% within a period of 20 min (based on the area ratio of acetaldehyde and ethanol) was found, for which the initial concentration of ethanol was 0.5 M and the electrolyte volume was 20 mL. The conversion amount was smaller than that for (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu (6.8%), which indicated that the EER activity of the present catalyst is lower than that of (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu. This difference can be explained by the different activation energies of the proton-transfer reaction from ethanol between (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu and (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu obtained by DFT calculations.

Structure Description of NTU-Z30 

The structure determined by a single-crystal X-ray diffractometer shows that NTU-Z30 has the monoclinic space group P21/c with two different SBUs (Figure a,b): one is a new trimeric [Co3(μ3-OH)(COO)7] SBU (Figure a), different from the reported trimeric [M3O(COO)6] SBU (M = Co, Cr, Mn, Ni, Cd), which consists of three Co2+ atoms coordinating with seven COO groups and one μ3-OH (Figure a). In this new trimeric SBU, two Co2+ centers (Co2 and Co3) display a trigonal-bipyramidal configuration and coordinate with one μ3-OH (Co-O 1.9723-2.1390 Å, Co3-μ3-OH 2.0526 Å, and Co2-μ3-OH 2.0768 Å) and four different O species from different COO units, while the third Co2+ center (Co1) is four-connected with one μ3-OH (Co-O 1.9633-1.9957 Å) and three different O atoms from different COO units. The second SBU (Figure b) is a mononuclear [Co(COO)4] species that is constructed by one Co2+ center and four O atoms from four different COO units with monodentate coordination mode (Co-O 1.9520-1.9874 Å). The ratio between these two SBUs in NTU-Z30 is 1:1. Moreover, there are three independent BTC linkers in NTU-Z30: one BTC is linked with Co cations through two different -COO groups with one bridging μ2-η1:η1 mode and a monodentate η1 mode (Figure c), the second one has two bridging μ2-η1:η1 modes (Figure d), and the third one has one bridging μ2-η1:η1 mode and two monodentate η1 modes (Figure e). The two SBUs are further linked together through BTC units to form three-dimensional structures with an intercrossed channel along the a and b axes (Figure f,g). Protonated HTEA+ and guest H3O+ cations act as charge-balance species and fill up the empty space in the channels. TGA (Figure S3, ) for NTU-Z30 reveals that the weight loss (22.85%) in the first stage between 80 and 375 °C is attributed to the loss of TEA and H2O (calcd 23.30%), and the weight loss of 64.35% in the second stage between 375 and 600 °C can be explained by the loss of BTC linkers (calcd 63.74%). The final residue of 12.80% is close to the calculated amount of CoO (12.96%; Figure S3, ).

Structure Description of NTU-Z31 

As shown in Figure a, a three-dimensional structure of NTU-Z31 is made from dimeric cobalt carboxylate clusters and BTC linkers. In Co2(COO)6 clusters, one Co atom has an inversion center symmetry to the other. Each Co center has a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Co-O 1.9488-2.0048 Å) and coordinates with four O atoms from four different but symmetrically equivalent BTC ligands through a bridging μ2-η1:η1 mode and two monodentate η1 modes (Figure b), resulting in a three-dimensional network (Figure c). As shown in Figure d, the framework of NTU-Z31 can be viewed as a decorated rutile net, where each BTC ligand links to three different SBUs and each SBU connects to six BTC ligands. The guest H2O and guest HTEA+ occupy the vacancies made by asymmetric units and have strong interaction with the network via hydrogen bonds. The weight loss of 28.35% (first stage) between 150 and 260 °C in TGA is attributed to the loss of guest TEA and H2O (calcd 27.03%), and the weight loss of 54.26% in the second stage from 260 to 700 °C corresponds to the loss of BTC linkers (calcd 55.40%). The final residue of 17.57% is close to the calculated amount of CoO (17.39%; see Figure S3, ).

Structure Description of NTU-Z32 

The three-dimensional framework of NTU-Z32 is constructed by BTC ligands and trinuclear [Co3(COO)8]2- SBUs. As shown in Figure a, the linear Co3 SBU consists of three crystallographically independent Co centers (Co1, Co2, and Co3). The central Co atom (Co2) has an octahedral configuration with all bridging -COO species from six different BTC ligands, while the terminal centers Co1 and Co3 adopt a four-coordinated distorted tetrahedron, which is completed by bridging four -COO groups from three different BTC ligands. The lengths of the Co-O bonds are in the range of 1.9452-2.1642 Å. The Co1-Co2-Co3 angle is ca. 144.556° (30), and the distances between metal centers are about 3.3969(11) Å. In addition, two independent BTC linkers are observed in NTU-Z32: one BTC is linked to Co centers via -COO groups through μ2-η2 mode, μ2-η1:η1 mode, and monodentate η1 mode (Figure b), and the second one has μ2-η1:η1 mode and η1 mode (Figure b). The framework of NTU-Z32 has channels with a diameter of ~12.56 Å along the b axis, where HTEA+ cations were filled for charge balance (Figure c). In NTU-Z32, each Co3 SBU connects with eight BTC ligands, and every BTC ligand links two or three Co3 SBUs, leading to the formation of a three-dimensional framework (Figure d). Noting that NTU-Z32 is an analogue of Ni3(NMe4)(BTC)3(DMF)2 except the coordination environments of metal atoms. TGA for NTU-Z32 (Figures S3, ) shows that the weight loss (20.05%) in the first stage (150-300 °C) belongs to the evaporation of guest TEA (calcd 20.28%), and the weight loss (59.58%) in the second stage (300-600 °C) comes from the loss of coordination BTC ligands (calcd 57.06%). The final residue of 21.37% is close to the calculated amount of CoO (22.66%; Figure S3, ).

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of NTU-Z30 (a), NTU-Z31 (b), and NTU-Z32 (c) have been examined for possible applications as molecular magnets. The magnetic susceptibilities (χM) of all samples were tested from 300 to 2 K under 100 Oe (Figure ), and χM of all materials follows the Curie-Weiss law in the testing temperature range. The calculated Curie (C) and Weiss (θ) constants for NTU-Z30, NTU-Z31, and NTU-Z32 are 3.10 cm3 K mol-1 and -33.50 K, 2.92 cm3 K mol-1 and -24.51 K, and 2.34 cm3 K mol-1 and -33.10 K, respectively. These results suggest that the neighboring Co cations in all three MOFs have weak antiferromagnetic interactions.

Although they could show some certain catalytic activities, NTU-Z31 and NTU-Z32 are unstable in DMF and are screened out for catalytic examination. The stable NTU-Z30 is the main object to be examined on the catalytic activity in the aerobic epoxidation as below. Figure  displays the relationship between the time and epoxidation ratio of trans-stilbene, where the conversion (98.2%) and selectivity (95.6%) toward the epoxide can be observed after 7 h of reaction. The average turnover frequency (TOF) of 17.6 h-1 based on the cobalt mass was obtained for a reaction lasting for 6 h at 100 °C with an O2 flow rate of 30 mL min-1. Elevating the reaction temperature or O2 flow rate could further improve the average TOFs (TOF = 20.5 h-1 when the reaction temperature is 120 °C). The catalytic activity of NTU-Z30 has been compared with the reported representative catalysts for the same reaction, and the results are summarized in Table . For transformation from trans-stilbene to its corresponding epoxide, NTU-Z30 shows high epoxide selectivity, excellent conversion ratio, and high TOF value, surpassing most of the reported MOF-based heterogeneous catalysts for the same reaction, and even rivals some traditional catalysts. Note that most reports involving MOF-based catalysts have to involve either cocatalyst or peroxides because of their poor catalytic behaviors. Clearly, the NTU-Z30 catalyst takes the lead among all MOF-based catalysts to approach a good catalytic performance.

The stability of NTU-Z30 has been carefully investigated because it is an important factor in evaluating the heterogeneous catalyst. The recycle experiments of NTU-Z30 were performed, and the results are summarized in Figure . Surprisingly, after the first run, the recycled NTU-Z30 showed an even greater catalytic activity. In the second run, the conversion and selectivity of trans-stilbene toward epoxide reaches 92.5% and 99.3%, respectively. After the third run, the conversion got increased to 97.4% and the selectivity is 98.6%. According to the calculation from Diamond software, the larger pore size of NTU-Z30 is 12 × 10 Å along the a axis; hence, the molecule as large as trans-stilbene is unable to enter the pore and contact with the active cobalt sites inside. Here we attribute the active cobalt sites to the cobalt sites on the outer surface of NTU-Z30. Therefore, the improved catalytic activity in the recycle test infers that NTU-Z30 turns to fragments to some extent and then a larger surface area is exposed or rather the number of active sites increases, which leads to the improved catalytic activity. The catalyst stability was further examined by PXRD and FTIR spectra. The PXRD (Figure S5, ) study of both pristine and spent NTU-Z30 shows no phase change, while no obvious peak shifts in the FTIR spectra (Figure S6, ) further confirm the stability of NTU-Z30, which is in agreement with the result of recycle usage. However, according to the ICP-MS result, only a negligible amount of cobalt species leaches into the solution, which might be due to expansion of the cobalt coordination sphere or removal of the cobalt ion, causing the collapse of the framework.

Porous materials have been identified as efficient sorbent media to remove volatile organic compounds. To evaluate their potential as adsorbents, the adsorptive removal of formaldehyde (FA) in aqueous environments was investigated using four materials, two water-stable metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) of UiO-66 (U6) and U6-NH2 (U6N) and two covalent organic polymers (COPs) with amine-functionality, CBAP-1-EDA (CE) and CBAP-1-DETA (CD). U6N exhibited the highest removal capacity of 93% (0.56 mg g-1) of the tested materials [e.g., CE (81.1%, 0.53 mg g-1) > CD (67.2%, 0.43 mg g-1) > U6 (66.9%, 0.42 mg g-1)], which was 2 times higher than that of the reference sorbent, activated carbon (AC: 50%, 0.30 mg g-1). The results of Fourier transform infrared and powder X-ray diffraction analyses confirmed the interactions between FA molecules and the amine components of the materials (U6N, CD, and CE). According to density functional theory calculations, the formation of hydrogen bonds between FA molecules and amine components was apparent and was further verified by FA/amine distance (CD: 2.83, CE: 2.88, and U6N: 2.66 Å) along with enthalpy values (CD: -32.4, CE: -45.5, and U6N: -272 kJ mol-1). In case of U6, the major interactions occurred in the metal-clusters (-19.3 kJ mol-1) via electrostatic interactions (distance: 5.49 Å). Furthermore, the sorption by amine-functionalized materials such as U6N is suggested to be dominated by hydrogen bonding which ultimately led to the formation of imine. If the performance of the tested materials is evaluated in terms of partition coefficient, U6N (1153 mg g-1 mM-1) is found as the outperformer in all tested subjects. Regeneration of spent MOFs/COPs was also plausible in the presence of ethanol to maintain their structural integrity even after 10 adsorption-desorption cycles. Overall, the selected MOFs/COPs were seen to have very high removal capacity for hazardous FA molecules in aqueous phase.

TGA curve of U6 (Figure S3a; blue curve) showed two weight-loss steps. An initial solvent and water weight loss of ca. 20% was detected in the broad initial temperature range of 100-300 °C. The second weight-loss step of ca. 30% was observed in the temperature range of 500-600 °C, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of organic linkers. However, the TGA pattern of U6N (Figure S3a; red curve) was characterized by a relatively slow weight-loss process. Except for the water or solvent lost, the U6N MOFs did not exhibit any substantial weight loss patterns until 350 °C. Likewise, two COPs materials (CE and CD) exhibited similar weight-loss steps throughout the TGA measurements (Figure S3b). Both COPs showed evaporation of solvent and water molecules around 100 °C, and the majority of the weight-loss took place between 350 and 500 °C due to decomposition/network collapse. 

The BET surface area and pore volume of U6/U6N were 1328/963 m2 g-1 and 0.79/0.58 cm3 g-1, respectively (Table S3). In the case of COPs, CE (674 m2 g-1 and 0.23 cm3 g-1) showed higher BET surface area and pore volume than CD (667 m2 g-1 and 0.32 cm3 g-1). In addition, it should be noted that the pore sizes of all four synthesized materials were similar. For instance, the adsorption average pore diameter (4V/A) of U6, U6N, CD, and CE was 1.56, 1.55, 1.90, and 1.69 nm, respectively. More specifically, the two selected MOFs followed the type I adsorption isotherm, indicating the microporous nature of the MOFs. In the type I model, the rate limiting step for sorption of guest molecules on these MOFs should be based on micropore volume rather than surface area. In short, adsorption in the MOFs was mainly monolayer adsorption. In contrast, although COPs followed the type I isotherm pattern, the adsorption track was different from that of desorption at an increased P/P 0 value (Figure S6). This result clearly indicates the heterogeneity of the pores, that is, a mixture of micro- and mesopores. In this case, at a relatively high P/P 0 value, the rate limiting factor for adsorption was capillary condensation rather than the pore filling phenomenon.

FA Adsorption Studies

The adsorption performance of four porous materials tested in this study [i.e., two MOFs (U6, U6N) and two COPs (CE, CD)] was explored for aqueous FA in reference to AC. The RE (%) and adsorption capacity (mg g-1) of adsorbents are compared and presented in  and . The maximum adsorption capacity values of U6 and U6N were 0.42 and 0.56 mg g-1, respectively, while their RE values were 67 and 94%. In the case of COPs, the corresponding RE [adsorption capacity (mg g-1)] values of CE and CD were 81% (0.53) and 67% (0.43), respectively. The results indicated that the RE of FA by U6N was higher than those of U6 and CD by almost 1.4 times and was 1.8 times higher than that of AC. Overall, the sequence of adsorption capacities of the various porous materials tested for FA sorption was in the order of U6N > CE > CD > U6 > AC. Thus, it was suggested that the amine-functionalized materials U6N and CE (functionalized with EDA) showed enhanced FA removal over their counterparts. In contrast, the considerable reduction in sorption capacity of amine-functionalized CD toward FA suggests that, apart from the influence of -NH2, there should be other factors, such as steric hindrance (because of the longer side chain) and pore properties, that play an important role in determining the sorption performance of MOFs and COPs. In order to clearly understand the sorption mechanism of the selected sorbents, the acquired kinetic data were fitted to various kinetic models.

Results of Kinetic Modeling Studies

The results obtained from various kinetic models are summarized in  and Figure S7. From the results, a pseudo-second-order kinetic model was found to show the best fit with a correlation coefficient (R 2) value <0.998. In addition, the predicted q e value from the pseudo-second-order kinetic model was almost equal to the experimentally derived maximum adsorption capacity values (). For instance, the estimated q e (mg g-1) values for U6N, U6, CE, and CD were 0.57, 0.43, 0.54, and 0.44 mg g-1, respectively, which were similar to the obtained q exp values of 0.56, 0.42, 0.53, and 0.43. In addition, the rate constant (k 2) value of U6N (3.13 g mg-1 h-1) was higher than that of others, which represents the effectiveness of the amine functionalization of the framework. In contrast, the decrease in rate constant value of another amine-functionalized COP (CD: 1.33 g mg-1 h-1) should be ascribable to the rigidity of the aliphatic chains of DETA. In summary, an increase in chain length of COPs could reduce the probability of interaction between the -NH2 group of COPs with the oxygen group of FA. 

Although the observed equilibrium capacities of U6 (0.43 mg g-1) and CD (0.44 mg g-1) were comparable to each other, the predicted k 2 value was higher in U6 (1.90 g mg-1 h-1) than in CD (1.33 g mg-1 h-1). This discrepancy between the k2 values of U6 and CD could be explained based on their removal efficiencies with respect to the time/loading rate. As shown in , U6 showed faster adsorption kinetics even at the initial time of the adsorption (3 h). This might be possible because of its larger available surface area (1328 m2 g-1) along with its extended pore volume (0.79 cm3 g-1). On the other hand, the active sites on the surface of U6N gradually decreased as time passed, which stabilized the sorption capacity at higher loading conditions (6 and 48 h). In contrast, the sorption behavior of CD was mainly dependent on -NH2 functionalization. The rigidity of the longer aliphatic side chain slowed the interaction of FA with the -NH2 groups of CD at lower loading conditions. However, at a higher loading of FA, the formation of hydrogen bond should have taken place on the surface of CD. Thus, hydrogen bond formation appeared to help enhance the RE of CD at higher loading conditions (3 and 6 h: 35.6 and 60.8%, respectively). On the basis of a study by Xiao et al., it was not possible to predict this kind of time dependent change in adsorption capacities from the pseudo second order kinetic model; thus, we concluded that U6 was able to rapidly remove aqueous phase FA even at a shorter contact (3 h) time than CD. For example, CD required at least 2 times longer contact time (i.e., 6 h: 60.8%) to reach the RE of U6 at 3 h (55.4 mg g-1).

Furthermore, the C values obtained from the intraparticle diffusion model for U6N, U6, CE, and CD were 0.068, 0.003, 0.019, and 0.012, respectively. It should be noted that, in the intraparticle diffusion model plot, the initial portion of the q  t  versus t 1/2 plot was attributed to the liquid film mass transfer, while the linear portion was associated with intraparticle diffusion. This smaller deviation of C with respect to the origin indicated the boundary layer effect, that is, the greater the C value, the larger the boundary layer effect. Accordingly, the higher C values of U6N (0.068) and CE (0.019) indicated the greater contribution from the surface sorption phenomenon. This result was in accordance with the corresponding K ID values of 0.20 and 0.19 mg/g/h0.5. Similarly, the lower C value of U6 (0.003) compared to CD (0.012) confirmed that the slower mass transfer of U6 should have taken place at a higher loading rate (linear portion). This result was also in accordance with the higher α (initial adsorption rate) value of U6 (0.65 mg g-1 min-1) than of CD (0.59 mg g-1 min-1). Apparently, all of the selected models were useful to meaningfully predict the adsorption kinetics of FA. Nonetheless, among all of those models, the one based on the pseudo-second order was found to have the best fit (>R 2 = 0.995). Thus, adsorption of FA on the selected material should be based on the chemical bond formation between the adsorbent and adsorbate.

Accordingly, the q max values for U6N and U6 derived using the Langmuir model were 0.75 and 0.56 mg g-1, respectively. However, the q max values for CD and CE were 1.80 and 1.26 mg g-1, respectively. These values were almost 3.3 and 2.9 times larger than the experimentally calculated q e values. On the other hand, the estimated R L values for CE (0.17) and CD (0.39) were larger than those for U6 (0.14) and U6N (0.04). This comparison confirmed that the monolayer adsorption of FA on U6N was highly spontaneous and more favorable than other materials (R L < 1). This result was also verified with the obtained 1/n values from the Freundlich isotherm. For instance, the calculated 1/n values of U6N (0.25), U6 (0.41), CE (0.58), and CD (0.65) were between 0 and 1 (1/n ≪ 1). On the other hand, their calculated E values from the Dubinin-Radushkevich isotherm model were 10000, 7071, 7071, and 5000 kJ mol-1, respectively. In this study, the E value represents the transfer of free energy for 1 mol of solute from the solution to the adsorbent's surface. An E value >8 kJ mol-1 indicates that chemisorption was the predominant mechanism in accordance with the kinetic studies. In contrast, the values of B from the Temkin isotherm were in the range of 0.09, 0.11, 0.31, and 0.34 kJ mol-1, respectively (except for U6, the R 2 values for this model were satisfactory). As such, this indicated that physisorption was also responsible for the adsorption of FA on MOFs and COPs. Overall, according to the isotherm model, adsorption of FA on the selected solid sorbent was accompanied by both physisorption and chemisorption.

Performance Comparison of FA Sorption Capacities between Different Studies

To assess the adsorption efficiency of the selected materials in this study, we performed a comparative analysis of the sorption capacity of materials tested between different studies (). It should be noted that, although a fairly large number of studies are available on the adsorption of FA in gas phase, only a limited number of studies were conducted on the sorption of FA in aqueous phase. In light of this limitation in the database, we narrowed our discussion with recognition of this constraint. The common traditional adsorbent of untreated AC (U-AC) was treated and modified with amino groups (N1-AC and N2-AC). The equilibrium (after 72 h) sorption capacities of N1-AC, N2-AC, and U-AC were 0.14, 0.2, and 0.13 mg g-1, respectively. The enhanced adsorption capacity of novel materials (MOFs/COPs) over that of AC clearly indicated the effectiveness of amine functionalization. Nonetheless, we obtained 0.56 mg g-1 of FA adsorption on U6N with shorter equilibration time (6 h). Accordingly, the superiority of MOFs over traditional sorbents in FA removal can be confirmed. Recently, Afkhami et al. reported that alumina nanoparticles coated with DNPH could be used as a sorbent for removal of FA from water. At an initial FA concentration of 250 ppm, the RE was 97% (411 mg g-1) (after 1 h). They conducted experiments at a significantly higher concentration than ours (0.2 ppm) to observe a much shorter duration of removal than that of the present study. It should be noted that DNPH has been commonly used as a capture medium for FA, because it exhibits excessive affinity toward FA. As such, the performance was studied at significantly high concentrations of FA. Likewise, a 3D nanoporous MOF [[Zn4O(C24H15N6O6)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O⋅DMF] n  (called: 1) was synthesized and used for absorptive removal of FA at an initial concentration of 100 ppm. The adsorption capacity of 1 was 75 mg g-1 for aqueous FA.

Electrochemical water splitting is considered as the most promising technology for hydrogen production. Considering overall water splitting for practical applications, catalysis of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) should be performed in the same electrolyte, especially in alkaline solutions. However, designing and searching for highly active and inexpensive electrocatalysts for both OER and HER in basic media remain significant challenges. Herein, we report a facile and universal strategy for synthesizing nonprecious transition metals, binary alloys, and ternary alloys encapsulated in graphene layers by direct annealing of metal-organic frameworks. Density functional theory calculations prove that with an increase in the degree of freedom of alloys or a change in the metal proportions in FeCoNi ternary alloys, the electronic structures of materials can also be tuned intentionally by changing the number of transferred electrons between alloys and graphene. The optimal material alloys FeCo and FeCoNi exhibited remarkable catalytic performance for HER and OER in 1.0 M KOH, reaching a current density of 10 mA cm-2 at low overpotentials of 149 mV for HER and 288 mV for OER. In addition, as an overall alkaline water electrolysis, they were comparable to that of the Pt/RuO2 couple, along with long cycling stability.

The performance of catalysts toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) was explored in a 1 M KOH solution by a typical three-electrode electrochemical cell. Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) and platinum foil electrodes were used as the reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. As illustrated in a, we conducted linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) to assess the activities of the oxygen evolution reaction for metal, binary alloys, and ternary alloys. We also measured the performance of Ir/C (20 wt % Ir on Vulcan carbon black purchased from Premetek Co.) and RuO2 (Alfa aesar) as references. In general, all catalysts except Co had OER activity much higher than that of RuO2. Ir/C is superior to most of our alloy samples; however, the overpotential to reach 10 mA/cm2 of FeCoNi-2 is still lower than that of Ir/C, indicating the excellent OER performance of FeCoNi-2. The overpotential of ternary alloys to reach a current density of 10 mA cm-2 is lower than that of the binary alloy and pure metal, indicating that incorporating transition metal and binary alloys into ternary alloys will improve their OER activity. In addition, FeCoNi-2 exhibits the best catalytic performance (overpotential of 325 mV at 10 mA cm-2) among all ternary alloys, proving that further altering metal proportions of ternary alloys could also enhance their properties. The Tafel plot of FeCoNi-2 was recorded and compared with that of RuO2 (b). The Tafel slope of FeCoNi-2 is 60 mV dec-1, which is much lower than that of RuO2 (92 mV dec-1), showing FeCoNi-2 is a better catalyst for driving the OER process than RuO2 is at a lower overpotential. The durability of FeCoNi-2 was also assessed by measuring polarization curves after particular cyclic voltammetric (CV) sweeps as illustrated in c. The polarization curve of FeCoNi-2 after 10000 cycles retained a performance almost similar to that of the initial test, exhibiting excellent cycling stability. Moreover, from the potential values recorded at different current densities of 10 and 40 mA cm-2 before and after the test (d), FeCoNi-2 exhibits high stability, obviously superior to the durability of its RuO2 counterpart. To further prove the material is wholly alloyed, we also obtained a mixture by mechanical mixing of FeCo and CoNi with a precursor ratio that is the same as that of FeCoNi-2. As shown in Figure S8, the mixture of FeCo and CoNi also exhibits OER activity obviously inferior to that of FeCoNi-2, indicating the core of our sample is also successfully alloyed. As illustrated in enlarged a (Figure S9), a slight peak emerging around 1.4 V versus RHE might be ascribed to partial oxidation of alloys during cycling according to previous research. However, the peak intensity is relatively lower compared with those of other transition metal-based OER catalysts without the protection of a graphene layer. In addition, the oxidation peak remained almost same after the 1000th cycle, indicating further oxidation was prevented by the graphene layer. We also used the saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as a reference electrode to verify the activity and stability of FeCoNi-2 as an OER catalyst, and the results were compared with those of the Ag/AgCl electrode. The difference between two electrodes of measured overpotentials to a reach current density of 10 mA cm-2 is only 5 mV as illustrated in Figure S10a. Besides, a long cycling test using the SCE also shows a similar result with the Ag/AgCl electrode: FeCoNi-2 exhibits negligible activity degradation even after the 10000th cycle, indicating the excellent stability of our catalyst (Figure S10b). The excellent activity as well as stability of FeCoNi-2 makes it a promising alternative for highly active nonprecious metal electrocatalysts for OER.

Utilizing a standard three-electrode electrochemical system, we assess the catalytic activity of samples for HER in 1 M KOH. The electrocatalytic activity of 20 wt % Pt/C (Sigma-Aldrich) was also measured to make a comparison. The polarization curves of the samples are illustrated in a. Pt/C is still one of the best HER catalysts in a basic electrolyte; meanwhile, pure Co exhibited relatively poor HER activity. We chose potentials at a current density of 10 mA cm-2 as criteria for comparing activities of various catalysts. The potentials increase in the following order: Pt < FeCo < FeCoNi-1 < FeCoNi-2 < FeCoNi-3 < CoNi < FeNi < Co. Unlike the OER test results, the binary FeCo alloy exhibits the best HER catalytic activity among all nonprecious samples, reaching a current density of 10 mA cm-2 at low overpotentials of only 211 mV. Tafel plots of the FeCo alloys and Pt/C are shown in b, which are usually used to reveal the inherent reaction mechanism of HER. The Tafel plot of the FeCo catalyst shows a value of 77 mV dec-1, demonstrating that the HER process is following the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism according to previous research. We also measured OER and HER activity of our best catalysts (FeCo and FeCoNi-2) in 0.1 M KOH (Figure S11) and compared them with those measured in 1 M KOH. As shown in Figure S11, both FeCo and FeCoNi-2 exhibit inferior activity in 0.1 M KOH compared to that in 1 M KOH; this phenomenon also exists in other electrocatalysts and even for Pt/C and Ir/C. The TEM images of FeCo and FeCoNi-2 after 10000 HER and OER cycles are also provided. As shown in panels a and c of Figure S12, the electrocatalysts maintained their original morphology after cycling, and from the enlarged TEM images (Figure S12b,d), we can still see the core-shell structure, further confirming the stability of the electrocatalysts.

In the practical application of electrochemical water splitting, the catalysts were usually grown or transferred onto conductive substrates with an increased amount of loading, especially for nonprecious catalysts. Therefore, we also measured the catalytic activity of HER and OER of our materials on carbon fiber paper with a loading amount of 1.0 mg/cm2. Compared with nickel foam or carbon cloth, carbon fiber paper exhibits negligible intrinsic activity, which will weaken the influence of measurement for catalysts. As illustrated in panels a and b of , bare carbon paper exhibited negligible activity of HER and OER; however, carbon paper loaded with FeCo and FeCoNi-2 catalyst reached a current density of 10 mA cm-2 at low potentials of 149 mV for HER and 288 mV for OER, which were extremely excellent among those of nonprecious electrochemical catalysts. The comparison of HER and OER activity measured on a glassy carbon electrode and three-dimensional substrates are illustrated in Tables S7 and S8. To demonstrate the practical application of catalysts for overall water splitting, a simple water electrolyzer was measured by using FeCo on carbon paper as a cathode and FeCoNi-2 on carbon paper as an anode. As shown in c, a current density of 10 mA cm-2 could be achieved by applying a potential of 1.687 V between two electrodes, which is even smaller than that of its Pt-RuO2 counterpart (1.696 V). The simple water electrolysis exhibited vigorous gas evolution on both electrodes, as shown in the Supplementary Video at a potential of 1.7 V. In addition, the very stable current density at a high potential of 1.8 V in i-t curves (d) further demonstrated the strong stability of the alloys. Bare carbon fiber papers were also measured at 1.8 V for comparison. The negligible activity of carbon paper further proved the activity came from the catalysts. The excellent activity of the alloy catalyst, accompanied by high stability, made it a potential alternative for precious catalysts in practical water splitting.

There is a change in the electronic properties and conductivities of the complexes after the drug molecule interacts with the COF surfaces. The E HOMO and E LUMO of COF-B surface are -9.31 eV and -0.49 eV, respectively, with E H-L energy gap of 8.82 eV, while the E HOMO and E LUMO of COF-Al surface are -9.13 eV and -0.15 eV, respectively, with E H-L energy gap of 9.28 eV. Following the interaction of the pure surfaces with drugs, the orbital densities and energy gaps are altered. The pure surfaces and complexes orbital densities are presented in . The E H-L energy gaps of BGN@COF-B and MET@COF-B are 8.29 and 7.42 eV, respectively, while the E H-L energy gaps of BGN@COF-Al and MET@COF-Al are 7.89 and 7.87 eV, respectively. The energy gaps of COF-B complexes are lower than that of pure COF-B. This is as a result of the destabilization of energies of HOMO and stabilization of the energies of the LUMO, which in turn enhance the transfer of charge from HOMO to LUMO. Nonetheless, BGN@COF-B is comparatively less conductive than that of MET@COF-B due to its high energy gap. Likewise, the energy gaps of COF-Al complexes are lower than that of pure COF-Al. This is also due to the destabilization of energies of HOMO and stabilization of the energies of the LUMO, which in turn enhance the transfer of charge from HOMO to LUMO. This result suggested that it is easy to form a chemical bond between COF-B and COF-Al and the drugs (BGN and MET). Nevertheless, MET@COF-Al is slightly more conductive than that of BGN@COF-B due to its low energy gap.

The ionization potential values are 9.31, 9.13, 8.80, 8.17, 7.88, and 7.85 eV for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al, respectively. This result agrees with the energy values of HOMO (), which shows that the ionization potential values are directly proportional to the energies of the HOMO values. The interaction of the isolated surfaces with the drugs molecules to form complexes resulted in the destabilization of the HOMO and stabilization of LUMO in all the complexes. The electron affinity values for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are 0.49, -0.15, 0.51, 0.75, -0.01, and -0.02 eV, respectively. The values of electron affinities of the studied systems indicate that the complexes are more reactive than the pristine surfaces that are in line with the ionization potential and electronegativity values. The chemical hardness and softness values for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are 4.41, 4.64, 4.15, 3.71, 3.95, and 3.94 eV (chemical hardness) and 0.113, 0.108, 0.121, 0.135, 0.126, and 0.127 eV-1 (chemical softness), respectively. The low values of chemical softness and high values of chemical hardness point to the fact that the isolated COF surfaces and complexes formed with drugs are naturally stable. The results also agree with the values of electron affinity and chemical potential. Also, high values for electrophilicity index indicate excellent interaction of drug molecules on the COF surfaces.

An enzyme mimic harboring iron porphyrin (DhHP-6) embedded in zeolite imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) was constructed through a biomimetic mineralization approach to obtain composite DhHP-6@ZIF-8. The composite was then used as a catalyst in the atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) of poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMA500) in which poly(PEGMA500) could be synthesized with monomer conversion of 76.1% and M n of 45900 g/mol, stronger than that obtained when using free DhHP-6 as a catalyst. More importantly, it could efficiently overcome the drawbacks of free DhHP-6 and achieve the easy separation of DhHP-6 from the catalytic system and the elimination of iron residues in the synthesized polymer. In addition, it exhibited an enhanced recyclability with monomer conversion of 75.7% after five cycles and favorable stability during the ATRP reaction with <3.0% of DhHP-6 release within 100 h. Thus, the enzyme mimic-ZIF-8 composite developed through biomimetic mineralization can be potentially used as an effective catalyst for preparing well-defined polymers with biomedical applications.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of DhHP-6@ZIF-8

Through the biomimetic mineralization approach shown in , enzyme mimic DhHP-6 could be embedded in a porous nanomaterial ZIF-8, in which Zn(OAc)2, HMeIM, and DhHP-6 were incubated with trace methanol at room temperature. The addition of trace methanol was used to facilitate the dissolution of HMeIM in water. The morphology of composite DhHP-6@ZIF-8 was characterized by SEM and TEM (). The SEM image clearly showed that DhHP-6@ZIF-8 possessed a uniform rhombic dodecahedral morphology, which was similar to that of blank ZIF-8, and the average particle size could be determined to be ca. 700 nm. The TEM image of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 also showed the same morphology, indicating that the loading of enzyme mimic DhHP-6 did not influence the morphology of ZIF-8. Meanwhile, EDS mapping of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 demonstrated the presence of a Fe signal in the composite, which provided direct evidence for the loading of enzyme mimic harboring iron porphyrin in ZIF-8 through biomimetic mineralization ( and S2). Through ICP-MS, the Fe and Zn contents in DhHP-6@ZIF-8 were measured to be 780.4 and 2.1 × 104 ppb, respectively, from which the DhHP-6 loading in ZIF-8 was calculated to be 16.8 wt %. Elemental analysis showed that the contents of C, H, and O of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 were kept at similar levels to those of me-ZIF-8 (Figure S3). In addition, the morphology of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 could be transformed to flower shape when the molar ratio of HMeIM and Zn(OAc)2 was decreased to 4:1 during biomimetic mineralization (Figure S4).

To ascertain that DhHP-6 was indeed encapsulated by a ZIF-8 crystalline shell, DhHP-6@ZIF-8 obtained through biomimetic mineralization was characterized by FT-IR and PXRD. As shown in a, the PXRD pattern of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 exhibited peaks matching well with those of simulated ZIF-8 and me-ZIF-8, suggesting that ZIF-8 frameworks were formed in the biomimetic mineralization and the structural integrity of ZIF-8 could be retained in the presence of DhHP-6. In the FT-IR spectra of DhHP-6@ZIF-8, characteristic peaks of DhHP-6 at 1640-1660 and 1510-1560 cm-1 could be clearly observed, attributing to amide I (mainly from C-O stretching mode) and II (mainly from a combination of N-H bending and C-N stretching modes) bands, respectively (b). Moreover, no new peaks and significant peak shifts were observed, implying that the encapsulation of DhHP-6 in ZIF-8 during biomimetic mineralization was executed in a self-assembly manner with no formation of covalent bonding. Composite FITC-DhHP-6@ZIF-8 was then detected by CLSM in a layer-by-layer scanning manner to trace the status of particles at different depths along the z-axis position (). Clearly, the fluorescence intensity of FITC displayed an increasing tendency from the top to middle and then decreased from the middle to bottom, which provided direct evidence for the loading of DhHP-6 in ZIF-8 during the crystal growth of porous nanomaterials. On the basis of the absorbance at 387 nm, DhHP-6 loading in ZIF-8 was calculated to be ca. 23.4 wt % with a loading efficiency of almost 100%, much higher than that for its encapsulation in other inorganic materials. 

Furthermore, nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at 77 K to assess the porosity of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 (Figures S5 and S6). The isotherm of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 exhibited a type I isotherm with a narrow hysteresis loop at P/P 0 = 0.05-0.10. Meanwhile, the pore width values of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 were determined to be 10.1 and 11.6 Å, which were similar to me-ZIF-8 (9.7 and 10.6 Å), revealing that the DhHP-6 loading through biomimetic mineralization did not influence the pore volume or width. The phenomenon was consistent with the previous research on the encapsulation of BSA in ZIF-8, which was attributed to the formation of ZIF-8 around the biomolecules and has been considered as a typical characteristic of biomimetic mineralization. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method was then employed to measure the surface area of samples, suggesting that there were no obvious differences between the surface areas of me-ZIF-8 and DhHP-6@ZIF-8 (Figure S7 and Table S1). The phenomenon was probably caused by the coordination of the histidine imidazole group in DhHP-6 with Zn2+ during the formation of ZIF-8, thereby achieving the assembly of enzyme mimic in the ZIF-8 backbone. The strategy of biomimetic mineralization did not involve the physical adsorption or encapsulation of enzyme mimic DhHP-6 into large pores of MOFs, thus no obvious structural changes could be observed between me-ZIF-8 and DhHP-6@ZIF-8. The assumption could also be confirmed by the fact that there was no peroxidase activity detected for DhHP-6@ZIF-8, as shown in Figure S14. Notably, TGA curves also demonstrated the presence of DhHP-6 in the composite (Figure S8), in which the first weight loss (about 21.0 wt %) of the DhHP-6@ZIF-8 composite in air happened in the range of 100-150 °C could be attributed to the decomposition of enzyme mimic molecules. The ratio was consistent with the DhHP-6 loading determined through the absorbance at 387 nm (23.4 wt %), as mentioned above.

Product poly(PEGMA500) was characterized by 1H NMR. As shown in Figure S10, the characteristic chemical shifts of poly(PEGMA500) could be clearly observed at 0.86-1.01 and 1.83 ppm, attributing to protons a and b, indicating the successful proceeding of ATRP. The monomer conversion could be calculated according to the integration of two vinyl protons of the residual monomer (5.71 and 6.13 ppm) and the methyl signal of poly(PEGMA500) (3.32 ppm). The catalytic profile of the DhHP-6@ZIF-8-mediated ATRP reaction is summarized in . Whereas no ATRP occurred using me-ZIF-8 as a catalyst, DhHP-6 and DhHP-6@ZIF-8 could achieve ATRP of PEGMA500 with high monomer conversion (65.6-86.5%). Remarkably, the DhHP-6@ZIF-8-catalyzed ATRP reaction could produce higher monomer conversion and product M n values than those for free DhHP-6 under the same ratio of monomer to initiator. However, HRP@ZIF-8 obtained through biomimetic mineralization could not execute the ATRP reaction at a [monomer]/[initiator] of 62:1, with only 29.4% monomer conversion and no products obtained (entry 10 in ). For instance, poly(PEGMA500) could be obtained with a monomer conversion of 76.1% and M n of 45900 g/mol using DhHP-6@ZIF-8 as a catalyst with [monomer]/[initiator] of 62:1. The enhanced ATRP catalytic ability of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 was probably induced by the better dispersion of DhHP-6@ZIF-8 in the catalytic system, which has effectively solved the issue of DhHP-6 aggregation during the reaction. Except for this, other two reasons could account for the improved ATRP catalytic ability: (1) hydrophilic HMeIM around enzyme molecules might facilitate the access of water-soluble monomers to the active site of enzyme and (2) only peptide was involved in the formation of porous crystals during biomimetic mineralization, and iron porphyrin was mainly located on the surface of ZIF-8, which would cause a high concentration of active sites on the ZIF-8 surface and thereby produce enhanced ATRP catalytic activity. Meanwhile, the synthesized polymer possessed uniform molecular weight distribution with low polydispersity index (PDI) values (1.10-1.27). Except for PEGMA500, DhHP-6@ZIF-8 could catalyze the ATRP reaction of PEGA and NiPAAm, but no catalytic activity could be observed for monomer PDMAEMA (Table S2). To further elucidate whether the reaction was triggered from the ATRP initiator, we synthesized a macroinitiator PEO-Br (M n = 3100 g/mol, PDI = 1.06; Figure S11) and then employed it in the ATRP reaction. As shown in Figure S12, the shift of molecular weight after chain extension could be clearly observed in GPC curves, yielding a block copolymer with M n and PDI values of 13100 g/mol and 1.07, respectively. Thus, poly(PEGMA500) synthesis catalyzed by DhHP-6@ZIF-8 was performed in an ATRP manner, in which the lower oxidation state of DhHP-6 was in equilibrium with its higher oxidation state in the presence of Asc during polymerization.

Using the present covalent force field, our simulations confirm the trend of negative thermal expansion as is evident from the plot in Figure  where experimental data for MOF-5 under N 2 gas atmosphere are shown for comparison. Our simulated volumetric thermal-expansion coefficient of MOF-5 (-22 × 10-6 K-1), determined by a linear fit of the unit-cell length as a function of temperature (dashed line in Figure ), is in agreement with other simulated values obtained using different force fields (-24 × 10-6 K-1, -39 × 10-6 K-1 and -40 × 10-6 K-1). An experimental value of -40 × 10-6 K-1 is obtained from a linear fit of the data points plotted in Figure  taken from ref . This value agrees with a recent direct experimental measurement of the thermal expansion of MOF-5 using neutron powder diffraction in the temperature range 4-600 K (-48 × 10-6 K-1). 

Our simulated elastic constants are in good agreement with the DFT predictions, further confirming that our FF reproduces the DFT potential energy surface. The Young's modulus, E = (C 11 - C 12)(C 11 + 2C 12)/(C 11 + C 12), of 20.7 GPa and the Poisson's ratio, ν = C 12/(C 11 + C 12), of 0.26 are also in accord with the DFT results (E = 21.9 GPa and ν = 0.28). Overall, our FF results are in better agreement with the DFT calculated values as those from other FF calculations, also shown in Table  . The elastic stiffnesses, C 11 and C 12, at room temperature were obtained from an ensemble average of the diagonal elements of the directly calculated stress tensor in a constant volume simulation (N V T, T = 300 K, 500 ps). An uniaxial compression of 0.5% was applied. The elastic stiffnesses, C 11 and C 12, determined separately, were found to decrease by about 15% and 40%, respectively, giving rise to a decrease of the bulk modulus by about 25% from the value calculated at 0 K. This trend is in agreement with other MD simulations based on different force fields.

Results and Discussion

The strongly luminescent white color single-crystalline Sr-MOF compound, shown in Figure S1, was synthesized by a hydrothermal technique through the chemical reaction between the precursors of metal nitrate (strontium nitrate) and organic linker 1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxylic acid (H4ntc). The details of the synthesis process of the MOF compound is discussed in the Supporting Informations. The structural analysis of the MOF compound was performed by a single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) study, as shown in Figure S2. To utilize the MOFs for device fabrication, the rectangular-shaped single crystal of the MOF compound was first ground to the size of nanoparticles, and then these nanoparticles were dispersed into an ethanol solvent. For good dispersion of the MOF compound into the ethanol solution, the solution containing the MOF was stirred with a magnetic stirrer. For a morphological analysis by a scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image, we used the solution of dispersed MOFs. The microstructural analysis of the MOF compound was performed by SEM, as shown in Figure S3. From the SEM micrograph, we observed strong uncontrolled agglomeration behavior with random shapes in the crystalline MOF due to nanocrystal formation. Because of this uncontrolled agglomeration effect, they look like an amorphous thin film in the SEM image. The optical properties of the MOF compound were investigated by photoluminescence and absorption measurements, as shown in Figure S4a,b. The optical investigations reveal strong white light emission from the MOF compound having photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) for light emission of ~58%. The PL spectrum covers the whole visible regime indicating the broadband light emission from the MOF compound. The PL spectrum having a CIE color coordinate (0.34, 0.35), as shown in Figure S5, with color rendering index (CRI) of 88 and color correlated temperature (CRT) of 5200, clearly reveals the white-light emission from this MOF compound. The broad emission spectra of the MOF compound mainly originated from the superimposition of multiple emissions from different radiative transitions because of the charge transformations between interligand, intermetallic, and metal to the ligand or vice versa. For a more precise analysis of the broadband emission spectrum from the MOF compound, we deconvoluted the PL spectrum, which contains the different emission blocks, as shown in Figure S6a. The strong blue emission block having an emission peak centered around ~455 nm corresponds to a π-π* interligand charge transformation. For further clarification of the emission of the free ligand, the PL spectrum of the ligand was measured, as shown in Figure S6b. The other emission blocks containing the emission peaks centered around ~405, 640, and 548 nm are associated with the charge transfer between intermetallic and metal to ligand, respectively. Broad emission from the MOF compound is also possibly due to our unique synthesis by a judicious choice of strontium metal in combination with a suitable organic linker. Because of its isotropic behavior, strontium itself has several strong radiative transitions that provide the emission spectrum covering the wide wavelength. The single-layer graphene was grown on copper foil by a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique and transferred on polymer PVDF. The monolayer of the synthesized CVD graphene on PVDF has been confirmed from a Raman spectroscopy study. The synthesis and Raman investigation details of graphene have been provided in the Supporting Information and Figure S7. The light-emissive self-powered vertical phototransistor was fabricated by sandwiching the MOF between graphenes on flexible substrate PVDF/PDMS as shown in the schematic of a. The details of the device fabrication procedure are provided in the  section. The corresponding SEM image of our fabricated vertical GrT/MOF/GrB/PVDF phototransistor device is shown in b. From the SEM micrograph, the estimated thickness of the MOF layer for optimized performance is ~300 nm. An optical microscope image of the top view of the actual fabricated device and a mobile photograph of the fabricated flexible device is shown in b and Figure S8, respectively. We measured the current-voltage (I-V) curve of our fabricated vertical phototransistor in the dark and under excitation from a 530 nm laser with a power density of 50 nW cm-2 on the device area of 2 mm × 300 nm, as shown in c. The nonlinear I-V curves indicate the existence of asymmetric Schottky barriers at the GrB/MOF and MOF/GrT interfaces. The mechanism responsible for asymmetric I-V curves is mainly because of the polarization effect of the ferroelectric PVDF layer below the bottom graphene, which enables one to induce polarization in the bottom graphene with respect to the top graphene and changes the density of states of GrB as compared to GrT. The optimized performance of the device was obtained by several photocurrent measurements through the thickness variation of the MOF compound, as shown in Figure S9. To investigate the induced polarization effect of the PVDF layer, we measured the I-V curves of the phototransistor device with and without a PVDF layer, as shown in Figure S10. The asymmetric Schottky junctions at different interfaces produce a strong built-in electric field, which facilitates generation of the photocurrent from this device without the application of an external electric bias. The built-in electric field produces a large depletion region, which can assist the dissociation of photogenerated excitons and the transport of electrons and holes to the electrodes. The Schottky barrier efficiently prolongs the lifetime of photogenerated excitons due to reduced recombination, which results in rapid exciton separation and their transport to the electrodes. d shows a dynamic photoresponse from our fabricated photodetector device without applications of electric bias having switched on/off under the illumination of a 530 nm laser. This clearly indicates that our fabricated device is a self-powered photodetector. The excellent self-powered photoresponse performance was confirmed through ultrahigh and ultrafast photoresponse (the photoresponsivity under 0 bias is ~1.3 × 103 A W-1 with response time of ~220 μs), reduced noise, and large detectivity. The observed self-powered photoresponse performance from our fabricated device is ~103 times higher than that of a reported similar device using silicon, versatile two-dimensional (2D) materials, and metal oxides. Such a self-powered photodetector has tremendous demand in next-generation IoT (Internet of things) technology, space exploration, and wireless environmental monitoring.

The photodetection performance of our fabricated vertical GrT/MOF/GrB/PVDF phototransistor was investigated under light illumination and application of electric bias through photoresponsivity (Rph), photocurrent gain (G), EQE, and detectivity (D*). The estimation details of all these optical parameters related to photodetection with a physical formula and their variation with illuminated light power are discussed in the Supporting Information. In order to investigate the photoresponse performance of our fabricated device, we measured the light power-dependent I-V characteristics and transient photoresponse curves, shown in a,b, respectively, under the illumination from a 530 nm laser on the device active area of 2 mm × 300 nm. This investigation indicates the generation of positive photocurrent from our fabricated vertical phototransistor device. The observed positive photoresponse from the phototransistor can be explained by the energy band diagram shown in c. The energy band is bent with a created band slope due to the mismatch between the Fermi energy of photon-absorbing MOF (-5.0 eV) and single-layer graphene (-4.6 eV). As described earlier, because of the asymmetric Schottky junction formations due to the polarization-induced effect of PVDF, the work function of GrB is higher as compared to that of GrT, which bends the energy band toward the bottom graphene, and the effective built-in electric field drives the photogenerated electrons toward the top graphene and generates a positive photocurrent. It is notable that there is the presence of asymmetry in the Schottky barriers at GrT/MOF and MOF/GrB/PVDF interfaces because of the different doping levels of the top and bottom graphene due to the utilization of the piezoelectric PVDF layer at the bottom of the GrB. It is expected that the Schottky potential of the MOF/GrB interface is higher than that of the GrT/MOF interface because of the doping effect from PVDF, which may bend the MOF layer band slope downward toward the top graphene contact, and the resultant built-in electric field drives the photogenerated electrons toward the GrT. A similar concept of the photoresponse from a GrT/MOS2/GrB heterojunction on a SiO2/Si substrate has been reported by Yu et al. for a GrT/MOS2/GrB heterojunction. In their device, the Schottky barrier height in the GrB/MoS2 contact is higher than that of the GrT/MoS2 contact, probably due to a p-type doping effect to the graphene by the substrate oxide. The variations of Rph, G, and EQE with illumination light-power density are shown in Figure S11a-c, respectively. We estimated the Rph, G, and EQE values are ~1.2 × 108 A W-1, 4.7 × 108, and 3 × 1010%, respectively, under the illumination power density of 12.7 nW cm-2 from a 530 nm laser and applied bias voltage 2 V, which are comparable with those of recently reported graphene-organometallic perovskite heterostructure phototransistors and 104 times higher than those of previously reported graphene-nanomaterials hybrid photodetectors. We measured the laser power from a 530 nm laser source by utilizing a power meter. We took into account the beam spot size in the calculation of laser power density falling into the vertical phototransistor device. We consider the maximum beam spot diameter 2 mm in our calculation to get minimum photoresponsivity. The actual laser beam spot size from the 530 nm laser source is smaller than this, which can give a higher value of photoresponsivity than our present reported results. In addition to its ultrahigh photosensitivity, our fabricated vertical phototransistor also shows ultrafast photoresponse, as shown in Figure S11d. This observed ultrahigh photoresponse from our fabricated vertical phototransistor can be explained by multiple aspects associated with our design and fabrication processes, which are provided in the Supporting Information. The estimated D* and noise equivalent power (NEP) are ~2.9 × 1015 cm Hz1/2 W-1 and 8.6 × 10-19 W, respectively. Such a high D* is 103 times higher than that of reported flexible hybrid photodetectors by using recently emerged hybrid perovskites, versatile two-dimensional materials, and similar architecture of Schottky contact-based graphene sandwich vertical photodetectors. The high detectivity is mainly attributed to the suppression of noise due to the decrease in dark current because of efficient charge separation and reduced trap-state occupancy. The estimated NEP is 103 times lower than that of the recently reported hybrid 2D covalent organic frameworks (COFs)-graphene and hBN/graphene/hBN heterojunction photodetectors. Such a low NEP (NEP < pW Hz-1/2) is advantageous for the detection of low-frequency (THz) light, which has multiple applications including quantum optics, imaging, biomedicine, tomography, and security. 

 a represents a schematic of a PVDF/GrB/MOF/GrT/PMMA vertical flexible photodetector under downward bending conditions. Because of its highly polarized unit cells and a strong concentration of β-phase having a trans-torsional distribution, PVDF possesses high piezoelectricity. Because of the different polarization effects of the piezoelectric PVDF layer below the bottom graphene under different applied mechanical strains, we investigated the device flexibility under upward and downward bending and measured the transient photoresponse characteristic curves, as shown in b. This investigation clearly reveals the different photoresponse under different bending conditions due to the induced polarization effect of PVDF, which can control the effective built-in electric field in the device. The schematic of the cross-sectional view of the device with the direction of the effective built-in electric field under different bending conditions is shown in c,d. We estimated the bending strain by using the following equation, bending      strain  ( % )  =   L - L '   L   × 100    , where L is the radius of curvature when the device is under the unbending condition, and L' is the radius of curvature under the bending condition, as shown in Figure S12. Figure S13 shows the photoresponse curve with a variation in bending diameter. The bending strain-dependent photoresponse under downward bending and upward bending conditions is shown in e,f, respectively. Evidently, the decrease of photocurrent with the enhancement of downward bending strain phenomenon is reversed for the application of upward bending strain. This interesting observation can be mainly ascribed to the induced polarization effect of the underlying PVDF layer of the bottom graphene. The application of mechanical strain electromechanically modulates not only the Schottky barrier of GrB/PVDF and GrT/MOF heterojunctions but also the Dirac point of graphene. Under downward bending strain, the electric field corresponding to the induced polarization of the PVDF layer is reversed to the built-in electric field of the GrB/MOF/GrT heterojunction, which is responsible for a decrease in photocurrent under downward bending strain. For upward bending strain, the induced piezoelectric field due to the deformation of the PVDF layer acts in the same direction as the built-in electric field of vertical GrB/MOF/GrT heterojunction, which enhances the photocurrent. More importantly, our investigation of the strain-dependent photoresponse from the flexible vertical GrT/MOF/GrB/PVDF photodetector clearly reveals that the magnitude and polarity of the photocurrent can be controlled by the induced piezoelectric field of the underlying PVDF layer, which shows an excellent potential of strain sensor performance of our designed vertical phototransistor device. The induced piezoelectric field produces different barrier heights of Schottky junctions at GrT/MOF and MOF/GrB interfaces. The sensitivity of the strain sensor in photoconduction under mechanical bending strain can be evaluated by a standard gauge factor estimation. The estimation details of the gauge factor are provided in the Supporting Information. The calculated gauge factors for upward and downward bending are ~4 and 1.2, respectively, under the application of large bending strain (66%), and they are comparable with the recently reported sensitivities (13.5 and 4.02 for compressive and tensile strain, respectively) of a piezoelectric-based graphene/GaN/PDMS strain sensor under the application of very small bending strain (0.1%).

The product after the first pass was pale yellow, consistent with the color expected of UiO-66-NH2. In accordance with the standard TSE procedure, the obtained mixture was fed through the extruder one more time to ensure larger residence times, and consequentially, a higher yield of the product. At the screw speed of 180 rpm, the accomplished throughput was around 23 g/min, equivalent to almost 1.4 kg of product per hour. The obtained pale-yellow powder was washed with a small volume of MeOH and identified as UiO-66-NH2 using PXRD analysis (c). The particles in the sample are smaller than 100 nm in diameter and agglomerate to loosely bound spheres, similar to UiO-66-NH2 obtained on a 200 mg scale by LAG procedure using a laboratory mixer mill (b, left).

Porosity Measurements

In addition to confirming crystallinity and topology, it is important to determine how the proposed mechanochemical procedures affect the MOF porosity. Zirconium MOFs are generally considered to be highly stable in aqueous environments, which is a basis for their potential application in remediation of chemical warfare agents and other pollutants. The surface area of UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, MOF-801, and MOF-804 samples, prepared by LAG with water and activated by a standard procedure, shows that the proposed laboratory mechanochemical LAG procedure did not influence significantly the porosity of prepared materials (). The measured Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) areas for samples of UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, MOF-801, and MOF-804 were 1145, 815, 540, and 755 m2/g, respectively ( and ). These results are consistent with the literature values for analogous materials synthesized solvothermally or by mechanochemical batch synthesis using LAG in the presence of MeOH additive. The hysteresis observed in the isotherm of the UiO-66 sample is most likely due to small particles (<100 nm diameter) which are compacted strongly (a), thus creating interparticle voids that may act like larger mesopores. UiO-66-NH2 prepared in a planetary mill on a 10 g scale with water additive displayed an excellent BET surface area (885 m2/g), while the sample made on a 100 g scale by TSE showed somewhat lower surface area (610 m2/g).

Charaterization of Porous Coordination Network (PCN)

Before gas adsorption measurement, 100 nm PCN-224 samples were thoroughly washed thrice with DMF and twice with acetone. After decanting acetone, samples were dried under vacuum for 3 h. Also, the dried powder was activated at 85 °C for 30 min and at 120 °C for 5 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for PCN-224 is 2296(8) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).

Results and Discussion

The crystal structure of PCN-224 has a she topology with Im3̅m space group that contains three-dimensional open channels with the size of 1.9 nm. As biocompatible Zr(IV) has strong interaction with the carboxylate linker, Zr nodes provide the framework robustness and thus ensure that the drug is delivered to cancer cells stably. In addition, the porphyrinic linker in the MOF framework allows efficient PDT without aggregation in the aqueous solution. PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized using a synthetic method described in a previous report. Synthesized PCN-224 nanoparticles were observed to have a spherical morphology with the diameter of 100 nm by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) (a,b). Nanoparticles of this size have a higher cellular uptake ability than that of other sizes. The structure of synthesized nanoparticles was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The experimental PXRD pattern of the MOF nanoparticles matches well with the simulated pattern (c) and still maintains crystallinity after HA coating, implying that the MOF structure remains during the synthesis process. The nanoMOF has a large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 2296(8) m2/g by N2 adsorption studies at 77K (d, S1a). This high surface area allow drug loading in large quantities, demonstrating the potential of the PCN-224 nanoparticles as a drug delivery carrier. We investigated the loading capacity of the hydrophobic Dox in nonmodified PCN-224 through physical entrapment. The drug encapsulation mechanism is caused by noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions, allowing PCN-224 to interact more effectively with the drug molecule. As shown in Figure S2, PCN-224 showed high loading capacity ability (108%, weight ratio between Dox and nanoMOFs). The porosity of Dox-PCN was confirmed by N2 adsorption. The BET surface area of Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. Although the surface area and pore size of Dox-PCN decrease, the porosity of Dox-PCN still remains after drug loading (Figure S1c).

To examine the thermal stability, TGA for the Zn-MOF was also performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere from 25 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C.min-1 (Figure S6). The TGA curve shows a weight loss of 29.0% up to about 320 °C, ascribed to the departure of two coordinated DMSO molecules. Upon further heating from 400 to 500 °C a weight loss of 45.0% was observed, which is consistent with the decomposition of the btca4- organic linkers and a collapse of the 3D structure. A residual weight of about 15% is attributed to the formation of ZnO.

Analytical Parameters and Performance

The emission spectra of the Zn-MOF sensor in the presence of various concentrations of cimetidine indicated an obvious enhancement in the emission intensity of the sensor. Upon the addition of cimetidine to the Zn-MOF suspension in the optimized experimental conditions, the fluorescence intensities gradually increased with drug concentrations (). The enhanced fluorescence intensity displayed two linear relationships at two concentration areas from 1.0 to 10.0 ng mL-1 and from 20.0 to 80.0 ng mL-1 (inset of ). The fitted linear equations would be expressed as F/F 0 = 0.0352 [Cimetidine] + 0.9611 (r 2 = 0.9922), F/F 0 = 0.012 [Cimetidine] + 1.1794 (r 2 = 0.9912), and the results show a good linear relationship.

Limit of detection (3Sd/K) was calculated based on the standard deviation (Sd) of 10 times measuring of F 0 and the slope (K) of the calibration graph. The limit of quantification (10Sd/K) was also evaluated by the above assumptions. The limit of detection (LOD) and limit of quantification (LOQ) is 0.31 and 1.05 ng mL-1. The precision is stated as the relative standard deviation (RSD) for two concentrations of cimetidine (7 and 60 ng mL-1). Their RSD were, respectively, obtained 4.1 and 3.2% for 10 replicate measurements.

Conclusions

In summary, a new zinc-tetracarboxylate MOF was synthesized via in situ ligand formation by the solvothermal reaction. The synthesized MOF reveals a three-dimensional structure with open rhomboidal channels. The channels were occupied by the guest solvent molecules. The compound acts as an effective room-temperature fluorescent sensor for selective and sensitive detection of cimetidine. The fluorescence response of the sensor was enhanced in the presence of various concentrations of cimetidine (on-mode). The phenomenon was investigated by FE-SEM, DLS, and EDX mapping analyses. Based on these findings, this luminescence turn-on sensor illustrates good sensitivity and selectivity over two linear ranges of 1.0-10.0 and 20.0-80.0 ng mL-1, respectively. The LOD and LOQ are calculated to be 0.31 and 1.05 ng mL-1, respectively. Further, the proposed sensor has been successfully conducted for cimetidine detection in the human plasma, urine, commercial ampule, and tablet. The applicability of the sensor was established using the obtained good recovery percentages. Considering the simplicity of the operation methodology, the current method is recommended to be applied for typical routine analysis. This work suggests a new strategy that may open a new level of interest in MOF-based sensors for on-site and real-time analytical detection of drugs in pharmaceutical factories and medical laboratories.
