In terms of gas adsorption, Rezaei et al. investigated the coating of MOF-74(Ni) and UTSA-16(Co) onto the surface of commercial cordierite and optimized the properties such as the crystal growth and film thickness to produce a monolith wrapped with 55 wt % MOFs (). The CO2 adsorption capacities of the coated MOF-74 and UTSA-16 were 1.7 and 1.1 mmol/g (1 bar), respectively, which were only 28% and 29% of the powder samples. Although the experiments demonstrated that the CO2 adsorption amount was essentially unabated after cycling, it was lower than expected, corresponding to the reduction in the BET surface area and pore volume (). Lawson et al. improved the coating technique using a Torlon polymer solution to preseed the MOF powder on the monolith, obtaining MOFs loading more than 70 wt %. The heat exchanger surface with aluminum fumarate MOF coating improves the cyclic hydrothermal stability owing to its good water adsorption properties. Jeremias et al. proposed an interesting route for HKUST-1 film fabrication, where the substrate for coating was immersed in the solution required for MOF synthesis that was actively cooled, while the substrate surface was heated to the temperature for MOF crystallization. This thermal gradient method enables MOF coatings with porosity, mechanical stability, and high thermal coupling that allows for applications in heat exchangers as well as in adsorption and catalysis. Their group also grew MOF films onto the carbon hollow fibers, and the CO2 adsorption capacity of MOF-74/carbon composite was 2 mmol/g (25 °C, 1 bar), which is comparable to that of the powders. Furthermore, the CO2 adsorption kinetics was evaluated using the adsorption response time, given that the composites had faster kinetics than the powders, with the UTSA-16 composite taking only 2.6 min to reach 90% of the adsorption capacity, while the powder took 4.1 min. Another coating process improved the cycling stability of the MOFs, maintaining an adsorption capacity at 10000 water adsorption and desorption cycles with no observed degradation of the adsorption capacity of 0.26 g/g, allowing CAU-10-H to show good performance in heat pump applications. 

Gel and Spongy Blocks

The formation of gel monolithic materials generally does not require pressure and binders, which can serve as precursors for MOFs films, and aerogels typically possess variable porosities and specific surface areas. The unconventional ZIF-8 gel material was derived by utilizing a high-concentration reaction, revealing that mechanical stimulation can lead to a reversible solution-gel conversion. Tian et al. followed a sol-gel synthesis process () to obtain a dense monomer under mild drying conditions, whereas powder was obtained when dried at higher temperatures or under a vacuum without any binders or pressure. The shaped HKUST-1 monolith has a methane capacity of 259 cm3 (standard temperature and pressure (STP)) cm-3 at 65 bar with a BET surface area of 1193 m2⋅g-1, making it the first qualifying adsorbent to meet the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) volumetric target for methane storage (263 cm3 (STP) cm-3), and it has a strong mechanical hardness. UiO-66 gels can also be converted to layered porous monomers as xerogels and aerogels, with surface areas and pore volumes (1459 m2⋅g-1, 2.09 cm3⋅g-1, and 1255 m2⋅g-1, 1.66 cm3⋅g-1, respectively) that far exceed that of UiO-66 powders. MIL-100(Fe) aerogel with a permanent porosity and pore volume was synthesized by Lohe et al. According to the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms, aerogels were obtained with a single-point BET surface area of 1618 m2⋅g-1, which is much higher than the powdered sample value of 1183 m2⋅g-1. It is clear from the pore size distribution that the aerogel has a relatively wide range of micropores and mesopores distribution, with the pore volume maximum at 1.3 nm. However, the mechanical strength was not discussed in the research, which is essential for practical applications such as adsorption and catalytic processes.

Kim et al. fabricated MIL-100(Fe) granules with a size of 1.18-1.70 mm by adding 10% silica sol as a binder. The adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77 K showed the BET surface area of 1619 m2/g for MIL-100(Fe) granule, which is about 90% of the powders without additional reduction. In addition, the MIL-100(Fe) granules had a better SF6 adsorption capacity, and the breakthrough time is 40 min faster at 1 bar than that of commercial zeolite 13X granules, which offers greater possibilities for practical industrial applications. Moreira et al. have used 1% graphite and 99% UiO-66 powder pressed into a tablet composite (), but the BET surface area was reduced by 22% compared to that of pristine UiO-66, which is unfavorable for the gas adsorption process. In most cases, the properties of MOFs with inorganic binders are retained (), but there is still a need for extensive research on the mechanical properties and stability performance of the composite monoliths.

Inspired by the earlier works of printing structural adsorbents, Thakkar et al. first applied 3D printing technology to MOFs shaping and successfully printed MOF-74(Ni) and UTSA-16(Co) monoliths (1.5 cm in height and 1.5 cm in diameter). The process of fabricating MOFs monoliths using 3D printing through direct ink writing is shown in , where bentonite clay and PVA were used as the binder and plasticizer, respectively. CO2 adsorption experiments showed that the working capacities of MOF-74(Ni) and UTSA-16(Co) monoliths were 4.0 and 3.0 mmol/g, respectively, corresponding to 5.7 and 3.5 mmol/g for the powder sample. The compressive strengths of the MOF-74(Ni) and UTSA-16(Co) blocks exhibited in the mechanical tests were approximately 0.48 and 0.56 MPa, respectively. Although the mechanical strengths are lower compared to that of the ceramic architecture obtained by 3D printing, typically showing strengths on the order of 1-5 MPa, they can also be applied well in adsorption devices. Lawson et al. systematically investigated the kinetics of 3D printed MOF-74(Ni) monolith by varying parameters such as feed velocity and adsorption time and pressure. It was demonstrated that the adsorption kinetics was affected by multiple factors, and the MOF-74(Ni) monolith showed the best separation performance of CO2/H2 at low CO concentration, high pressure, low feed velocity, and short adsorption time. Bible et al. printed acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS) metal and MOF (ZIF-8 and HKUST-1) composites using a commercial 3D printer, and the structure was retained even after immersion in water. The specific surface area of the mixture was close to the theoretically calculated specific surface area; therefore, it is reasonable that the N2 adsorption capacity was also preserved. However, the MOFs content was only 10%, and the authors proposed the necessity for improving the fabrication process to increase the MOFs content and improve the application efficiency. Another study also demonstrated the potential of 3D printed MOFs (ZIF-67) in organic dye removal applications, with an average removal rate of 97-98% for rhodamine B after 10 continuous degradation cycles. The differences in performance for 3D-printed MOFs do not merely relate to additives; they also depend heavily on the process conditions and structure of monoliths. Denayer's group printed ZIF-8 monoliths for the biobutanol recovery by layer-by-layer printing using 16.7 wt % bentonite and 16.7 wt % methylcellulose as an additive. The advanced selectivity of the block for butanol recovery was verified from dynamic breakthrough experiments.

The xylene adsorption characteristics of four different MIL-53 materials were initially probed using single-component/unary vapor adsorption isotherms at 323 K (). The step in the adsorption isotherms occurs at the transition between the NP and the LP structures. The transition pressure and the saturation capacity are different for each adsorbate and also differ between materials. MIL-53(Sc) demonstrated an essentially nonporous structure with no significant NP → LP transition, and the two xylene isotherms (mX and oX) collected for this material showed negligible adsorption (Figure S4, Supporting Information). MIL-53(Al) has the highest gravimetric oX saturation capacity (4.5 mmol/g) and the lowest transition pressure for oX uptake. MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-53(Ga) show the lowest transition pressures for pX adsorption, but the highest pX capacity is exhibited by MIL-53(Al). MIL-53(Fe) had the highest mX capacity at saturation but had the most difficulty in reaching the NP → LP transition. Even after the transition pressure was reached,  isotherm collection took an unusually long amount of time, indicating that the structure may not have fully reached the LP form. The EB capacity is consistently the lowest among all if the C8 isomers in all four materials.

Quantitative values of selectivity and capacity were obtained from the experimental data and are depicted in . A detailed listing of the obtained values is given in Table S9. The oX selectivity relative to all other components combined ("oX/All") of MIL-53(Al) is around 5, while MIL-53(Cr) gives a selectivity of 3, and MIL-53(Ga) leads to a selectivity of 2.5. There is no statistically significant difference between the oX/pX and the oX/mX selectivities of MIL-53(Al), the mean values of which were computed to be 5.2 and 5.1, respectively. This is in agreement with previous work on MIL-53(Al) that reports no relative pX and mX selection in this adsorbent from binary liquid-phase breakthrough experiments. However, MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-53(Ga) both show a significant mX/pX selectivity of around 1.4. The oX/EB selectivity in MIL-53(Cr) is 4.9, which is much less than MIL-53(Al), where it is around 8. In terms of overall capacities, MIL-53(Cr) (4.9 mmol/g) is similar to that of MIL-53(Al) (4.6 mmol/g). MIL-53(Ga) had the lowest overall capacity of 3.4 mmol/g. This is consistent with its smaller BET surface area even when accounting for the different framework densities of the MOFs due to their different metal centers (). In terms of the oX capacity, MIL-53(Al) had the highest value (3 mmol/g).

N2 adsorption analysis on the activated samples was performed at 77 K to study the porous property of JLU-Liu33. In Zhu's work, CH2Cl2 was used as exchanged solvent, which make the activated sample partly collapse and result in classical type-I N2 adsorption isotherm. By contrast, the PXRD pattern of the activated JLU-Liu33 indicates that the sample will not collapse after soaking in CH3CN for 2 days (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Meanwhile, the solvent molecules can almost be removed, which can be seen from the TGA data (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). Interestingly, as shown in , JLU-Liu33 exhibits an unusual adsorption property, which shows two steps in the adsorption branch of the isotherm. At low pressure, the material adsorbs a small amount of N2. To our surprise, up to a relative pressure of 0.06, the amount of N2 adsorption suddenly increases to a saturated uptake of 319 cm3 g-1. The desorption part of the isotherm do not trace the adsorption process, resulting in a large hysteresis loop. This peculiar phenomenon reveals that a breathing behavior happens in the process of N2 adsorption, giving rise to a significant increase in volume.

On the other side, JLU-Liu33L and JLU-Liu33H were also measured for N2 adsorption at 77 K. JLU-Liu33L exhibits three distinct steps, which are different from JLU-Liu33. It shows slight N2 uptake at low pressure. Up to a relative pressure of 0.12, the amount of N2 adsorption suddenly increases up to 110 cm3 g-1, which is much lower than that of JLU-Liu33. To our surprise, up to a relative pressure of 0.89, a second abrupt increase is observed. The maximum adsorption amount reaches to 290 cm3 g-1, which is similar to JLU-Liu33. By contrast, JLU-Liu33H does not show breathing behavior up to 1 atm. As revealed by the isotherms, the breathing behavior of JLU-Liu33 can be tuned by introducing Co ions into Zn4O clusters. In addition, to corroborate our hypothesis that the gate opening effect of the materials is caused by the removal of coordinated DMF, the crystal was soaked in CH3CN for 5 days to remove excess DMF. However, the Fourier transform infrared spectrum (FT-IR) of the sample still shows a resonance at 1665 cm-1, which can be attributed to the CO stretch of DMF (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). This confirmed that some coordinated DMF cannot be removed totally after solvent exchange. The amounts of C, H, and N of the materials after solvent exchange and N2 adsorption characterization are also performed (Table S4 in the Supporting Information). The result indicates that the remaining coordinated DMF will be shifted during the N2 adsorption measurement. Upon removal of DMF, a shift between two nets may happen and result in transformation of the framework, which was indicated by the shift of the peaks and the change of their intensity in the PXRD (see Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). In parallel work, Jaheon Kim's group also found that, upon removal and addition of coordinated DMF, the degree of interpenetration of the framework will be changed and the material shows a dynamic behavior upon N2 adsorption. Those exhaustive parallel studies largely support our proposed mechanism. Some examples of interpenetrated MOFs that exhibit a gate opening effect are also listed in Table S5 in the Supporting Information.

The CO2 adsorption properties at 195 K were carried out to further investigate the breathing performance. Similar to the N2 adsorption isotherm, JLU-Liu33 is also found to exhibit the breathing behavior upon CO2 (a). In the first step, the adsorption amount of CO2 is ~50 cm3 g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.04, then it reached up to 205 cm3 g-1 in the second step. Similarly, the desorption part of the isotherm does not coincide with the adsorption branch, resulting in a small hysteresis loop. As shown in b, JLU-Liu33L also exhibits a dynamic response to CO2 sorption, but it shows three distinct steps, which is consistent with its N2 adsorption isotherm. The gate opening pressures of JLU-Liu33L are P/P 0 = 0.02 and 0.3. However, JLU-Liu33H exhibits a highly reversible type-I isotherm, reaching a saturated uptake of 111 cm3 g-1, which is much lower than JLU-Liu33 and JLU-Liu33L (c). The analysis data indicates that the skeleton of JLU-Liu33H will not change during the gas sorption, but the frameworks of JLU-Liu33 and JLU-Liu33L come to phase transition, which make the pores in the materials expand during the process of adsorption.

In order to calculate the isosteric heat (Q st), the CO2 adsorption isotherm of the materials were examined at 273 and 298 K. The CO2 uptake at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar for JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H are 32 and 20 cm3 g-1, 48 and 32 cm3 g-1, and 61 and 39 cm3 g-1, respectively (see Figure S8 and Table S6 in the Supporting Information). Furthermore, at zero loading, the Q st of JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H are 33.9, 35.5, and 37.8 kJ mol-1, respectively (d). All these Q st values are impressive and exceed many MOFs with Lewis basic sites (LBSs), such as JLU-Liu20 and ZTF-1, similar to that of NH2-MIL-53(Al). Such high Q st values are attributed to the narrow pores, and this character may make a contribution to molecular sieving. The above analysis data fully indicates that the adsorption amount and isosteric enthalpy values of JLU-Liu33 for CO2 will be improved with the increasing amount of Co ions in the framework. Lots of parallel examples also confirmed the fact that Co ions could make a contribution to improving the capacity of CO2 adsorption. 

The CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 isotherms for the three compounds then were also measured at 273 and 298 K. The CH4 uptake at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar for JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H are 14 and 7 cm3 g-1, 25 and 13 cm3 g-1, and 17 and 8 cm3 g-1, respectively. The C2H6 uptake at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar for JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H are 41 and 33 cm3 g-1, 39 and 30 cm3 g-1, and 42 and 35 cm3 g-1, respectively. The C3H8 uptake at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar for JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H are 44 and 38 cm3 g-1, 42 and 31 cm3 g-1, and 43 and 31 cm3 g-1, respectively (see , as well as Figures S9 and S10 and Table S6 in the Supporting Information). The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption changed inconspicuously as the amount of Co2+ in the framework increased. Interestingly, only JLU-Liu33 shows breathing behavior upon C2H6, and its gate opening pressures are P/P 0 = 0.24 and 0.48 at 273 and 298 K, respectively (). On the other hand, all these materials show breathing behavior upon C3H8 adsorption, and the gate opening pressures of JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H are as follows: P/P 0 = 0.03 and 0.06; P/P 0 = 0.039 and 0.264; P/P 0 = 0.033 and 0.302 at 273 and 298 K, respectively (see , as well as Figures S10a and S10b). The above analyses also indicated that the gate opening pressures of JLU-Liu33 for C2H6 and C3H8 could be tuned through doping Co ions into the framework.

To evaluate the affinity of the interpenetrated MOFs for small molecules, the Q st of the series of JLU-Liu33 for small gases, which possess normal gas adsorption behavior (CH4 and C2H6) were calculated. The Q st of CH4 for JLU-Liu33, JLU-Liu33L, and JLU-Liu33H is 25.50, 24.05, and 26.90 kJ mol-1, respectively. The Q st of C2H6 for JLU-Liu33L and JLU-Liu33H is 36.2 and 34.6 kJ mol-1 (Figures S11 and S12 in the Supporting Information).

To test this hypothesis, the BET surface areas of MOF-5 powders with different exposure times to the two relative humidity levels were measured, as shown in Figure . In general, the changes to surface area vs exposure time & RH follow closely the trends seen for hydrogen uptake in Figure . Prior to exposure, the measured surface area was 2355 m2/g. For the RH = 45% samples, relatively small changes in SA are observed for exposure times up to 48 h. At 66 h the surface area then drops more precipitously to a value which is half (1217 m2/g) its initial maximum, which is again consistent with the changes observed to the isotherms in Figure a. [It is also evident that the pellets (discussed in more detail below) exhibit enhanced robustness to humidity; the pellets maintain higher BET surface areas compared to those of powders for the same exposure conditions. The surface area of the unexposed pellets (corresponding to t = 0 in Figure ) is slightly above that of the unexposed powders because the media is sourced from a different batch of MOF-5 material.] In contrast, for the RH = 61% samples the BET surface area decreases more rapidly, achieving a value of nearly zero (34 m2/g) after 66 h. The declining surface area for both RH values indicates that the porosity of the MOF-5 powders is continuously reduced upon exposure to humid conditions.

N2 absorption/desorption isotherms of ZnO@C550, ZnO@CC, and ZnO@CC/SSQDm are shown in c-e, which are typical type IV curves. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory was used to deduce the surface area of all of the samples, the pore size distributions of ZnO@C550 and ZnO@CC/SSQDm were determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method on account of their mixed macroporosity and mesoporosity, and density functional theory was employed to find the pore size distribution of the mesoporous ZnO@CC sample. ZnO@C550 has a BET surface area of 222 m2 g-1, with pore sizes distributed over around 49 and 545 nm and a pore volume of 0.352 m3 g-1. ZnO@CC has a BET surface area of 252 m2 g-1, a pore size below 20 nm, and a pore volume of 0.387 m3 g-1. ZnO@CC/SSQDm shows 231 m2 g-1, with pore sizes over around 41 and 576 nm and a pore volume of 0.366 m3 g-1. The enlarged surface area and pore volume of ZnO@CC and ZnO@CC/SSQDm indicates that the penetrated glucose in the pores larger than microsize has decomposed in hydrothermal and calcination treatment to become amorphous carbon, which contributes more pore area and volume. The total carbon contents of ZnO@C550, ZnO@CC, and ZnO@CC/SSQDm are 20, 17.4, and 14.3%, respectively, as shown in Figure S4. f displays the Raman spectra of ZnO@C550 and ZnO@CC/SSQDm. ZnO has optical phonons represented as A1, E1, 2E2, and 2B1, amongst which the A1 and E1 modes are polar modes active for both Raman and infrared, the E2 mode is nonpolar and only active for Raman, and the B1 mode is a silent mode. A1 and E1 modes split into longitudinal and transverse components, and the E2 mode comprises low-frequency phonons, E2(L), and high-frequency phonons, E2(H). The bands around 435 and 327 cm-1 (inset of f) are due to the E2(H) mode and multiphonon scattering consisting of predominant A1 and smaller E2 and E1 symmetry. The bands at 1340 and 1589 cm-1 are typical D and G modes of carbon materials, and the intensity ratio I D/I G is indicative of the fraction of the graphite structure. The I D/I G ratios of ZnO@CC/SSQDm and ZnO@C550 are 0.83 and 0.95, respectively, indicating that the degree of graphitization increases as glucose decomposes in ZnO@C550.

  displays the high-resolution XPS spectra of Ag, S, and Zn of ZnO@CC/SSQDm. The spectrum of Ag 3d in a shows characteristics typical of a metal. This spectrum contains two components: one at 368.3 eV for Ag 3d5/2 and the other at 374.3 eV for Ag 3d3/2; the difference in binding energy of 6 eV results from spin-orbital effects. The orbital spin of silver metal leads to the loss of features at the higher binding energy side of each component. The intensity of the S 2p spectrum, as shown in b, is considerably weaker than that for Ag. The S 2p spectrum is consistent with the presence of ZnS and a very small amount of S in the as-prepared composite, with the absence of Ag-S confirming that all the SSQDs have been reacted to Ag nanoparticles, in agreement with the Ag 3d XPS deconvolution and XRD analysis. The S 2p3/2 of ZnS is located at 161.7 eV and that of S is at 163.8 eV. The spin-orbit of S 2p results in 1.16 eV difference between S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2. In agreement, the Zn 2p spectrum, as shown in c, displays two 2p3/2 components at 1022.1 and 1021.9 eV pointing to Zn-O and Zn-S, respectively. The spin-orbital of Zn 2p results in a pair of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 with a difference of 23 eV in binding energy. The atomic ratio of S/Ag/Zn is 0.9:7.6:91.5 through the XPS survey of S 2p3/2, Ag 3d5/2, and Zn 2p3/2; see Figure S8. The small amount of ZnS in the composite, consistent with a sub-monolayer of ZnS on the ZnO surface, explains the absence of ZnS signals in the XRD patterns and the Raman spectra. Figure S9 shows the atom ratio of S/Ag/Zn is 2.9:7:90.1 in ZnO@CC/SSQDm; thus, the ratio of ZnS/ZnO increased from 1:90 to 1:30 when three times more SSQDs are added in the synthesis of ZnO@CC/SSQD3m. The Ag content is found to be lower than that in ZnO@CC/SSQDm, indicating the Ag particles aggregate during the sulfidation reaction, consistent with the EDX mapping.

Structural Studies of the New Phase CYCU-3'

As mentioned before, to further clarify the nature of the isolated CYCU-3' x_50 materials, we modeled the CYCU-3' 50_50 structure by CRED. For this purpose, the images of the CYCU-3' 50_50 material were obtained using a transmission electron microscope, and the ED data of a selected area were recorded. The crystals have long ribbon-like morphology (Figure S3), as previously observed in the corresponding SEM images (Figure S2). The 3D reciprocal lattice of CYCU-3' 50_50 was reconstructed from the ED frames (Figure S4) and used for the determination of the unit cell parameters (a = 16.35 Å, b = 62.15 Å, c = 6.73 Å, α = 89.7°, β = 94.5°, and γ = 88.1°). These values showed some differences, particularly in the a-axis and β angle, in comparison to those of pristine CYCU-3 (a = 34.067 Å, b = 60.07 Å, c = 6.312 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 90.0°, and γ = 90.0°), which may suggest that CYCU-3' 50_50 is a new structure of the original MOF. Unfortunately, the CYCU-3' 50_50 structure is disordered along the b axis, as severe diffraction streaks along this direction were observed in the reconstructed 3D reciprocal lattice (Figure S4). Thus, this disorder, together with the flexible behavior of the crystals (bending, twisting, and coiling) (Figure S4a-c), avoids a direct structure solution using the CRED data. For this reason, the Pawley fit was applied to the PXRD data to confirm and refine the unit cell parameters (Figure S5). The refinement was conducted using a Pearson VII-type peak profile function, followed by the refinement of the unit cells and zero-shift. The R-value was converged to R p = 0.110, R wp = 0.0634, R exp = 0.267, and goodness of fit (GOF) = 0.237. The high R exp and low GOF values are due to the broad peaks caused by the disorder and preferred orientation. The new refined unit cell parameters (a = 16.971 Å, b = 64.039 Å, c = 6.694 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 94.447°, and γ = 90°) confirmed that CYCU-3' 50_50 changes to a new structure. On the basis of these data, an average structural model for CYCU-3' 50_50 was built (Figure S6). The crystal structure is based on the corner-shared AlO6 octahedra, leading to 1D chains, as in CYCU-3. However, there are more Al chains in the unit cell of CYCU-3' 50_50 than in CYCU-3, as the a axis of the former is halved (a = 16.35 and 34.067 Å, respectively). As a consequence, the CYCU-3' 50_50 framework is 61% more dense than pristine CYCU-3 (0.731 and 0.453 g/cm-3, respectively), resulting in a material with a lower Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (see the preparation of hybrid materials for more details). In addition, the new CYCU-3' 50_50 structure has 1D channels that represent the small pores of CYCU-3. On the other hand, the disordered nature of the CYCU-3' 50_50 crystals (Figure S4) could be caused by the coordination of acetate instead of the SDC ligands to the Al centers, not only in the crystal surface but also in the inner structure, creating defects (a). This hypothesis is further supported by the elemental analysis, in which a high acetate/SDC ratio of 1.63 was found. To confirm the structural model, ED pattern simulation was applied (b). The experimental ED pattern of CYCU-3' 50_50 (b-I) was compared with the CYCU-3' 50_50 average model (b-III) and the simulated ED pattern of CYCU-3 (b-II, generated from the previously reported CYCU-3 structure). Extra diffraction rows are observed in b-I, which agrees well with the pattern from the CYCU-3' 50_50 average model (b-II), whereas the simulated ED pattern of CYCU-3 lacks these rows (b-III). This suggests that the proposed model of CYCU-3' 50_50 is correct, and it is of a different phase from the original CYCU-3. However, the high degree of disorder found in CYCU-3' 50_50 may be caused by the previously mentioned ligand defects and/or by the missing AlO6 chains.

Afterward, the matrixes were activated (150 °C under vacuum for 24 h), and the TGA measurements of the desolvated materials were recorded, confirming that, in all cases, the CYCU-3 materials were free of ligands and/or solvent molecules, as no mass loss was observed up to ~350 °C (Figure S7). Regarding thermal stability, the decomposition temperature increases with particle size (ca. 351, 408, and 473 °C for CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3' 50_50, respectively). In addition, we evaluated the permanent porosity of these materials by measuring the nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure S8). In all cases, the isotherm profiles were characteristic of the materials with both micro- and mesopores. Besides, CYCU-3 20_0 and CYCU-3 50_5 exhibited a similar BET surface areas (2225 and 2270 m2 g-1, respectively) than that previously reported for pristine CYCU-3 (2760 m2 g-1), whereas the adsorption capacity of CYCU-3' 50_50 was markedly lower (265 m2 g-1), probably because of its more dense framework compared to that of pristine CYCU-3 (see the structural studies for more details). The pore size distribution of the different porous frameworks was also determined (Figure S9).

Evaluation of ALF794@CYCU-3 Hybrid Materials as Potential CORMAs

To test the potential biological application as CORMAs of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50, their photoinduced CO release properties were first investigated in solution (10 mM PBS, 37 °C) by UV-vis spectroscopy using the myoglobin assay. Although both the hybrid materials released appreciable amounts of CO (0.46 and 0.24 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM, respectively, upon 24 h of irradiation with visible light, Figure S12), molybdenum leaching was also detected (94 and 25%, respectively, after 6 h of incubation with no further leaching in the next 72 h) (Table S1). The high extent of metal leaching from ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 might be attributed to its smaller particle size, which unfortunately leads to a high degradation of the framework in PBS. In contrast, ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 shows a significantly lower metal leaching (25% of Mo) related to its less porous structure and larger particle size. Taking into account the latter fact, ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 is the only hybrid material that can be considered as a real CORMA in solution.

To further explore the ability of these hybrid systems as CORMAs, we decided to study their CO delivery properties in the solid state, envisaging their potential use for topical applications (i.e., anti-inflammatory bandages). In this context, the previously reported innovative application of photoactive CORMs for topical treatment of epidermal cancer should be highlighted. Indeed, CORM-2, [Ru2Cl4(CO)6], lotions were shown to reduce the acute and chronic inflammation and tumor multiplicity in hairless mice with induced photocarcinogenesis. Thus, an in-line CO detector was customized to measure the CO released from the ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 solid matrixes (Figure S13). In particular, both hybrid materials were spin-coated and irradiated at 250-385 nm with 50 mW cm-2 of light power to promote the CO release. The delivered CO was transferred using N2 as the carrier gas to the in-line detector. The CO release efficiencies of the ALF794-loaded materials were compared to that of free CORM (). Thus, pristine ALF794 behaves also as a photoCORM in the solid state, releasing 0.42 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM after 220 min (photo-releasing efficiency: 42%). In addition, both hybrid materials retain the photoactive properties of the molybdenum tricarbonyl complex, showing an average CO delivery of 0.44 and 0.35 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM (44 and 35% of CO release efficiency) for ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50, respectively.

Given the exceptional specific surface area, geometry, and periodic porosity, transition-metal sulfides derived from crystalline metal-organic frameworks have spurred great interest in energy storage systems. Herein, employing a different sulfurization process, well-aligned NiCo2S4 and CoS2 nanoarrays with a hollow/porous configuration derived from pentagon-like ZIF-67 are successfully designed and constructed on Ni foam. The hollow/porous structure grown on a conductive matrix can significantly improve electroactive sites, shorten charge/ion diffusion length, and enhance mass/electron transfer. Consequently, the obtained NiCo2S4 possesses an excellent specific capacitance of 939 C/g, a fast charge/discharge rate, and a favorable life span. An advanced asymmetrical supercapacitor is fabricated by engaging NiCo2S4 and CoS2 as cathode and anode materials, respectively, with a well-separated potential window. The obtained device delivers an exceptional energy density of 55.8 W h/kg at 695.2 W/kg, which is highly considerable to the recent transition metal sulfide-based devices. This facile tactic could be employed to construct other electrode materials with superior electrochemical properties.

 a discloses the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared NiCo2S4, NiCo-LDHs, and ZIF-67. The three strong peaks situated at 44.3, 51.7, and 76.4° could be ascribed to the metallic nickel substrate (JCPDS card no. 65-2865). Besides the peaks originating from the nickel substrate, a series of peaks of ZIF-67 are observed. After the crystallization process between ZIF-67 and Ni(NO3)2, the typical peaks of ZIF-67 vanish for the as-prepared products with the emergence of a series of new peaks, pointing the change of crystal structure for ZIF-67. After the sulfurization process, a series of peaks emerge at 16.1, 22, 31.8, 38.2, 47.2, and 55°, which coincide well with the (111), (220), (400), (422), (511), and (440) planes, signifying the formation of NiCo2S4. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum of these three electrodes is illustrated in b, and the peaks between 600 and 1500 cm-1 are attributed to the imidazole ring in ZIF-67. Moreover, the peak located at 2929 cm-1 is ascribed to the aromatic nucleus in 2-methylimidazole, which confirms the successful preparation of ZIF-67. After the sulfurization treatment, the typical peaks disappear for the as-prepared products, which further confirm the successful change of crystal structure. Nitrogen isothermal adsorption/desorption test is implemented to analyze the textural properties of NiCo2S4. A model of IV isotherm and H3 hysteresis loop can be seen from c. The hysteresis at a relatively higher pressure (P/P 0 > 0.4) reveals the typical characteristic of the mesoporous structure. Furthermore, the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda curve further manifests the existence of the mesoporous structure (d). Besides, the specific surface area of NiCo2S4 is estimated to be 79.3 m2/g. The unique hollow/mesoporous structure could provide continuous ion diffusion pathways.

 c indicates the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) profiles of NiCo2S4 at different current densities. The obvious potential platform further confirms the subscription from the Faradaic redox process. Besides, these curves are substantially symmetrical, which reflects that NiCo2S4 possesses a favorable reversibility. Furthermore, Figure S1 shows the CV profiles of ZIF-67, NiCo-LDHs, and NiCo2S4 at the same scan rate, and it shows that NiCo2S4 possesses a much enhanced capacitance with respect to the other samples. Such a notably enhanced electrochemical performance is also proved through the GCD profiles. For comparison, the specific capacitances of these three products against different current densities are plotted in d. The NiCo2S4 electrode exhibits a superior specific capacitance of 939 C/g at 1 A/g and still retains 712 C/g at 10 A/g (about 75.8% capacitance retention). Besides, NiCo2S4 possesses a high areal capacitance of 2.5 C/cm2 at 1 mA/cm2 (e). Obviously, the specific capacitance and areal capacitance of NiCo2S4 are quite competitive to that of the previously recorded NiCo2S4-based composites in  and Table S1. Such a superior electrochemical behavior benefits from their desirable porous/hollow nanostructures. In particular, the inner hollow configuration and the mesoporous structure could offer more reactive sites and larger electrode/electrolyte interfaces.

In addition, the unique structure also performs well in promoting the transport of ions/electrons. As confirmed in f, the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) values of ZIF-67, NiCo-LDHs, and NiCo2S4 are 0.38, 1.09, and 0.12 Ω, respectively, which imply that NiCo2S4 possesses an enhanced conductivity and a rapid charge transfer. In addition, the internal resistance values of each of them are 0.58, 0.56, and 0.37 Ω, respectively. To validate the cycling stability of NiCo2S4, continuous GCD tests are investigated at a current density of 10 A/g (Figure S2). An outstanding life span has been manifested by NiCo2S4, that is, only 7.2% capacitance decay is witnessed after 5000 consecutive cycles. The excellent cycling stability might be attributed to the void space that figures as an ion-buffering reservoir for the electrolyte ions, shortening the ion/electron diffusion path and buffering the structural expansion and contraction during the charge/discharge cycles.

The electrochemical properties of CoS2 are shown in . The CV profiles at various scan rates reveal distinct redox peaks, reflecting its characteristic pseudocapacitive feature (a). The pseudocapacitance originates from the electron transfer course among the Co2+/Co3+/Co4+ redox couples. The relatively symmetrical GCD curves demonstrate a relatively high Coulombic efficiency by reason of the high reversibility of the Faradaic redox process during the charge/discharge course (b). The maximum specific capacitance calculated from the GCD plots is 343.5 C/g at 1 A/g. In addition, it possesses 146.3 C/g at 20 A/g with a superior rate capacity of 45.2% (c), and the areal capacitances of CoS2 at various current densities are displayed in Figure S5. From the Nyquist plots in d, the intersection at real axis indicates a low internal resistance. Besides, the small semidiameter at the high-frequency region demonstrates the facile charge-transfer process at the electrode/electrolyte interface.

Nonlinear GCD profiles further confirm the subscription from the Faradaic redox process (c). The maximum specific capacity achieved with this device is 287 C/g at 1 A/g. The correlation between the critical parameters, energy and power density, is depicted in d. Remarkably, the highest energy density of the obtained device could reach up to 55.8 W h/kg at a power density of 695.2 W/kg; even at an ultrahigh power density of 6788.6 W/kg, the energy density could still be maintained at 23.8 W h/kg. The activity of our devices is fairly considerable to the recently reported TMS-based devices, such as NiCo2S4@Ni3V2O8//AC, NiCo2S4/CT//AC, NiCo2S4//AC, NiCo2S4@CNFs//AC@pCNFs, NiCo2S4@Co(OH)2, NiCo2S4/Co9S8//AC, NiCo2S4//AC, and NiCo2S4@NiO//AC, indicating the excellent pseudocapacitive properties of NiCo2S4 and CoS2.

Moreover,  illustrates the capacitance retention of the asymmetrical device upon operating consecutive GCD cycles. More interestingly, an approving capacitance retention behavior of 91.9% over 5000 consecutive cycles at 10 A/g is witnessed. The feature of NiCo2S4 and CoS2 after the cycling test is further investigated (Figure S6). Obviously, the nanoarrays and pentagon-like morphology of NiCo2S4 and CoS2 are well-preserved even after cycling. The excellent cycling behavior of the asymmetrical supercapacitor NiCo2S4//CoS2 reveals that the electrode materials can maintain good mechanical integrality and high electrochemical stability.

Conclusions

In summary, the pentagon-like ZIF-67 nanoarrays have been directly assembled on Ni foam, and via different sulfurized treatments, they can be transformed into NiCo2S4 and CoS2, suitable as a cathode and an anode, respectively, in an advanced asymmetrical supercapacitor. Owing to the highly hollow/porous configuration and their direct contact with a conductive matrix, the obtained NiCo2S4 delivers a superior specific capacity of 939 C/g, which is quite competitive to that of the previously recorded NiCo2S4-based composites. The asymmetrical supercapacitor achieved by NiCo2S4 and CoS2 shows a favorable energy density of 55.8 W h/kg. Therefore, this versatile method to prepare TMS-based materials would open up vast opportunities for energy storage applications.

A key challenge in the field of electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction is the design of catalytic materials featuring high product selectivity, stability, and a composition of earth-abundant elements. In this work, we introduce thin films of nanosized metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as atomically defined and nanoscopic materials that function as catalysts for the efficient and selective reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide in aqueous electrolytes. Detailed examination of a cobalt-porphyrin MOF, Al2(OH)2TCPP-Co (TCPP-H2 = 4,4',4",4‴-(porphyrin-5,10,15,20-tetrayl)tetrabenzoate) revealed a selectivity for CO production in excess of 76% and stability over 7 h with a per-site turnover number (TON) of 1400. In situ spectroelectrochemical measurements provided insights into the cobalt oxidation state during the course of reaction and showed that the majority of catalytic centers in this MOF are redox-accessible where Co(II) is reduced to Co(I) during catalysis.

Balancing reactant diffusion and charge transport is essential for electrochemical catalysis. To this end, the thickness of the MOF catalyst film was tuned to optimize the performance of the MOF catalyst by varying the starting ALD alumina layer thickness from 0.5 to 10 nm (D). Upon testing a carbon disk electrode with only 5 layers (0.5 nm) of ALD precursor converted to the MOF, resulting in an ~10 nm thick MOF layer, we observed a twofold increase in the catalytic current density (measured at -0.57 V vs RHE at a sweep rate of 100 mV/s) relative to that of the bare carbon disk substrate. The performance of the MOF catalyst increased with increasing active-site loading until reaching a maximum at 50 ALD cycles (MOF thickness of ~30-70 nm). Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission absorption (ICP-AES) was utilized to quantify the total cobalt loading on this sample and indicated an upper limit of 6.1 × 1016 cobalt atoms (1.1 × 10-7 mol) per square centimeter. The performance decrease observed for higher active-site loading is likely due to charge-transport limitations from the electrode to the MOF periphery or impedance through a thin insulating alumina layer not fully converted to the MOF. This result highlights the strength of our ALD-based MOF conversion technique, which allows nanometer precision of catalyst loading to balance active-site density with mass/charge transfer.

Comprehensive product analysis using gas chromatography (GC) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was carried out to reveal the nature of the chemical processes occurring within our MOF catalysts (Figure S7). As illustrated in E, the two main products measured were CO and H2, with current selectivity for CO reaching up to 76% at -0.7 V vs RHE. The average steady-state current density from these measurements is displayed in F. In contrast, the unmetalated MOF produces primarily H2 (Figure S8). When plotting the partial current density for CO production on a logarithmic scale versus the thermodynamic overpotential (G), we obtain a Tafel slope of 165 mV/decade in the low-overpotential region, which points to a one-electron reduction of CO2 to form the CO2 ⋅ radical as a probable rate-limiting step, though the reaction is likely to be at least in part diffusion-limited. However, the exact nature of the rate-limiting step is difficult to determine from the Tafel slope alone, especially in a more complicated system such as ours. For comparison, studies of porphyrin homogeneous catalysts have measured Tafel slopes ranging from 100 to 300 mV/decade; thus, the rate-limiting step and mechanism may depend on more than just the active site itself. We stress that this is the first incarnation of our MOF electrocatalyst, and efforts are being undertaken to further exploit the modular nature of such systems for the next generation of catalyst.

The stability of the MOF catalyst was next tested over an extended period of time. In controlled potential electrolysis at -0.7 V vs RHE in CO2-saturated aqueous bicarbonate buffer, the current density reached a stable state after several minutes and subsequently showed no sign of decrease for up to 7 h, generating 16 mL of CO (0.71 mmol, 5.25 cm2 substrate; A, S8, and S9). The lower limit of the TON of the MOF catalyst is quantified through ICP analysis of the electrode after testing and is determined to be 1400 assuming every cobalt atom is an electrochemically active site (turnover frequency (TOF) ~ 200 h-1). The MOF largely retains its crystallinity after electrolysis, and preservation of the framework was evidenced through the retention of the major powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) peaks (B). Furthermore, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis reveals that the platelike morphology has been retained (C,D). In situ surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) was utilized to confirm the integrity of the organic units throughout the catalytic process (Figure S11). At each applied potential, the primary SERS peaks attributed to the porphyrin linker remain in the SERS spectrum.

As mentioned, one strategy for incorporating defects into the MOF structure is by modulating stoichiometric ratios of linker and metal node components to achieve specific metal node coordination environments. For example, a recent report demonstrated the use of in situ spectroelectrochemical and electroanalytical techniques to interrogate the influence of defect sites within the Ni-MOF-74 structure on a model electrochemical hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA). In situ Raman and attenuated total reflectance infrared (ATR-IR) spectroelectrochemical techniques showed that defects in the Ni-MOF-74 structure were systematically incorporated by modulating the ratio of linkers containing the absence of free hydroxyl functionalities capable of binding to nearby Ni sites. Additionally, ex situ spectroscopic techniques were able to identify signals corresponding to the presence of highly electron dense NiO4 defect sites in XPS, while Raman spectroscopic measurements were able to further corroborate this by identifying shifts in the Ni-O bands. The defect-rich Ni-MOF-74 converted HMF to FDCA at a 95% yield with an 80% Faradaic efficiency. Moreover, the difference in the Tafel slopes for HMF oxidation between the defect-rich Ni-MOF-74 (160 mV/decade) and defect-free Ni-MOF-74 (300 mV/decade) reveals the influence of Ni coordination defects on the electrocatalytic activity of the defective material. Here, the systematic integration of defect sites enabled investigations into the reaction mechanism, which showed that an adsorbed *OH could abstract protons from adsorbed HMF intermediates on adjacent exposed Ni nodes and push the reaction toward FDCA formation. While this indicates that defective Ni-MOF-74 shows promise as a viable electrocatalyst for HMF oxidation to FDCA, additional investigations should focus toward maintaining a similar level of performance under larger, more industrially relevant current densities than those reported here (~1-20 mA/cm2).

Defects can also be produced post-synthetically, as exemplified in a report that showed that photoirradiation of a bimetallic NiFe node MOF (with 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid ligands) can induce lattice strain and systematically increase the fringe lattice parameter from 1.16 nm in the pristine MOF to 1.18, 1.20, and 1.21 nm. The lattice-strained NiFe MOF demonstrated specific activities of 500 A/gmetal at a half-wave potential of 0.83 V for the ORR, which outperformed the benchmark Pt/C specific activity of 262 A/gmetal at 0.83 V. Similarly, the lattice-strained MOF demonstrated a 2000 A/gmetal at 0.30 V overpotential for the OER, which outperformed benchmark RuO2 OER catalysts by 2 orders of magnitude (~17 A/gmetal at 300 mV overpotential). Notably, the electrocatalytic OER and ORR experiments showed stable current densities of 200 mA/cm2 and -100 mA/cm2 with near unity Faradaic efficiencies for both reactions across an operational lifetime of 200 h. The corresponding benchmark materials (RuO2 for OER and Pt/C for ORR) both showed a 50% decrease in current density over the same operational lifetime, indicating that the strain-defect-containing MOFs exhibit both increased activity and stability over corresponding benchmark materials. The increase in electrocatalytic performance of the defect-strained MOFs was suggested to derive from the strain-induced Ni 3d-O 2p hybridization in the valence band, which promoted electron transfer from the N 3d band into the O 2p band and enabled favorable binding of oxo species to more electron-deficient Ni sites. Mechanistic insights using synchrotron radiation Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy showed a band at ~1050 cm-1 that was observed for both ORR and OER applications, which the authors assigned to adsorbed superoxide *OOH intermediate present in both OER and ORR proposed mechanisms.

While MOFs can be used and manipulated as electrocatalysts, similar tunings in electrocatalyst performance can be achieved by using a MOF as a non-catalytic layered component over a more traditional electrocatalyst. A proof-of-concept example of this process incorporated thin layers of UiO-66(Zr) MOFs over Ag electrocatalyst surfaces for CO2 reduction. UiO-66-layered Ag electrodes showed an improved Faradaic efficiency for CO production (FECO = 79%) compared to the bare Ag electrode (FECO = 43%) at -0.8 V vs RHE, despite similarities in the electrochemically active surface area between the two electrodes. These results suggested that the MOF overlayer could enhance the CO2 reduction activity through three mechanistic routes: (i) enhancing CO2 reduction activities by increasing local CO2 concentrations via increased mass transfer through MOF pores, (ii) second coordination sphere hydrogen-bonding stabilization between MOF acid sites and adsorbed *COO- intermediates, and (iii) ion functionalization for controllable proton delivery. To decouple the effects of second coordination sphere acid site stabilization from the effects of mass transport, OH groups on Zr6O4(OH)4 node components were titrated using benzoic acid. This modified overlayer showed a decrease in FECO to ~60%, suggesting that, while limiting mass transport can improve the FECO of the MOF-overlayered Ag electrodes, the additional effect of proton stabilization for pendant OH groups on Lewis acid sites can further stabilize CO2 reduction intermediates. Further enhancements were achieved through the incorporation of 3-(carboxypropyl)trimethylammonium (TMA) into the MOF overlayer backbone, resulting in a semipermeable ion-selective membrane that showed an improved FECO (90%) compared to the non-functionalized MOF membrane at 79% and the bare Ag electrode at 49%. This utilization and systematic evaluation of UiO-66(Zr) as a model overlayer to enhance electrochemical CO2 reduction demonstrates the utility of MOFs as tandem materials that can indirectly enhance catalysis on catalytically active surfaces; however, the translational utility of this strategy will require a demonstration of electrocatalytic activity at partial current densities above ~-1.0 mA/cm2.

This difference in H content points toward the major chemical difference between Ca- and KPHI: the proportion of cations remaining after aqueous workup. Indicators of cation-complexed imides (e.g., IR peak near 1000 cm-1 and 13C chemical shift at 168 ppm) were much stronger for KPHI than for CaPHI. XPS quantification showed cation:N ratios of 0.64 for KPHI but only 0.02 for CaPHI. This discrepancy is much too large to be explained by charge-balance alone, so a large proportion of the imide-complexed Ca2+ cations were likely displaced by protons during water washing. Additionally, as XPS is a surface sensitive technique, the cation concentration in the top few nanometers of the PHI particles could have been much smaller than the bulk. To more closely investigate the cation content of the bulk PHI frameworks, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was employed, and the results are summarized in SI Table S2. These studies suggested that KPHI exhibited around 17 wt % K+, implying a charge-balanced structural formula close to (C12N17)3K6H3. On the other hand, CaPHI exhibited only 6.4 wt % Ca2+, suggesting a formula of (C12N17)3Ca2H5. This difference in extent of proton exchange could have been caused by changes in the pH of the washing solution upon salt removal or slight changes in the pK a of the resulting polymeric backbones. Further investigation of the acid-base characteristics of these PHI materials was achieved via potentiometric titration experiments, and discussion can be found in the SI.

These differences in crystal structure, despite chemical similarity of the backbone, are likely related to the difference in ionic radius (152 pm for K+ vs 114 pm for Ca2+), more than doubled charge to radius ratio, valence, and resulting Lewis acidity of the framework-complexed cations. While K+ ions interact predominantly with a single layer of the sheet-like PHI, the much more polarizing Ca2+ ions interact with as many as three PHI sheets, acting as bridging moieties. This heightened interaction of the Ca2+ sites with Lewis base sites on neighboring PHI sheets is present during structure assembly. To accommodate this difference in the templating cation, the crystal structure flexes in the ab plane and expands slightly along the c-axis as evident by the shift of the 002 peak in b from ~28.3° to ~27.9°, corresponding to d-spacings of 3.14 and 3.19 Å in H+/KPHI to H+/CaPHI, respectively. Scherrer analysis on this 002 reflection of the synthesized H+/CaPHI and H+/KPHI indicated comparable average crystallite sizes of 8.7 and 11.4 nm, respectively, along the c-axis (SI Table S3). This disrupting in the planar crystal structure of CaPHI compared to KPHI might be the cause of the loss of crystallinity upon exchange of K+ with Ca2+ previously observed by Savateev et al.; once the sheets stack in a planar fashion, they likely cannot easily flex to accommodate Ca2+. However, despite the apparent disruption in planarity of the PHI sheets, the CaPHI structure exhibits a similar stacking motif to the previously studied KPHI, where heptazine units align along the c-axis to form an ordered pore channel filled with the templating cation, Ca2+. This feature of the PHI family is in stark contrast to most allotropes of carbon nitride, such as the popular graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4). The fully condensed g-C3N4 differs from PHI materials in that there are no bridging amines between heptazine monomers, resulting in an AB stacking motif and an absence of ordered pore channels.

The optoelectronic properties of these two different carbon nitride allotropes varied significantly as a result of the altered crystalline structure and morphology. The band structure (d) of CaPHI, KPHI, and H+-exchanged counterparts was quantified with diffuse reflectance UV-vis spectroscopy (DRUV-vis) (a) and ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) (c). In contrast to KPHI and H+/KPHI, which show relatively sharp absorption onsets near 450 nm, CaPHI and H+/CaPHI exhibit at least two different electronic transitions. Further insight was extracted from DRUV-vis data by employing analysis proposed by V. Kumar et al. to quantify the band gaps in these PHI materials (b). The measured optical band gaps for KPHI and H+/KPHI were 2.72 and 2.93 eV, respectively. CaPHI and H+/CaPHI, alternatively, showed comparatively larger band gaps of 2.82 and 3.07 eV. In each case, ion exchange of the frameworks led to ~0.2 eV increase in the observable band gaps. This primary transition was associated with the π-π* transition in the conjugate heptazine moiety as previously observed by Sahoo, Kühne et al. Additionally the Ca2+-derived materials showed evidence of additional electronic transitions of 2.21 eV for CaPHI and 2.43 eV for H+/CaPHI that are likely associated with additional n-π* transitions involving the lone pair of pyridinic N atoms, accessible due to the corrugation of the PHI sheets. Similar states residing within the bandgap were observed to a lesser extent for KPHI by Savateev et al. associated with slight disorder and flexibility in the planar arrangement that allowed for out-of-plane conformations. While DRUV-vis data here shows a slight indication of these intraband states for KPHI (e.g., small absorption onset near 600 nm), these transitions were not as prevalent as in CaPHI or H+/CaPHI and seem to be totally absent in H+/KPHI. With UPS, the valence band positions of these PHI materials were also estimated (c). KPHI and H+/KPHI showed an onset of photoelectron emission at 2.79 and 3.12 eV, and CaPHI and H+/CaPHI exhibited valence positions around 4.84 and 4.64 eV, respectively. Further confirmation of n-π* transitions in CaPHI and H+/CaPHI is evident in the UPS data, with gradual onsets occurring at energies around 3.4 eV. Combined with the extracted optical band gaps, the information on the valence band positions allowed an estimation of the band structure of the PHI class of materials (d). This relative comparison of the optoelectronic structure between the various allotropes of PHI frameworks demonstrates that despite similar polymeric backbone, the corrugated and compressed crystalline structure associated with Ca2+-templating shifted the bands of CaPHI and H+/CaPHI toward more oxidizing positions than the more planar KPHI structure.

Textural properties of the various synthesized carbon nitride framework materials were quantified with N2 porosimetry. All of KPHI, CaPHI, and their proton-exchanged analogues exhibited a convolution of Type I and Type IV isotherm shapes with H4 hysteresis (a), indicating a hierarchical pore structure composed of both micro- and mesopores. After proper point selection, BET analysis (SI Figure S5) revealed that, despite similar average primary crystallite sizes, the surface area of CaPHI (43.5 m2 g-1) was more than three times smaller than the surface area of KPHI (152 m2 g-1). These differences therefore likely stem from differences in the secondary particle size, as larger particles would be associated with a smaller external N2-accessible surface area. As visible in the extracted pore size distributions in b,c, these cation-complexed frameworks exhibited near negligible microporosity (<0.01 cc g-1), and most of the surface area was composed of mesopores larger than 4 nm, likely due to stacking faults between the primary nanocrystals that comprised the micron-sized particles. However, upon removal of Ca2+ or K+ via washing with acid, the interior pore channels of these frameworks were accessible for N2 adsorption, and the BET surface area increased to 264 m2 g-1 and 334 m2 g-1 for H+/CaPHI and H+/KPHI, respectively. Pore size distributions (b) revealed that a considerable amount of microporosity was generated in both PHI allotropes after acid washing. As evident in c, H+/CaPHI exhibited almost twice as much ultramicroporosity as H+/KPHI, with nearly 0.04 cc g-1 of pores with width less than 0.7 nm. This increase in volume of these narrow pores has been shown to be critical for enhanced low-pressure CO2 uptake and was likely associated with the altered crystalline structure of H+/CaPHI as compared to H+/KPHI. On the other hand, H+/KPHI exhibited more than 0.12 cc/g of micropores (<2 nm), with most having a width of 1 nm. In addition to this increase in micropore volume and BET surface area, proton exchange was also associated with a large increase in volume of larger mesopores (>4 nm) for both allotropes, with the total measured porosity of H+/CaPHI exceeding 0.5 cc g-1. Overall, while the cation-complexed frameworks exhibited moderate external surface areas stemming from the secondary particle agglomerations, acid-washed counterparts H+/CaPHI and H+/KPHI showed that the cation exchange for much smaller protons allowed N2 to access at least a portion of the inner porosity of the ordered pore channels formed by the stacked PHI sheets.

While the adsorption saturation capacities between the two carbon nitride frameworks were very different, the energetics of adsorption were more comparable, which is indicative of similar modes of adsorption likely due to the analogous composition and surface chemistry of the two PHI materials. For ΔH ads,i  in both H+/CaPHI and H+/KPHI, the primary site exhibited an enhancement of nearly 15 kJ mol-1 as compared to the secondary site, which helps to explain the order of magnitude difference in the pressure-response between these two sites. Despite this similarity between the materials, H+/CaPHI did however exhibit about 5 kJ mol-1 increase in affinity for CO2 compared to H+/KPHI. For H+/CaPHI and H+/KPHI, the extracted ΔH ads,A  in the primary sites were -42.2 kJ mol-1 and -38.3 kJ mol-1; in the weaker site, the ΔH ads,B were -28.6 and -23.7 kJ mol-1, respectively. The magnitudes for ΔH ads,A, while smaller than those typically encountered for chemisorptive mechanisms (>80 kJ mol-1), were much larger than commonly measured for conventional physisorption which operates by pore filling alone (~25 kJ mol-1). Extracted ΔH ads,B  values, on the other hand, fall in this range expected for traditional physisorption mechanisms.

In contrast to the large differences in ΔH ads,i observed between the two adsorption sites, the ΔS ads,i were of comparable magnitude, differing only by about 5 J mol-1 K-1 between the primary and secondary sites. For H+/CaPHI, the ΔS ads,A and ΔS ads,B were -70.2 and -65.1 J mol-1 K-1, and for H+/KPHI, the ΔS ads,A and ΔS ads,B were -65.9 and -50 J mol-1 K-1, respectively. These similar values of entropic losses likely indicate that the pore columns in the PHI architecture confine CO2 and restrict the translational and rotational motion to similar extents at both adsorption sites, despite the difference in enthalpic interactions. The slightly larger ΔS ads,i  could be indicative of a more restrictive environment in the H+/CaPHI material, but further work on the exact physical mechanisms contributing to the entropic losses on gas adsorption in covalent frameworks are needed for a more comprehensive understanding. Overall, H+/CaPHI exhibited both larger capacity and affinity for CO2 than H+/KPHI in both adsorption sites despite their similar polymeric structure, which demonstrates the critical importance of the altered crystal structure and pore configuration for endowing CO2 adsorptive capacity.

Energetic metal-organic frameworks (EMOFs) with a high oxygen content are currently a hot spot in the field of energetic materials research. In this article, two series of EMOFs with different ligands were obtained by reacting 1-(trinitromethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic acid (tntrza) with metal iodide and metal nitrate, respectively. Furthermore, their structure, thermal stability, thermal decomposition kinetics, and energy performance are fully characterized. The research results revealed that the synthesized EMOFs possess a wide range of density (ρ = 1.88~2.595 g cm-3), oxygen balance (OB(CO2) = -21.1~ -4.3%), and acceptable energy performance (D = 7.73~8.74 km s-1 and P = 28.1~41.1 GPa). The difference in OB(CO2) caused by the ligand structure and metal properties has a great impact on the distribution of gas-phase products after the decomposition of these EMOFs. Noteworthy, [Ag(tntrza)] n  is particularly prominent among these EMOFs, not only because of its excellent detonation performance (D = 8.74 km s-1 and P = 41.1 GPa) endowed by its extremely high density (ρ = 2.595 g cm-3) and oxygen balance (OB(CO2) = -4.3%) but also because of its effective catalytic effect on the decomposition of ammonium perchlorate (AP). This article broadens the horizon for the study of oxygen-enriched EMOFs with catalytic effects and helps understand the mechanism of thermal decomposition of EMOFs with nitroform and dinitro groups.

Structure Characteristics

As an energetic ligand with high oxygen content, tntrza crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 containing two energetic molecules and two water molecules in a unit cell. Different from the high density of energetic molecules with high oxygen balance, the crystal density of tnrza at room temperature is 1.77 g cm-3, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal (A). Obviously, the energetic molecules in the same layer are arranged in the form of head-to-head, and there is a relatively short distance of 2.329 Å between the two heads. (with the nitroform group as the head and carboxyl as the tail) (B). It is undeniable that water molecules play an important role in the formation of hydrogen bonds in tntrza crystals (O(2)-H (2)⋅⋅⋅O (9), O(9)-H(9A)⋅⋅⋅N (2), O(9)-H(9A)⋅⋅⋅O(5A), O(9)-H(9A)⋅⋅⋅O (1), and O(9)-H(9B)⋅⋅⋅O (1)). It not only participates in the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds in the same layer but also connects two adjacent molecular layers through hydrogen bonds (C, D).

[Rb(dntrza)] n  crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Pn with a calculated density of 2.297 g cm-3 at the temperature of 170 K. Interestingly, the coordination of rubidium and dntrza is very similar to that of potassium, that is, there are six rubidium to coordinate with each dntrza molecule (A). Even so, there are differences between Rbdntrza and Kdntrza, and the main difference is reflected in the coordination of metal atoms and carbon atoms. In [Rb(dntrza)] n , rubidium atoms and carbon atoms form three coordination bonds (Rb-C3 (3.717 Å), Rb-C4 (3.690 Å), and Rb-C4 (3.461 Å), while in [K(dntrza)] n , there is only one kind of coordination between potassium and carbon atoms (K-C3 (3.428 Å)) (A, C). Except for the formation of coordination bonds consistent with [K(dntrza)] n , the formation of hydrogen bonds (O5-H5⋅⋅⋅O3, O5-H5⋅⋅⋅O4, O5-H5⋅⋅⋅N1, and C2-H2⋅⋅⋅O1) is also similar to that of [K(dntrza)] n  (D).

[Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n  crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group cmca with a calculated density of 2.301 g cm-3 at the temperature of 296 K. Unlike [K(dntrza)] n  and [Rb(dntrza)] n , each unit cell of [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n  has two dntrza molecules which form coordination bonds with the surrounding 10 cesium atoms and two water molecules (A). Although there are three coordination metals in different environments, their distribution has strong regularity. That is, Cs1 and Cs2 are distributed on the vertical centerline of the crystal, and Cs3 is distributed on both the sides of the centerline (B-D). C shows the coordination of Cs3 and dntrza molecules in the same plane; each Cs3 is coordinated with two nearby dntrza molecules, and the lengths of the coordination bond are Cs3-O (3.158~3.272 Å) and Cs3-N (3.363 Å). D shows the coordination of Cs1 and Cs2, both of which have coordinated with six energetic molecules. It is worth noting that the coordination of Cs1 and Cs2 with energetic molecules only occurs on the oxygen atom of the nitro group.

For complex [K(tntrza)] n , it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a calculated density of 1.88 g cm-3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each potassium atom forms a coordination bond with eight surrounding tntrza molecules, and this can be clearly seen from A. From the top of the small diamond-shaped area at the horizontal center line of the stacking diagram (B), it is clear that the distribution of intermolecular hydrogen bonds is generated by the C-H on the triazole and the oxygen atoms on the carboxyl group (C). D shows the acute-angled top (with the angle of 58.64°) of the horizontally arranged rhombus chain. Obviously, each rhombus is not separated from each other, and they are closely connected to each other through the coordination bond K-O8 (3.200 Å). Although the tntrza molecules are arranged in a compact manner, this did not contribute to the formation of 3D-MOF (this can be clearly seen from the Supporting Information).

As for [Ag(tntrza)] n , its crystal belongs to triclinic space group P-1 with a calculated density of 2.595 g cm-3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each tntrza molecule forms a coordination bond with the surrounding four silver atoms (A). Unexpectedly, unlike other MOFs described above, the nitro group of [Ag(tntrza)] n  does not participate in the formation of the coordination bonds. In addition, there are only intramolecular hydrogen bonds in the crystal (C). Similar to [K(tntrza)] n  and tntrza, the adjacent 2D layers inside the crystal of [Ag(tntrza)] n  are close to each other with nitroformyl groups (the distance between the two parallel MOF blocks is 1.633 Å) (B, C), which makes the MOFs prone to generate "hot spots" in the cavities near the nitroform group that cause combustion or detonation when MOFs are subjected to external mechanical stimulation. It is worth noting that inside the 2D layer, the thin layers, as shown in C, are close to each other (with a distance of 3.11 Å) through the coordination bond Ag-N3 (2.735 Å).

Thermal Stability and Decomposition Product Analysis

To illustrate the thermal stability and the decomposition processes of these complexes, DSC at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, TGA at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, and thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 were applied. As shown in A, it is obvious that the EMOFs with tntrza and dntrza as the ligands show better thermal stability (T d = 168.1, 153.9, 144.4, 161.9, and 189.9 °C for [K(dntrza)] n , [Rb(dntrza)] n , [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n , [K(tntrza)] n , and [Ag(tntrza)] n , respectively) than the nitroform tetrazolium MOFs (RbTNTz (119.6 °C), AgTNTz (123.4 °C), and Cu(NH3)3(TNTz)2 (117.3 °C)), and the onset decomposition temperature is also higher than that of the ligand compound tntrza (137.0 °C). Interestingly, there is a regular phenomenon between the thermal stability of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the atomic number of the alkali metal, that is, the larger the atomic number, the worse the thermal stability of the EMOFs will be. From B, it is clear that there is a significant difference in the decomposition process of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the tntrza-based EMOFs. As for the former, there are two stages of mass loss during the decomposition process. The first stage occurs at the exothermic peak in the DSC curves, which are 159~171 °C ([K(dntrza)] n ), 150~157 °C ([Rb(dntrza)] n ), and 143~148 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), respectively, and the corresponding quality loss values at this stage are 15.13, 16.75 and 14.21%, respectively. The second stage occurred in the temperature range of 173~176 °C (K(dntrza)] n ), 159~162 °C ([Rb(dntrza)] n ), and 151~155 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), and the corresponding mass loss values are 15.89, 20.16, and 11.87%, respectively, while the decomposition process of the tntrza-based EMOFs has only one stage of quality loss. As for the latter, the mass loss only occurs in the vicinity of the exothermic peak, which is 159~171 °C ([K(tntrza)] n ) and 190~198 °C ([Ag(tntrza)] n ), and the mass loss accounts for 76.14 and 45.39% of the total mass, respectively. TGA revealed that the abovementioned compounds exhibited a violent energy release process, especially the tntrza-based EMOFs. According to the TG-MS test results (), the main gas-phase products of tntrza decomposition include CH4 (16), H2O (18), HCN (27), CO (28), CH2O (30 and 29 (CHO)), N2O (44), and NO2 (46). Obviously, CH2O and N2O occupy the largest proportion in the entire gas-phase product. When tntrza reacts with metal iodides to form the dntrza-based EMOFs, the types of gas-phase products produced by decomposition are simplified compared with tntrza, and the main gas-phase products are CO, CH2O, and N2O. It is worth mentioning that with the increase in the sequence of alkali-metal atoms, the proportion of heavy gases (N2O) gradually decreases, while the proportion of light gases (CO and CH2O) increases, especially CH4 ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ). For tntrza-based EMOFs, their decomposition gas-phase product distribution is similar to that of tntrza, with the obvious difference being CH2O and NO2. In summary, the high OB can promote the decomposition of compounds, that is, it can lead to the production of more small molecule gases.

The DSC curves of the above six compounds at the heating rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 °C min-1 are shown in . Based on the peak temperature of decomposition at different heating rates, the nonisothermal kinetic parameters of the above six compounds can be obtained (). Obviously, the values of E calculated using the Kissinger (E k) and Ozawa (E o) methods are in good agreement with each other and range from 125.7 kJ mol-1 (tntrza) to 231.1 kJ mol-1 ([K(tntrza)] n ). It is worth noting that tntrza-based EMOFs exhibited significantly higher E than dntrza-based EMOFs, which implies that the thermal stability of tntrza-based EMOFs is better than that of dntrza-based EMOFs. In order to further estimate the rate constant of the initial decomposition process of the six complexes and also to determine their thermal decomposition mechanism, the Arrhenius equation can be expressed as follows: lnk = 25.3 - 125.7 × 103/(RT), lnk = 24.6 - 129.6 × 103/(RT), lnk = 26.9 - 133.4 × 103/(RT), lnk = 28.9 - 137.3 × 103/(RT), lnk = 53.1 - 231.1 × 103/(RT) and lnk = 35.2 - 176.7 × 103/(RT).

where D is the detonation velocity (km s-1), P is the detonation pressure (GPa), N is expressed as the number of moles of detonation gases per gram of explosive (mol g-1), M̅ is the gaseous product of the average molecular weight (g mol-1), ρ represents the density (g cm-3), and Q is the heat of detonation (kcal g-1). It should be pointed out that the calculation of the detonation velocity and the pressure of the above complexes is carried out in accordance with the explosion equation of the largest exothermic principle (H2O-CO2) (Supporting Information). For the calculation of the heat of detonation of the above energetic complexes, their constant pressure reaction heat (ΔC U) was measured using an oxygen bomb calorimeter (Supporting Information). To express the energy performance of the above complexes intuitively, their detonation velocity (D), detonation pressure (P), and heat of detonation (Q) are listed in . The calculation results show that tntrza exhibits excellent detonation performance superior to RDX and comparable to HMX, and this can be attributed to its higher density (1.82 g cm-3) and oxygen balance (-6.4%) than RDX. These favorable conditions also profoundly affect the energy performance of MOFs based on tntrza and dntrza. The obtained EMOFs show a good detonation velocity higher than 7.0 km s-1, especially for [Ag(tntrza)]i n . Its exceptionally high density (ρ = 2.595 g cm-3), nearly zero oxygen balance (-4.3%), and appropriate heat of detonation lead to its superior detonation properties (D = 8.74 km s-1, P = 41.1 GPa) over the energetic precursor tntrza (D = 8.72 km s-1, P = 33.9 GPa).

For safety evaluation, the impact and friction sensitivities of the above complexes were measured using the BAM standard method, and all the obtained data are summarized in . For energetic ligands, the nitroform structure of tntrza results in a higher mechanical sensitivity (IS = 5.0 J and FS = 100 N) than RDX. Therefore, it can be expected that the EMOF based on tntrza exhibits extremely high mechanical sensitivity, especially [Ag(tntrza)] n  (IS = 1.5 J and FS = 50 N). In general, tntrza-based MOFs exhibit higher mechanical sensitivity than dntrza-based MOFs. Among them, [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n  exhibits the lowest mechanical sensitivity, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal.

Effects on the Decomposition of AP

As the main oxidant of the composite solid propellants, the amount of added AP reached 60 to 90%. Unfortunately, the extremely high decomposition temperature of AP has a negative effect on the combustion performance of the propellant. It is reported that MOFs containing silver generally have a good promoting effect on the decomposition of AP. In this article, [Ag(tntrza)] n  showing an excellent overall performance (high oxygen balance, acceptable detonation performance, and thermal stability) has been reported. Therefore, the catalytic activity of [Ag(tntrza)] n  on the thermal degradation of AP was examined as a reference for its catalytic performance in the composite solid propellant (the effect of other EMOFs prepared in this study and the effect of AgNO3 on the decomposition of AP have also been explored, see the Supporting Information). The thermal decomposition curve of the same quality of pure AP (at the heating rate of 5 °C min-1) and AP mixed with 10% [Ag(tntrza)] n  (at the heating rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 °C min-1) is shown in . The thermal decomposition of pure AP exhibits three peaks, including one endothermic peak and two exothermic peaks. The endothermic peak temperature at 241.9 °C is caused by the transformation of the crystal from orthorhombic to cubic. The first exothermic peak appeared at 311.2 °C, representing the partial decomposition of AP (LTD), and the second exothermic peak was at 420.7 °C, representing the complete decomposition of AP (HTD). As can be seen from , AP mixed with 10% [Ag(tntrza)] n  exhibits the same exothermic peak at 239.1 °C similar to pure AP, which implies that the crystal transition process of AP is hardly affected by [Ag(tntrza)] n . As for the values of LTD and HTD, they are reduced by 47.0 and 85.5 °C, respectively, than pure AP when AP is mixed with [Ag(tntrza)] n . [Ag(tntrza)] n  can not only make LTD and HTD advanced obviously but also weaken the peaks of HTD. This result indicated that compound [Ag(tntrza)] n  can be regarded as a catalyst to promote the thermal decomposition of AP.
