The long-term durability of vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs) depends on the stability and performance of the membrane separator. We have architected a hybrid membrane by uniform dispersion of MIL-101(Cr) (Cr-MOF) in a partially fluorinated polymer grafted with sulfonic acid groups (PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0)). The single cell VRFB performance of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane was studied in comparison with the Cr-MOF incorporated Nafion membrane (NafionCr-MOF(1.0)) and showed an excellent result with 97.5% Coulombic efficiency (CE) at 150 mA/cm2 without any significant deterioration in the charge-discharge process for 1500 cycles (over 650 h). Meanwhile, the CE value of the NafionCr-MOF membrane (94.5%) deteriorated after 800 cycles (about 360 h) under similar conditions. The high VRFB performance of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane has been attributed to the synergized properties and good interactions between Cr-MOF and partially fluorinated polymer matrix responsible for the creation of hydrophilic proton-conducting channels to achieve high selectivity. Furthermore, the cost-effective polymer and thus membranes may open new windows for practical applications in other energy devices such as fuel cells, electrolysis, and water treatment.

In Figure S9A-D, the SEM image confirms the octahedral shape of Cr-MOF, whereas elemental mapping and EDX spectra reveal the presence of the Cr3+ metal center and successful synthesis of Cr-MOF. Figure S9A depicts the SEM image of crystals in a cluster of MIL-101(Cr), whereas Figure S9B shows the magnified image of a single crystal (not in the cluster) in which chromium (Cr) metal has been mapped. Figures S9E,F and S7A-E also support the absence of Cr3+ in the pristine PHP@AMPS membrane. Furthermore, elemental mapping and EDX spectra (top and bottom) of the NafionCr-MOF membrane show the successful interaction of Cr-MOF with the Nafion matrix, with uniform distribution without any agglomeration (Figure S9G-I (top) and J-L (bottom)). Figure S9M,N (top) and P-R (bottom) also reveals similar information in the case of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF membrane because of the good dispensability and uniform dispersion of Cr-MOF with the PHP@AMPS matrix. The EDX spectra (Figure S9O) reveal the elemental compositions, which are close to the Cr-MOF precursor, implying its successful incorporation in the PHP@AMPS matrix. The amount of Cr in the membrane matrix was analyzed by SEM/EDX and ICP-MS, which reveal 0.11 wt % and 1.72 ppm, respectively.

 Figure S10 exhibits AFM height images of pristine PHP@AMPS, PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0), and NafionCr-MOF membranes. The pristine PHP@AMPS membrane shows a smooth surface (Figure S10A,B), whereas 3D images of PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) and NafionCr-MOF membranes show a rough surface due to the regular distribution of Cr-MOF in the polymer matrix (Figure S10D,F). The phase-aggregated morphology of PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) and NafionCr-MOF membranes is further supported by AFM phase images. This is a result of the separation of hydrophobic (light regions) and hydrophilic (dark regions) domains, as well as the excellent compatibility between Cr-MOF and the polymer matrix (Figure S10C,E). The surface roughness value for the pristine PHP@AMPS (R q: 0.499 nm) membrane increases to R q: 1.057 nm for PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0), whereas NafionCr-MOF shows a comparatively low surface roughness value (R q: 0.899 nm).

Oxidative and chemical stabilities of membrane are crucial in determining the lifespan of VRFB activities in highly acidic (H2SO4) and oxidative (VO2+) environments. Formation of oxidative species is expected during redox reaction of VO2+, responsible for membrane degradation. Oxidative and chemical stabilities for different membrane samples were analyzed by percentage weight/conductivity loss after treatment with Fenton's reagent (3% H2O2 containing 3 ppm FeSO4) (80 °C for 10 h) and 1.5 M VO2+ solution in 3.0 M H2SO4 (3 months at 30 °C) (Table S1). Hybrid membranes (PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5), PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0), and NafionCr-MOF) show <2.0% weight/conductivity losses under an oxidative environment, which may be due to the lack of accessibility of active sites for attack of oxidative species due to the strong interaction between Cr-MOF and the polymer matrix. Moreover, the fact that membrane stabilities improved following the addition of Cr-MOF into the polymer matrix demonstrates that Cr-MOF functions as an efficient modifier to prevent membrane deterioration, hence boosting its suitability for VRFB application. Figure S11 illustrates that the tensile strength of the PHP@AMPS membrane (20 MPa) increases after the inclusion of Cr-MOF, and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5) (25 MPa), PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) (27.5 MPa), and NafionCr-MOF (26 MPa) membranes with about 300 μm thickness show good tensile strength. Tensile strength measurements were repeated to check the variability of the data represented by the error bars in the graph of Figure S11. The three-step weight loss process of Cr-MOF, pristine, and hybrid membranes illustrates their thermal stability (Figure S12). For Cr-MOF, in the first step (50-250 °C), weight loss indicates the evaporation of absorbed/bound water, and in the second step (250-400 °C), weight loss confirms the dereliction of functional groups. The weight loss at >400 °C reveals the decomposition of the polymer skeleton. The prepared Cr-MOF was thermally stable up to 350 °C. Pristine PHP@AMPS and all hybrid membranes exhibit thermal stability up to 400 °C followed by degradation of functional groups and the polymer matrix. The fluorinated polymer matrix was considered as thermally robust, and incorporation of Cr-MOF also did not alter the thermal degradation because of the stable nature of the filler and inter/intramolecular hydrogen bonding.

Water uptake (WU), swelling ratio (SR), and ion-exchange capacity (IEC) are necessary characteristics for validating the CEM for VRFB applications (). With the addition of Cr-MOF to the membrane matrix, the WU (20.2%) of the pristine PHP@AMPS membrane increases; however, the SR (12.1%) value significantly decreases. The improved WU for hybrid membranes PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5) (22.8%) and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) (23.7%) may be credited to the amended hydrophilic nature (existence of the Cr-MOF framework and allied functional groups). Similarly, the progressive reduction in SR value may be elucidated by entrenching of Cr-MOF in the soft PHP@AMPS matrix that confines the swelling of the polymeric membrane matrix. The NafionCr-MOF membrane also exhibits comparative WU (21.6%) and SR (10.1%) values, which reveal the good dimensional stability of hybrid membranes in spite of the Cr-MOF hydrophilic nature. Moreover, ion-exchange capacity (IEC), which represents the concentration of functional groups in the membrane matrix, plays a crucial role in ionic conductivity. The IEC value of pristine PHP@AMPS (1.38 mequiv/g) increases with the inclusion of Cr-MOF, and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) shows an IEC value of 1.64 mequiv/g. A similar trend has been also observed for membrane conductivity. Conductivity values for pristine PHP@AMPS, PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5), PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0), and NafionCr-MOF membranes were estimated at 30 °C from Nyquist plots (Figure S13A-D) and are summarized in .

The conductivity of the pristine PHP@AMPS membrane increases with the incorporation of Cr-MOF, and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) shows 15.05 × 10-2 S cm-1 κ m  at 25 °C, which is significantly high in comparison to NafionCr-MOF (12.21 × 10-2 S cm-1). The significantly high conductivity of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane is attributable to the formation of ion-conducting nanochannels and is an indicator of coordinatively unsaturated metal sites in Cr-MOF, which exhibits a Lewis acid behavior. The presence of OH- and H+ groups (generated by the hydrolysis of unsaturated metal sites) results in the augmentation of the membrane acidic nature that causes the establishment of dynamic H-bonding and thus ionic clusters (ion transport pathways) responsible for ionic transmission. Additionally, membrane conductivity also increases with temperature (40-80 °C) (Figure S14).

A-C exemplifies average CE, EE, and VE values for Nafion117Cr-MOF, PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5), and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membranes during single cell VRFB (effective membrane area: 4.0 cm2) operation at 100-150 mA/cm2. To check the variability of the data, experiments were repeated three times for determining standard deviation represented by the error bars in the graphs (A-C). The PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane shows a relatively high CE in comparison with Nafion117Cr-MOF and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5), which also reveals the dominance of VO2+ permeability and electrolyte cross-mixing (Figure S18A-C). The VE is dependent on the inner cell resistance and decreases gradually with increasing current density as a result of overpotential (Ohmic resistance). The PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane depicts ~90% VE because of the lower IR drop in comparison to Nafion117Cr-MOF and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5) membranes (Figure S18D-F). EE values may be a key indicator of the performance of energy storage systems. The EE indicates energy loss during charge-discharge testing, and its behavior with current density is depicted in Figure S18G-I. The EE values for all three membranes similarly vary with current density. At 150 mA/cm2, the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane demonstrates a relatively high EE (~87.3%), indicating its imminent and effective candidacy for VRFB applications. The PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane shows synergized conductivity and VO2+ permeability and therefore elevated EE in comparison with other studied membranes. Single cell VRFB with the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane at 150 mA/cm2 exhibits relatively higher CE (97.0%), EE (87.3%), and VE (90.0%) than NafionCr-MOF (D-F). These results demonstrate advancement in VRFB performance with a battery of enhanced characteristics, including stability, selectivity, conductivity, and capacity retention.

At low and high current density (100 and 0.125 mA/cm2), the pristine PHP@AMPS membrane shows incompetent performance for VRFB application (Figure S19A,B and video). This observation rules out the suitability of the membrane for high-performance VRFB. A long-time durability test was performed with different membrane samples in single cell VRFB, as represented in A. Figure S20A,C and B show the long-term cycling test of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane in single cell VRFB at 100-150 mA/cm2 for 500 cycles. The cell shows a regular charge-discharge behavior without any electrolyte rebalance. Synthesized PHP@AMPSCr-MOF (1.0) shows extremely low VO2+ permeability (CE > 98%) CEM has a very steady nature with no voltage drop for 1000 h. Supporting videos for the validation of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane long-term cycling test are also included in the Supporting Information. The capacity loss during VRFB operation is closely related with VO2+ crossover during the cyclic charge-discharge process. The corresponding capacity retention remained at ~97.8% up to 1500 cycles for PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) (C), which is significantly higher than that of NafionCr-MOF and PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5) membranes. Therefore, the reported hybrid membrane with optimized inclusion of Cr-MOF in the partially fluorinated polymer shows potential for VRFB applications in view of its ultrarobust and high performance. The PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane also exhibits unaltered capacity retention up to 1500 cycles (studied in this case) at 100-150 mA/cm2 current density (Figure S20B).

 D-F and Figure S18 reveal the lifetime test of the single VRFB cell assembled with different membranes at 100-150 mA/cm2 current density. In the case of PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(0.5) and NafionCr-MOF membranes, cycle tests are terminated after 800-865 cycles when discharge capacity decays significantly. In contrast, the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane demonstrates continuous efficiencies up to 1500 cycles. The VRFB cell with the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane demonstrates 97% initial CE at 150 mA/cm2 and is stable even after 1500 cycles, but for the NafionCr-MOF membrane, the initial CE decreases from 94.5 to 92.5% even after 800 cycles. Similarly, the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane nearly maintains EE (87.3%) and VE (90.0%), respectively, at 150 mA/cm2 up to 1500 cycles, whereas for the NafionCr-MOF membrane, EE (80.7 to 77.5%) and VE (85.5 to 84.7%) values decline moderately even after 800 cycles. After 1500 cycles, the integrity of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane is well-maintained and intact, as confirmed by PXRD and the optical image (D and Figure S3A,B). These data demonstrate the longevity of the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane.

Conclusions

Cr-MOF (MIL-101 Cr) and sulfonated PVDF-co-HFP (PHP@AMPS) are successfully synthesized to architect the hybrid membranes of ~300 μm thickness by the solution casting method. The hybrid membrane incorporating 1.0 wt % Cr-MOF (PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0)) exhibits superior dimensions; oxidative, mechanical, and chemical stabilities; conductivity; strong ion selectivity; and low vanadium ion permeability. Favorable properties arise because of the dispersion strengthening effect of the Cr-MOF, as follows: (1) obstructed and elongated ion transmission path; (2) partially fluorinated polymer matrix; and (3) appropriate interactions and arrangement of functional groups. The well-optimized PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane shows excellent VRFB performance and elevated efficiencies (CE: ~97.5% and EE: ~88.5% at 150 mA/cm2) with an almost constant charge-discharge process for 1500 cycles (over 650 h). Capacity retention percentage remains at ~97.2% after 1500 cycles, in good divergence with the NafionCr-MOF membrane with ~91.5% capacity retention in just 800 cycles (about 360 h). The proven hybrid fabrication technique for the PHP@AMPSCr-MOF (1.0) membrane is promising for VRFB use because of its ultraresilient performance; it is also applicable to other electromembrane devices and other relevant fields.

Thermal and PXRD Analysis

To investigate the thermal stability of compounds 1-4, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in the temperature range of 30-650 °C under a flow of N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (Figure S18 of the ). Compound 1 was stable up to 180 °C, and then a rapid weight loss of ~34% (exptl) was observed between 180 to 320 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of bpmh linkers (calcd = 39.8%) and then decomposes to an unidentified product. Compound 2 was found to be stable up to 260 °C; the first step weight loss of 31% (calcd = 37%) in the range of 260-350 °C could be due to the loss of the bpmh linker, and the second step weight loss of ~40% (calcd = 44%) in the temperature range of 350-500 °C is due to the decomposition of the 1,3-adaa ligand, and the remaining organic ligands start burning above 500 °C. Compound 3 was stable up to 120 °C, and a weight loss of 45% was observed between 120 and 320 °C and then gradually decomposed in the temperature range of 320-500 °C, whereas compound 4, also stable up to 120 °C, then started losing the 1,4-pdaa ligand, which was confirmed by 40% weight loss (calcd = 42%). The second step weight loss started at 270 °C probably due to decomposition.

Luminescence Properties

The ligand-based luminescence in MOF's is an attractive research topic for the selective sensing and detection of the metal ions. Apart from the conventional applications, MOFs have been used as photoluminescent materials, owing to their higher stability compared to the organic materials and some typical advantages over inorganics. Generally, d10 complexes are promising to exhibit the photoluminescence properties. We have investigated the solid-state emission properties of both the ligands as well as complexes 1 and 2 (Figure ). The solid-state fluorescence maxima of 1,3-adaa and bpmh was observed at 406 and 403 nm excited at λex = 280 nm, respectively (Figures S19 and S20 of the ). The emission spectra of 1 and 2 resembles both ligands, but the intensity of both the complexes were different. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit an emission band with a maxima at 406 nm for an excitation at λex = 280 nm (Figures S21 and S22 of the ). For d10 complexes, no emission originates from metal-centered MLCT/LMCT excited states, since the d10 metal ions are difficult to be oxidized or reduced. Thus, the emission observed in the complexes is tentatively assigned to the (n → π* and π → π*) intraligand fluorescence (i.e., ligand-based emission). The difference in the intensity of the emission band of compounds 1 and 2 from the ligands may be attributed to a different rigidity of the crystal packing in the solid state. The slight differences in the positions of luminescent peaks in compounds 1 and 2 may be due to the different coordination modes of the ligands. It is surprising to note that there is no emission band observed for compound 3 on excitation in the range of 280 to 372 nm, although intense fluorescent emissions were observed for free ligands. [Fluorescence maxima was observed at 456 nm (λex = 372 nm) for free 1,4-H2pdaa and at 402 nm (λex = 208 nm) for free bpmh]. Although the reason for the absence of the emission band for complex 3 was not clear, it might be attributed to the difference in the dicarboxylate ligand. Since in 1 and 2, the 1,3-adaa ligand contains a rigid adamantane ring which, upon coordination [Zn(II) for 1 and Cd(II) for 2, respectively], increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay, thereby enhancing the luminescence in comparison to 3. In compound 3, the 1,4-pdaa ligand does not have such a type of rigid moiety, which might contribute to the absence of the luminescence.

Magnetic Properties

For magnetic investigation, dc susceptibility data was collected for compound 4 on the polycrystalline sample in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K at 0.1 T. The dc magnetic susceptibilities are shown in the form of the χM T (where χM is the molecular magnetic susceptibility) versus temperature (T) plot in Figure . The room temperature χM T value of 4.88 cm3 mol-1 K is higher than the expected spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 mol-1 K (for 2 isolated Co2+, g = 2.0) due to the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment. Once the temperature is lowered from 300 K, the χM T value decreases gradually, due to the antiferromagnetic interactions between metal centers and shows a plateaulike behavior between 20 to 10 K, probably owing to the spin-orbit coupling effect. With further decline of temperature, the χM T value decreases rapidly to reach the value of 2.55 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K. The decline at a low temperature is probably due to zero-field splitting. 

The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K nicely follow the Curie-Weiss law [χM T = C/(T - θ)], giving C = 5.3 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -29.6 K (Figure S23 of the ). The negative value of θ indicates antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co(II) ions. To understand the low-temperature behavior, the experimental data (Figure ) were fitted using the noncritical-scaling theory with the following simple phenomenological equation.     χ   M   T = A ⁡ exp  ( -   E   1   / k T )  + B ⁡ exp  ( -   E   2   / k T )   where E 1 > 0 represents the activation energies corresponding to the spin-orbit coupling, E 2 signifies the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions, and (A + B) equals the Curie constant. The best fit to the above equation was obtained with the fitting value of E 1/k = 0.38 cm-1, E 2/k = 85.21 cm-1, and (A + B) = 5.4 cm3 K mol-1. Obtained A + B values agrees well with the fitting of the Curie-Weiss equation at high temperature. The low E 1 value suggests little contribution of the spin-orbit coupling, and a high value of E 1 indicates significant antiferromagnetic exchange between adjacent Co2+ centers.

The M/NμB verses H plots from 2 to 10 K (Figures S24 of the ) show a steady increase with the field that reaches up to 3.44 μB at 7 T and 2 K, which is inconsistent with the expected value of 6 μB (for 2 isolated Co2+, g = 2.0). This indicates the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions, even at the highest field of 7 T. The M/NμB verses the H/T plot (Figure S25 of the ) further confirms the presence of the little anisotropy of Co2+ centers, which prevents single molecular magnetic behavior from being shown.

Results and Discussion

A typical cyclic voltammogram of NiHAB in basic solution is shown in a. It is characterized by a symmetric butterfly shape and a capacitance consistent with previously reported values of about 400 F/g. A clear deviation from the rectangular shape expected for a purely EDL-based capacitive mechanism indicates substantial contributions from redox-based charge storage. The contribution of the double layer is small as the specific surface area of the MOF is low, about 100 m2/g (Figure S2), which would only account for <5% of the capacitance in the material (see Supporting Information).

 In situ Ni K-edge XAS measurements were performed during cyclic voltammetry (CV) with a potential scan rate of 1 mV/s in the potential range from -0.75 to -0.25 V vs Ag/AgCl, utilizing a pouch-type three-electrode cell (Figure S3a). CVs collected in the in situ cell are shown in Figure S3b. c shows the Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra at different potentials during CV. All of the spectra have a distinct, weak pre-edge peak ("A") at 8334 eV, a relatively strong, second pre-edge peak ("B") at 8340 eV, and a strong main absorption peak ("C") at 8351 eV. Peak A is assigned to the dipole-forbidden but quadrupole-allowed transition 1s → 3d, which signals 3d and 4p orbital hybridization of the Ni central atoms. Peak B is associated with the transition from 1s to 4p z  orbitals typical for four-coordinate, square-planar Ni complexes, whereas peak C is the dipole-allowed transition of 1s electrons to unoccupied Ni 4p states. As can be seen from c, all XAS spectra overlap perfectly, indicating a lack of changes in the Ni oxidation state upon charge and discharge within the operational potential range. To confirm the lack of Ni oxidation state changes, we also obtained XAS spectra in the steady state to rule out possible undesired reaction delays in the window region in the in situ cell, a problem previously reported in the battery research community. In this type of measurement, the applied potential during CV was held constant until a steady-state current was attained before and during the XAS measurement. Again, no spectral changes were observed at any of the potentials tested (Figure S3c,d). By comparing the edge energy position derived by the integral method with Ni-oxide reference materials (NiO and LiNiO2; Figure S4), the nominal Ni oxidation state is estimated as +2.5. Thus, we confirm that the pseudocapacitive mechanism of the charge storage for the NiHAB MOF is based on reversible redox reactions related to the conjugated ligand. It is important to note that even though Ni does not change its oxidation state during cycling, the transition metal cations play two important ancillary roles in the electrochemical response of the HAB MOF. First, they prevent solubilization of the ligand. Second, they define materials' electronic structure and the position (potential) of the redox peaks as can be seen by comparison of the respective electrochemical response of the isostructural CuHAB MOF. 

As the redox reaction is ligand-based, it is important to better understand its state in the as-synthesized MOF. To this end, we performed a number of XPS measurements in the N 1s region that allowed us to identify and quantify the specific nitrogen bonding environments present in the MOF (d). These N 1s XPS spectra show that nitrogen in the ligand is present in a combination of states in the following ratio: 75% quinoid nitrogen (-N) and 25% benzenoid nitrogen (-NH-). Based on these XPS data, the original state of the ligand in pristine NiHAB MOF can be represented as 25% of motif "A" (Ni1.5C6N6H3) and 75% of motif "B" (Ni1.5C6N6H5) (e). Therefore, we propose that the electrochemical process responsible for the promising capacitive response of NiHAB is related to electroreduction of the quinoid nitrogen to benzenoid nitrogen. Assuming a complete reduction of the ligand to hexaaminobenzene, we estimate that theoretically each Ni3C12N12H9 can accept 8e -. It is important to note that such electrochemical reduction generates a negative charge on the ligand and will be compensated by external cations during charging. From the experimentally observed capacitance of 400 F/g, the voltage range of 0.5 V, and the capacity of 200 C/g measured herein, we calculate that each NiHAB unit (Ni3C12N12H9) accepts about 1e - in the potential range between -0.25 and -0.75 V, and specifically during this process, motif "A" get electrochemically reduced following the reaction shown in f. Hence, experimental capacity constitutes 12.5% of the theoretical capacity. To examine the reasons for this relatively low experimental capacity, we performed further studies on the charge storage mechanism of NiHAB in aqueous electrolytes.

Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder XRD was performed using a Bruker D8 Advance (Bruker Corp., Billerica, USA) using a Cu Kα source. The particle size was estimated with the Scherrer equation, using 0.9 as the dimensionless shape factor and using the fwhm of the tallest peak (7.754 in 2θ, fwhm = 0.597054 in 2θ), yielding an estimated crystallite size of 31 nm.

Four new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from the bent triazole dicarboxylic acid ligand 3,5-bis(4'-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole (H2bct) have been discovered by a solvothermal method. These MOFs, [M5(μ2-H2O)2(μ3-OH)2(bct)4(H2O)8]⋅4H2O} n  (1, M = Co; 2, M = Ni), {[Cd2(bct)2(bipy)]⋅5H2O} n  (3) (bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine), and {[Cd(bct)(tib)]⋅H2O⋅DMF} n  (4) (tib = 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene), exhibit diverse coordination modes and fascinating crystal structures. The crystallographic structures, thermal stabilities, photoluminescence, and magnetic properties have been studied. 1 and 2 share the identical structural features based on planar pentanuclear clusters except for the central ions, where the one-dimensional chain structures are constructed from the pentanuclear secondary building units linked with bct2- ligands, while 3 and 4 have similar layered structures. Magnetic analyses of 1 and 2 reveal that an overall antiferromagnetic coupling within the pentanuclear Co(II) cluster nodes are observed, which can be switched to strong ferromagnetic coupling when using Ni(II) to replace the Co(II) sites. Both 3 and 4 show intense blue emission under ultraviolet excitation. Moreover, 4 can be applied as a selective sensor for quantitatively testing the concentration of acetone in water based on the luminescence quenching effect, with a quenching constant (K sv) value of 12.89 L mol-1 in water.

{[Cd(bct)(tib)]⋅H2O⋅DMF} n  (4)

 4 adopts triclinic space group P1̅, and the crystallographically independent Cd atom exhibits a pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry with five carboxylic O atoms constituting an equatorial plane and two imidazole N atoms of tib ligands in the fixed points (a). The chelating-bridging tridentate coordination types of the carboxyl groups result in the edge-shared dinuclear [Cd2(η2-CO2)2] SBUs, in which the distance of neighboring Cd(II) centers is 3.884 Å (b). The normal Cd-N and Cd-O distances are 2.2712(19)-2.292(2) Å and 2.3260(18)-2.5160(18) Å, respectively. 

PXRD, Thermal Analyses and Magnetic Properties

The purity of 1-4 was confirmed by PXRD, as shown in Figure S9. The experimental PXRD matches well with the simulated SCXRD. In addition, TGA cures of 1-4 are also given in Figure S10. Taking 4 as an example, we can see three platforms: first, the mass loss of 2.69% at 110 °C due to the release of H2O molecule (theoretical value: 2.29%); then the continuous loss of 9.54% at 300 °C is ascribed to the decomposition of DMF (theoretical value: 9.31%); and above that, the weight loss suggests the decomposition of the organic component.

The temperature-dependent χM T and χM -1 curves of 1 and 2 are given in . The experimental χM T values match well with the calculated values at 300 K, such as 15.01 vs 14.65 cm3 K mol-1 for 1 and 5.57 vs 5.51 cm3 K mol-1 for 2.

In 1, with decreasing temperature, the χM T value decreases gradually to 9.46 cm3 K mol-1 at 28 K, and then increases to 10.27 cm3 K mol-1 at 9.5 K. Upon further cooling, the χM T value continues to decline to 7.75 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The χM-T curve in 75-300 K can be well described by the Curie-Weiss rule. The calculated C and θ are 17.06 cm3 K mol-1 and -43.27 K, respectively, which indicates an overall antiferromagnetic interaction. The increase of the χM T value below 28 K could be attributed to ferrimagnetism or spin-canting.

For 2, the maximum value of χM T is 9.12 cm3 K mol-1 at 3.47 K, suggesting a ferromagnetic (FM) coupling between the Ni(II) ions within the planar pentanuclear clusters. Further cooling resulted in the decrease of the value to 8.16 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which could be caused by the zero-field splitting (ZFS) effects and/or the antiferromagnetic interaction between adjacent clusters at low temperature. On the basis of the Curie-Weiss law in 75-300 K, the calculated θ is 18.64 K. Such positive θ confirms that the FM interactions between Ni(II) ions.

Luminescence Properties and Luminescence Sensing of Small Organic Molecules

MOFs based on d10 metal centers usually exhibit luminescence properties and thus could be used as luminescent materials. Accordingly, solid-state luminescence spectra of 3 and 4, as well as ligands H2bct, bipy, and tib, were measured at room temperature. The emissions at 376, 415, and 407 nm were observed for H2bct, bipy, and tib ligands, with excitation wavelengths of 273, 344, and 360 nm, respectively (Figure S11). Such emissions could be attributed to π* → π or π* → n transitions. With excitation maxima at 369 and 368 nm, the emission spectra of 3 and 4 at room temperature give intense blue emission bands centered at 425 and 450 nm, respectively (). Due to the similar emission bands for both samples, the emissions of 3 and 4 can be attributed to metal-perturbed intraligand charge transfers (ILCT) and/or ligand-to-ligand charge transfers (LLCT).

Taking advantage of the porous structure and luminescence properties of 4, further study on luminescence sensing of small molecules was undertaken. It was anticipated that free DMF and H2O molecules located in the void space of 4 could be replaced by other different common solvents. We have first recorded the room-temperature emission and excitation spectra of 4 suspended in water with the concentration of 0.5 mg mL-1. As shown in a, 4 in water gave an intense λem(max) = 375 nm (λem = emission wavelength) in water, under λex = 300 nm (λex = excitation wavelength). To investigate the feasibility of luminescence sensing, the solid powder of 4 was immersed in different solvents, and kept still for 1-2 min to reach equilibrium, to carry out the solvent-dependent emission spectra. These solvent molecules have appropriate sizes for entering the pores of 4. b gives the luminescence responses of 4 for the various solvents, showing the solvent-dependent emission intensity. All emission spectra in these solvents were measured under the same experimental conditions. Among all the tested solvents, acetone exhibited the drastic luminescence quenching effect to 4, leading to the disappearance of the emission. Nevertheless, except for the enhancing effect of DMF, the other tested solvents only resulted in quite moderate reduction of the luminescence of 4. The phenomena suggest that 4 exhibits a highly selective luminescence quenching effect for acetone and therefore can be used as a convenient sensor simply coupled with a handy UV lamp to detect acetone. Such phenomenon could be attributed to the energy transfer from the organic ligands of 4 to acetone molecules. 

Moreover, to evaluate the quenching effect, quenching constant (K sv) was estimated by the Stern-Volmer equation, as follows: 1      (     I   0     I   )  =   K   s v    [ M ]  + 1    where the luminescence intensity before (I 0) and after (I) the addition of acetone was obtained by experiment, and [M] is molar concentration of acetone. A linear relation can be found at low concentrations (0-0.15 mol L-1), and the K sv value can be calculated to be 12.89 L mol-1 (d), further attesting to the luminescence sensing ability of 4 for acetone in aqueous solution.

BET surface areas of 1, 2, and 3 were obtained from measured N2 isotherms using established consistency criteria, and were found to be 2583, 1978, and 1416 m2 g-1, respectively. These are in good agreement with previously reported BET surface areas for UiO-67 and with geometrical calculations (see Supporting Information). N2 isotherms acquired after activation from water confirm the decomposition of 1 and 2; following only one cycle of activation from water, sample 1 loses its porosity (s A (BET) < 5 m2 g-1), and the surface area of 2 was reduced to 1112 m2 g-1. For 3, however, only a slight increase was observed, to 1452 m2g-1. After repeated syntheses and measurements of 3 only slight deviations in s A (BET) between as-synthesized and water-activated samples have been observed.

The newly synthesized MOFs 2 and 3 were found to be slightly less thermally stable than 1, and started to decompose around 400 °C (see Supporting Information for TGA).

Single Crystal Structure Analysis

The structures of the two linkers, 1,1'-binaphthyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (as a DMF solvate) and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (crystal structure previously unreported of the pure compound), and MOFs 2 and 3 were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. In the structure of 2 and 3, two positions of the carboxylate oxygen were observed and allocated to missing linkers, in accordance with previous literature reports. TGA measurements also indicate the presence of missing linker defects in the powder samples. The SC-XRD refinement statistics are summarized in .

The adsorption isotherm has three distinct parts; before, during, and after the water condensation. Initially (p/p 0 = 0.0-0.4), it exhibits a non-negligible rise in adsorption (for p/p 0 = 0.0-0.02), followed by a linear segment (for p/p 0 = 0.02-0.4). If we consider the crystal density of 0.937 for this material, the initial amount of water adsorbed (n 0) corresponds to 0.645 mmol cm-3, or to about 7.5 water molecules per unit cell, which is in good agreement with the 8 water molecules (2 per Zr6-cluster) expected to undergo chemisorption upon rehydroxylation of the cluster. According to the Langmuir equation, more than 90% of the rehydroxylation is completed at a relative partial pressure as low as p/p 0 = 0.015.

The second part of the adsorption isotherm consists of a water condensation phenomenon which occurs at p/p 0 = 0.53 with a significant rise in water adsorption equivalent to 92% of the total water adsorption capacity. This large uptake is followed by the third part, a linear increase that could originate from further ordering of adsorbed water molecules into additional layer(s) with higher pressure, thus increasing the density in the larger pores and allowing some additional adsorption. The total water uptake finally reaches 27.4 mmol/g (0.495 cm3/g) at p/p 0 = 0.90 (see ).

The CH4 adsorption capacity (), derived from isotherms at 25 °C (), is moderate for all three MOFs, and below the best performing MOFs. Despite the steric shielding of the cluster corners (which are the preferred gas adsorption sites) and above all the reduction of porosity (by 26% in the case of 3), the volumetric capacity of 3 is 147 cm3(STP) cm-3 at 65 bar, whereas it is 127 for 1 and 135 for 2. This observation seems to encourage the adopted strategy of functionalizing the linker with pending methyl or aryl groups to enhance the interaction with the framework and thus the methane adsorption capacity.

The PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized samples matches well with the simulated pattern (Figure S5), indicating the phase purity of PCN-136. In addition, PCN-136 was characterized by thermalgravimetric and infrared (IR) spectra analysis (Figures S6 and S7). The architectural stability and permanent porosity of PCN-136 were confirmed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurement at 77 K with a reversible type-I isotherm feature (Figure S8a). The result suggests that PCN-136 is highly porous with a BET (Langmuir) surface area of 1768 m2⋅g-1 (2009 m2⋅g-1). The pore volume of PCN-136 calculated at 0.95 P/P 0 is 0.73 cm3 g-1. The pore size was calculated to be 15 Å from the nitrogen adsorption isotherm. This is consistent with the pore size determined from crystallographic analysis (Figure S8b). For comparison, the N2 sorption isotherm of pbz-MOF-1 was also performed at 77 K (Figure S9). The BET surface area and pore volume of pbz-MOF-1 are similar to those of PCN-136. As shown in Figure S10, carbon dioxide adsorption-desorption isotherms of PCN-136 at 273 K were measured. Carbon dioxide uptake was as high as 61.01 cm3 g-1 at saturation. This result suggests that the interactions between sp2-bonded carbon atoms from the hexabenzocoronene fragments and CO2 molecules may play an important role in the carbon dioxide uptake. In a previous computational study, the utilization of hexabenzocoronene unit as a central part of the linker resulted in a significant enhancement of the uptake of gases for the entire family of MOFs in the study. The successful construction of PCN-136 provides a platform for the comparison of structure-dependent photocatalytic performance between PCN-136 and pbz-MOF-1.

Photoelectrochemical Properties

As suggested by the UV-vis data results, PCN-136 exhibits a broad-band absorption covering the whole UV-visible-light region (a). This feature is desirable for photocatalytic applications. However, the visible-light absorption of pbz-MOF-1 is only up to ~450 nm (a). The optical absorption of PCN-136 shows large broadening compared to the free ligand HCHC (Figure S11). This difference is mainly derived from the aggregation of the HCHC ligands in the framework on the basis of fluorescence results (Figure S12). These results suggested that the electrons of PCN-136 can be more easily promoted to an excited state upon the visible-light irradiation when compared to free HCHC or pbz-MOF-1. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to study the possible difference in the optical bandgap in pbz-MOF-1 and PCN-136 that may have resulted from the π-conjugated organic fragments. As shown in Figure S13, the frontier molecular orbital distributions for organic linkers (HCBB and HCHC) in pbz-MOF-1 and PCN-136 are presented. The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) in HCBB is mainly delocalized over the exterior biphenyl carboxylic acid fragments, while the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is delocalized over both the central benzene ring and the exterior biphenyl carboxylic acid fragments. The HOMO in the HCHC ligands mostly delocalizes over the central π-conjugated hexabenzocoronene unit, while the LUMO is formally delocalized over both the central π-conjugated hexabenzocoronene unit and the terminal benzoic acid fragments. It can be clearly seen that more extended conjugation generally leads to a smaller HOMO-LUMO gap (4.26 eV for HCBB vs 3.32 eV for HCHC). This accordingly enhances the degree of charge transfer from the ground state to the excited state. The DFT calculations confirm that the MOFs containing larger π-conjugated fragments would be more efficient for the utilization of the solar spectrum with similar metal nodes and frameworks. In addition, the photocurrent profiles of PCN-136 and pbz-MOF-1 also indicated that PCN-136 is more active than pbz-MOF-1 under visible-light illumination (b). The replacement of the central phenyl core in pbz-MOF-1 with the hexabenzocoronene moiety in PCN-136 did not lead to a significant change in the structural feature, but the optical absorption ability was greatly tuned. It is postulated from this result that the presence of a flat hexabenzocoronene central core will improve the light harvesting of a desired MOF. With this in mind, the use of HCHC linkers can be shown to endow PCN-136 with light-harvesting capabilities in order to be utilized as a suitable platform for photocatalytic studies.

The Mott-Schottky measurements on PCN-136 and pbz-MOF-1 were performed at a frequency of 500, 1000, and 1500 Hz, in order to elucidate their semiconductor characters and the possibility for the subsequent CO2 photoreduction study. As shown in c and S14, the positive slope of the obtained C2- values (vs the applied potentials) is consistent with those of typical n-type semiconductors. The intersection points are independent of the frequency, and the flat-band position of PCN-136 is determined from the intersection to be ~-0.95 V vs Ag/AgCl (i.e., -0.75 V vs normal hydrogen electrode (NHE)). Generally, the bottom of the conduction band (LUMO) in n-type semiconductors can be determined to be approximately equal to the flat-band potential. According to this, the LUMO of PCN-136 is estimated to be -0.75 V vs NHE. The optical bandgap of PCN-136 was calculated to be 1.18 eV based on the UV-vis spectrum (Figure S15), and its valence band (HOMO) was estimated to be 0.43 V vs NHE (c). Given the much more negative potential of the LUMO in PCN-136 than the reduction potential for the conversion of CO2 to formate, it is theoretically feasible for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to generate formate to be accomplished utilizing PCN-136 as a catalyst. Furthermore, the Mott-Schottky plots suggest that pbz-MOF-1 can be employed as a visible-light-harvesting material utilizing the same method (Figure S14).

Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction

Considering the permanent porosity, broad optical absorption, and semiconductor characteristics exhibited by PCN-136, the photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide over PCN-136 was further evaluated in the presence of triisopropanolamine (TIPA) as a sacrificial agent under visible-light irradiation. Similarly, TIPA was employed in the reaction serving as an electron donor and hydrogen donor to recycle the catalytic process like the role of triethanolamine (TEOA). Moreover, TIPA is a milder alkaline medium when compared to TEOA. In order to determine the optimized catalytic experimental conditions, the photocatalytic conversion reaction was conducted over a wide variety of experimental conditions (). The concentration of HCOO- was detected and quantitatively analyzed by in situ ion chromatography. HCOO- anions were continuously produced and analyzed as time increased for the reaction. Remarkably, PCN-136 shows a higher photocatalytic activity for carbon dioxide reduction in a mixed MeCN/H2O system than in a single solvent. No other products can be detected in the gas and liquid phases, suggesting that the catalyst is highly selective toward the conversion. No HCOO- was detected in the absence of PCN-136, demonstrating the critical role of the photocatalyst in the reaction. Moreover, no HCOO- was generated when the reaction was carried out in the dark, demonstrating a truly photocatalytic process. A total amount of 10.52 μmol formate anions was produced within 12 h in the mixed solvents of acetonitrile (40 mL) and water (5 mL) in the presence of TIPA (5 mL) under continuous visible-light illumination. According to the above results, the following photocatalytic reduction of CO2 was carried out in the presence of TIPA (5 mL) in a mixed solvent systems (CH3CN/H2O, v:v (mL) = 40:5) under Xe light (300 W, λ ≥ 420 nm). For comparison, HCHC was also used as a catalyst for CO2 photoreduction under similar conditions. However, HCHC has no activity on CO2 photoreduction (Figure S17), suggesting that the photocatalytic activity can be greatly improved by assembling the HCHC linkers into MOFs. Furthermore, pbz-MOF-1 was studied as the photocatalyst under the same conditions, and the amount of HCOO- anion produced was only 3.53 μmol after 12 h (a). The turnover numbers of PCN-136 and pbz-MOF-1 are 1.12 and 0.40, respectively, suggesting that the HCOO- yield of PCN-136 is nearly 3 times higher than that of pbz-MOF-1 under the same reaction conditions. The results suggest that PCN-136 is superior to pbz-MOF-1 for applications as an active photocatalytic material in the conversion of CO2 to HCOO- under visible-light irradiation. The presence of extended π-conjugated hexabenzocoronene-based linkers in PCN-136 not only improves the optical absorption of the materials but also largely increases the yield of the photocatalytic reaction. As a comparison, Ru(bpy)3Cl2 (bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine) was introduced into the pbz-MOF-1 (20 mg) system as the photosensitizer with an amount of 11.2 mg (15 μmol) under similar conditions (Figure S18). Under these conditions, the amount of HCOO- anion produced from pbz-MOF-1 increased from 3.53 μmol after 12 h to 11.11 μmol in 12 h, which is comparable to that of PCN-136. These results demonstrate that PCN-136 is very active and capable of selectively converting CO2 to HCOO- under visible-light irradiation. PCN-136 exhibits one of the highest performances of visible-light-driven CO2 photoreduction to formate among reported MOFs or crystalline photocatalysts. In addition, PCN-136 can be easily separated and recovered from the reaction media by centrifugation for continued use. The recycling performance of the material was further investigated to examine the stability of PCN-136. The results of the cycling performance suggested that no obvious change in the yield rate of HCOO- occurred during the four continuous runs (b). After the photocatalytic experiments, the PXRD pattern was analyzed demonstrating that the structure of PCN-136 was maintained after reaction cycling (Figure S5).

SALI-derived samples were then treated with 0.2 M aqueous acid solutions (5 mL each) with varying pH (realized by using acids with different pK as with constant reagent concentration; see ). Similar degrees of ligand loss (~12-25% by 1H NMR) but no significant linker (TBAPy4-) leaching were detected for SALI-BA and SALI-PPA. Subsequent N2 isotherm measurements indicated 85-96% porosity retention for SALI-BA and 94-98% retention for SALI-PPA, as judged by BET surface areas. PXRD patterns (Figures E,  F, and SI-5, ) were unchanged.

Ligand Binding Mode in SALI-PPA 

Exposure to an organic base, piperidine (pK a of the conjugated acid ~11) in DMF, left SALI-BA essentially unchanged: 1H NMR data (Figure SI-15, ) indicated no loss of BA ligands, no residual base, and no change in N2 isotherm at 77 K and corresponding BET surface area. In contrast, 1H NMR data for a digested sample of a piperidine-exposed sample of SALI-PPA (Figure A) revealed incorporation of 0.8 piperidines per PPA ligand. An attractive interpretation consistent with the mode of phosphonate coordination proposed in Scheme  is reaction of the added base with PPA's P-O-H moiety. DRIFTS data for the piperidine-exposed SALI-PPA sample (Figure C) clearly show diminished band intensities at 3662 and 3650 cm-1 relative to the 3674 cm-1 transition. Among these, the band at 3650 cm-1 is especially affected by the piperidine treatment, suggesting that the transition is associated with the acidic hydroxyl group of the bound phosphonate ligand. We attribute (speculatively) a broad band at 3598 cm-1 to an H-bonded species formed by the piperidinium moiety with the Zr-bound phosphonate, hydroxyl, and residual solvents; note a corresponding band in the SALI-PPA sample, prior to piperidine treatment, appearing at 3614 cm-1. Regardless of the assignments, it is clear that piperidine binds via an acid/base interaction that is unavailable in SALI-BA. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data (see  section S8, Figure S-20) showed ~8% mass loss at 250 °C as expected for the ~1 piperidine per PPA ligand (calculated ~10%).

Synthesis and General Characterization. The compound [Cu(pic)2] is only slightly soluble in methanol. At low pH and in the presence of Cu(II) salt it is progressively dissolved as it reacts to form compounds 1, 2, and 3, depending on the anion of the used Cu(II) salt. When copper(II) perchlorate or fluoroborate was allowed to react with the suspension of [Cu(pic)2], a two-dimensional, rectangular grid-like polymeric structure (compounds 1 and 2) resulted (Scheme ). This grid-like structure results from the union of Cu(II) chains with a very unusual ‘fish backbone' structure. On the other hand, when copper(II) nitrate was added to [Cu(pic)2], a one-dimensional polymer (compound 3) having the same metal to ligand ratio (3:2) but with very different carboxylate-bridging connections than those in 1 and 2 was formed (Scheme ). It is to be noted that the amount of added Cu(II) salt is higher than the stoichiometric requirement. When we added [Cu(pic)2] and the copper salt in a stoichiometric 3:1 ratio, a considerable amount of the former remained as an insoluble product and the yield became very low. For the alternative method of synthesis (see Experimental Section) when we increased the copper salt:picolinic acid ratio from 2:3 to 1:1 the amount of initial separation of [Cu(pic)2] decreased and consequently the yield of the products was higher. Besides elemental analysis all three complexes were initially characterized by IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis. The compound [Cu(pic)2] is a ‘inner metallic' neutral complex and does not contain any anion, whereas all three compounds, 1, 2, and 3, contain the corresponding counteranions and their characteristic intense peak in the IR spectra can easily be detected (1102, 1071, and 1384 cm-1 for ClO4 -, BF4 -, and NO3 -, respectively). The TG curves of the three complexes show a mass loss corresponding to the water molecules present in the structure (for 1 calcd 3.0%, found 2.86% in the temperature range 120-180 °C; for 2 calcd 3.0%, found 2.99% in the temperature range 120-170 °C; for 3 calcd 6.0%, found 6.23% in the temperature range 100-200 °C). 

 Magnetic Properties.  Compounds   1   and   2  . The magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2 in the form of a χm T vs T plot (χm is the molar susceptibility per two copper(II) ions) are shown in Figures  and , respectively. As expected from the structural similarities, both complexes show very similar  magnetic behavior. Thus, the room temperature χm T values are 0.78 and 0.79 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 for 1 and 2, respectively. These values are the expected ones for two magnetically quasi-isolated spin doublets. On cooling, the χm T values increase gradually in the temperature range 300-50 K and then abruptly below 50 K, reaching a value of 0.96 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 for both 1 and 2 at 2 K. This behavior indicates the presence of overall weak ferromagnetic exchange interactions between the Cu(II) ions in both compounds.   

This model also very satisfactorily reproduces the magnetic data of both compounds in the whole temperature range (not shown) with the following parameters: g = 2.03 and J = 0.64 cm-1 for compound 1 and g = 2.05 and J = 0.37 cm-1 for compound 2. As expected, the average coupling constant in compounds 1 and 2 is weak and ferromagnetic, as also observed in compounds 1 and 2 with the chain model. Note that with this model we obtained an average J value since the complexity of the model precludes a precise determination of each of the coupling constants since they are correlated and, therefore, are not independent in the fitting procedure (there are many sets of different values that reproduce the magnetic data). 

 Compound   3  . The magnetic properties of complex 3 are shown in Figure  in the form of χm T vs T (χm is the molar susceptibility per two copper(II) ions). It shows a room-temperature value of 0.81 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 that remains constant in the temperature range 300-100 K. Below ca. 100 K the χm T product shows a smooth increase to reach a value of ca. 1.3 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2 K (Figure ). This behavior indicates, as in compounds 1 and 2, the presence of ferromagnetic exchange interactions between the Cu(II) ions. Since the structure of compound 3 shows a chain of Cu(II) ions connected through alternating syn - anti carboxylate bridges we used a chain model with two alternating (J and J‘) exchange coupling constants (Figure ).

As depicted in Figure S1 of the Supporting Information (SI), the absorption maximum of SNNU-153 is around 410 nm in dimethylformamide (DMF), which, upon excitation, gives a strong emission maximized at 450 nm (a). The emission has a small Stokes shift of ~2000 cm-1 with respect to the lowest-lying absorption peak and is considered as a normal emission. A normal emission of SNNU-153 was also observed in solid samples (Figure S2). The lack of ESIPT, i.e., the proton transfer from -OH to the carboxylate oxygen, can be rationalized by the weak basicity of the coordinated carbonyl oxygen where its electron density has been shifted to the metal (In) center upon coordination.

The absorption and emission spectra of SNNU-153 in DMF as a function of the added N2H4 concentration were then studied. Despite the smooth change of the N2H4 absorption titration spectra (Figure S1), drastic changes in ratiometric emission were observed. As shown in a, upon adding N2H4, the strong 450 nm blue emission drastically decreased, accompanied by a long wavelength shoulder that became obvious with a peak wavelength at 543 nm at a N2H4 concentration of, e.g., 100 ppm. After continually adding N2H4 from 100 to 5500 ppm, the emission intensity at 543 nm dominated the spectra with the disappearance of the 450 nm emission band. The titration established a ratiometric fluorescence pattern for hydrazine detection. The fluorescence quantum yield (QY) of the SNNU-153 450 nm band and its saturated 543 nm emission with N2H4 was measured to be as high as 18 and 49%, respectively, in DMF (Table S2). Due to the strong fluorescence intensity for both 450 and 543 nm bands, amid the N2H4 titration, SNNU-153 showed an apparent emission color change from blue to yellow that can be clearly visualized by the naked eyes under a conventional 366 nm UV light (inset of a). The sensitive fluorescence emission changes match well with the CIE chromaticity diagram (Figure S3a).

SNNU-153 acts as a molecular sieve; therefore, the kinetic domain, i.e., the time course of reaching equilibrium for luminescence intensity at 450 and 543 nm amid N2H4 titration, is important, which was measured by in situ monitoring the real-time fluorescence intensity (b). It can be seen that the fluorescence intensity at emission 450 nm sharply decreased and quickly reached a minimum constant value in 7 and 88 s with the addition of 3.2 ppm (0.1 mM) and 1000 ppm (31.25 mM) of N2H4, respectively, showing an extraordinarily fast response for MOF-based sensors. For a fair comparison, we summarize the performance data of other reported sensors in Table S3, where the response time for most N2H4 sensing probes always exceeds 10 min. For example, the MOF sensor phthalimide-UIO-66 showed a response time of 18 min for 2.25 mM N2H4, and a common molecule sensor, EPH, exhibited a response time of 60 min when adding 1 mM N2H4.

 c shows the plot for the emission intensity at 543 nm (I 543) versus that at 450 nm (I 450) as a function of the added N2H4 concentration ([M]). Note that each measurement was made 5 min after adding N2H4 to ensure the establishment of equilibrium between N2H4 and the SNNU-153 MOF sensor (vide supra). As a result, a straight-line behavior was obtained within the added N2H4 concentration of 0-700 ppm. The linear relationship was then fitted by the Stern-Volmer relationship, i.e., I 543/I 450 = A + K SV[N2H4], and a K SV value of 406.4 M-1 was deduced. The detection limits (DLs) or limit of detection (LOD) can be estimated by the relationship DL = 3σ/k, where σ denotes the standard deviation of 10 blank tests and k is the slope of the linear relationship, which is equivalent to K SV. As a result, the detection limit was calculated to be 0.0595 ppm or 1.86 μM. Upon increasing the concentration up to 700 ppm, the deviation from the linearity gradually appeared, accompanied by the decrease of the titration slope, i.e., the ratio of I 543/I 450 versus [N2H4] (c). Nevertheless, in the [N2H4] range of 700-5500 ppm, if we qualitatively impose a linear plot, a Stern-Volmer plot with K SV of 37.76 M-1 can be obtained. The cause of perturbation in the high concentration of [N2H4] will be discussed in the later section. It is noted that the detection limit of the SNNU-153 MOF probe is superior when compared with that reported in the literature, such as BTP-LB (2.74 μM), HFP (2 μM), and CD2 (4.5 μM). Nevertheless, it is also slightly inferior to some probes, such as phthalimide-UIO-66 (0.87 μM) and 2-Ac (0.96 μM). Furthermore, the K SV value is comparable with some N2H4 probes such as BTP-LB (3.81 × 103 M-1) and BTP-LN (5.53 × 103 M-1). Overall, taking the ultrafast response performance into account, the SNNU-153 MOF probe is very promising for sensing N2H4.

The time-resolved experiments for the SNNU-153 probe in DMF with and without N2H4 were also conducted (Figure S4). The average lifetime of the SNNU-153 probe in DMF (λem = 450 nm) is 3.21 ns. After addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution (λem = 450 nm), the average times are 2.94, 2.96, 2.99, 3.03, and 3.32 ns, respectively. The average lifetime at λem = 543 nm of SNNU-153 is 6.40 ns; after addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, 300, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution, the average times at λem = 543 nm are 8.06, 8.56, 9.49, 9.50, and 9.65 ns, respectively. Within the experimental error, the essentially unchanged average lifetime indicates that the fluorescence response of SNNU-153 for N2H4 originates from the ground state.

Activation and N2 and CO2 Sorption Properties

Compound NIIC-30(Ph)⋅DMF can be safely stored at room temperature and remains stable for at least 1 year. Since direct activation requires a high enough temperature to remove guest molecules, we substituted DMF with low boiling acetone. This sample is then activated under dynamic vacuum for 6 h at 60 °C without any structural degradation. Then, textural characteristics of the activated sample were studied. Due to the rather narrow cross section of the channel, the compound practically does not sorb nitrogen at 77 K. For this reason, the determination of the inner surface area was carried out according to carbon dioxide sorption data at 195 K (Figure S11). Framework NIIC-30(Ph) demonstrates the type I isotherm (IUPAC) typical of microporous compounds, and a small hysteresis between the sorption-desorption curves is explained by the kinetic effect of a narrow and tortuous channel aperture. The BET surface area was found to be 451 m2/g, and the pore volume was 0.241 cm3/g. This corresponds to the volume of channels found in the structure according to X-ray diffraction data (0.206 cm3/g).

Since the exclusive sorption of carbon dioxide with respect to nitrogen was demonstrated already at the stage of studying the textural characteristics, we studied the sorption of these gases at different temperatures in more detail. The adsorption isotherms of N2 and CO2 were measured at 273 and 298 K (). The selectivity factors (SFs) of the adsorption of CO2 over N2 were estimated by three commonly used methods (see the SI): (i) as a ratio of adsorbed volumes, (ii) as a ratio of Henry's constants, and (iii) by the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST).  shows the results of the selectivity factor calculations for NIIC-30(Ph) at 273 and 298 K for an equimolar gas mixture. According to IAST, the SF values at P total = 1 bar were 10.7 and 24.5 for 298 and 273 K, respectively. In addition, the IAST calculations (see the SI) made it possible to obtain the selectivity factors as a function of the gas mixture composition or the absolute pressure for the CO2/N2 mixture at both 273 and 298 K (b). The compound demonstrates moderately high IAST SF, which is way behind record reported values for Qc-5-Cu-sql-b (40000 IAST) and SIFSIX-3-Zn (1818 IAST); nevertheless, framework NIIC-30(Ph) has a slightly higher CO2 uptake of 2.855 mmol/g in comparison with 2.16 and 2.54 mmol/g for Qc-5-Cu-sql-b and SIFSIX-3-Zn, respectively. These data demonstrate the good potential of the obtained MOF for gas separation applications.

Benzene/Cyclohexane Sorption and Separation

In our previous work, we showed the successful separation of benzene and cyclohexane on an isostructural framework based on nitroterephthalate ligand [Li2Zn2(bpy)(NO2-bdc)3]. The driving force of the separation process was narrow channels combined with the formation of specific interactions between the functional groups of the ligands of the framework and the guest benzene molecules. Since compound NIIC-30(Ph) has unique narrow tortuous channels that are capable of forming several types of weak interactions with a benzene molecule, the obvious next step in the study was an attempt to carry out the selective separation of benzene and cyclohexane. First, individual vapor sorption isotherms for benzene and cyclohexane at 298 K were obtained (). Both isotherms are type I (IUPAC), which is typical for microporous materials. Some noticeable adsorption-desorption hysteresis observed at low relative pressures for both benzene and cyclohexane should probably be attributed to the effect of a narrow and tortuous channel aperture. The capacity in the case of benzene was found to be 59 mL/g (2.5 mmol/mmol) and only 15 mL/g (0.6 mmol/mmol) in the case of cyclohexane. The resulting volume ratio is 4, which is a rather significant difference that prompted us to investigate the adsorption properties of NIIC-30(Ph) for the real separation of mixtures of benzene and cyclohexane, as well as to elucidate the nature of such remarkable selectivity in detail.

Water Adsorption Properties of Zirconium MOFs

Condensation Pressure and Uptake Capacity

The water isotherms are shown in Figure  (Figures S30-S39 in ). For comparison, we first studied the water uptake properties of the prototypical Zr-MOF, UiO-66 (Figure a, black squares), and compared it to data reported by other researchers. The water isotherm of UiO-66 (group 1) has a sigmoidal shape with a moderate hysteresis loop at P/P 0 = 0.3-0.4. Maximum water uptake at 25 °C reaches 535 cm3 g-1 (43 wt %) at P/P 0 = 0.9 (Table ). These results, recorded on a volumetric instrument (uptake vs P/P 0), show the same trend as those previously reported and measured on a gravimetric system (uptake vs relative humidity, RH%). 

The water isotherm of MOF-801-SC measured at 25 °C is shown in Figure a, blue squares. The adsorbed amount of water gradually increases with increasing pressure up to P/P 0 = 0.05, followed by abrupt water uptake in the pressure range from P/P 0 = 0.05 to 0.1, and the maximum uptake is 350 cm3 g-1 (28 wt %) at P/P 0 = 0.9. The step pressure is much lower than that of UiO-66, indicating a higher water affinity for this material. A similar trend is observed by MOF-801-P (Figure a, red squares), while the maximum water uptake is now 1.3 times greater than MOF-801-SC [450 cm3 g-1 (36 wt %) at P/P 0 = 0.9]. This difference in maximum uptake between the two forms of MOF-801 was also observed in the N2 sorption measurements, and we attribute this to the possibility of a large amount of missing linker defects in MOF-801-P. MOF-802 shows a type I isotherm (Figure a, green squares). Although this compound does not show significant N2 and Ar uptake, the total water uptake is 100 cm3 g-1 (8.0 wt %) at P/P 0 = 0.9, indicating that the pore is large enough to allow inclusion water molecules due to its smaller kinetic diameter (2.6 Å).

The water isotherms for group 2 MOFs display significant steps with a hysteresis loop (Figure b). The limited water uptake at lower pressure from these steps indicates that the affinity of water to the MOF surface is low. This is related to the hydrophobicity of the organic linker; therefore, higher water vapor pressure is required to induce the pore filling. This is clearly illustrated by the behavior of PIZOF-2, which has a large pore diameter and does not take up water up to P/P 0 = 0.7. Once the uptake starts, it reaches a total water storage capacity of 850 cm3 g-1 (68 wt %) at P/P 0 = 0.9. This high uptake capacity at high relative pressure indicates a strong correlation between porosity and total water uptake (Figure S50 in ). The maximum uptake of DUT-67 and MOF-808 is 625 cm3 g-1 (50 wt %) and 735 cm3 g-1 (59 wt %), respectively. DUT-67 shows several steps in its isotherm, which can be correlated to the filling of the variously sized cavities that are present in this structure. MOF-841 shows an isotherm with a steep adsorption commencing at P/P 0 = 0.2 and reaching 550 cm3 g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.3 (640 cm3 g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.9).

In the case of group 3 MOFs, MOF-804 shows a type I isotherm profile (Figure c, red circles), while sigmoid isotherms are observed for the larger pore materials MOF-805 and MOF-806 (Figure c, blue and green circles, respectively). All three MOFs in this group show relatively low maximum uptakes, compared to the other studied MOFs: MOF-804 has a maximum uptake of 295 cm3 g-1 (24 wt %) at P/P 0 = 0.9, while MOF-805 and MOF-806 have a maximum uptake of 415 cm3 g-1 (33 wt %) and 425 cm3 g-1 (34 wt %), respectively. 

Temperature Dependency of Water Uptake

Since water adsorption is an exothermic process, a large amount of heat can be utilized if the adsorption enthalpy is large. With that in mind, released heat can increase the temperature in adsorbent beds so that the uptake capacity can be drastically influenced by this temperature change. Therefore, we have measured the water isotherms for the best performers, MOF-801-P and MOF-841, at various temperatures between 15 to 55 °C (Figure S52, S54 in ). These isotherms show that the maximum uptake capacity is not significantly influenced by the temperature, indicating that water molecules are easily condensed within the MOF pores. We have estimated the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of water from the isotherms measured at various temperatures (Figures S53, S55 in ). The Q st value in the low water coverage range for MOF-841 is around 50 kJ mol-1, which remains nearly constant throughout the entire adsorption process, and represent 25% greater energy than the latent energy of water (40.7 kJ mol-1). The Q st value for MOF-801-P is even greater than for MOF-841, approximately 60 kJ mol-1.

Applications to Thermal Battery and Water Delivery in Remote Desert Regions

With these values, we can estimate how much heat can be stored in 15 kg of MOF-801-P. Assuming that the storage capacity and Q st of MOF-801-P are 20 wt % (at P/P 0 = 0.1) and 60 kJ mol-1, respectively, the total heat expected to be released is 10 MJ. If such a system is operated for 1 h with 65% efficiency, the power capability is equivalent to 1.8 kW: a value approaching the 2.5 kW power target for typical thermal batteries as set by DOE.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Structural Characterization of 1 

The solvothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, tipb, and H2adc in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) resulted in the formation of red prismatic crystals of 1. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that only one crystallographically independent CoII center is involved in the fundamental asymmetric unit. CoII locates in the center of a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, defined by three nitrogen atoms from three independent tipb ligands and three oxygen atoms from two different adc2- ligands (Figure S1). Each tipb ligand connects three CoII atoms, affording a 63 layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure S2). The 63 layers packed in an ABCD fashion were interconnected by adc2- ligands to give an overall three-dimensional (3D) framework with one-dimensional (1D) channels (0.96 × 0.73 nm in size) along the c axis (). After removing the DMF and H2O molecules from the channels, PLATON calculations show that the porous structure of 1 composes a void of 3706.0 Å3 that represents 35% per unit cell volume [10586.0 Å3]. Taking into account the vdW surface, the free volume is 5352.4 Å3, occupying ~51% volume of a unit cell. Topology analysis (see the Supporting Information for more details) revealed that the framework of 1 could be simplified into a rare self-interpenetrated gra net (Figure S4). Additionally, a stability test confirmed that 1 has high thermal and chemical stability (see the Supporting Information for more details).

Selective Gas Adsorptions

In order to characterize the nature of the pores and gas adsorption properties of 1, isotherms are measured for N2, H2, O2, CH4, and CO2. The N2 adsorption isotherm of activated 1 is measured at 77 K (Figure S10). It shows a classic type I isotherm with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 514 m2 g-1 and Langmuir surface area of 680 m2 g-1. The fit of the adsorption data to the Horvath-Kawazoe method demonstrated the pore width distribution from about 0.5 to 0.9 nm (Figure S11).

At 195 K, 1 exhibits a type I isotherm toward CO2 gas and gives an uptake of 28.51 wt % (145 cm3 g-1 at STP) at 620 mmHg. Most interestingly, 1 shows high adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2 and O2 as shown in . The adsorption selectivities are calculated via ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST). The CO2/N2 (in a 15:85 molar ratio) selectivity is estimated as 2094 at 195 K (80 KPa) and 27.8 at 273 K (100 KPa). The predicted CO2/CH4 selectivity is 113 at 195 K (80 KPa), 7.4 at 273 K (100 KPa), and 5.4 at 303 K (100 KPa) from equimolar gas-phase mixtures (Figures S14-16). At 303 K, almost no N2 and O2 is adsorbed (Figure S13). It is insignificant to calculate the selectivity.

This is verified by periodic DFT calculations (see the Supporting Information for more details): The calculated interaction energy is -4.2 kcal/mol for N2, -6.2 kcal/mol for CH4, and -7.8 kcal/mol for CO2. The calculated values are in good agreement with the experimental results and can be attributed to the effect of the regional electric field. Notably, the dipole moments play more important roles than the quadrupole moments in this case.
