The construction of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable electrocatalysts is a significant challenge for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, we report a facile strategy to fabricate ultrathin metal-organic framework (MOF) nanosheet arrays doped with two rare-earth elements, Y and Ce, and self-supported on nickel foam (NF) to enhance the HER and OER performance by constructing abundant active sites and bimetallic synergistic effects. The NiYCe-MOF/NF features an ultrathin nanosheet array structure and is uniformly and richly codoped by Y and Ce. When it was explored as both the anode and cathode electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, it achieved 10 mA cm-2 at 136 and 245 mV for the HER and OER in an alkaline electrolyte, respectively. Notably, an extremely low cell voltage of 1.54 V was required to achieve 100 mA cm-2 in 1.0 M KOH solution, making it a promising substitute for noble-metal catalysts.

Herein, we report the synthesis of Y- and Ce-doped ultrathin MOF nanosheet array electrocatalysts by a simple hydrothermal method using Ni-MOF as a template. The obtained NiYCe-MOF/NF was employed as a bifunctional electrocatalyst to explore the overall water splitting. In particular, the structural characterizations verified that the doping of rare-earth atoms at the Ni sites induced electron transfer to the Ni sites. Benefiting from the unique electronic and structural features of the constructed catalyst, the resulting NiYCe-MOF/NF showed excellent electrochemical HER and OER activities with overpotentials of 136 and 245 mV at 10 mA cm-2, respectively, which are significantly better than those of previously reported Ni-MOF-based catalysts.

XANES and EXAFS were measured to further explore the chemical states of typical Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF using Ni foil, NiO, and Ni(OH)2 as references. As shown in a, the peaks of the samples located at approximately 8349 eV in the pre-edge region can be attributed to the dipole-forbidden but quadrupole-allowed transition from 1s to 3d, which were equivalent to the NiO benchmark. The positions of the rising edges of the samples compared to the reference value of the Ni foil indicated that the oxidation state of Ni was between Ni0 and NiII. Meanwhile, the rising-edge positions of Ni-MOF were negatively shifted compared to those of NiO, while NiYCe-MOF showed a similar trend. This phenomenon indicated that some electrons were transferred to the site of Ni after the introduction of Y and Ce, which may be due to the rearrangement of electron distribution caused by the interaction of Ni with rare-earth elements. As presented in b, the FT-EXAFS intensities of all the corresponding peaks for the NiYCe-MOF were decreased relative to those of Ni foil, NiO, Ni(OH)2, and Ni-MOF control samples, indicating an increase in the coordination number of the Ni atoms. The EXAFS spectra of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF showed a main peak at 1.62 Å, corresponding to Ni-O coordination, which indicated that Ni ions were dominant in the oxidation state. The above results showed that the coordination number of the Ni-O shell remained nearly constant after Y and Ce codoping, suggesting a well-preserved stability structure. At the same time, the maximum intensities of Ni states in the WT contour map of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF were also significantly different from those of Ni foil and NiO (c-f), suggesting that the Y and Ce heteroatoms were successfully doped into the Ni-MOF matrix. g shows that NiYCe-MOF exhibited a highly abundant porous structure along with the highest absorption capacity, resulting in the highest specific surface area (124.6 m2/g); additionally, the specific surface areas of Ni-MOF, NiCe-MOF, and NiYCe-MOF were 106.4, 112.0, and 94.2 m2/g, respectively (Figure S13). In addition, the porous structure of NiYCe-MOF further exhibited a hierarchical porous size, extending from nanometers to sub-micrometers, with an average pore size of 30 nm (see the inset in g). These results indicated that NiYCe-MOF contained a substantial number of mesopores, which favored the mass transfer process.

The electrocatalytic performances of the samples were evaluated in 1.0 M KOH solution with a typical system of commercial Pt/C (20 wt %) and RuO2 catalysts as benchmarks. The quantitative analysis data of doping elements and the amounts of catalyst loadings are detailed in Figured S14-S16 in the Supporting Information. A representative LSV test (a) shows that NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited superior OER activity compared with Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, and NiCe-MOF/NF. Even the OER performance of NiYCe-MOF/NF is significantly better than that of commercial RuO2. Likewise, the line-fitting Tafel plot of 65 mV dec-1 for NiYCe-MOF/NF in b was lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, NiCe-MOF/NF, and commercial RuO2, indicating the more effective reaction kinetics of NiYCe-MOF/NF for the OER. As shown in c, a chronopotentiometric test was employed to estimate the stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF. The retention rate of the initial catalytic activity can reach 94% after 100 h at 100 mA cm-2, while NiYCe-MOF/NF a suffered slight performance degradation (10%) at 200 mA cm-2. The above analysis results illustrated that NiYCe-MOF/NF possessed excellent stability in the long-term OER operation process. As shown in Figure S17, the EIS of the samples showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited a small polarization resistance and demonstrated faster catalytic kinetics and an enhanced electron transfer rate relative to Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, and NiCe-MOF/NF due to the abundant active catalytic sites and the synergistic effect between different metal centers. In addition, the electrochemical active surface areas (ECSAs) were also calculated by measuring the Cdl values from CV curves (d and Figure S18). NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited a Cdl value of nearly 36.5 mF cm-2, higher than those of Ni-MOF/NF (4.1 mF cm-2), NiY-MOF/NF (25.9 mF cm-2) and NiCe-MOF/NF electrodes (29.8 mF cm-2), indicating that NiYCe-MOF/NF was equipped with more active sites. The mass activity (the current density normalized to the mass) of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 614 A g-1 at 1.5 V vs RHE, which was approximately 6-fold higher than that of RuO2 (e). The corresponding specific activity (the current density normalized to the ECSA) of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 22.6 mA cm-2, which was 7 times higher than that of the commercial RuO2 catalyst. In contrast, Ni-MOF/NF had almost no catalytic activity toward the OER. As shown in f and Table S1, the as-prepared NiYCe-MOF/NF showed remarkable catalytic performance compared with state-of-the-art RuO2 and other recently reported OER electrocatalysts, suggesting that NiYCe-MOF/NF was a promising substitute for noble-metal electrocatalysts.

As shown in a, the HER activity was first evaluated by LSV at 10 mV s-1; NiYCe-MOF/NF showed the highest HER activity with the lowest overpotential of 136 mV vs RHE, which was obviously better than those of Ni-MOF/NF (260 mV), NiY-MOF/NF (236 mV), and NiCe-MOF/NF (180 mV) at 10 mA cm-2. Moreover, the catalytic HER reaction kinetics were investigated by fitting the corresponding Tafel slopes to the LSV curves (b). The Tafel slope of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 74 mV dec-1, lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF (148 mV dec-1), NiY-MOF/NF (126 mV dec-1), and NiCe-MOF/NF (91 mV dec-1), indicating a more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics for the HER. The HER durability of NiYCe-MOF/NF was also tested by running 3000 consecutive LSV cycles and long-term chronopotentiometric tests over 100 h (c). In all, 3000 LSV cycles under a low-voltage window showed negligible current degeneration. Meanwhile, the chronopotentiometric test results showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF can be stably operated for more than 100 h with almost no attenuation.

To evaluate the electrocatalytic stability of the constructed samples in practical applications, overall water-splitting measurements were performed in a two-electrode cell (d). As shown in e, NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited excellent overall water-splitting performance with a total cell voltage of 1.54 V at 100 mA cm-2, which was obviously better than those of NiY-MOF/NF (1.68 V) and NiCe-MOF/NF (1.59 V). Furthermore, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited impressive durability for the overall water-splitting reaction at different current densities from 10 to 150 mA cm-2. f shows that the water electrolysis voltage of NiYCe-MOF/NF can not only steadily increase with the increasing current density but also return to the initial state, suggesting fast recoverability. g shows that the current density can be kept stable at 300 mA cm-2 during a long-term stability test over 240 h; moreover, the surface morphology of NiYCe-MOF nanosheet arrays showed almost no change after a durability test for 240 h as shown in the insets. The chemical compositions of NiYCe-MOF were also deeply investigated after a 240 h long-term test (Figures S19 and S20). It can be seen that the morphology of NiYCe-MOF can still be well maintained, and the XRD pattern of NiYCe-MOF/NF after testing showed that the characteristic peaks were still tightly held without the formation of the other phase, demonstrating that the MOF structure effectively prevented the corrosion of the metal. The elemental mapping and EDS showed that C, O, Ni, Y, and Ce were uniformly distributed throughout the region. Additionally, NiYCe-MOF/NF also showed superior durability in alkaline solution after 3000 CV cycles (h). The above analysis results demonstrated the excellent stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF during the overall water-splitting process. The ultralow total cell voltage and excellent stability for overall water splitting may provide a potential candidate for practical industrial applications.

In summary, we reported a facile method for the fabrication of ultrathin MOF nanosheet arrays doped with Y and Ce self-supported on NF to enhance performances toward the HER and OER. The doping of Y and Ce atoms into Ni-MOF has been proven to promote water-splitting performance by creating a bimetallic synergistic effect and constructing abundant active sites. The electronic structure of NiYCe-MOF/NF was controllably tailored by Y and Ce doping. When it was explored as an OER electrocatalyst, it achieved a low overpotential of 245 mV and a low Tafel slope of 65 mV dec-1 at 10 mA cm-2. Additionally, it also exhibited outstanding HER activity with a moderate overpotential of 136 mV at 10 mA cm-2. Notably, the required cell voltage was 1.54 V to achieve 100 mA cm-2 when NiYCe-MOF/NF was used as both the anode and cathode electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. Meanwhile, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited superior stability during a 240 h durability test. The proposed doping of rare-earth elements into MOF catalysts to boost overall water splitting provides new insight into the design and synthesis of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable MOF catalysts for other electrocatalysis fields.

TiO2 is a most promising anode candidate for rechargeable Na-ion batteries (NIBs) because of its appropriate working voltage, low cost, and superior structural stability during chage/discharge process. Nevertheless, it suffers from intrinsically low electrical conductivity. Herein, we report an in situ synthesis of Co2+-doped TiO2 through the thermal treatment of metal organic frameworks precursors of MIL-125(Ti)-Co as a superior anode material for NIBs. The Co2+-doped TiO2 possesses uniform nanodisk morphology, a large surface area and mesoporous structure with narrow pore distribution. The reversible capacity, Coulombic efficiency (CE) and rate capability can be improved by Co2+ doping in mesoporous TiO2 anode. Co2+-doped mesoporous TiO2 nanodisks exhibited a high reversible capacity of 232 mAhg-1 at 0.1 Ag1-, good rate capability and cycling stability with a stable capacity of about 140 mAhg-1 at 0.5 Ag1- after 500 cycles. The enhanced Na-ion storage performance could be due to the increased electrical conductivity revealed by Kelvin probe force microscopy measurements.

N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms measurements were adopted to investigate the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore size distribution of the as-prepared samples, as presented in . It is clearly shown that all the samples have a type IV curves. The BET surface area and the pore volume of antase TiO2 were determined to be 101 m2 g-1 and 0.20 cm3 g-1, respectively. As shown in b, TiO2 possesses a narrow pore size distribution located aroud 6 nm according to BJH analysis. TiO2-16Co has a larger surface area (146 m2 g-1) and pore volume (0.36 cm3 g-1). As to TiO2-32Co, it exhibits a largest surface area (175 m2 g-1) and pore volume (0.37 cm3 g-1). TiO2-32Co has a similar pore size with TiO2-16Co, where is mostly located aroud 5 nm. Accordingly, the obove three samples exhibit a relatively uniform mesoporous structure. The pore size of both the prepared TiO2 and Co2+ doped TiO2 with mesoporous structure is larger than that of the previous report of porous TiO2 (1-2 nm) derived from MIL-125(Ti). It is notable that a relatively large pore size is necessary for Na-ion intercalation, which is also in favor of cycling stability for NIBs. 

It is demostrated that electrode material with a high electrical conductivity is crucial for Na-ion batterites with enhanced electrochemical performances. Generally, an electron escaping from the material was hindered by the forces of interaction with a crystal lattice, leading to the creation of a potential barrier on a material surface. Herein, surface potential of the samples was measured by means of Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy (KPFM). In this measured technique, surface potential is defined by the work function difference between the tip and the sample:       V   cpd   =     W   tip   -   W   sample     e     Here, W tip and W sample are work functions of the tip and the sample, respectively. V cpd is the contact potential difference, e is the elementary charge. As show in a, the surface potential map of Au foil was measured as a reference sample. b-d depicts the surface morphology and the corresponding surface potential maps of TiO2 and TiO2-32Co, respectively (the corresponding measurements of TiO2-16Co are shown in Figure S5). It is observed that the surface potential of TiO2 increased with the doping content of Co2+ and TiO2-32Co has a largest surface potential among them, suggesting a decreased work functions after, and thus leading to improved electrical conductivity. Furthermore, the work functions of TiO2, TiO2-16Co and TiO2-32Co were calculated, as shown in f. It is notable that the work function decreased from 5.02 eV for TiO2 to 4.74 eV for TiO2-32Co (4.87 eV for TiO2-16Co).

Recently, MOFs have been also explored as the ideal templates for the synthesis of porous metal oxide nanostructures with good electrochemical properties. Herein, mesoporous TiO2 doped by Co2+ with uniform morphology was constructed from metal organic frameworks precursors, which would be expected with a good performance for NIBs. As shown in a, a couple of redox peaks between 0.5 and 1.0 V vs Na/Na+ with a scan rate of 0.5 mV s-1 are observed from cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement, which would be ascribed to the reversible reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+. CV curve at the first cycle reveals the irreversible side reactions with electrolyte at the first reduced process. Nevertheless, the subsequent cycles basically have the same profile, suggesting a reversible Na-ion storage process. b-d shows the charge-discharge profiles of TiO2-32Co, TiO2-16Co, and TiO2 from the selective cycles at 0.1 Ag1- in the voltage window of 0.01-3 V. All the samples did not exhibit a well-defined voltage plateaus during charge/discharge process, which is typical for TiO2 anode for NIBs. TiO2-32Co displays a discharge capacity of 498 mAh g-1 and charge capacity of 232 mAhg-1 at the first cycle. The first charge capacity of TiO2-16Co and TiO2 is 184 and 168 mAhg-1, respectively. Thus, the reversibe capacity of TiO2-16Co is larger than that of TiO2, and TiO2-32Co is largest among them. The first Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 47%, 43%, and 38% were obtained for TiO2-32Co, TiO2-16Co, and TiO2, respectively. Generally speaking, the three samples all dispaly a large irreversible capacity at the first cycle, which could be mainly ascribed to the formation of a solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) formation of TiO2 accroding to the previous report. Nevertheless, The reversible capacity and CE could be improved after Co2+ doping, which may be due to the smaller work functions.

 a shows the rate capability of TiO2, TiO2-16Co, and TiO2-32Co. The electrodes were cycled for the initial five cycles at 0.1 Ag1-, and the current density gradually increased to 2 Ag1-, and finally returned to 0.2 Ag1-. Although all the three samples display a relatively low (<50%) first Coulombic efficiency, it will increased to 98% after 5 cycles. The reversible capacity (average) of TiO2 is about 168, 140, 105, 77, and 43 mAhg-1 at the current density of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 Ag1-, respectively. TiO2-16Co exhibits a larger reversible capacity than that of TiO2. It is notable that the reversible capacity of TiO2-32Co is up to 220, 193, 156, 121, and 94 mAhg-1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 Ag1-, respectively. Therefore, the reversible capacity of TiO2-32Co is largest capacity among them, which also demonstates a high rate performance. This may be due to the largest surface area and pore volume, as well as the smallest thickness, which can provide most electrochemical active sites and short ions/electronics diffusion path, leading to improved Na-ion storage capacity and high rate performance. At the same time, the increased electrical conductivity due to the oxygen vacancies would also be favor for the rate capability, which will be discussed in the following text. b presents the cycling performance of the above three samples at 0.1 Ag1-. The reversible capacity of 127, 141, and 170 mAhg-1 could be maintained after 100 cycles for TiO2, TiO2-16Co and TiO2-32Co, respectively. The long-term cycling performance of TiO2-32Co was shown in c. It is notable that the reversible capacity starts at 162 mAhg1 and still maintains at 139 mAhg-1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 Ag1-, suggesting excellent cycling stability. These results suggest that the prepared mesoporous anatase TiO2 derived from metal-organic frameworks basically exhibited a very good cycling stability and rate capability for Na-ion storage.

AC impedance measurements were performed on the fresh batteries made of TiO2, TiO2-16Co, and TiO2-32Co to investigate their characterizations of electrochemical performance for Na-ion storage. As presented in d, the Nyquist complex plane impedance plots are composed of the electrolyte resistance (R s) at high frequencies, a depressed semicircle at the middle frequencies reflected the impedance of the charge transfer reaction (R ct) and a slope at low frequencies arising from the Warburg impedance (W) corresponded to the Na+ diffusion in the electrode. By fitting the impedance data, the R ct of 521, 332, and 273 Ω was obtained for TiO2, TiO2-16Co, and TiO2-32Co, respectively. Thus, it is verified that the R ct of mesoporous TiO2 decreased with the increasing content of Co2+ doping, which could be due to the increase of oxygen vacancies caused by heteroatom doping, leading to the decrease in work functions. Besides, the large surface area and pore volume can offer abundant electrode-electrolyte interfaces to store sodium ions, which may be in favor of kinetic performance. The crystal structure of Co2+-doped mesoporous TiO2 electrode during chage/discharge process was sudied by XRD, the results are shown in Figure S6. It is obseved that the TiO2 diffraction peaks become weaker compared with the pristine electrode after first discharge, which may be due to the partial transformation of anatase into a rather amorphous sodium titanate structure upon sodium insertion. In the subsequent charged process, the diffraction peaks of TiO2 can be basically recovered, suggesting its reversibility during the Na-ion insertion/extraction process.

TGA curves of three uranyl MOFs show a weight loss of 6.20, 6.35, and 5.96 (calcd 6.41, 6.28, and 6.11%) below 190 °C, respectively, suggesting the loss of dimethylamine cations. Another weight loss of 56.15, 56.75, and 58.14% (calcd 55.98, 56.80, and 58.01%) occurred during 190-568 °C, respectively. They are attributed to the destruction of the coordinated ligands. HNU-64, HNU-64-CH3 , and HNU-64-Cl display no further weight loss above 568, 466, and 494 °C, respectively (Figure S5). The results are consistent with results of elemental analysis.

In order to assess the electronic band structures and optical character of HNU-64, UV-vis absorption spectra and Mott-Schottky plots were tested (Figure S10a,b). It is found that HNU-64 has a broad absorption band in the range of 360-500 nm, suggesting the ability to capture visible light. It is also found that the band energy level of HNU-64 is in the range of -0.87 to 1.65 V, in comparison with the oxygen photoreduction potential (E red = -0.24 V vs Ag/AgCl) and amine oxidation potential (E oxi = +0.56 V vs Ag/AgCl), which indicates that HNU-64 has photocatalytic potential. Therefore, HNU-64 was explored for oxidative coupling of amines, and benzylamine was selected as the reaction substrate example. The catalytic reaction was performed under an oxygen atmosphere and 25 °C, and experimental results are listed in . With the increase of time, the conversion of benzylamine also increases. Within 7 h, benzylamine is almost completely converted to N-benzylbenzaldimine (entry 1-4) with a turnover frequency (TOF) of 3994 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1 (entry 4). Compared with the reported photocatalysts, HNU-64 shows a higher catalytic activity than inorganic semiconductor materials under similar reaction conditions and better performance than MOF NH2-MIL-125(Ti) and is comparable to other porphyrin or pyridine-based MOF photocatalysts (Table S2). In addition, HNU-64 has good recyclability. After five catalytic cycle reactions, HNU-64 still has good catalytic performance and maintains its crystal structure well (Figure S11).

The PXRD patterns confirm good crystallinity of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4), well matching the N-ZIF-8-20 and simulated one (a). In addition, the same FTIR spectra of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8-20 indicate that the four characteristic peaks belonging to the phenyl ring of PS disappeared (b), proving that PS is completely removed. HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) was further investigated by nitrogen-sorption measurements (c). HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) and ZIF-8@PS show similar type IV isotherms at P/P0 of ~0.05 and ~0.95, demonstrating the existence of mesopores in the two products, which is ascribed to the occurrence of capillary condensation in the mesopores. And it increases sharply at very low relative pressure, which is consistent with the uniform microporous characteristics of ZIF-8. This confirms that micropores and mesopores of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) keep unchanged after etching. The distributions of micropores, mesopores,  and macropores of the products were tested by NLDFT, BJH, and mercury intrusion porosimetry. As shown in d-f, the formed mesopores and macropores have sizes of about 9 and 400 nm, respectively. The formation of mesopores is due to the close arrangement of N-ZIF-8-20 particles in the spray drying process. Moreover, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) has the BET surface area and pore volume of 1646.3 m2 g-1 and 1.28 cm3 g-1, respectively, which slightly increase compared with those of N-ZIF-8-20 (1537.7 m2 g-1 and 0.95 cm3 g-1) (SI Figure S4). As a result, HP-ZIF-8 including macro-meso-microporous structure is thus obtained after etching. TGA and DTG results (SI Figure S5) of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) indicate that HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) decomposes thermally at 600 °C to form zinc oxide. Under the same treatment conditions, the weight losses of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8-20 are similar. SEM image, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) after being calcined at 300 °C (SI Figure S6) prove that the skeleton can maintain thermal stability at this temperature.

Knoevenagel Reaction Performance

To further demonstrate the structure advantage of HP-ZIF-8 with macro-meso-microporous structures, the catalytic experiments were performed based on the Knoevenagel reaction. As shown in a, HP-ZIF-8 exhibits significantly enhanced activities compared with M-ZIF-8 (SI Figure S9). The benzaldehyde can be completely converted in 3 h for the HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8-20, whereas only 72% conversion is achieved for M-ZIF-8 after 8 h (SI Figure S10). Furthermore, with the increased macropore diameter of HP-ZIF-8-20 from 100 to 400 nm, the reaction efficiency increases and the reaction time is obviously shortened from 6 to 3 h. The obvious difference in catalytic performances suggests that the improved catalytic efficiency may benefit from the unique pore structure and larger BET surface area of HP-ZIF-8 (SI Table S1 and SI Figure S11), which offer larger channels to accelerate the diffusion of molecules in the material. Compared with the traditional microsized ZIF-8, HP-ZIF-8 provides more accessible active sites. Compared to N-ZIF-8-20, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) has similar catalytic efficiency that the conversion of benzaldehyde is completed within 3 h. However, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) exhibits much better recyclability than N-ZIF-8-20. HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) can be recycled at least five times (b), and the conversion of benzaldehyde only decreases from 96.1 to 82.9% in 3 h. In contrast, a decrease of >5% in catalytic performance is observed in every following run for N-ZIF-8-20 and decreases to 60% after 5 cycles. Owing to the small particle size of N-ZIF-8-20 and wall hanging in the Knoevenagel reaction process, N-ZIF-8-20 is difficult to be centrifuged in the recovery process, which is the main reason for its poor recyclability. The PXRD pattern and SEM image show the pristine and constructed hierarchical porous structures are both well preserved after catalytic cycling (c,d). As shown in d,e, the BET surface area and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) after reaction are about 1634 m2 g-1 and 7 nm, respectively, which are not much different from those before reaction.

Adsorption Isotherms

Adsorption isotherms of the C8 alkylaromatics and n-octane at 70 °C, 110 °C, and 150 °C are shown in Figure . Large adsorption capacities, up to almost 40 wt% at 70 °C were measured, corresponding to a pore filling degree of 3.4 molecules per unit cell or 1.7 molecules per channel segment (see Figure ). At the same temperature, all isomers show a very steep isotherm. The largest adsorption capacity is measured for pX, in order followed by oX, mX, and EB. pX reaches its plateau at a partial pressure of 0.005 bar, but for the other isomers the amount adsorbed keeps on increasing over the whole experimental pressure range. It therefore cannot be ruled out that all C8 alkylaromatics reach the same adsorption capacity at sufficiently high pressures.

Compared to the C8 alkylaromatic components, significantly smaller amounts of n-octane are adsorbed under all conditions, in spite of the higher adsorption enthalpy of this component (Table ). n-Octane only reaches an adsorption capacity of 23 wt% or 1.9 molecules/unit cell at 70 °C (about 1 molecule per channel segment). This confirms the hypothesis that linear alkanes adsorb with their main carbon chain in the direction of the longest pore axis (see Figure ). Because of steric constraints, only 1 alkane molecule fits in the cross section of the pore, limiting the adsorption capacity to 1 molecule per channel segment at maximum. The number of adsorption sites for the n-alkanes is only the half of that of the C8 alkylaromatics, readily explaining the lower preexponential factor of the former molecules (Figure ).

As revealed in its N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, the activated NU-901-RT shows high porosity with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 2130 ± 50 m2/g (a). Along with the expected 12 Å micropore, the density functional theory (DFT)-calculated pore size distribution (b) shows a 27 Å mesopore with a smaller pore volume compared to the micropore. The presence of this mesopore suggests two possibilities: (1) the obtained NU-901-RT is phase impure, where a small fraction of NU-1000, a MOF constructed from identical building blocks but with large mesoporous channels (~31 Å), is present or (2) the crystals have defect sites (i.e., missing linkers/nodes) creating larger mesopores, analogous to the case of UiO-67. The PXRD pattern of NU-901-RT (Figure S2) does not exhibit a detectable peak characteristic of the (100) plane in NU-1000 (2θ = 2.5°). The cumulative pore size distribution of NU-901-RT (Figure S3b) suggests a minimum of 16 mol % NU-1000 impurity if all the apparent mesopores are from NU-1000. Yet, the PXRD pattern of a physical mixture of 16/84 mol % NU-1000/NU-901 shows a sharp peak at 2θ = 2.5° (Figure S2). Thus, we conclude that NU-901-RT may contain defect sites, presumably creating significantly larger pores due to a missing Zr6 node making the resulting mesopore comparable in dimensions to that of NU-1000 (). It is worth noting that a similar phenomenon has been observed for UiO-66 synthesized at room temperature. Supporting evidence accrues from the diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of NU-901-RT, nondefective NU-901, and the H4TBAPy organic linker (Figure S4). The CO stretches at 1700 and 1736 cm-1 observed for NU-901-RT suggest the presence of some carboxylic groups on the linker that are not coordinated to the Zr6 node. Note that whereas the same stretches were observed for the H4TBAPy linker, that of nondefective NU-901 did not exhibit the CO stretches.

Room temperature synthesis of MOFs is ideal for encapsulating NPs as thermally induced aggregation of nanoparticles can effectively be mitigated. Pt NPs, synthesized according to a reported procedure, were dispersed in 10 mL of the acetic acid/DMF/Zr6 node solution under the same conditions as listed previously. The concentration of Pt NPs in this solution is ~700 ppm. The remaining protocol of the MOF synthesis is identical to that without the NPs. The resulting composite (Pt@NU-901) possesses a slightly lower BET surface area (1650 ± 40 m2/g) when compared to NU-901-RT due to mass gain from the Pt NPs, but it retains a similar DFT pore size distribution, suggesting that the encapsulation of Pt NPs does not significantly affect the pore structure of the MOF (Figure S3c). Approximately 70% of the volumetric surface area of NU-901-RT was retained in Pt@NU-901 (i.e., from 1500 ± 40 to 1050 ± 30 m2/cm3, see the SI for details), further suggesting the retention of the porous network upon the NP encapsulation. Through an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurement, 11 ± 1 wt % loading of Pt was confirmed in Pt@NU-901. Similar wt % loading was determined through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure S7). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images show no difference in the crystallite morphology of NU-901-RT versus Pt@NU-901 (300-500 nm tear-shaped crystals), and the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image shows that in Pt@NU-901, most Pt NPs are encapsulated within MOF crystals while small amount are perhaps physisorbed onto the surface of the crystals (Figures S8 and S9). The size distribution of the NPs in the composite was confirmed to be similar to that of bare NPs, with an average diameter of 4.0 ± 0.5 nm (Figures S9 and S10). A diffuse reflectance UV-vis spectrum of Pt@NU-901 shows significant enhancement of extinction in the 500-800 nm region as compared to that of NU-901-RT (Figure S10). This is presumably a result of close packing between the NPs and the framework, resulting in high scattering. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to verify that the oxidation state of Pt in Pt@NU-901 is Pt0 (Figure S11).

As Pt NPs are known as effective alkene hydrogenation catalysts, we chose to test the propensity of Pt@NU-901 to perform hydrogenation reactions (for details in experimental, see the SI). Namely, we chose cis-stilbene as the substrate; given the 7.8 Å kinetic diameter, it should readily diffuse through the pores of NU-901 (ca. 12 × 26 Å). Indeed, when Pt@NU-901 was subjugated to the reaction condition for 1 h, a conversion of 31 ± 1% was confirmed (see Figures S13 and S14 for 1H NMR and GC-MS spectra that were used to identify the substrate/product). PXRD patterns confirm that the framework retained its crystallinity after the NP encapsulation and after the catalysis (Figure S15). N2 isotherm of the composite after catalysis also reveals that much of its porosity has been retained (Figure S16). A TEM image of the composite after catalysis (Figure S17) shows no significant agglomeration of NPs and ICP-OES measurements confirmed no detectable loss of Pt. In comparison, bare Pt NPs undergo rapid agglomeration in the reaction mixture, as shown by SEM and TEM images (Figures S18 and S19). Consequently, after 1 h, no detectable catalysis was observed. When a composite with Pt NPs only on the exterior of the crystals (named Pt/NU-901; for synthesis and characterization, see the SI) was instead used as a catalyst, conversions ranging from 25 to 42% were detected. The high variability is attributed to the uncontrolled MOF crystal agglomeration induced due to the low solubility of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) surfactants on the NPs in the reaction mixture, as shown by the TEM image (Figure S20). We note that the individual NPs retain their 3-4 nm size after catalysis (Figure S20). Pt/NU-901 also retained its crystallinity as shown by the PXRD pattern in Figure S21. Control reactions, without the Pt NPs and without the parent framework, show no catalytic behavior, thus confirming that both the MOF and the Pt NPs are necessary to achieve hydrogenation.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description of 1 

Single crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 is constructed from infinite Cd-O-C rod as its SBUs. 1 crystallizes in the chiral triclinic space group P1. The asymmetric unit consists of six crystallographically unique Cd atoms, three X4-ligand, and six coordinated water molecules. As illustrated in Figure A, six Cd atoms have three coordination modes. The odd-numbered Cd atoms are in an octahedral geometry coordinated by two O atoms from two aqua ligands and four O atoms from four different X4- ligands (Cd-O 2.203-2.325 Å). Cd2 and Cd4 atoms are in a distorted octahedral geometry coordinated by six O atoms from four different X4- ligands (Cd-O 2.185-2.489 Å). Cd6 atom is in a trigonal bipyramidal geometry coordinated by five O atoms from four different X4- ligands (Cd-O 2.295-2.364 Å). X4- ions link each [Cd6(CO2)12(H2O)6]∞ rod in the a and b directions to nine neighboring rods, resulting in three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with two types of one-dimensional (1D) rhombic channels running along the [1 1 0] direction (Figure B,C): one is hydrophilic, with the coordinated aqua ligands aligning the channel walls and a channel size of 4.4 × 4.0 Å2. The other is hydrophobic, surrounded by aromatic rings of X4- ligands, with a size of 5.8 × 5.4 Å2. The void volume in 1 occupied by the guest solvent molecules is 42.3% calculated by the PLATON/VOID routine.

Thermal Stability

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were conducted to characterize the thermal stability of frameworks in compounds 1-3. TGA of compound 1 shows a two-step weight loss of about 18.2% starting at room temperature (RT) and finishing at 210 °C, implying the removal of water molecules first and then the trapped DMF solvent molecules. No further weight loss was observed until 350 °C at which the compound starts degrading quickly. Compound 2 shows a rapid weight loss of about 31% between RT and 150 °C, corresponding to the loss of DMF and water molecules in 2. No further weight loss was observed until 360 °C. Compound 3 shows the loss of coordinated water molecules and guest DMA molecules from RT up to 250 °C. The compound starts to decompose at 360 °C. The PXRD patterns of 1 before and after activation at 200 °C confirm the stability of the host framework upon solvent removal. However, for 2 and 3, both structures collapse after heating the sample at 150 °C (see ).

Gas Adsorption Measurements

The thermal stability of the framework of 1 upon desolvation has encouraged us to examine its gas adsorption properties. The BET surface sorption experiments were performed on desolventized 1 using nitrogen at 77 K and CO2 at 273 K in order to determine its potential use for gas separation and storage purposes. As shown in Figure A, the activated 1 displays a reversible type-I adsorption isotherm of CO2, which is typical of microporous materials. Derived from the adsorption data, 1 has the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface and Langmuir surface areas of 231 m2/g and 249 m2/g, respectively. To our surprise, no nitrogen diffusion is observed at 77 K (BET surface area <1 m2 g-1) even though the framework is stable and has seemingly adequate pore size, implying the N2 molecules are only absorbed on the surface of the material and could not enter the pores (Figure B). BET surface area measurements on 2 and 3 show negligible uptake of either N2 or CO2 and imply the frameworks become nonporous after guest removal, consistent with their PXRD measurements.

The activated 1 solid was also investigated for adsorption of CO2 and CH4 at low and high pressures at room temperature using a volumetric gas analyzer (HPVA-100). At 1 bar (Figure A), the solid sorbs 6.0 wt % of CO2 (30 mL/g at STP), six times of the uptake of CH4 (1.0 wt %, 14 mL/g at STP). From the CO2 sorption isotherm, it suggests that there is no saturation at 1 bar; therefore, high pressure adsorption measurements are performed and show complex 1 sorbs 14 wt % of CO2 at 30 bar (70 mL/g at STP, Figure B), where the CH4 uptake is 2.8 wt % (39 mL/g at STP). The selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4 in 1 could be ascribed to the higher quadrupole moment and polarizability of CO2 compared to CH4. These gas adsorption results imply complex 1 holds great potential for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation applications.

Four compounds show different dimensions and topologies. Compound 2 is developed as a highly selective and sensitive probe for the detection of picric acid in DMF solution, and K sv was calculated to be 5.9 × 104 M-1.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description of 1 

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pcca and displays a 3D coordinate framework. In the asymmetric unit of 1 (a), there exist one crystallographically identical Cd(II) center, one BDC ligand, one DPBT ligand, and two free water molecules. The Cd(II) center adopts a six-coordinated octahedron geometry (CdO4N2) by coordinating to four oxygen atoms from three BDC anions and two nitrogen atoms from two DPBT molecules. The Cd-N and Cd-O distances are in the ranges of 2.304(2)-2.334(2) Å and 2.273(2)-2.417(3) Å, respectively, which deviated from normal bond lengths found in other Cd compounds. In the BDC ligand, the two carboxylate groups display two different coordination modes: one adopts a bidentate chelating mode to link one Cd(II) ion and the other also adopts a bidentate bridging mode to combine two Cd(II) ions. Nitrogen atoms from DPBT ligands locate in the axis direction of the plane that formed by oxygen and Cd(II) atoms.

The presence of channels formed by the stacking of 2D layers in an AAA⋅⋅⋅ mode is one interesting structural feature of 2. Infinite one-dimensional channels are created along the a-axis when the parallel layers are accumulating (d). e shows the channels viewed along the c axis. The solvent-accessible volume of these channels, calculated with the PLATON program, is 458.2 Å3, or 19.3% of the total unit cell volume whose channels are occupied by many disordered DMA solvent molecules.

Crystal Structure Description of 3 

Compound 3 reveals a 3D structure and crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system of the Pcc2 group. As a shows, the asymmetric unit of 3 consists of two crystallographically identical Co(II) centers, two BDC ligands, two DPBT ligands, two free DMF molecules, and five solvent water molecules, of which some of the solvent molecules are squeezed by PLATON. The Co(II) center adopts a six-coordinated octahedral geometry (CoO4N2) by coordinating to four oxygen donors from three BDC anions and two nitrogen atoms from two DPBT molecules. The Co-O and Co-N distances are in the ranges of 1.999(3)-2.200(4) Å and 2.132(4)-2.169(4) Å, respectively, which are similar to the values found in other Co compounds. 

Photofluorescent Properties

Because compounds 1 and 2 are constructed from Cd2+ and Zn2+ ions with d10 electron and a rigid fluorescent DPBT ligand, they are highly likely to exhibit potential photoluminescence (PL) properties. Thus, the PL properties of both compounds were examined. The spectra of single-crystalline powder samples of compounds 1-4 and the DPBT ligand were recorded at room temperature. As shown in , upon excitation at 356 nm for 1 and 375 nm for 2, the maximum emission peaks of the compounds are observed at 464 and 513 nm, respectively. Compared with that of free DPBT ligand, the emission intensities of both compounds are much stronger; namely, the formation of MOFs enhances the fluorescence of the DPBT ligand, which is a typical instance of aggregation-induced emission (AIE). The emission peak of compound 1 is slightly blue shifted in comparison to that of the DPBT ligand (λem = 465 nm), which can be assigned to n-π* and/or π-π* transition. However, compound 2 is red-shifted 48 nm, which may be because of the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences in the peak positions of these compounds might be attributed to the differences in coordination environments and the metal centers.

The sensing performances of 2 for nitro compounds were investigated by PL titration experiments. The addition of nitro compounds into DMF emulsions results in a fluorescence quenching effect (b and ). The order of quenching efficiency is PA > 1,4-DNB > NB > 4-NT > 1,3-DNB > 2,4-DNT. The highest fluorescence quenching percentage is PA, which quenches the emission by as much as 99.7% when the concentration reaches 0.1 mM. However, under the same concentration, other nitro compounds exhibit indistinct changes with a QP of 10.8% for 1,4-DNB and lower values for the other four nitro compounds. These results shows that 2 as a fluorescence sensor material has great potential to selective detect PA. The relationship between the fluorescence intensities and the concentration of PA can be fitted well with a first-order exponential equation, and a K sv of 5.9 × 104 M-1 is observed for PA (R 2 = 0.999, ). It is obvious that an upward and nonlinear curve appears with an increase in the PA concentration, suggesting that there is possibly simultaneous static and dynamic quenching in the process of fluorescence quenching.As shown in b, the fluorescence emission of the emulsion without PA is 443 nm. As the concentration of PA increased, the maximum emission of the emulsion gradually shifts, which may be due to fluorescence resonance energy transfer. 

The fluorescence responses of 1 to various nitro compounds were also investigated (). Similar to 2,the incremental concentration of PA to 1 led to high and fast fluorescence quenching behavior with a QP of 74.3% at 0.1 mM. The emission of 1 almost completely disappeared when the concentration of PA was as low as 0.2 mM. However, the other five nitro compounds exhibit minor quenching effects on the fluorescence change of 1. Those results show that 1 can be applied to highly selectivity detect PA as an efficient fluorescence sensor.

In addition, we also investigated the emission decay lifetimes of both compounds. The curves () are best fit by biexponentials in emulsions. The emission decay lifetimes of compounds 1 and 2 are as follows: τ = 4.93 ns (χ2 = 1.113) for emulsion 1 and τ1 = 6.27 ns (69.35%) and τ2 = 2.83 ns (30.65%, χ2 = 0.995) for emulsion 2. The emission lifetime values of both compounds are up to nanoseconds, which indicate that both compounds can be used as fluorescence materials to detect PA and metal ions.

Thermogravimetric Analyses and Powder X-ray Diffraction

The thermal behaviors of compounds 1-4 were investigated by TGA to understand the stability of the coordinated skeletons. As shown in , because of the loss of the solvent water molecules and the collapse of the molecular skeleton, two weight losses are observed at approximately 120 and 460 °C, respectively, for compound 1. Compound 2 also shows two main steps of weight loss: one is observed from 150 to 250 °C resulting from the loss of solvent DMA molecules, and the other occurs after 370 °C, which is due to collapse of the molecular skeleton. There are three steps for compound 3; the former two steps of weight loss are in the ranges of 40-115 °C and 120-300 °C, which are attributed to the loss of the solvent water molecules and free DMF molecules. The final step is observed at higher than 350 °C, which results from the collapse of the molecular skeleton. There is only one weight loss for compound 4 in the range 460-500 °C, which results from collapse of the molecular skeleton.

Samples of the as-synthesized biocomposites were examined by PXRD, which confirmed that they were phase-pure and possessed the sodalite topology (Figure S6). The crystal size and morphology were assessed by SEM, which showed that FCAT@ZIF-8 and FCAT@ZIF-90 samples were dispersed rhombododecahedral crystals whereas some crystal intergrowth was observed for FCAT@MAF-7 (Figure S7). Gas adsorption isotherms were conducted to assess porosity, yielding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of 1205.7(21.2), 1059.2(2.0), and 1070.6(2.2) m2 g-1 for FCAT@ZIF-8, FCAT@ZIF-90, and FCAT@MAF-7, respectively (Figures S8-S10). Furthermore, comparison of the pore size distributions of the biocomposites and their corresponding neat ZIFs suggests that enzyme encapsulation does not affect the bulk pore structure of the ZIFs (Figures S8-S10). The spatial distribution of FCAT within the samples was assessed using confocal laser microscopy (CLSM) (b and Figure S12); the images show that the FCAT molecules were more homogeneously distributed throughout FCAT@MAF-7 and FCAT@ZIF-90 crystals than in FCAT@ZIF-8, in which FCAT was predominantly located in the subsurface region. The latter data is in agreement with our previous studies and shows that the hydrophilic and hydrophobic ZIFs give rise to different enzyme spatial distributions. FCAT loading in all samples was determined by tracing its fluorescence signal after dissolution in 0.1 M citric acid-sodium citrate buffer (pH 5) (Table S1). The weight percentage of enzyme encapsulated varied from 0.5 to 3.3 wt % for FCAT-on-MAF-7 to FCAT@ZIF-8, respectively (b and Table S1). It is noteworthy that higher FCAT loading in the biocomposites can be achieved by using a higher dosage of FCAT during synthesis (Table S1).

To determine the effect of framework chemistry on the performance of the encapsulated enzyme, we measured H2O2 decomposition for each of the FCAT/ZIF composites. For comparison, we also evaluated the activity of free FCAT under the same conditions. In addition, we have found that the handling conditions for the ZIF-based biocomposites can affect the integrity of the ZIF coating. For example, phosphate buffers, such as PBS, give rise to rapid decomposition of ZIF-8 crystals and we anticipate that this will affect enzyme activity studies. Consequently, we avoided exposing our biocomposites to PBS. Ongoing work in our laboratory is focused on establishing protocols for the storage, handling, and activity studies of ZIF-based biocomposites. A noteworthy result, shown in c, Figures S22-S26, and Table S2, is that FCAT@ZIF-8 composites showed no measurable catalytic activity (a,c). Furthermore, FCAT adsorbed onto the surface of ZIF-8 was also inactive (a,c). A similar phenomenon was observed in the case of fluorescence-tagged horseradish peroxidase (FHRP, Figure S39). These data are consistent with studies that show protein adsorption on hydrophobic surfaces can lead to a loss of activity and suggests recent reports of enzyme activity for FCAT@ZIF-8 may need to be re-evaluated. In contrast to the FCAT/ZIF-8 biocomposites, FCAT@MAF-7 showed comparable activity to that of free FCAT: 3.2 × 10-3 mM s-1 for FCAT@MAF-7 versus 4.4 × 10-3 mM s-1 for free FCAT (c, Figures S24 and S25). Additionally, FCAT@ZIF-90 showed a substantial reduction in activity compared to the free enzyme (1.4 × 10-3 mM s-1, c and Figure S26). We believe that the slightly slower reaction rates of FCAT-on-MAF-7 and FCAT-on-ZIF-90 compared to those of FCAT@MAF-7 and FCAT@ZIF-90 may be attributed to hindered substrate diffusion and/or changed enzyme orientation that is engendered by close packing of FCAT on the MOF surface (surface-crowding effect). To provide a more comprehensive comparison of the FCAT/MOF biocomposite with free FCAT, we evaluated the Michaelis-Menten kinetic parameters (Figure S28 and Table S2). The K m and k cat values for FCAT@MAF-7 are 0.99 mM and 950 s-1, respectively (Table S2), which are comparable to those of free FCAT and superior to those of FCAT@ZIF-90 (Figure S28 and Table S2). The loss of activity for the FCAT/ZIF-8 biocomposites could be due to a number of factors, such as (1) the presence of the acetate anion inhibiting the FCAT activity, (2) binding of HmIM to the iron-heme active site of FCAT during the synthesis process, (3) denaturation of the enzyme during the encapsulation or surface immobilization process as a result of hydrophobic interactions between FCAT and ZIF-8, and/or (4) hindered diffusion of the substrate (H2O2)/product (H2O) by the hydrophobic framework of ZIF-8 (for FCAT@ZIF-8). Importantly, CAT (i.e., not fluorescein tagged) was found to be inactive for the CAT@ZIF-8 composites (Figure S28), indicating the deactivation of FCAT in/on ZIF-8 is not ascribed to the enzyme surface functionalization.

Given that the catalytic activity of the encapsulated enzymes is preserved for FCAT@MAF-7 and FCAT@ZIF-90 (c), we sought to examine the capacity of these ZIF coatings to protect the enzymes from inhospitable environments. This "shielding" effect has been previously observed for ZIF-90; thus, it serves as an excellent benchmark material for FCAT@MAF-7. To assess the capacity of the ZIF coating to protect the biological cargo from elevated temperatures, we measured the enzymatic activity for FCAT, FCAT@MAF-7, and FCAT@ZIF-90 after incubating the catalysts at 50, 60, and 70 °C (a and Figure S29), along with a room temperature (RT, 25 ± 1 °C) control experiment. As anticipated, without protection via encapsulation, the activity of free FCAT decreased dramatically from 3.7 × 10-3 mM s-1 at RT to 0.9 × 10-3 mM s-1 after treatment at 70 °C. Consistent with previous studies, ZIF-90 provides a degree of protection for embedded FCAT: ca. 80 and 65% of its original activity was retained after exposure to 50 and 60 °C, respectively. Notably, FCAT@MAF-7 offered far superior protection to elevated temperatures than ZIF-90, retaining 79% of its original activity after exposure to a temperature of 70 °C compared to 24% and 25% for FCAT and FCAT@ZIF-90, respectively. We then exposed the ZIF-based biocomposites to urea, a chaotropic agent that engenders loss of biological function by unfolding proteins. a shows that free FCAT retained only 8% of its original activity after contact with urea; however, FCAT@MAF-7 and FCAT@ZIF-90 maintained 89% and 48% of their original activity, respectively. It is worth noting that analogous experiments employing FCAT-on-MAF-7 and FCAT-on-ZIF-90 led to essentially complete deactivation of the surface-adsorbed protein (Figure S30). Thus, by exposing FCAT@MAF-7 and FCAT@ZIF-90 to urea, we were observing only enzymatic activity from encapsulated enzyme. In the presence of protease (2 mg mL-1 for 4 h at RT) FCAT@MAF-7 retained 85% of its original activity compared to only 14% for free FCAT and 19% for FCAT@ZIF-90 (a and Figure S31). Both MAF-7 and ZIF-90 possess Å-sized pore apertures that would size-exclude the protease and prevent contact with the embedded enzyme. These observations are commensurate with urea treatment and is again presumably due to the deactivation of the surface-adsorbed enzyme, which is more significant in FCAT@ZIF-90 (Figure S31). Finally, both MAF-7 and ZIF-90 protect the embedded FCAT from organic solvents (a). Specifically, FCAT@MAF-7 maintained 96% and 64% of its original activity after exposure to dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and tetrahydrofuran (THF), respectively. In comparison, the activity of free FCAT is significantly diminished upon exposure to these solvents (a). These experiments suggest that MAF-7 offers superior protection to enzymes than other reported ZIFs and may provide the stability necessary for the enzymes to retain their performance under commercially relevant conditions. 

Encouraged by the excellent stability of FCAT@MAF-7, we sought to investigate recyclability, a critical performance metric for practical applications. We cycled FCAT@MAF-7 ten times without an appreciable reduction in enzymatic activity (b). Furthermore, fluorescence spectroscopy confirmed negligible leaching during repeated usage (Figure S33) and PXRD analysis showed that crystallinity was retained subsequent to the cycling process (Figure S34). Lastly, we explored the generality of MAF-7 as a host for biomacromolecules by performing an analogous set of experiments on fluorescein-tagged urease, FU. After immobilization, FU@MAF-7 retained 82% of the urease activity compared to FU@ZIF-90 (21%) and FU@ZIF-8 (13%) (Figure S43). In addition, compared to ZIF-90 and ZIF-8, MAF-7 provided better protection: FU@MAF-7 maintained 61% of its original activity after heating (70 °C for 1 h) and 74% after exposure to a proteolytic enzyme (Figure S44).

X-ray Powder Diffraction and Thermogravimetric Analysis

The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of 1-Ln and 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   is consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that the duplicated samples are pure phase, which can be used for subsequent property exploration (Figure S3). 1-Ln was heated from 30 to 800 °C for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in a N2 atmosphere. 1-Ln had similar thermal stability due to its isostructural properties, and 1-Eu was taken as an example to analyze in detail. The TGA of 1-Eu showed that weight loss was 31.3% (calcd 31.5%) between 35 and 309 °C, possibly attributed to the free solvent molecules and the coordinated water molecules being removed. The frame structure existed stably between 309 and 550 °C, then the frameworks collapsed (Figures S3c and S4).

Solid-State Fluorescence Properties of 1-Ln 

The solid-state photoluminescence properties have been studied for the H3L ligand and 1-Ln complexes under ambient conditions. The photoluminescence spectra of the H3L ligand revealed the maximum (Figure S7) mission at 404 nm (λex  = 343 nm), attributed to the electron transition of π → π* after absorbing energy (). The luminescence of 1-Ln was restricted to the selection of f-f transition and the luminescence achieved by the "antenna effect" of the organic ligands. Complex 1-Tb excited at 334 nm displays narrow peaks at 489 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 544 nm (5D4 → 7F5) (strong), 582 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 618 nm (5D4 → 7F3), corresponding to the electronic transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6-3) of Tb3+ ions. Thus, 1-Tb showed a strong green fluorescence emission. Based on electron transitions of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4, 1-Eu exhibited characteristic peaks of Eu3+ at 592, 616, and 695 nm, respectively (λex  = 338 nm). The relative intensities of the 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F1 transitions are used to measure the coordination state (a). Considering the feeble symmetry of Eu3+ at 5D0 → 7F1, the intensity of the magnetic dipole transition was weak. The intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition allowed the electric dipole transition to increase, forming a sharp emission spectrum. On the contrary, a less intense wide peak was observed in the 5D0 → 7F4 transition (695 nm) (b). The single exponential decay of 1-Tb and 1-Eu were 473.75 and 365.29 μs, respectively (Figure S8). Compared with 1-Eu, the relatively lower lifetime of 1-Tb was mainly the result of the different sensitivities of these ions quenched by O-H.

Selective Sensing of Antibiotics

 1-Eu has stable red emission and excellent water stability (Figure S9a); hence, the fluorescence sensing of drugs in water by 1-Eu was studied. Eight common antibioticsSM2 (sulfadimidine), SMZ (sulfamethoxazole), AMX (amoxicillin), SFZ (sulfadiazine), FFC (florfenicol), ERM (erythromycin), MDZ, and TET (Scheme S1)()were selected in this experiment. 3 mg 1-Eu was added into 3 mL aqueous solution of different drugs (1 × 10-3 mol/L); then, it was ultrasonicated for 10 min to form uniform suspensions and the fluorescence spectra of different drugs were measured. The results show that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is significantly quenched in MDZ and TET, and the quenching efficiencies are up to 99.8 and 99.9%, respectively. For other drugs, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu also decreased to different degrees ( and S10).

In order to detect the sensitivity of 1-Eu to MDZ and TET, the blank water samples were titrated with MDZ and TET, respectively, and the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu after each titration was recorded. The result indicates that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu decreases with the increase in the concentrations of MDZ and TET. The fluorescence of 1-Eu is completely quenched when TET and MDZ are at concentrations of 0.348 and 0.306 mM, respectively (a,b). According to Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv [M]), it is possible to calculate quantitatively the quenching efficiency (I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of MDZ or TET, K sv is the quenching constant (M-1), and [M] is the concentration of MDZ or TET, respectively). The SV equation is used to determine the relationship between the concentration of MDZ or TET and fluorescence intensity. In the low-concentration range from 0 to 0.06 mM, the SV curve of MDZ or TET is virtually linearly connected. But the SV curve gradually deviates from the linear relationship with the increase in the antibiotic concentration (c,d). The nonlinear relationship of the SV curve may be attributed to energy transfer or the self-absorption of antibiotics. According to the fitting results, the K sv values of MDZ and TET are 1.5 × 104 and 1.45 × 104 M-1, respectively. Therefore, 1-Eu can be used as a promising fluorescent probe to detect MDZ and TET. According to the formula 3σ/K sv (σ is the standard deviation), the limit of detection (LOD) of MDZ and TET is 1.46 × 10-5 and 1.51 × 10-5 M, respectively, which are almost equivalent to those reported in the literature (Table S3).

UV-Vis Spectra of Nicotinic Acid and the Anderson-type (NH4)3Al(OH)6Mo6O18⋅7H2O

The free ligand nicotinic acid in ethanol solution (c = 1 × 10-3 mol⋅L-1) displays UV absorption bands at 261 nm (Figure S2, SI), which are assigned to the π → π* transition of the ligand. The molar extinction coefficient value 4.58 × 103 L⋅mol-1⋅cm-1 (261 nm) for the ligand indicates that it is an effective light-harvesting chromophore to sensitize lanthanide luminescence. The singlet state energy level 1ππ* of nicotinic acid was estimated to be 35714 cm-1 from the absorbance edge (280 nm) of its UV-vis spectrum.The UV-vis absorption spectrum of the aqueous (NH4)3Al(OH)6Mo6O18⋅7H2O (c = 2 × 10-5 mol⋅L-1) is shown in Figure S3 (SI). Two UV absorption bands appear at 208 and 242 nm, which are assigned to O → Mo charge transfer in (NH4)3Al(OH)6Mo6O18⋅7H2O. The large molar extinction coefficient values 2.93 × 104 L⋅mol-1⋅cm-1 (208 nm) and 3.28 × 104 L⋅mol-1⋅cm-1 (242 nm) for (NH4)3Al(OH)6Mo6O18⋅7H2O indicate that the ligand is a suitable light-harvesting chromophore to sensitize lanthanide luminescence. The singlet state energy level of (NH4)3Al(OH)6Mo6O18⋅7H2O was estimated by referencing its absorbance edge, which was 32680 cm-1 (306 nm) and 31546 cm-1 (317 nm), known from its UV-vis spectrum. 

Thermal Stability Analysis

For thermal stability analysis, the thermogravimetric (TG) curves of compounds 1 and 2, selected as representatives, were obtained in the temperature range from 40 to 800 °C.  shows the TG spectra of compounds 1 and 2 obtained under air flow. The results of thermogravimetric analysis showed that compounds 1 and 2 mainly experienced a two-step gradual weight loss reaction. The first weight loss of 17.57% (calcd 17.60%) and 17.67% (calcd 17.52%) for compounds 1 and 2 in the range of 40-265 °C corresponds to the removal of lattice water molecules and coordinated water molecules, respectively. A sharp weight loss of 11.37% (calcd 11.13%) in the range of 385-504 °C for compound 1 and 11.35% (calcd 11.08%) in the range of 385-532 °C for compound 2 is ascribed to the decomposition of the compounds and release of organic moieties. From the TGA curves, it is known that the compounds are not stable in air. The low thermal stability is also proved by the XRD measurement for the samples of compound 1 selected as a representive which were treated under different temperatures (Figure S4, SI). It is found that the characteristic X-ray diffraction peaks of compound 1 disappear after treatment at 120 °C, indicating its amorphous character.

The intensity of all transitions decreases as the temperature is increased from 77 K to room temperature, with very similar I 77K/I rm intensity ratios of about 2.6 and 2.8 for the 5D0 → 7F1 transitions for λex = 280 and 311 nm, respectively. No obvious shift of the peak positions indicated that the structure of compound 1 does not change with the increase of temperature. The temperature dependence of the luminescence intensity for all excitation wavelengths is similar, possibly because of the thermal relaxation of the O → M LMCT state. The Eu-O-Mo bond angle (152.789o) allows effective d1 hopping through fπ-pπ-dπ orbital mixing, resulting in inefficient energy transfer at room temperature. 

The room-temperature excitation spectrum of compound 2 (black line in a') obtained by monitoring around λ = 545 nm for Tb3+ showed two broad and strong bands at 225 and ca. 268 nm, which are ascribed to the electronic transitions of nicotinate ligands, and some peaks in the range of 300-400 nm correspond to the 7F6 → 5L10, 5D2-3 (at 352, 369, and 378 nm) intraconfigurational forbidden 4f8 → 4f8 transitions of Tb3+ ion also being detected. The absence of an excitation peak of [Al(OH)6Mo6O18]3- indicates that in contrast to the Eu analogue, the sensitization of the Tb3+ ion at room temperature is solely via the organic ligand and does not involve POM-centered LMCT states. This is due to radiationless deactivation involving Tb(III)-Mo(VI) charge transfer states leading to inefficient sensitization for Tb3+ ion, which is consistent with results from Yamase and Boskovic and their co-workers. As shown in b',c', under the excitation at 309 nm wavelength, the emission intensity of compound 2 at room temperature decreased 20 times compared to the 77 K luminescence intensity but only decreased 1.7 times at 268 nm excitation wavelength light. These results indicate more significant temperature-dependent Tb(III) sensitization for excitation through the POM compared with excitation through the nicotinate ligand.

The experimentally determined luminescence lifetimes (τobs) are 344 and 662 μs for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. The pure radiative lifetime (τR) of Eu(III) 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0-4) transitions in compound 1 is calculated to be 7080 μs by using the equation  2    1 /   τ   R   =   A   MD , 0     n   3    (   I   tot   /   I   MD   )    where A MD,0 = 14.65 s-1 is the spontaneous emission probability of the 5D0 →7F1 transition of Eu(III), n is the refractive index of the medium, and I tot/I MD is the ratio of the integrated total area of the corrected Eu(III) emission spectrum to the area of the magnetic dipole 5D0 → 7F1 transition. The intrinsic quantum yield of the Eu(III) luminescence step (ΦLn) in compound 1 is evaluated to be 4.86% by using the formula ΦLn = τobs /τ R. Thus, the ligand sensitization efficiency (ηsens) is the product of two processes involving intersystem crossing (ISC) from the first excited singlet state of the ligand to the triplet state. The energy transfer (LET) to the lanthanide is calculated as 72.84% for compound 1 by using ηsens = ΦtotΦLn, where the absolute emission quantum yield (Φtot) of ligand-sensitized lanthanide emission is obtained experimentally to be 3.54%, which is moderate as compared to those of the compounds reported in the literature.

Metal-organic framework (MOF)/polymer composites combining advantages of both materials have received significant attention in the recent years. However, the complexity and inefficiency of the current fabrication approaches have hindered their further development. Herein, we demonstrate a facile one-pot solvent crystal template strategy to efficiently fabricate ZIF-8/polyurethane (PU) composites. This method eliminated the pre-synthesis and purification of MOFs, thus greatly simplifying the fabrication process. Moreover, the solvent crystal template introduced macropores in the polymer matrix, which generated a hierarchically porous structure to facilitate the molecular diffusion in the composite. The obtained ZIF-8/PU composites exhibited an accelerated dye adsorption rate constant of 1.89 × 10-3 g mg-1 min-1, which was 2.6 times higher than that of MOF powders. The Langmuir isotherm study further confirmed favorable adsorption of dye molecules with a maximum adsorption capacity of 18.1 mg g-1.

Herein, we propose a facile one-pot solvent crystal template strategy to prepare ZIF-8/polyurethane (PU) composites with a hierarchically macro-/microporous structure. MOF precursors and polymers were dissolved in the solvent, which was then frozen and exchanged with iced water. Macropores in the polymer matrix were formed by the solvent crystal template, while micropores came from MOF particles crystalized during the process. This unique one-pot strategy not only avoided a time-consuming stepwise synthesis for the hierarchical architecture but also guaranteed a uniform MOF distribution within the polymer matrix. The obtained ZIF-8/PU composite showed good mechanical properties and enhanced adsorption performance. Compared with pristine MOF particles, the composite displayed a 2.61 times higher dye adsorption rate constant and a high equilibrium uptake of 6.42 mg g-1. Moreover, the adsorption isotherm study confirmed its behavior in accordance with the Langmuir adsorption model having a maximum adsorption capacity of 18.1 mg g-1.

Results and Discussion

The hierarchically porous ZIF-8/PU composites were fabricated by a one-pot solvent crystal template strategy, as shown in a. In brief, ZIF-8 precursors and PU were dissolved in DMSO with a mass ratio of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O/2-MeIM/PU/DMSO = 0.67:1.33:1:15, which was then frozen at -25 °C. The solvent crystallized and the polymer was expelled and solidified under this temperature, leading to a bi-continuous network. The solvent crystals were leached out by soaking in iced water, and finally, the composite was obtained after vacuum-drying. It is worth mentioning that this one-pot strategy (i) alleviated the MOF aggregation and sedimentation problem since it started from a uniform mixture of MOF precursors and the polymer, (ii) eliminated the need to prepare and disperse MOF particles separately since the growth of MOFs occurred during the fabrication process, and (iii) efficiently introduced macropores since it applied a solvent crystal template that could be easily removed. The obtained composite monolith was labeled as ZIF-8/PU(2). XRD results confirmed the formation of ZIF-8 in the composite, matching well with the simulated XRD pattern (b). Additionally, the FTIR spectrum of ZIF-8/PU(2) showed peaks at 1565, 1145, and 421 cm-1, attributed to the CN stretching and aromatic C-N stretching from 2-MeIM and the Zn-N stretching, respectively (c). The composite morphology was characterized by SEM, as shown in d. It can be observed that ZIF-8 particles were randomly dispersed in the macroporous polymer matrix. The average sizes of MOF particles and polymer macropores were estimated to be ~34 nm and ~0.64 μm, respectively (Figure S3). MOF loading was determined by TGA and calculated to be 30.4%, corresponding to a MOF conversion of 89.8% (Figure S4 and Table S1). Besides, the composite exhibited a specific surface area of 187 m2 g-1, as determined by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis (Figure S5).

Next, the effect of the initial ZIF-8 precursor amount on ZIF-8/PU composite properties was systematically investigated. ZIF-8/PU(x) represents the composites prepared with x mass portions of the initial MOF precursor (Table S1). In all the cases, PU and DMSO were kept at 1 portion and 15 portions, respectively. As the mass potion of the ZIF-8 precursor increased from 0.5 to 3, the surface of the PU matrix became rougher because more MOF particles were formed (Figure S6). The corresponding MOF loading increased from 10.4 to 37.0% with an average conversion of 85.6% (Figure S4 and Table S1). The mechanical properties of the composites increased first and then decreased, as displayed in . ZIF-8/PU(1) showed the best compression properties among all the samples with a Young's modulus of 1747 ± 150 kPa, a yield stress of 224.3 ± 7.1 kPa, and a yield strain of 11.4 ± 1.3%. Besides, the cyclic compression test was performed and the ZIF-8/PU(1) composite could maintain its mechanical behavior (Figure S7). When the amount of the initial ZIF-8 precursor increased to 2 portions, the composite still retained good mechanical properties, having a Young's modulus of 1147 ± 81 kPa, a yield stress of 94.1 ± 7.0 kPa, and a yield strain of 9.6 ± 0.4%. However, as the mass portion further increased to 3, the mechanical properties of the composite dramatically declined. This was because when a small amount of ZIF-8 was added into the composite, the compressive stress would transfer from the polymer matrix to the uniformly dispersed ZIF-8 particles, thus reinforcing the composite; however, when the amount of ZIF-8 increases to a relatively high level, some aggregation might occur and the stress could not be uniformly distributed throughout the composite, leading to a decrease in mechanical properties. Therefore, in balancing good mechanical properties and high MOF loading, ZIF-8/PU(2) could be considered a promising candidate for adsorption applications.

The macroporous network in a polymer matrix has been proven to improve the diffusion rate of guest molecules and the accessibility of MOF particles. In this work, the hierarchically porous ZIF-8/PU(2) composite was used to adsorb LY from wastewater. For comparison, the adsorption behaviors of PU and pristine ZIF-8 powder were also evaluated, as shown in . PU itself did not show any adsorption, while the other two materials exhibited similar behavior, that is, showing rapid adsorption initially and then gradually reaching their equilibrium states. However, ZIF-8/PU(2) attained the highest uptake earlier than ZIF-8 powder did (a), indicating a faster kinetics of the composite. The adsorption kinetics were then fitted with both the pseudo-first-order model and pseudo-second-order model, and the latter gave a significantly higher coefficient of determination (R2 ≥ 0.997) (b,c and ). Based on the pseudo-second-order model, the composite showed a kinetic rate constant of 1.89 × 10-3 g mg-1 min-1, which was 2.61 times higher than 7.23 × 10-4 g mg-1 min-1 of pristine ZIF-8 powder under the same condition. Furthermore, the time required to attain half of the equilibrium adsorption value (t 1/2) was 83 min for ZIF-8/PU(2), while it was much longer at 211 min for ZIF-8 powder (). Moreover, the composite possessed a dye uptake of 6.42 mg g-1 (based on the MOF mass in the composite), which was competitive with 7.85 mg g-1 of ZIF-8. The slight decrease in the dye uptake might be attributed to the partial blocking of ZIF-8 by the polymer in the composite. In addition, the composite could be recycled and retained 81% of its original uptake after three cycles (Figure S8). Finally, no structural variation could be observed on the composite, indicating its great stability (Figures S9 and S10). Therefore, the hierarchical pore structure lowered the mass transfer resistance and increased the exposure of inner surfaces, thus exhibiting a greatly improved adsorption performance.

The effect of initial concentration on LY adsorption performance of the ZIF-8/PU composite was then analyzed using the abovementioned adsorption kinetic models, as shown in  and . Similarly, the experimental results were well-fitted with the pseudo-second-order model with R2 ≥ 0.999. The rate constant, k2, decreased from 1.65 × 10-2 to 1.89 × 10-3 g mg-1 min-1 when the initial dye concentration increased from 10 to 50 mg L-1 (). This could be due to stronger competition for the adsorption sites at higher initial LY concentrations, leading to the decrease in the adsorption rate accordingly.  displays the LY adsorption isotherm study of the composite, and  lists the linear fitting parameters accordingly. The Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models have been widely applied to illustrate the organic dye adsorption onto porous materials. In this work, the isotherm adsorption data fitted better with the Langmuir model with a coefficient of determination of 0.998 (a), indicating the monolayer coverage of LY molecules on the surface of the adsorbents. Besides, it also gave the maximum LY adsorption capacity of 18.1 mg g-1. The dimensionless factor R L in all the tested concentrations was calculated to be in the range of 0-1, suggesting a favorable adsorption of LY on the composite.
