Novel side-chain-type sulfonated poly(arylene ether ketone) (SNF-PAEK) containing naphthalene and fluorine moieties on the main chain was prepared in this work, and a new amino-sulfo-bifunctionalized metal-organic framework (MNS, short for MIL-101-NH2-SO3H) was synthesized via a hydrothermal technology and postmodification. Then, MNS was incorporated into a SNF-PAEK matrix as an inorganic nanofiller to prepare a series of organic-inorganic hybrid membranes (MNS@SNF-PAEK-XX). The mechanical property, methanol resistance, electrochemistry, and other properties of MNS@SNF-PAEK-XX hybrid membranes were characterized in detail. We found that the mechanical strength and methanol resistances of these hybrid membranes were improved by the formation of an ionic cross-linking structure between -NH2 of MNS and -SO3H on the side chain of SNF-PAEK. Particularly, the proton conductivity of these hybrid membranes increased obviously after the addition of MNS. MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% exhibited the proton conductivity of 0.192 S⋅cm-1, which was much higher than those of the pristine membrane (0.145 S⋅cm-1) and recast Nafion (0.134 S⋅cm-1) at 80 °C. This result indicated that bifunctionalized MNS rearranged the microstructure of hybrid membranes, which could accelerate the transfer of protons. The hybrid membrane (MNS@SNF-PAEK-3%) showed a better direct methanol fuel cell performance with a higher peak power density of 125.7 mW/cm2 at 80 °C and a higher open-circuit voltage (0.839 V) than the pristine membrane.

FT-IR was used to further confirm the successful synthesis of MNS, and the spectra were displayed in b. Compared to pristine MIL-101, all intermediates and target MNS showed the characteristic peaks at 2934 and 3263 cm-1, ascribing to the absorption peaks for ν(CH) and ν(NH), respectively, which indicated the successful grafting of N-boc-ethylenediamine and the remain of ethylenediamine after sulfonation. In addition, the IR adsorption band at 1207 cm-1 for MIL-101-SO3H-NHBOC and MNS was assigned to the asymmetric vibration mode of -SO3H. Besides, the postsynthetic modification was also proved via XPS analysis (Supporting Information), where the sulfur XPS signal appeared at a binding energy of 168.97 eV corresponding to S6+ of the sulfonic acid group, whereas the nitrogen XPS signal appeared at a binding energy of 402.06 eV corresponding to N 1s of ethylenediamine that was attached to metal-oxygen clusters. Then, we drew a conclusion that MIL-101 was converted into MNS successfully by the postsynthetic modification. Besides, the SEM image in a shows the octahedral structure of MNS, as same as MIL-101, which has been reported by previous work. The result confirmed that MNS still retained its framework structure after modification. The thermodynamic stability of MOFs was measured by TGA (Supporting Information). The result showed that the decomposition temperature at 5% weight loss (T d5%) of MIL-101 and MNS was 200 and 280 °C, respectively. This indicated that they had good thermal stability to be used in DMFCs.

Thermal and Oxidative Stabilities and Mechanical Properties of Membranes

TGA measurements of pristine and hybrid membranes were performed to evaluate whether the membranes were thermally stable within the temperature range for applications in DMFCs. As shown in , all membranes displayed two decomposition stages. The first stage starting from 220 to 330 °C belonged to the decomposition of the grafted flexible sulfoalkyl groups on the side chain, and the second stage in the range from 400 to 650 °C was assigned to the degradation of the polymer backbone. According to the data in , all the decomposition temperatures at 5% weight loss (T d5%) of samples were higher than 230 °C. After the addition of MNS, the T d5% increased from 244.93 to 266.51 °C. It is because of the cross-linked structure formed by MNS, restraining the decomposition of the polymer matrix. Therefore, the composite membranes have good thermal stabilities to be used for DMFCs.

As summarized in , all these MNS@SNF-PAEK-XX and SNF-PAEK membranes showed higher strength properties of tensile strength (33.38-36.97 MPa) and Young's modulus (0.90-1.06 GPa) than those of tensile strength and Young's modulus of recast Nafion of 13.7 MPa and 0.24 GPa, respectively. With increasing the amount of MNS addition, Young's modulus increased from 0.90 to 1.06 GPa, whereas the tensile strength increased from 33.38 to 36.97 MPa. However, the elongation at break decreased sharply from 118 to 10% as the content of MNS varied from 1-5%. Besides, the stress-strain curves of MNS@SNF-PAEK-XX membranes are shown in Figure S4 (Supporting Information). It is because MNS at an increasing content exists as an ionic cross-linker in the composite membranes. Because the amino groups of ethylenediamine were immobilized onto the metal-oxygen clusters of MIL-101, they could be cross-linked with the polymer matrix of SNF-PAEK by the formation of electrostatic forces between sulfonic groups and amino groups. Furthermore, all inorganic fillers act as a physical cross-linker which blocks the movement of the molecular chain. Hence, the tensile strength of hybrid membranes increases due to the formation of the cross-linked structure, whereas the toughness decreases at a higher density of cross-linking.

IEC, Water Uptake, and Swelling Ratio of Membranes

As shown in , IEC increased with increasing the content of MNS. There were large amount of sulfonic acid groups on the framework of MNS, so the addition of MNS led to extra more ionic exchange groups into the matrix, thus resulting in a higher IEC.  shows the water uptake and swelling ratio of membranes as a function of temperature. MNS@SNF-PAEK-1%, MNS@SNF-PAEK-2%, and MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% displayed higher water uptake (45.71-47.32%) than the pristine membrane (45.44%) at 30 °C. This was because extra more hydrophilic groups, such as sulfonic acid groups and amino groups, in the inorganic fillers could absorb more water. However, the water uptake of MNS@SNF-PAEK-4% and MNS@SNF-PAEK-5% (45.03 and 43.08%, respectively) was lower than that of SNF-PAEK because of higher density of the cross-linking structure formed between MNS and the polymer matrix, which restricted the water absorption. Meanwhile, all hybrid membranes exhibited lower water uptake (75.55-62.46%) than pristine membrane (75.66%) at 80 °C. This could be attributed to the interaction between the polymer matrix and MNS, which suppressed the absorption of water in the membranes. As for dimensional stability, MNS reduced the swelling ratio of the membranes, especially at high temperature (49.65 and 32.10% for SNF-PAEK and MNS@SNF-PAEK-3%, respectively).

Proton Conductivity, Methanol Permeability, and Selectivity of Membranes

The performance of a fuel cell is usually based on the proton conductivity of the PEM materials. The proton conductivities of all membranes were measured at 100% RH and plotted as a function of temperature (). As expected, the proton conductivities increased with increasing the temperature. All the membranes showed a proton conductivity comparable to the recast Nafion. It was interesting to observe that the proton conductivities increased first and then decreased with increasing the amount of MNS addition. The proton conductivities increased from 0.055 to 0.080 S⋅cm-1 at 25 °C and from 0.145 to 0.192 S⋅cm-1 at 80 °C as the content of MNS increased from 0 to 3%. Then, the conductivities decreased from 0.080 to 0.070 S⋅cm-1 at 25 °C and 0.192 to 0.174 S⋅cm-1 at 80 °C when the content of MNS up to 5%. This indicated that too much MNS led the polymer matrix to a high density of cross-linking, which might hinder the motion of the molecular chain. As listed in , MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% exhibited the highest proton conductivity (0.080 S⋅cm-1 at 25 °C and 0.198 S⋅cm-1 at 80 °C) among these hybrid membranes, even higher than that of recast Nafion (0.073 S⋅cm-1 at 25 °C and 0.134 S⋅cm-1 at 80 °C). The results indicated that the hybrid membranes have the potential to be used as the practical PEM for applications in fuel cells.

Methanol permeability of membranes was obtained according to the method mentioned in our previous work, and the data are showed in . It could be found that hybrid membranes displayed a lower methanol permeability of 4.92 × 10-7 cm2⋅s-1 (MNS@SNF-PAEK-4%) compared with the pristine membrane of 6.44 × 10-7 cm2⋅s-1 and recast Nafion (2.18 × 10-6 cm2⋅s-1). In general, proton and methanol utilize the same pathway for transport, thus high conductivity leading to high methanol crossover. Selectivity (φ, S⋅s⋅cm-3) is another factor to evaluate the methanol resistance property of PEMs, which shows the relationship between proton conductivity and methanol permeability. MNS makes the polymer chain be cross-linked as the hybrid membranes become more compact, and the compact structure improves the methanol resistance of hybrid membranes. For instance, MNS@SNF-PAEK-4% exhibited the highest selectivity of 15.24 × 104 S⋅s⋅cm-3, which implied that the hybrid membrane maintained its low methanol permeability even at a high conductivity. However, the extra free MNS destroys the compact structure of the polymer matrix; then, the methanol permeability increases, whereas the selectivity declined when the content of MNS increases up to 5%. However, both the pristine membrane and hybrid membranes performed much better than recast Nafion in methanol resistance (21.87 × 10-7 cm2⋅s-1) and selectivity (3.34 × 104 S⋅s⋅cm-3).

Single Cell Performance

To further investigate the practical application of the hybrid membranes in DMFC, a single cell measurement was carried out at 25, 40, 60, and 80 °C. As shown in a-c, the power density of membranes increased obviously with increasing the operating temperature, which is similar to the tendency of proton conductivity. d shows the peak power density of SNF-PAEK, MNS@SNF-PAEK-3%, and recast Nafion at different temperatures. The hybrid membrane (MNS@SNF-PAEK-3%) demonstrated a higher power density than the pristine SNF-PAEK membrane, especially at a low operating temperature. For instance, MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% gave peak power densities of 23.5 mW/cm2 at 25 °C and 40.2 mW/cm2 at 40 °C, much higher than those of SNF-PAEK (14.9 mW/cm2 at 25 °C and 28.6 mW/cm2 at 40 °C) and recast Nafion (9.1 mW/cm2 at 25 °C and 10.9 mW/cm2 at 40 °C). Furthermore, MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% reached high levels of peak power density at high temperatures, 79.5 mW/cm2 at 60 °C and 125.7 mW/cm2 at 80 °C. In short, higher power density is attributed to higher proton conductivity of the hybrid membrane. In addition, owing to a superior methanol resistance, MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% showed better open-circuit voltages, 0.839 V in average, compared with those of SNF-PAEK of 0.816 V and recast Nafion of 0.634 V. The maximum peak power densities of different membranes at different temperatures can be found in Table S2 (Supporting Information). Compared with other hybrid sulfonated polymeric PEMs listed in , MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% showed higher proton conductivity, good methanol resistance, and much better single cell performance. All these results indicated that the hybrid membrane based on the SNF-PAEK matrix and the MNS nanofiller has great potential to be used as alternative PEMs for DMFCs.

Conclusions

In this study, novel SPAEK with flexible pendent sulfonic acid groups, consisting of naphthalene and fluorine on the main chain, was successfully prepared. Then, bifunctionalized MNS was used as a functional nanofiller to the SNF-PAEK matrix for preparing a series of hybrid membranes. The remarkable enhancement on dimensional stability, mechanical properties, and methanol resistance property of hybrid membranes was attributed to the incorporation of MNS that acted as an ionic physical cross-linking agent. In addition, MNS provided extra dense and sequential sulfonic acid groups and rearranged the polymer microstructure by electrostatic interactions formed by the amino groups, helping hybrid membranes display the highest proton conductivity of 0.198 S⋅cm-1 at 80 °C. Moreover, MNS@SNF-PAEK-3% showed an excellent single cell performance of 125.7 mW/cm2 at 80 °C, thus proving its great potential for applications in DMFCs.

The multiple superwettability of a solid surface to achieve water and oil self-transportation in air and underliquid environments is indispensable. The AO-ZIF-67/CS surface was superhydrophilic/superoleophilic, as displayed in a-b. The oil contact angle underwater (UWOCA) and water contact angle underoil (UOWCA) of AO-ZIF-67/CS, however, were both up to 150°, indicating the great underliquid superoleophobicity/superhydrophobicity (c-e). The wettability of ZIF-67/CS was hydrophilic with a water contact angle (WCA) of 50.0° and superoleophilic with an oil contact angle (OCA) of almost 0°, as shown in . After modification with hydrophilic AO, the surface of AO-ZIF-67/CS will become superhydrophilic with WCA approaching 0° because oxalate improves the affinity of the surface to water. When the surface was immersed in an aqueous solution, water could penetrate in the microstructure of the surface and replace the air to form a liquid layer due to the superhydrophilicity. This water layer would prevent oil droplets from spreading on its surface and thus demonstrate underwater superoleophobic state. The underoil superhydrophobic state of the surface could be obtained similarly. Since the structure of Cu(OH)2 on copper surface was frequently used for water droplet movement in air, evaporation behavior of a prewetted water layer on Cu(OH)2/CS and AO-ZIF-67/CS was compared as demonstrated in f. The AO-ZIF-67/CS surface exhibits greater capacity in water retention than Cu(OH)2/CS surface due to the smaller microchannels and unique microstructure of AO-ZIF-67/CS surface (). 

Droplets Transportation on Wedge-Shaped AO-ZIF-67/CS Surface

A surface well designed for both water and oil droplet self-transportation and applicable in either air or underliquid environments could reduce the restrictions of operating conditions and enhance surface versatility compared with existing surfaces limited to one droplet or media environment. The water and dodecane transportation in air environment on a wedge-shaped AO-ZIF-67/CS surface with wedge angle (α) of 9.2° was demonstrated in  and . When dripped on the surface, the water (or dodecane) droplet could move rapidly from the tip (narrow end) to the tail (wide end) of the surface as displayed in a-b. The evolution of droplet displacement and velocity with time was calculated in c. After dropped on the surface, the water droplet had initially a maximum velocity and then slowed on account of the decreasing unbalanced interfacial tension caused by the wedge structure until it reached the ultimate distance. The motion of dodecane droplet followed a similar pattern as water droplet; the maximum displacement of dodecane droplet (17.9 mm), however, was smaller than that of water droplet (24.5 mm) because of the low surface tension (γwater = 72.8 mN/m and γdodecane = 25.4 mN/m). The maximum displacement (x max) and average velocity (V average) presented basically a negative correlation with the wedge angle of the wedge-shaped AO-ZIF-67/CS surface as shown in d. The unbalanced interfacial tension between droplet and wedge surface along the moving direction caused by the wedge-shaped structure drove the droplet moving forward to realize self-transportation. The larger wedge angle (α) would result in a reduced unbalanced interfacial tension and thus decrease the moving distance. If we further lowered the wedge angle (α) to 4.6°, however, the maximum velocity (V max, usually in the initial) of the droplet is not optimal because of the droplet bulging (e and ). The capillary force from droplet bulging impeded movement of the droplet front, and this phenomenon is more serious in the underwater environment. In addition, it is difficult to deposit the droplet onto the wedge-shaped AO-ZIF-67/CS surface with a very small wedge angle. Therefore the wedge-shaped AO-ZIF-67/CS surface with a wedge angle of 9.2° was chosen for further experiment in applications. In addition, the stability of AO-ZIF-67/CS surface was tested. After 40 times of repeated prewetting and drying, the unchanged ultralow WCA of 0° display that the surface has good reusable performance in .

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have appeared to be promising competitive candidates as crystalline porous materials for proton conduction. Explorations of the method of preparation of proton conductive MOFs and the proton transfer mechanism have enabled them to attract widespread attention, and tremendous efforts have been made to improve the proton conductivity of MOFs. On the basis of our previous work, we explicitly propose that ligand exchange can upgrade the proton conduction performance of MOFs. Using MOF-azo as the precursor, the proton conductivities of exchange products MOF-bpy and MOF-bpe increase by 3.5- and 2.8-fold, respectively. After the MOFs had been doped into the Nafion matrix to prepare composite membranes, the proton conduction performance of composite membranes filled with subproducts (2.6 × 10-2 and 1.95 × 10-2 S cm-1) is significantly better than that of a composite membrane filled with a parent product (1.12 × 10-2 S cm-1) under ambient conditions (without heating or humidifying). The ligand exchange strategy presented herein demonstrates great promise for the development of high-proton conductivity MOFs and MOF composites with expanded future applications.

The proton conduction performance of Ni-MOFs and Nafion/Ni-MOF composite membranes is significantly improved by a ligand exchange strategy. Under ambient conditions, the proton conductivities of Nafion/MOF-bpy and Nafion/MOF-bpe reach ultrahigh values of 2.6 × 10-2 and 1.95 × 10-2 S cm-1, respectively, which are 2.3- and 1.7-fold higher than that of Nafion/MOF-azo, respectively.

In this work, MOF-bpy and MOF-bpe were obtained by ligand exchange using MOF-azo as the precursor. An alternating current impedance test shows the proton conductivities of MOF-bpy and MOF-bpe are 1.27 × 10-3 and 1.01 × 10-3 S cm-1, respectively, at 100% relative humidity (RH) and 95 °C, which are 3.5- and 2.8-fold higher than that of the original MOF-azo, respectively. These MOFs are doped into the Nafion matrix to yield composite membranes. The proton conductivities of Nafion/MOF-bpy and Nafion/MOF-bpe are calculated to be 2.6 × 10-2 and 1.95 × 10-2 S cm-1, respectively, being 2.3- and 1.7-fold higher than that of Nafion/MOF-azo (1.12 × 10-2 S cm-1), respectively.

The humidity dependence of proton conduction is shown in Tables S1-S3. At 58% RH and 90 °C, the observed proton conductivities of MOF-azo, MOF-bpy, and MOF-bpe are 3.61 × 10-6, 6.09 × 10-6, and 5.54 × 10-6 S cm-1, respectively. With the RH improving to 87%, the conductivity values increase to 3.85 × 10-5, 5.61 × 10-5, and 5.83 × 10-5 S cm-1, respectively. When the humidity reaches 100%, the conductivities increase to 3.15 × 10-4, 7.29 × 10-4, and 8.31 × 10-4 S cm-1, respectively. The proton conductivity increases with relative humidity, clearly demonstrating the water-mediated proton conduction process. In the closed system, a higher humidity can contribute more water, which is adsorbed by MOFs and enters the crystal lattices. The adsorbed water is connected together with the lattice water through hydrogen bonds to form a proton conductive network. More water is adsorbed, and a larger and denser proton conductive network is generated. The proton-conducting paths will be more diverse, thereby increasing the proton conductivity of MOFs.

Water vapor adsorption isotherms are used to study the relationship between the relative humidity and adsorbed water molecules (). The as-synthesized samples are immersed in acetone for 2 days to exchange the solvent molecules inside the frameworks and then dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h. The solution is then replaced with fresh acetone three times a day while soaking. This activation pretreatment is to remove lattice H2O as much as possible, to make room for the absorption of water molecules from the environment. With the increase in relative pressure (relative humidity), the adsorption capacity of water molecules increases gradually. When P/P 0 is 0.99 (close to 100% RH), the adsorption capacities of MOF-azo, MOF-bpy, and MOF-bpe reach the maximum values of 378.5, 264.5, and 215.4 cm3/g, respectively, which means the higher the relative humidity, the more water molecules are adsorbed by these MOFs. For MOF-azo and MOF-bpy, their water vapor adsorption isotherms show type IV characteristics. When P/P 0 is <0.2, the isotherm is relatively flat. The rapid adsorption begins from a P/P 0 of 0.3 because the capillary condensation of water vapor occurs. After a P/P 0 of 0.7, vapor adsorption occurs only on the MOFs' outer surface whose area is much smaller than the inner surface area, so the isotherms tend to be stable. The notable hysteresis before a P/P 0 of 0.8 may also account for the fact that each [Ni1.5(L)(4,4'-azobpy)(H2O)] unit and each [Ni1.5(L)(4,4'-bpy)(H2O)] unit adsorb more free water molecules than the initial unactivated samples. The adsorbed water molecules can combine with each other to form rich hydrogen bond networks, which can be expanded by other hydrogen bonds formed between lattice water in 1D hydrophilic channels and carboxyl oxygen atoms. The strong affinity maintained by hydrogen bonding interaction makes the release of water molecules extremely slow, thus showing a distinct hysteresis. MOF-bpe exhibits a type I isotherm. In the low-pressure region (P/P 0 = 0-0.3), the adsorption capacity increases sharply, indicating that the cavity is filled as much as possible by adsorbed water vapor. Then, the isotherm shows a platform with a slow rising trend, which stemmed from the condensation of water vapor on the external surface of MOF-bpe, which is deeply inspired by the previous report. There are two  fewer adsorbed water molecules in each [Ni1.5(L)(bpe)(H2O)] unit than in the unactivated sample, which is ascribed to incomplete removal of lattice water molecules during the activation process.

N2 adsorption isotherms (Figure S3) collected at 77 K are used to evaluate their intrinsic porosity. MOF-azo, MOF-bpy, and MOF-bpe have adsorption capacities of 11, 10, and 12 cm3/g, respectively, and their BET surface areas are calculated to be 2.3, 1.6, and 2.3 m2/g, respectively. The lack of adsorption sites in their frameworks and the larger kinetic diameter of N2 molecules may be the reasons for the low nitrogen adsorption capacity. The kinetic diameter of a H2O molecule (2.6 Å) is 1 Å smaller than that of a N2 molecule (3.6 Å). In this sense, MOFs can adsorb as many H2O molecules as possible instead of N2. As adsorption sites of water molecules, the 1D water chain in the c axis channel can form hydrogen bonds with the adsorbed H2O, which further enhances the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOFs. This explains the difference between nitrogen adsorption capacity and water vapor adsorption capacity.

The temperature-dependent proton conducting behavior of MOF-azo, MOF-bpy, and MOF-bpe can be observed at every humidity (Figures S4-S6). For example, at 93% RH and 40 °C, their proton conductivities are found to be 4.18 × 10-5, 5.07 × 10-5, and 5.15 × 10-5 S cm-1, then increase to 5.29 × 10-5, 6.72 × 10-5, and 6.83 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 60 °C, and then increase to 9.04 × 10-5, 1.40 × 10-4, and 1.33 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 90 °C, respectively. At 100% RH and 30 °C, the conductivity values of MOF-azo, MOF-bpy, and MOF-bpe are calculated to be 1.60 × 10-4, 2.45 × 10-4, and 3.06 × 10-4 S cm-1, then increase to 2.50 × 10-4, 4.22 × 10-4, and 5.78 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 70 °C, and finally reach maximum values of 3.63 × 10-4, 1.27 × 10-3, and 1.07 × 10-3 S cm-1 at 95 °C, respectively. Obviously, their proton conductivities gradually increase with temperature. This is mainly due to the boost in the internal energy of the electrolyte system caused by the increasing temperature, which accelerates the rate of mobility of proton carriers and facilitates the proton transfer through a path separated by a smaller energy barrier.

The water uptake capacity of Nafion/MOF composite membranes at room temperature is germane to proton conduction performance under ambient conditions. The water uptake and area swelling were calculated to be 37% and 21% for Nafion/MOF-azo, 36% and 19% for Nafion/MOF-bpy, 33% and 18% for Nafion/MOF-bpe, and 43% and 29% for pure Nafion, respectively. As a result of being immersed in water for a long time, these membranes have undergone a full water absorption process and show high water uptake capacity at room temperature, so it is not difficult to understand their excellent proton conductivity. In addition, the water uptake capacity and area swelling capacity of the pure Nafion membrane are higher than those of composite membranes because the molecular structures between MOFs and Nafion are quite different. Nafion has a large number of hydrophilic sulfonic groups that so easily absorb water molecules that the Nafion membrane with a flexible PTFE carbon chain expands. The relatively rigid MOFs have difficulty absorbing more water through expansion, as Nafion does. When MOFs are added to a Nafion matrix, the overall flexibility of the formed composite membranes is slightly impaired. Therefore, water uptake capacity and area swelling capacity are not as good as those of the pure Nafion membrane.

The optical activity properties of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses (a) were further studied at room temperature. The photoluminescence (b and S6) showed that SURchirMOF-4 displayed a similar intense fluorescence with the maximum emissions at 390, 410, and 432 nm when it was excited at 365 nm, which were similar to the UV-vis absorption spectra (Figures S7 and S8). The CD data recorded for SURchirMOFs [Zn2(Dcam)2DAP] n  (d-SURchirMOF-4) and [Zn2(Lcam)2DAP] n  (l-SURchirMOF-4) were shown in c. The CD spectra showed four negative bands at 243, 271, 335, and 395 nm and two positive bands at 249 and 307 nm for d-SURchirMOF-4 fabricated exclusively with enantiopure Dcam and DAP. Moreover, the enantiomeric pairs show dichroic absorption of an equal in magnitude but opposite signal.

CPL is a unique property used to evaluate the chirality of chiral materials. Recently, scientists have reported a ligand-exchange approach to form a chiral zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) powder for CPL. However, such a ligand-exchange approach usually cannot exchange the ligand completely and the powder form of ZIF is also not convenient in the practical CPL application. Therefore, the in-situ epitaxial growth of MOF thin films for CPL is a promising material for CPL application. Herein, we investigate the CPL of the d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses. Different handedness CPL signals () could be observed and the relative CPL signals were at ~330 nm. The results display that the CPL signals of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 were opposite. The corresponding g lum factors (Figure S9) were ~3 × 10-3 and -8 × 10-3 for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively.

To further study the chiral recognition of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, the adsorption performance of enantiomers can be carried out in this work. A gas phase QCM technology has been developed for investigating the enantioselectivity of homochiral MOF thin films, which can monitor mass changes with nanogram by detecting the change of resonance frequency. The d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 thin films were grown on Au-coated QCM sensors. The thickness of d-SURchirMOF-4 was measured by cross-section SEM and was about 320 nm (Figure S10). A pair of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate was selected as the chiral probe molecules for studying their enantioselectivity. The related adsorption amount of d and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 and l-SURchirMOF-4 were carried out respectively, which were shown in . The adsorption amount of d- and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 was ~2.08 (M D) and ~3.54 (M L) μg/cm2, respectively (a). The different adsorption showed an important enantioselective adsorption for one enantiomer methyl-lactate in SURchirMOF-4. When we applied the equation "ee % = (M L - M D)/(M D + M L) × 100" for analyzing the enantioselectivity, the enantioselectivity ee % of SURchirMOF-4 for methyl-lactate was found to be 26%. With the same measurement, the probe enantiomers of d/l-methyl-lactate were used for studying the enantioselective adsorption of l-SURchirMOF-4. The recorded data (b) showed that the adsorption amounts of d- and l-methyl-lactate were ~3.62 (M D) and ~2.02 (M L) μg/cm2 for l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively. The related enantioselectivity ee % was 28% after using the same equation, which was the opposite enantioselective adsorption of d-SURchirMOF-4.

Macroscopic Presentation: Sensitivity to Concentration Fluctuations

A preliminary understanding of the photoactivity over Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 photoanodes was obtained by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) measurement (a). M-Fe2O3 modification increased the photocurrent density of pristine hematite at 1.23 VRHE from 0.46 to 0.96 mA⋅cm-2, which was more than doubled. The combination of M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 further increased the photocurrent to 3.08 mA⋅cm-2 at 1.23 VRHE, 5.7 times higher than that of pristine hematite. We found that the MOF-induced photoactivity is extremely sensitive to the concentration fluctuations, especially 1,4-BDC. As given in b, the photocurrent density increased with the rise of the Ti(OiPr)4 concentration, reaching maximum at 0.78g/60 mL, whereas further increase in the concentration led to a decrease in the photocurrent. This proves to be an optimal concentration of Ti(OiPr)4 where excessive or insufficient M-TiO2 is not conducive to the charge transport of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (Figure S12). In addition, it was found that the photoanode was very strongly dependent on 1,4-BDC observed in c. Starting from 3 g/60 mL, the photocurrent density of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 decreases from 3.08 to 1.2 mA⋅cm-2 at 1.23 VRHE, and when it comes to 2 g/60 mL, the photocurrent density decreased by 61%. This revealed that 1,4-BDC must reach an excess, in line with the results of the aforementioned morphological characterization (Figures S8-S10). As we can see, d shows the comparison of the PEC performance when the hydrothermal substrate is converted from FeOOH to Fe2O3 by calcination (AHA-Fe2O3/TiO2). It is worth noting that AHA-Fe2O3/TiO2 shows a markedly reduced photocurrent density and increasing onset potential, suggesting the essential role of the substrate FeOOH's ability to interact with 1,4-BDC, in accordance with the SEM characterization results (Figure S13).

Avoidance of Secondary Defects: Tight Interface Connection

The surface shallow trap activation is not fulfilled, still exhibiting a large number of hole accumulation due to surface defects, as shown in e (obvious transient spikes, red line). A part of surface deep traps stems from the original deep trap that has not been eliminated, and the other part stems from the secondary defects caused by surface corrosion. The self-assembly onto terminal carboxyl overcomes this potential surface secondary trap to the greatest extent because the atoms at the interface between M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 are regularly arranged without disorderly arrangement. The tight connection of the M-TiO2 and M-Fe2O3 would function as an electron transport channel, thereby accelerating the charge transfer of hematite. The IMPS plot was thus applied to measure the charge transit time (τ) in the hematite films, followed by the following equation: τ = (2πf)-1, where f is the value of minimal frequency in the IMPS plots. As shown in a, the obtained values of f corresponding to Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 are 5.123, 4.364, and 6.975 Hz, and thus, τ values were calculated to be 31.1, 36.5, and 22.8 ms, respectively. The largest τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 demonstrated that photogenerated electrons more hardly reach the back contact, which may be caused by reintroduced surface traps in M-Fe2O3. The introduction of M-TiO2 not only constructs a well-interconnected interface but also greatly reduces the transmission resistance, thus accelerating the electron transfer, confirmed by the minimum value of τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2.

In addition, the chopped LSV curve of the optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 in e exhibits indiscernible transient current spikes, indicating the minimum amount of hole accumulation, viz., the holes trapped by the surface shallow traps are rapidly involved in water oxidation. These positive shallow traps act as the outstanding OER active site, combined with its porous structure and water permeability characteristics, resulting in superior surface OER kinetics. As shown in the Tafel slope in Figure S17, the Tafel slope of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 is 237 mV⋅dec-1, which is significantly lower than those of Fe2O3 (368 mV⋅dec-1) and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 (334 mV⋅dec-1), denoting the dramatically increased OER efficiency of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2.

The permanent porosity of the four MOFs was evaluated by nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K. The permanent porosity of NU-500 was first evaluated by N2 sorption; however, almost no N2 uptake was observed at 77 K (Figure S31), likely due to the contraction of the framework after the desolvation by thermal activation. Based on the crystal structure, PLATON calculation revealed that the free volume of NU-500 was 13676 Å3 per unit cell (60% void space in the unit cell, compared with the unit cell volume of 22847 Å3). As a result, its theoretical pore volume was calculated to be 0.56 cm3/g. Due to the negligible N2 uptake of NU-500, the permanent porosity of NU-500 was attained by CO2 adsorption at 195 K (Figure S32), thanks to the enhanced molecular interactions arising from the quadrupole moment of CO2 and its smaller kinetic diameter compared to N2. The CO2 sorption isotherm showed a type I isotherm, indicating microporosity. The saturated uptake of CO2 at P/P 0 = 0.90 reached 53 cm3/g, and the surface area and pore volume were 140 m2/g and 0.03 cm3/g; the pore volume was much lower than the theoretical pore volume, meaning only a small amount of porosity was accessed. Water is a strong polar molecule, and its sorption isotherm was also collected to confirm the porosity of NU-500 (Figure S33). NU-500 showed a high water uptake of up to 200 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.92 and 298 K. Considering the theoretical porosity, neither CO2 nor water was able to completely reverse the structure of the closed phase. NU-600 and NU-1008 (a,c) both showed type IV isotherms, indicative of hierarchically porous structures with both micropores and mesopores, while a type I isotherm was observed for NU-906 (b), confirming its microporous structure. The calculated BET areas were 1190, 1120, and 1390 m2/g for NU-600, NU-906, and NU-1008, respectively. Pore size distributions based on DFT indicated micropores at 10.9 Å for NU-906 (e), hierarchically porous structures with micropores at 11.8 Å and mesopores at 20.0 Å for NU-600 (d), and micropores at 11.8 Å and mesopores at 29.5 Å for NU-1008 (f). The total pore volumes were 0.69, 0.45, and 0.92 cm3/g for NU-600, NU-906, and NU-1008, respectively.

Adsorption of n-Hexane

Owing to their high porosities, MOFs have been widely utilized as adsorbents for high gas uptakes. In this work, n-hexane was examined as the probe vapor to investigate the adsorption performance of the Zr-based MOFs with different pore volumes and sizes at 298 K. The structure of n-hexane resembles the linear alkyl chain of sulfur mustard (HD), a chemical warfare agent (CWA). Although n-hexane may have different adsorption behaviors, we utilized it as a simplified mimic of HD for understanding the adsorption of the more complex CWA. Since activated NU-500 had small pores, the saturated uptake of n-hexane was only 5.2 cm3/g at 180 mbar (P/P 0 = 1) (Figure S34); therefore, we excluded NU-500 from the comparison with the other three MOFs. As illustrated in a, the adsorption-desorption isotherms of n-hexane on NU-600, NU-906, and NU-1008 at 298 K exhibited different adsorption behaviors without hysteresis loops, indicating the robust nature of the frameworks. At 180 mbar, the saturated uptakes of n-hexane were 103.5, 79.7, and 167.7 cm3/g for NU-600, NU-906, and NU-1008, respectively. The isotherm of NU-906 showed a type I feature with steep uptake of n-hexane at a relatively low pressure (b), demonstrating strong guest--framework interactions between n-hexane and NU-906, due to van der Waals forces. Notably, NU-906 reached saturation at 2.50 mbar and adsorbed 55.6 cm3/g n-hexane, which was attributed to the presence of rhombic micropores in the NU-906 structure. The amount adsorbed of 79.7 cm3/g at 180 mbar gave a micropore volume of 0.44 cm3/g converted based on the Gurvich rule, which is close to the experimental pore volume (0.45 cm3/g) based on N2 adsorption at 77 K. In contrast, NU-600 and NU-1008 displayed distinct stepwise adsorption behaviors toward n-hexane (b). For NU-600, the isotherm of n-hexane clearly exhibited two steps. The first step up to 0.96 mbar adsorbed 19.9 cm3/g, due to the inclusion of n-hexane into the intrinsic micropores. The second step occurred with continuous increase of the pressure from 0.96 to 7.94 mbar, accompanied by further increase in n-hexane uptake, which was attributed to the continuous filling of n-hexane into the mesopore structure in NU-600. Although both NU-600 and NU-1008 are hierarchically porous structures with micropores and mesopores, NU-1008 has larger mesopores of 29.5 Å compared to those of NU-600 (20.0 Å). As a result, NU-1008 displayed an interesting adsorption behavior toward n-hexane with three steps. Initially, the first step led to a steep increase in n-hexane uptake in the pressure range of 0.00-1.61 mbar with an uptake of 33.0 cm3/g, accompanied by the observed second step with an uptake of 102.6 cm3/g at 17.76 mbar. As the pressure further increased, rapid uptake of n-hexane occurred in the following narrow pressure range. This phenomenon implies that, after the n-hexane molecules were adsorbed into the hexagonal mesopores during the second step, the accommodated n-hexane molecules led to the hexagonal mesopores in NU-1008 structure narrowing into micropores, giving rise to a sharp filling that is characteristic of a micropore in the third step, resulting in the almost complete occupation of the NU-1008 framework with a final uptake of 140.7 cm3/g at 20.64 mbar.

Dynamic Adsorption of 2-Chloroethyl Ethyl Sulfide under Dry and Humid Conditions

Due to the high toxicities of CWAs, MOFs have been designed as efficient adsorbents for high uptake of these toxic compounds. In this study, NU-600, NU-906, and NU-1008 differing in pore structures were evaluated for dynamic adsorption of 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES), a sulfur mustard simulant, under both dry (0% RH) and humid (80% RH) conditions (Figure S36). Detailed procedures are provided in the Supporting Information. A CEES concentration of 4000 mg/m3 was used for breakthrough experiments herein. The loadings of CEES were compared among the investigated MOFs varying in pore size/volume and Zr6 node connectivity to confirm which factor mainly affected CEES uptake (). NU-906 with the smallest pore showed the highest uptake (13.3 mol/kg) of CEES under dry conditions among the three MOFs, due to the strong interaction between the analyte and the MOF framework. Considering that NU-906 and NU-1008 have the same 8-connected Zr6 nodes while the pore volume of NU-906 is much smaller than that of NU-1008, these results corroborated that pore size had an apparent effect on the CEES uptake under dry conditions. As demonstrated by the steep uptake of n-hexane at low pressures for NU-906 (), the microporous nature of this MOF may have facilitated the high adsorption under these breakthrough conditions.

We also analyzed the desorbed amounts of CEES to test the retained percent of the CWA simulant due to strong interactions with the MOFs (). Under dry conditions, the strong interaction between the CEES and the MOF nodes led to low desorption amounts. Only small desorbed percentages of 5.0 and 4.3% were observed for NU-600 and NU-1008, respectively, attributed to strong adsorption in the MOFs. In contrast, NU-906 had the highest percent desorbed of 10.5% while the retained loading was found to be 11.9 mol/kg CEES. A contributing factor of high loading of an analyte in MOFs is strong interactions between the analyte and the MOF framework, which can also lead to lower desorbed amounts due to the higher energy costs of desorption. For NU-906, the desorbed amount of the analyte was the highest, which may be explained by the reason that multilayer adsorption with higher loading of CEES occurs, leading to more guest-guest interactions rather than host-guest interactions. Due to the weaker interactions of CEES-CEES as compared to CEES-MOF, it is easier to desorb more. The desorption amounts were higher under humid conditions due to the competition with water for binding onto the active sites of the MOF, thereby weakening CEES-framework interactions under humid conditions. NU-600 had the highest percent desorbed of 77.3%, while NU-906 and NU-1008 had much lower percentages of analyte desorbed (13.9 and 20.7%, respectively). These results corroborated that decreasing the connectivity of the Zr6 node, thereby adding more aquo and hydroxyl moieties on the node, led to a higher percentage of the CWA simulant desorbed.

Conclusion

In conclusion, a series of Zr-based MOFs were synthesized using the same tetratopic carboxylate linker H4TCPB-Br2, but resulting in four different topologies through tuning the synthetic solvents and modulators employed. In particular, NU-500 with a novel topology displays the first example of a 5-connected Zr6 node in MOFs. Compared to NU-600 with a she topology constructed by a 6-connected Zr6 node, both shp topology NU-906 and csq topology NU-1008 are constructed by 8-connected Zr6 nodes with different conformations of the flexible tetratopic carboxylate linker. H4TCPB-Br2 serves as a flexible building block capable of rotational deformations that adjust its geometrical characteristics between the inner phenyl ring and the outer phenyl ring allowing it to fit well into particular structures. The adsorption performance of n-hexane, used as a simplified model of sulfur mustard, within these MOFs illustrates the occurrence of distinct adsorption behaviors corresponding to their specific pore structures, demonstrating the relationship between structure and n-hexane uptake. CEES dynamic adsorption revealed that NU-906, possessing the smallest pores, has the highest uptake of 13.3 mmol/kg under dry conditions, confirming that pore size has an apparent effect on the CEES uptake. With exposure to moisture, the competing adsorption between water and the CWA simulant led to reduced loading of the CWA simulant. Our work highlights that polyaromatic carboxylate linkers are excellent platforms for constructing Zr-based MOFs and facilitate the discovery of novel structures, enriching the structural diversity present in these materials.

The biomolecule-friendly synthetic conditions ensured the preservation of collagen's secondary and tertiary structures during the generation of the MOF composite. According to the DSC analysis (), the uncoated ECM underwent an endothermic event with onset at 59.7 °C, which can be attributed to the start of the denaturation of the collagen protein. The biomimetically synthesized ZIF-8 coating (in the ECM-MOF composite) shifted the denaturation temperature to 64.8 °C, offering a mild benefit in structure stabilization.

MOF composites are commonly characterized with respect to the crystal structure, thermal stability, and porosity, whereas the mechanical properties are rarely accounted for. In this study, the viscoelastic properties of the ECM-MOF composite were investigated by DMA (). A repeated-measures ANOVA with a Greenhouse-Geisser correction determined that the complex modulus (E*) means differed significantly between time points [F(1.917, 13.420) = 70.945, p < 0.001]. Post hoc analysis with a Bonferroni adjustment revealed that E* increased from pre-treatment (baseline) to any time points of the post-treatment: immediate (p < 0.01), 10 d (p < 0.01), 30 d (p < 0.01), and 90 d (p < 0.01). Immediately after the biomimetic growth of the MOF coating, the E* mean increased to 17.1 ± 2.4 MPa (A), representing a twofold increase over the baseline (8.8 ± 1.3 MPa). Another significant increment (p = 0.002) occurred from post-treatment (immediate) to 10 d (E* = 24.2 ± 4.7 MPa). Then, a plateau was maintained during the simulated physiological aging (10-90 d), and the means differences were not significant (p > 0.2). The relatively higher E* means indicate an improvement in the stiffness of the ECM after the MOF formation. Thus, enhanced mechanical strength was imparted to the dentin ECM by the ZIF-8 coating.

The increment in mechanical strength provided by the ZIF-8 coating is relatively low compared to that of natural collagen cross-linkers or the native mineral phase. Nevertheless, the increment is enough to sustain a crystalline framework that withstands stress, including destructive enzymes. A primary goal of this study was to verify if protective ZIF-8 coatings can improve the biostability of fibrillar collagen, preventing its degradation due to hydrolysis and enzyme action. The results of the collagen degradation assay () suggest that MOF-modified collagen (ECM-MOF) degrades nearly twice less than unmodified collagen (ECM) under physiological conditions. Furthermore, when exposed to collagen-degrading enzymes to accelerate the proteolysis, the ECM-MOF composite degraded significantly less (205.1 ± 37.3 μg mL-1) than the unprotected ECM (480.2 ± 22.8 μg mL-1).

Surface roughness, a critical parameter for adhesion in dentin, should be considered in modifications of the dentin matrix with hybrid materials. The roughness of the ECM-MOF composite was estimated from AFM images (). The arithmetic average roughness (R a) was 12.0 ± 3.7 and 78.4 ± 6.7 nm for the ECM and EM-MOF, respectively. The considerably rougher texture that the frameworks impart to the dentin matrix creates extended surface area, beneficial to dentin bonding. Furthermore, the hydrophobic and microporous nature of ZIF-8 could favor the infiltration of apolar resin monomers, commonly used in dentin bonding procedures. 

Biomedical applications often require biomaterials to be engineered with crucial biocompatible characteristics, including low toxicity. When integrating the dentin ECM with MOFs, the resulting composite must maintain good compatibility with cells relevant to the tooth tissues. A shows the viability of DPSCs cultured on ECM and ECM-MOF substrates. A Tukey post hoc test (on a one-way ANOVA) revealed no statistically significant differences between the ECM and ECM-MOF groups after 1 d (p = 0.959) and 3 d (p = 0.546). However, after 7 d of culture, the cell viability was higher on the ECM surface than the ECM-MOF (p < 0.001). Overall, the cell proliferation followed a similar trend on both substrates (Supporting Information, Figure S2), but the MOF coating led to a lower proliferation rate compared to the uncoated scaffolds (ECM). Except for a slower proliferation, cytotoxic effects were not substantiated by the results. For instance, the ECM-MOF group's viability reached 434.9% by the end of the experiment (A). In addition, strong evidence of the viability of attached DPSCs is presented in C, where primarily live cells are observed on the composite's surface. The DPSCs on the ECM-MOF samples exhibited elongated shapes similar to the control group (B).

A Rhodamine B (RhB) dye coordinated, 2D metal-organic framework (MOF), {[Zn2(L)(RhB)]⋅5DMF} n  (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), was constructed solvothermally from a -NH2-functionalized ligand and ZnII ions. The MOF features interlayer π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the RhB molecules with an overlap of almost 100%. One- and two-photon-excited fluorescence measurements were carried out on micrometer-sized single crystals of varied thickness with continuous-wave and femtosecond pulsed lasers, respectively. The two-photon absorption coefficient was measured relative to the CdS crystal and found to be 7.1 ± 0.7 cm/GW at a wavelength of 1030 nm. Our findings demonstrate a new way of achieving solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.

To establish the effect of the coordinated RhB dye, the emission spectra of three different forms (powder, solution, and MOF crystal) were examined, as shown in . A large red shift in the emission peak between the solution (λem = 570 nm) and powder (λem = 710 nm) was observed that could be attributed to the presence of higher molecular aggregates of RhB in the powder form. A red shift between the emission peaks of RhB in solution and MOF crystal was also observed, attributable to the highly rigid form of coordinated RhB in 1 that prohibited nonradiative decay. Furthermore, the emission peak of 1 appeared at 675 nm, which was blue-shifted by 35 nm compared to RhB in the form of powder. This small blue shift in 1 was due to the dimeric form of RhB, which showed strong π⋅⋅⋅π interaction in the crystal structure.

A commercial microscope setup (Nikon, Eclipse Ti-2) (Scheme S2) was employed to conduct one-photon fluorescence (OPF), TPF, and time-resolved TPF measurements. The details on the different measurements can be found in Table S1. Linear- and nonlinear-optical measurements on the crystals of 1 were carried out using the above-mentioned setup without using the half-wave plate along the beam path. OPF experiments were conducted on single crystals of three different thicknesses (20, 26, and 30 μm) under a continuous-wave laser excitation at λex = 403 nm with varying power density.  shows the emission spectrum from a 30-μm-thick crystal as an example (see Figure S11 for more results on 20- and 26-μm-thick crystals). The log-log plot of integrated fluorescence versus excitation power density, given as the inset, afforded a value of 1.0 for the slope, implying the involvement of one-photon absorption (OPA) process.

Time-resolved TPF measurements were also performed to determine the excited-state lifetime using the time-correlated single-photon-counting method. Three spots were randomly selected (a) on a single crystal of 1 (thickness ~26 μm) for the measurements. The decay time (for 0° polarization excitation) for three different spots were found to be (32 ± 3) × 10, (32 ± 3) × 10, and (33 ± 3) × 10 ps, which were ~10 times smaller than the radiative decay time of the RhB solution in an acetonitrile solvent. (see the SI for a detailed calculation of the decay time of spots 1-3). The reduction of the TPF lifetime of RhB in the MOF was due to an efficient energy transfer, which was ensured by the presence of the ligand L. Furthermore, the excitation power and polarization dependence of time-resolved TPF were also investigated. The polarization dependence of time-resolved TPF measurements were done by employing an additional half-wave plate in the setup (Scheme S2). b shows the normalized time-resolved TPF signals for various laser excitation powers. Parts c and d of  show the polarization-resolved TPF decay time for a laser excitation density of 63 GW/cm2. The polar plot shown in c reveals an isotropic decay time for crystal 1. These measurements showed that the decay time was independent of both the excitation power and polarization of the laser beam.

The two-photon action cross section, ηβ, was measured relative to a standard crystal of CdS (thickness ~1 mm). The quantum efficiency (η) and TPA coefficient (β) of the CdS crystal are 0.01 and 6.4 cm/GW, respectively. The Rayleigh length of the excitation Gaussian beam was found to be 12 μm (for 1030 nm). Because the thickness of the CdS crystal was 1 mm, which was far greater than the Rayleigh length of the excitation beam, TPF of CdS was considered to occur within a length of 2z 0. By using , the value of ηβ for a crystal of 1 (thickness~ 30 μm) was found to be 7.1 ± 0.72 cm/GW. This value was 1 order greater than that of the CdS crystal. Such a large action cross section was attributed to the presence of large voids within the MOF unit cell (~47%), preventing RhB from aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching, as was the case for tightly arranged organic crystals formed from molecular chromophores. It was also suggested that restriction of the intramolecular rotation of the chromophore molecule in a rigid structure can enhance the TPF efficiency. Because RhB molecules themselves acted as spatially confined ligands, their intramolecular rotations were limited, which facilitated a large value of the two-photon action cross section. Such a 2D-layered MOF crystal with a large ηβ value should possess great potential for solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.

The thermal stability of 1 was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S9). TGA revealed a loss of DMF solvent molecules up to ~260 °C and decomposition of the framework could be achieved only beyond ~400 °C. Further stability studies were performed using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD; Figure S10a,b). PXRD of the as-synthesized and simulated patterns matched well, suggesting phase purity of the bulk sample. Furthermore, VT-PXRD analysis suggested the sample retained its crystallinity at least up to 200 °C. The porosity of 1 was further examined by N2 gas sorption measurement. As shown in Figure S16, the N2 gas adsorption measurement at 77 K and 1 atm revealed a type I isotherm with a maximum uptake of 79.9 cm3/g (STP) corresponding to a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 263 m2/g.

In conclusion, we have designed and demonstrated a novel type of micrometer-sized MOF with the incorporation of RhB dye molecule as the coordinating organic ligand and investigated the enhancement in TPF efficiency of these MOF crystals. In contrast to the aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching in solid-state organic dyes, the RhB-coordinated network in 1 exhibits a highly efficient TPF with an action cross section of 7.1 ± 0.72 cm/GW. Restriction of the intramolecular rotation of RhB molecules, combined with the presence of a large void in the framework, resulted in such an efficient TPF. Thus, MOF 1 promises to be a suitable candidate as a cost-effective luminescent material in solid-state form for many photonic applications. Our synthesis approach also promises a systematic realization of highly luminescent MOF crystals by the rational choice of dye molecules with the coordinating ability to the MOF framework. Such MOF crystals with large two-photon action cross section values should possess great potential for solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.

Conversion from CO2 to the more desirable and valuable C2+ products under neutral conditions is important for the development of energy and the environment, but it is a challenging work. In this work, we demonstrate that the bi-copper sites on the crystal surface of a metal-organic framework Cu-HITP (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) are very suitable for catalyzing the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. The in situ infrared spectroscopy, theoretic calculations, and controlled experiments show that polydopamine coating of Cu-HITP could provide a carbon dioxide reduction reaction-favored local environment with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors around the bi-copper active sites to promote *CO hydrogenation and stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH), resulting in a high selectivity of the C2+ reduced products [Faradaic efficiency (C2+) of 75(3)%, Faradaic efficiency (C2H4) of 51(1)%] in the KHCO3 electrolyte. This work provides an insight into the catalytic activity on the surface of metal-organic frameworks and the local environment for electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products.

The catalytic CO2RR performances of Cu-HITP were assessed in a gastight H-type electrochemical cell separated by a proton exchange membrane. The working electrode was prepared by coating the microcrystalline powder of the catalyst onto the glassy carbon electrode with a Nafion (perfluorosulfonic acid-PTFE copolymer) binder. Then, the performance of CO2RR was tested in a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte. The gaseous and liquid products were monitored and analyzed by using online gas chromatography (GC) (Figures S24-S29) and proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra, respectively (Figure S30). The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of Cu-HITP showed that the current density measured in the CO2-saturated electrolyte is significantly higher than that measured in the Ar-saturated electrolyte (Figure S5), suggesting that the intrinsic activity of the catalyst is for CO2RR rather than for the hydrogen evolution reaction. Notably, Cu-HITP shows a high selectivity for ethylene [FE(C2H4) = 30%] and less hydrogen production [FE(H2) = 17%] at -1.2 V versus RHE (Figure S6). Combined with liquid-phase products, the FE(C2+) products (including ethylene, ethanol, and acetic acid) of Cu-HITP (a) reach 42(2)% with a current density of 5.2 mA cm-2 at -1.2 V versus RHE. We also measured the CO2RR performance of the nanosheet sample (Figure S9) of Cu-HITP. Compared to the rod-like sample, the nanosheet sample shows a much poor performance [FE(C2+) of 14%] of CO2RR to C2+ products. Both the structural analysis (Figure S7) and TEM images (Figures S2 and S8) showed that there are more bi-copper sites on the surface of the rod-like sample, while the nanosheet sample has more CuN4 sites, suggesting that the bi-copper sites () along the c-axis on the surface of the Cu-HITP crystal might be the active sites for CO2RR to give C2+ products. On the one hand, the distance between adjacent Cu sites (d Cu-Cu = 3.4 Å) is very suitable for catalyzing *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH in the low-energy pathway. Additionally, it is possible to improve the FE(C2+) by providing a CO2RR-favored local environment (with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors) around the bi-copper active sites. 

With amino (-NH-) and phenolic hydroxyl groups, conductive polymer PDA can be used as hydrogen-bond donors and proton sources at the same time (a and S23). Therefore, coating it on the Cu-HITP surface may significantly increase the C2+ products' selectivities. With all this in mind, we assembled PDA in situ on the Cu-HITP surface through the self-polymerization reaction of dopamine and fabricated Cu-HITP@PDA samples with different PDA coating amounts at mass ratios of Cu-HITP/dopamine of 10/1, 10/3, 10/5, and 10/7 (Figure S11) to find out the optimal amount of coating. Also, the HRTEM and SEM images of Cu-HITP@PDA (d and S10-S15) showed that the Cu-HITP crystal was coated by a uniform shell, suggesting the existence of PDA. Besides, compared with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy line scan mode of Cu-HITP, the shell of Cu-HITP@PDA has an O element, suggesting the shell of PDA on the Cu-HITP core (f). The LSV curves show that Cu-HITP@PDA and Cu-HITP exhibit similar current density (Figure S16). As depicted in a, as the amount of PDA coating increased, the yield of CO and CH4 products decreased, while the selectivity of C2+ products increased; especially, the FE of C2H4 was improved from 30.8 to 51% (Figure S32). Furthermore, with the increase in potential, the FE of the C2+ products increased gradually and reached a maximum value of 75(3)% at -1.2 V versus RHE and then decreased (b). Also, the best performance gives 75(3)% FE(C2+) (C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH), 4(0.39)% FE(CH4), 3(1.5)% FE(HCOOH), 0.62(0.23)% FE(CH3OH), 3(1.1)% FE(CO), and 13(3.1)% FE(H2) at -1.2 V versus RHE (b). The FE(C2+) value of Cu-HITP@PDA is much higher than that of Cu-HITP under the same conditions, indicating that the local chemical environment (local hydrogen bonding and proton sources) formed by the PDA shell around the bi-copper active sites plays a critical role in improving the selectivity of C2+ products. It should be noted that the performance of Cu-HITP@PDA is obviously higher than that of most electrocatalysts and only slightly lower than that of three Cu-based nanomaterials [Re-Cu-I, boron-doped copper, and Cu-polyaniline (PANI)] under neutral conditions in the H-cell (c and Table S2). The definite structure-property relationship established by this well-defined structural model system (Cu-HITP@PDA) can provide more insights on the reaction mechanism for understanding the C-C coupling and optimizing the C-C coupling pathway.

Compared with the H-type cell, CO2 gas can flow continuously through the gas-diffusion layer in a flow cell, thus facilitating the mass transfer of CO2 to the electrocatalyst and leading to an increase in current density. The LSV curves of Cu-HITP@PDA in a three-electrode flow cell with a gas diffusion electrode as the working electrode in a 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution were also measured. At -1.2 V versus RHE, the current density increased to 55 mA cm-2 and reached 130 mA cm-2 at -1.5 V versus RHE (Figure S46), and no obvious degradation was observed at 55 mA cm-2 over 10 h of continuous operation (Figure S47). In a 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution, benefitting from diverse functions (influencing Bader charge of catalyst surfaces and tuning the catalytic pathway by nucleophilic reactions with surface intermediates) of OH- ions, the current density could even reach 310 mA cm-2 (-1.2 V vs RHE), which is over the commercially relevant current density of 300 mA cm-2. Importantly, after 10 h of electrolysis at a current density of 310 mA cm-2, no significant decay was observed (Figure S47).

Results and Discussion

Compound 1 features a three-dimensional open framework with intrinsically chiral quartz topology. Single crystal X-ray structure analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group of P21212. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of three independent Zn ions, two 4-pca ligands, one μ3-ade ligands, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). Two 4-pca ligands adopt one kind of coordination mode: two pyrazole nitrogen atoms bridge two Zn(II) ions and one carboxylate oxygen atom connects one Zn(II) ion. The μ3-ade ligand links three independent Zn ions, and two Zn ions (Zn1 and Zn2) are bridged together by one μ3-ade ligand and two 4-pca ligands to form a dinuclear unit with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.3338(15) Å. All independent Zn ions adopt tetrahedral coordination geometry. The dinuclear unit is surrounded by one μ3-ade ligand, one aqua molecule, and three 4-pca ligands, while the simple Zn3 center is bonded by two nitrogen atoms from two ade ligands and two oxygen atoms from two 4-pca ligands. The dinuclear units and the Zn3 centers are further connected to other neighboring units to construct a 3D open framework (Figure b). Here, both the binuclear unit and Zn3 center act as 4-connected nodes, so the final framework of 1 can be topologically represented as a qtz net (Figure c). Since qtz net is intrinsically chiral, the chirality presented in this framework is obvious. The framework of 1 contains right-handed helices along the b-axis, giving rise to the left-handed channel (Figures b,d); the opening size of the window is ~5.2 Å × 6.7 Å, which is explored by the Poreblazer V 3.1.2 program. The void volume of 1 is 53.3% of the crystal volume (1972.3 out of the 3700.4 Å3 unit cell volume), calculated by PLATON (probe radius = 1.80 Å). 

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 was carried out under N2 atmosphere (Figure S1 in the ), revealing that compound 1 can be stable up to 320 °C. A fresh sample of 1 was dipped in methanol, the solution was exchanged ten times in 3 days, and then TGA of the activated sample was also performed. Activated compound 1 has weight loss of about 27% from 30 to 250 °C, indicating that the guests can be removed from the framework. Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement for 1 was performed from room temperature to 240 °C under an air atmosphere (Figure  and Figure S2, ). The peaks of dehydrated compound 1 shows obvious shifting from low angles to high angles (9.94°, 11.27°, and 22.25° oriented toward to 10.38°, 11.98°, and 23.93°, respectively), confirming the flexibility and shrinkage of the framework. Moreover, the energy of the structure without guest molecules was minimized by Materials Studio/Forcite. The peak positions of the computational model from 10.19° shift slightly toward high angle compared with the peaks of the original sample. This result also proves that the framework has a degree of flexibility (Figure S4, ). Additionally, the PXRD patterns could return back the original one, when the activated 1 was immersed in DMF solvent again (Figure S3 in the ). The results show that the contraction-opening of the framework is reversible.

The flexible features of the porous framework as well as free amino groups presented in the pores prompted us to investigate the gas sorption properties of 1. The permanent porosity of the desolvated form of 1 was established by N2 sorption experiments at 77 K, which showed type-I adsorption isotherm behavior (Figure S5 in the ). The Langmuir and BET surface areas were 526.8 and 368.7 m2 g-1, respectively.

The adsorption of the C1 to C3 light hydrocarbons was performed at 273 K and room temperature. The gas sorption isotherms of 1 are shown in Figure . Generally, the adsorption capacity of CH4 is relatively low, due to the weak interaction between methane and framework. The uptake values of other small hydrocarbons follow the trend C2H2 > C2H4 > C2H6 ~ C3H8, which is in line with the increasing of kinetic diameter of the gases. Moreover, large hysteretic behaviors can be observed. Compound 1 can take up 134.0 cm3 g -1 C2H2, and a moderate amount of C2H4 (90.0 cm3 g-1), C2H6 (84.3 cm3 g-1), and C3H8 (80 cm3 g-1) at 273 K and 1 bar and C2H2 (109.9 cm3 g-1), C2H4 (79.3 cm3 g-1), C2H6 (69.3 cm3 g-1), and C3H8 (73.4 cm3 g-1) at 290 K and 1 bar.

Specially, for the dynamic adsorption of compound 1 at 273 K, the adsorption branch of C2H2 shows a slight slope on the whole. The desorption pathway cannot trace the adsorption curve, resulting in a hysteretic behavior. Different from C2H2, the isotherms of C2H4 and C2H6 show distinct hysteretic loops. The opening pressure from narrow pore to big pore need 610 and 550 mmHg for C2H4 and C2H6, then the C2H4 and C2H6 adsorption abruptly increase, and the door-closing pressure is nearly up to 760 mmHg for C2H4 and C2H6. Moreover, the desorption branches only have slight decrease until 89 and 101 mmHg, generating very large hysteretic loops. These results indicate that such compound could serve as the candidate for ethylene and ethane storage via a kinetics-based trapping process. For C3H8, the first stage reaches the inflection point at a very low pressure of 29 mmHg, and the uptake is close to saturation at 110 mmHg. Obviously, the transformation pressure between narrow pore and large pore of C3H8 becomes lower than that of C2H4 and C2H6.

Structural analysis and magnetic properties of the 2-D compounds [M(N3)2(bpa)]n (M = Mn, Co or Ni; bpa = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane)

Isomorphous compounds exhibiting the general formula [M(N3)2(bpa)]n (M = MnII1, CoII2 or NiII3; bpa = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) have been prepared and magnetostructurally characterised. X-Ray diffraction analysis revealed a 2-D arrangement of octahedrally co-ordinated metal cations where di-μ-(1,3)-N3-bridged metallic chains are connected through bpa ligands. IR and UV-VIS spectra were consistent with this structural characterisation. Magnetic analysis carried out by means of ESR spectroscopy and susceptibility measurements indicated that the three compounds are antiferromagnetic, J values being -5.7, -14.0 and -80 cm-1 for 1, 2 and 3, respectively.

The diffuse reflectance spectrum for compound 2 is typical of octahedral high spin cobalt(II) complexes. Thus, the UV-VIS spectrum shows three spin-allowed transitions from 4T1g to 4T2g (ν1 8698 cm-1), 4A2g (ν2 18886 cm-1) and 4T1g(P) (ν3 20585 cm-1), respectively, the ν2 transition appearing as a shoulder of ν3 (ν2/ν1 = 2.17). The values of Dq = 683 cm-1 and B = 668 cm-1 which have been calculated from these transitions are typical for high spin cobalt(II) complexes. The value of B is indicative of a 70% covalency of the Co-N bonds in 2. The spectrum also shows a charge-transfer band above 30000 cm-1.

Compound 3 exhibits four UV-VIS bands which have been assigned to the spin allowed transitions from 3A2g to 3T2g (ν1 9622 cm-1), 3T1g (ν3 15867 cm-1) and 3T1g(P) (ν4 28800 cm-1) and the spin forbidden transition to 1Eg (ν2 15415 cm-1). According to these bands, values of Dq = 962 cm-1, B = 954 cm-1 and C = 4175 cm-1 have been calculated (indicating an 88% covalency of the Ni-N bonds). These values are typical for octahedral nickel(II) compounds. The spectrum also shows a charge-transfer band above 35000 cm-1.

ESR spectroscopy and magnetic properties

X-Band powdered ESR spectra recorded for compound 1 exhibit isotropic signals (g ;= 2.000) over the whole range of temperature (4-300 K) studied. This  is consistent with the presence of octahedral MnN6 chromophores in which manganese(II) ions are very slightly distorted. In order to study the thermal variation of the area under the ESR signal (which is directly proportional to the magnetic susceptibility), the ΔH (linewidth in Gauss) and I (intensity in arbitrary units) of the signals at each temperature were estimated by fitting the spectra by Lorentzian curves (R > 0.999 for T ≥ 50 K, >0.99 for T ≥ 15 K, >0.96 for T ≥ 4 K). The variations of the gain, attenuation and modulation amplitude during measurements were considered for the fitting.

Plotting ΔHvs. T () reveals that the linewidth remains practically constant down to 50 K, at which a broadening can be observed. The great increase of the linewidth is indicative of 1-D magnetic coupling taking place at low temperatures. This can also be deduced from the analysis of the thermal variation of the signal area (I⋅ΔH product which is also shown in ). Thus, I⋅ΔH values continuously increase upon cooling to a broad maximum (ca. 65 K) below which the curve rapidly decreases. The 1-D ordering temperature has been estimated to be 36 K, at which a tangent plotted on the increasing region of ΔH reaches the zero value (). The nature and extension of the 1-D magnetic coupling deduced from ESR spectroscopy will be discussed below after analysing the magnetic susceptibility data.

 shows the thermal variation of the magnetic susceptibility, χm, and the χmT product for compound 1. As can be seen, χm values increase for decreasing temperatures (from 11.31 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1 at RT) reaching a broad maximum at 62 K (18.18 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1). The curve drops to a minimum at 12 K (15.35 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1), at which χm values exponentially increase upon further cooling. The χmT magnitude continuously decreases with decreasing temperature. On the other hand, χm-1 has been observed not to follow the Curie-Weiss law over the measured temperature range.

Taking into account that the magnetic interactions through bpa ligands must be very weak, just the coupling through azide-bridged chains should be considered to be responsible for the bulk magnetic behaviour. Therefore, magnetic data can be interpreted in terms of an infinite-spin, linear chain model, , scaled for S = 5/2, where N and k are the Avogadro and Boltzmann constants, respectively, and β is the Bohr magneton. According to , the best fit parameters for compound 1 have been determined to be g = 2.003 (in good agreement with the experimental data) and J = -5.7 cm-1. As can be seen in , this theoretical curve quite well reproduces the thermal variation of χm, with the exception of the region below 12 K. These data indicate the occurrence of antiferromagnetic coupling along the di-μ-(1,3)-N3 chains, which accounts for the bulk magnetic behaviour down to the minimum. The further increase of χm can be explained by considering the presence of a paramagnetic impurity of the same molar mass as 1 whose contribution (δ) can be evaluated by means of . The best fitting obtained by using  corresponds to δ = 0.002 and the same values of J and g (-5.7 cm-1 and 2.003, respectively). As can be seen in , the corresponding theoretical curve does reproduce a minimum at 12 K but exhibits noticeable discrepancy with the experimental χm around it. Therefore, although present in small amount, the contribution of the impurity clearly obscures the antiferromagnetic coupling at very low temperatures.

The magnetic data recorded for compound 2 are displayed in  as the thermal variation of χm and χmT. As can be observed, the curves are qualitatively similar to those for 1. Thus, χm values increase (from 8.58 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1 at RT) upon cooling reaching a maximum (ca. 62 K, 14.02 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1), followed by a drop to 26 K (1.30 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1) and a further increase. Additionally, the χmvs. T curve shows another small maximum at 54 K (14.59 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1) which will be discussed below. The χmT values, on the other hand, continuously decrease upon cooling. As for 1, χm-1 does not follow the Curie-Weiss law. The bulk magnetic behaviour of compound 2 should also be expected to be the result of the antiferromagnetic coupling along the azide-bridged chains. Therefore, χm* in  has been calculated by using χm in  scaled for S = 3/2. The best fit parameters were J = -14.0 cm-1, g = 2.69 and δ = 0.015 (the molar mass of the impurity being the same as that of 2). As can be seen in , the theoretical data quite well reproduce both χm and χmT experimental values, with the exception of the region close to the minimum in χm. This discrepancy can be attributed to the fact that S = 1/2 can be expected to be the most populated state at low temperatures. It should also be pointed out that, on the JS(S + 1) criterion (S(S + 1) being the scaling parameter for , the values of J for 1 and 2 are comparable in magnitude.

2.2 Thermal studies of complex (1)

The thermal behaviour of (1) has been examined by  performed under an inert atmosphere of flowing  gas (25 cm3 min-1) with a heating rate of 20 °C min-1. The DTG of the precursor (1) shows systematic four distinct stages of heat gain at 107.7, 278.5, 328.7 and 448.6 °C () during the thermal pyrolysis process. The  indicates that thermal degradation of (1) begins slowly with the loss of one THF molecule at 107.7 °C, consistent with a weight loss of 5.8%. The second and major degradation of the complex takes place in the temperature range of 107.7-278.5 °C corresponding to a weight loss of 35.5%. This weight loss is attributed to the loss of three THF molecules and two acetate groups. The third phase begins with the loss of two trifluoroacetate groups showing a weight loss of 54.9% of the total mass of the complex (1) at 328.7 °C. Most of the compound has been degraded before the onset of the final pyrolysis stage. The final step of the weight loss begins at 448 °C yielding a solid residue. Further heating of the residue to 600 °C did not bring any change in weight indicating complete  of (1) to furnish a 34.2% of the residual mass, which is a little greater than the expected value of 32% for CdO as indicated in the chemical equation below:

This small difference in weight% of CdO is attributed to the presence of carbon contamination that is not removed at this temperature. This is also supported by  of the thin films.  

2.3  studies

A representative  pattern of zinc-cadmium oxide solid solution thin films prepared in THF solution is shown in . Similar patterns were observed for films deposited from  and  and are given in the ESI (Fig. S7 and S8). All the diffraction peaks can be indexed to the hexagonal wurtzite structure of ZnO with lattice constants of a = 3.25 and c = 5.22 Å, and the diffraction pattern matches well with the literature. In the XRD, peaks at 2θ values of 31.68°, 34.36°, 36.1°, 47.42° and 56.2° correspond respectively to (100), (002), (101), (102) and (110) lattice reflection planes of a hexagonal wurtzite structure showing that the 17% substitution of small Zn (r = 74 Å) by the large Cd (r = 97 Å) atoms did not bring any change in the original hexagonal structure of ZnO. Furthermore, no impurities such as CdO (intense peak at 2θ = 44.228° is missing) or formation of any other phase were detected.

2.5 Band gap

We have chosen thin films having particle sizes in the nanorange and possessing high concentrations of cadmium for band gap measurements. The  of thin films deposited at 500 °C using THF  having a thickness of 350 nm ( KLA Tencore P-6 surface profiler) was recorded on a Lambda 35 Perkin-Elmer   in the wavelength range of 300-850 nm using a similar FTO coated glass substrate as a reference to exclude the substrate contribution in the spectrum. The   of the Zn0.83Cd0.17O thin film shows an absorption edge at 402 nm and the band gap was calculated by plotting the Tauc plot of energy versus (αhν)2 to give a value of 2.40 eV () for the band gap. It is reported in the literature that band gap of Zn(1-x)CdxO solid solution thin films highly depends on the value of x (cadmium contents), which shows the band gap of 2.3 and 2.5 eV for 20 and 14% Cd contents respectively. In our case incorporation of 17% Cd gave a band gap of 2.4 eV that is in a good agreement with the reported value.

2.6 Photoelectrochemical properties of Zn(1-x)CdxO thin films

The effect of nature of , film deposition temperature and electrolyte concentration on photoresponse of the thin film electrodes under illumination (L) and dark (D) conditions was investigated and presented in . It is evident that photocurrent density heavily depends on morphology, deposition temperature and electrolytic concentration. The photoelectrodes deposited from THF solution at 500 °C produce the maximum photocurrent in 0.5 M NaOH solution. The formation of  shaped structures from THF deposition solution is attributed to the higher heat of  of THF (2501 kJ mol-1) as compared to  (736 kJ mol-1) and  (1370 kJ mol-1).

4 Conclusion

In summary hexagonal nanostructured zinc-cadmium oxide solid solution Zn(1-x)CdxO thin films were deposited on FTO coated glass substrates from a common solution of  and a newly developed polymeric cadmium precursor [Cd3(TFA)4(OAC)2(THF)4]n (1) by the aerosol-assisted chemical vapour deposition () technique and applied for photoelectrochemical  splitting. Various parameters have been studied to optimize the conditions for fabrication of stable, robust and efficient photoelectrode thin films. The  analysis of the photoelectrode thin films shows that the morphology of the grown thin films strongly depends upon physical characteristics of the . Photoelectrodes grown out of THF solution have higher concentration of Cd and showed to have better photocatalytic activity than the photoelectrodes grown from  and  that have lower Cd concentration. A band gap of 2.40 eV and a photocurrent density of 0.23 mA cm-2 at 0.60 V vs. Ag/AgCl/3 M KCl (~1.23 V vs. RHE) have been obtained for photoelectrodes grown from THF solution that indicates that the material has potential for photoelectrochemical and solar energy applications such as photovoltaic cells and photocatalytic  of organic contaminants.
