A cobalt arylphosphonate MOF - superior stability, sorption and magnetism

We report a novel metal-organic framework (MOF) based on a cobalt arylphosphonate, namely, [Co2(H4-MTPPA)]⋅3NMP⋅H2O (1⋅3NMP⋅H2O), which was prepared solvothermically from the tetrahedral linker tetraphenylmethane tetrakis-4-phosphonic acid (H8-MTPPA) and CoSO4⋅7H2O in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). Compound 1 has the highest porosity (BET surface area of 1034 m2 g-1) ever reported for a MOF based on an aryl phosphonic acid linker. The indigo blue crystals of 1⋅3NMP⋅H2O are composed of edge-shared eight-membered Co2P2O4 rings, and are thermally very stable up to 500 °C.

The BET surface area of 1 was derived from its simulated N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K obtained by grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations (ESI). Such calculations have been widely used for characterizing the surface area of MOF materials. The calculated BET surface area for 1, 1034 m2 g-1, is 107 m2 g-1 higher than that reported for its Zn analogue, Zn2H4-MTPPA, which was 927 m2 g-1. However, it is significantly higher compared to the isostructural zinc compound Zn2H4-STPPA (565 m2 g-1). The same chain pattern was also observed in structurally rigid naphthalene arylphosphonate linkers with square pyramidal and octahedral metal atoms producing microporous frameworks. The stability of such edge shared Zn2P2O4 chains is significant as robust inorganic building units for future metal organophosphonate compounds, which could hypothetically produce isoreticularly expanding void channels with tetratopic, tritopic and ditopic ligands with expanding tether lengths. As seen in the thermogravimetric analysis graphic (see ESI), the compound is an unusually stable MOF as organic components from MTPPA start decomposing at ca. 525 °C, and 27% (calculated 29.5%) of total weight loss of MTPPA continues until 700 °C. The initial ca. 20% (calculated 27%) weight loss corresponds to the solvent molecules (ESI). A recent article about ultra stable ZrH4-STPPA also shows a similar STPPA decomposition pattern but 1 is approximately 100 °C more stable than the previously reported zirconium compound, which was not porous. The magnetism in MOFs is an active research area. We investigated the magnetic properties of 1via ab initio calculations (ESI). Spin-polarized density functional theory analysis is performed on the structure that is revealed from XRD data and it is observed that the electronic structure tends to converge towards a state where a net spin of 3 per Co atom is established (). While the charge density of this net spin has been observed to concentrate mainly around Co atoms it is not totally localized and extends throughout the structure along the b axis of the crystal which may point to a ferromagnetic interaction between Co atoms as well as the magnetic anisotropy in the crystal.

In conclusion, we report an extremely stable and rare metal-organic framework (MOF) based on cobalt arylphosphonates. The calculated surface area of 1034 m2 g-1 indicates that 1 has the largest surface area synthesized with a tetrahedral arylphosphonic acid. The extreme stability (up to 500 °C) at high temperatures is certainly a great advantage for potential industrial applications. Metal organophosphonates already have a myriad of applications, such as the catalysis of butane to maleic anhydride, imaging, bone remodelling, identifying micro calcifications, proton conductivity and osteoporosis treatment etc. Moreover, organophosphonates are thought to be involved in many biochemical pathways. The porous metal arylphosphonate compounds are rare but the recent efforts using the novel arylphosphonate linkers have been gradually contributing to the library of porous metal organophosphonates.

Physicochemical properties

Complexes 1 and 2 each have a subnormal magnetic moment at room temperature (0.99 and 0.70 μB, respectively) suggesting an operation of antiferromagnetic interaction within the molecules. The χAvs.T curves for 1 and 2 are given in . The magnetic susceptibility for 1 decreased with decreasing temperature to a near plateau value of 50 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 around 90 K and showed an increase below 50 K. The plateau value corresponds to the temperature-independent paramagnetism arising from the second-order Zeeman effect. Similarly, the magnetic susceptibility of 2 continuously decreased with decreasing temperature to a plateau value of 60 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 near 110 K and showed an increase below 50 K. The slight increase in magnetic susceptibility at low temperature suggests the presence of paramagnetic impurities. Magnetic simulations were carried out using the Bleaney-Bowers equation involving a correction term for paramagnetic impurities ():

where N is Avogadro's number, β is the Bohr magneton, k is the Boltzmann constant, J is the exchange integral, T is the absolute temperature, Nα is the temperature-independent paramagnetism, and ρ is the fraction of paramagnetic impurity. A good magnetic simulation was obtained for 1 with , using magnetic parameters of g  =  2.07, J  =  -255 cm-1, Nα  =  50 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1, and ρ  =  0.003. The discrepancy factor defined as R(χ)  =  [Σ(χobsd - χcalcd)2/Σ(χobsd)2]1/2 was 0.053. Similarly, the cryomagnetic property of 2 was well reproduced by , using magnetic parameters of g  =  2.07, J  =  -355 cm-1, Nα  =  60 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1, and ρ  =  0.0006. The discrepancy factor defined was 0.052.

The χAvs.T curve of 3 is given in . The magnetic moment at room temperature is 3.07 μB which decreased with decreasing temperature to 0.46 μB at 2 K. The magnetic susceptibility increased with decreasing temperature to a maximum value at 28 K and then decreased. Such cryomagnetic behavior is typical of a dinuclear Ni(S  =  1)Ni(S  =  1) system exhibiting an intramolecular antiferromagnetic interaction. The increase in magnetic susceptibility at low temperature indicates the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurity. Thus, magnetic simulations for 3 ware carried out using the magnetic susceptibility  including the correction term for the paramagnetic impurity:

The cryomagnetic property of 3 could be well reproduced by this equation using the magnetic parameters, J  =  -10 cm-1, g  =  2.12, Nα  =  300 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 and ρ  =  0.03. The discrepancy factor for the magnetic simulation was 0.056.

Complex 4 has a room-temperature magnetic moment of 6.32 μB that decreased with decreasing temperature to 5.58 μB at 2 K. Evidently an antiferromagnetic interaction operates between the adjacent CuII and MnII ions through the carboxylate group, but it must be emphasized that the magnetic moment at 2 K is significantly low for   =  5/2 arising from an antiferromagnetic interaction within the pentanuclear CuCuMnCuCu unit. It appears that an intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction also occurs between the adjacent pentanuclear units, probably through the Cu2-O5b-N2b-Cu1b pathway.

Low temperature heat capacity, standard entropy, standard enthalpy and magnetic property: a new 1D CuII coordination polymer incorporating tetrazole-1-acetic acid and p-nitrobenzoic acid

A new 1D CuII coordination polymer, formulated as {[Cu(TZA)(PNA)]⋅H2O}n (1) (HTZA = tetrazole-1-acetic acid, HPNA = p-nitrobenzoic acid), was synthesized and structurally characterized. Thermogravimetric analysis demonstrated that the main frame of 1 exhibited good thermostability up to 473 K. The non-isothermal kinetics for the first exothermic process of 1 were studied by Kissinger and Ozawa methods. The magnetic study revealed that 1 possessed antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between CuII ions through the carboxyl-bridge. The low-temperature (1.9 to 300 K) heat capacity of 1 was measured using the heat-capacity option of a Quantum Design Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS). In addition, the thermodynamic functions in the experimental temperature range were derived by fitting the heat-capacity data to a series of theoretical and empirical models. The standard entropy and standard enthalpy of 1 were respectively calculated to be 411.37 ± 4.11 J mol-1 K-1 and 60.21 ± 0.60 kJ mol-1.

2.2. Low-temperature heat-capacity measurements

The heat-capacity measurement was performed using a Quantum Design PPMS in zero magnetic field with logarithmic spacing over the temperature range from 1.9 to 100 K and at 10 K intervals from 100 to 300 K. The accuracy of the heat-capacity measurements on a high-purity copper pellet and α-Al2O3 cylinder (SRM720) was found to be ±2% and ±1% in the temperature ranges from 1.9 to 20 K and from 20 to 400 K, respectively. The crystalline sample was measured according to a PPMS heat-capacity measurement technique developed by Shi et al., and the accuracy of this technique was verified to be ±3% and ±1% in the temperature ranges below 20 K and from 20 to 300 K, respectively, by measuring a powdered benzoic acid sample (SRM 39j) using PPMS. The details of the sample preparation and the heat-capacity experimental procedure can be found in related publications. In general, sample mounting consisted of mixing the sample with copper strips in a copper cup, which was then compressed into a pellet using a stainless steel die. The copper cup was formed from a 0.025 mm thick pure copper foil, with a mass fraction purity of 0.99999, while the pellet had a 2.8 mm diameter and height of 3.5 mm. A typical heat-capacity measurement involved two steps: the heat-capacity measurement of the addenda of the PPMS platform with Apiezon N was first decided as Cp,1, and then the heat capacity of the pellet consisting of the sample, the copper strips, and the copper cup was measured as Cp,2. Thus, the heat capacity for the sample was calculated by subtracting Cp,1 from Cp,2. Using the PPMS technique, the heat capacity of 9.17 mg of a crystalline sample of 1 was measured over the temperature range of 1.9 to 300 K.

3.2 Thermal decomposition

Under the linear heating rate of 10 K min-1, DSC and TG experiments were carried out to investigate the thermal decomposition behavior of a crystalline sample of 1. The DSC and TG curves of 1 are illustrated in . As shown in , 1 possessed one endothermic peak and two continuous exothermic peaks during the thermal decomposition process. The endothermic process begins at 337 K and ends at 365 K. The first exothermic process is from 473 K to 543 K, with the peak temperature at 503.4 K, while the second exothermic decomposition process begins at 543 K and ends at 693 K.

In the TG curve (), there are three weight loss stages from 340 K to 693 K, which correspond to the three processes in the DSC curve. The first weight loss stage starts at 340 K and ends at 365 K, with a weight loss of 4.65% involving the loss of solvent water (calcd, 4.80%). From 473 to 693 K, there are two successive weight loss stages, which can be considered as from breaking the TZA- and PNA- ligands. After that, the polymer is completely converted to CuO with a residue weight percentage of 21.10%, which is in good agreement with the calculated value of 21.23%. The remaining CuO was evidenced by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (Fig. S1).

3.4 Magnetic property

Magnetic measurements were performed on crystalline samples of 1 in the temperature range of 1.9-300 K. The temperature-dependent susceptibilities of 1 under a 1000 Oe applied field are shown in .

It can be observed that the χMT value at 300 K is 0.34 cm3 K mol-1, corresponding to 1.66μB of the CuII magnetic moment, which is a littler smaller than the expected magnetically isolated spin only value of 1.73μB (0.37 cm3 K mol-1, S = 1/2, g = 2.0), indicating that there already exist antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the two CuII ions at 300 K through the carboxyl groups-bridging. As shown in , the χMT value gradually decreases as the temperature decreases from 300 K to 70 K. This experimental fact indicates a very strong antiferromagnetic coupling interaction existing in the CuII dimes. Besides, there is a minimum magnetization present at 65 K in the curve when further lowering the temperature, and also an abrupt increase in the magnetic moment at T = 20 K can be seen. This could be attributed to a small amount of paramagnetic impurities present. According to the structure of 1, the antiferromagnetic interactions originate from the carboxyl groups-bridging (J) CuII ions; therefore we fitted the χMT versus T plot using  to take into account a proportion of the non-coupled CuII ions above 70 K. (3)where J is the exchange parameter and ρ is the percentage of paramagnetic impurities. The fitting gives the parameters J = -159 cm-1, g = 2.15, and ρ = 0.09, further confirming the antiferromagnetic interaction between the CuII ions. The field cooling (FC) and zero field cooling (ZFC) curves measured in 1000 Oe are shown in . It can be observed that the two curves are almost coincide from 300 K to 70 K, while the two curves diverge below 70 K, which is caused by some kind of disordered magnetic state of the impurities. The isothermal field-dependent magnetization measured at 10, 50, 80, and 300 K is shown in the inset of . It is in agreement with the results of the M-T curves, and shows that the coercivity of the sample increases with decreasing the temperature.

3.5 Low-temperature heat capacity

The heat capacity of the crystalline samples of 1 measured by PPMS are given in  and are plotted vs. temperature in . It can be seen that the heat capacity increases smoothly with the temperature increasing and no thermal anomalies are found in the entire experimental region.

Based on the fitting parameters, the molar thermodynamic functions of 1 were calculated at selected temperatures from 0 to 300 K. The calculated results are listed in . The standard molar entropy and the standard molar enthalpy at T = 298.15 K were calculated to be 411.37 ± 4.11 J mol-1 K-1 and 60.21 ± 0.60 kJ mol-1, respectively.

b

Standard uncertainties u are u(T) = 0.01 K and u(p) = 2 kPa.

4. Conclusion

In summary, a new 1D CuII coordination polymer constructed from tetrazole-1-acetic acid and p-nitrobenzoic acid was synthesized and structurally characterized. Its main frame possessed good thermostability up to 473 K. The Arrhenius equation for the thermal decomposition process of the polymer can be expressed as lnk = 42.81 - 196.02 × 103/RT. The magnetic behavior indicates that antiferromagnetic exchange interactions exist between the CuII ions through the carboxyl-bridge. This result was confirmed by the low-temperature heat-capacity of the polymer. This demonstrates that the magnetic property is the main contribution to heat capacity. Moreover, the standard entropy and standard enthalpy of the polymer at T = 298.15 K were respectively calculated to be 411.37 ± 4.11 J mol-1 K-1 and 60.21 ± 0.60 kJ mol-1. Work is underway on probing the relationship between the magnetic property and low-temperature heat-capacity of polynuclear coordination polymers.

Four nodal self-catenated [{Ni8(Bpy)16}V24O68]⋅8.5(H2O), combining three dimensional metal-organic and inorganic frameworks

The chiral three dimensional crystal structure of [{Ni8(Bpy)16}V24O68]⋅8.5(H2O) is the first example of a hybrid vanadate combining a three dimensional metal-organic subnet with a three dimensional inorganic framework. The metal-organic framework consists of 3D + 2D polycatenation of a 3D "cds" like net and two 2D "sql" layers. The  subunit is a complex chain constructed from V5O15 cycles linked through a single tetrahedron. The vanadate chains are located in the channels of the metal-organic framework, and corner linked to the nickel metal centres giving rise to an unprecedented four nodal self-catenated framework. Moreover, as far as we as concerned, this is the first vanadate in which the V5O15 cycles has been isolated in the solid state. The   molecules are partially encapsulated between the organic ligands and the inorganic framework. The loss of   molecules gives rise to a contraction of the 0.6% of the unit  volume. The  shows the characteristic bands of the  subunit, and the bpy ligand. The BET measurement gives rise to a type III profile, (3.7 cm2 g-1), suggesting weak adsorbate-adsorbent interactions. The thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility is attributed to the zero-field splitting for eight non interacting Ni(II) cations.

The BET measurement shows that the compound has a small surface area (3.7 m2 g-1) (). The sorption and desorption isotherms have a type III profile, characteristic of weak adsorbate-adsorbent interactions, and most commonly associated with both non-microporous and microporous adsorbents. The radius value of the , obtained from BET measurements, is 1.93 Å, which is slightly greater than the calculated from the scan method. This results could possibly be attributed to the method employed for surface area measurement. There are difficulties associated with performing BET  surface area measurements of organic-inorganic compounds with large organic surface .

The thermal behaviour of the title compound was studied by  (ESI, Fig S8) and thermodiffractometry (). The  exhibits two steps of weight loss. The first one, with a value of 3.0%, between room temperature and 80 °C, corresponds to the loss of   (calcd 2.8%); and the second one (380-450 °C), with a value of 44.2%, is related to the exothermic loss of the bpy ligands (calcd 46.3%). The thermal behaviour was also studied by time resolved  in an air atmosphere. The thermodiffraction analysis reveals that the crystal structure is stable up to 370 °C, in good agreement with the . However, the powder patterns show that the crystallinity decreases dramatically by 355 °C (). At higher temperatures, several inorganic vanadates and vanadium oxides are observed: NiV3O8 + NiV2O6 (370-445 °C) → NiV2O6 + V2O5 (445-480 °C).(). The visual analysis of some reflections, related to the initial compound, shows the existence of significant displacements with temperature (). Qualitatively, two trends are observed during the heating process, the first one between 25 and 100 °C, and the second one in the temperature range 100-370 °C.

In the  (ESI, Fig. S10), two absorption bands of strong intensity corresponding to the allowed transitions: 3A2g(3F) → 3T2g(3F), 3T1g(3F), at 9800, and 16000 cm-1 are observed. At higher frequencies a broad band due to the charge transfer is detected. From the spin transitions corresponding to the d8-high spin Ni(II) cation in octahedral geometry, the Dq and Racah B parameters have been calculated, by using the energy expressions given in the Tanabe-Sugano diagrams. The values are Dq = 980 and B = 875 cm-1. The B-parameter is, approximately, 85% of that of the free Ni(II) cation (1030 cm-1), which indicates an appreciable covalent character in the chemical bonds inside the NiN4O2 octahedron.

Magnetic measurements for the title compound were performed in a powdered sample from room temperature to 5.0 K, at a magnetic field of 0.1 T. The thermal evolution of the molar magnetic susceptibility, χm, and χmT vs. T is shown in . The χmT value at 300 K is (9.34 cm3 K mol-1) near the expected (9.68 cm3 K mol-1) for eight non-interacting Ni(II) (S = 1, g = 2.2) ions. The χm curve shows a continuous increase of its value between 300 K (0.03559 cm3 mol-1) to 5 K (1.459 cm3 mol-1). Due to the large distance between Ni(II) ions (approx. 8.3 Å through the vanadate chains and 11.2 Å through the bpy ligand) significant exchange interactions between the metal centres are not expected. Therefore, the decrease of the χmT value with decreasing temperature is attributed to the zero-field splitting, typical of an axially distorted d8 high spin isolated Ni(II) system.

Heterometallic CuII/LnIII polymers active in the catalytic aerobic oxidation of cycloalkenes under solvent-free conditions

Heterometallic 3d-4f inorganic polymers were prepared using 3,5 pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2PDC), {[CuLn2(PDC)2(SO4)2(H2O)6]⋅H2O}n (Ln: SmIII, CuSmPDC, EuIII, CuEuPDC, GdIII, and CuGdPDC). These catalysts are active in the aerobic oxidation of cycloalkenes under solvent-free conditions, with a conversion for the oxidation of cyclohexene of 71% after one hour of the reaction, and a TOF value of 1438 h-1 for CuSmPDC. On the other hand, the oxidation of cycloheptene and cyclooctene exhibited slightly lower conversions of 52% and 47%, and TOF values of 1053 and 159 h-1 after 1 and 6 hours of the reaction, respectively. The radical mechanism for the oxidation reaction of cyclohexene was assessed by Raman and EPR spectroscopy. The first evidenced the formation of Cu-O2 adducts and the second permitted is to observe the presence of the oxygen centered radical species, which act as initiators of the reaction chain to generate the products. An increase in the temperature of the reaction correlates with the adduct formation, and with the enhancement of the oxidation reaction.

The effect of the oxygen concentration was tested using pressures from 1 to 5 bar (). These results show a direct dependence of the conversion on the oxygen pressure; the best result was 71% after 1 hour of the reaction using 5 bar of the initial pressure. In addition, an experiment performed with an initial 5 bar pressure was recharged with 5 more bar of oxygen, when the first amount of oxygen was consumed. For this reaction, the conversion reached 90% after one additional hour. The selectivity was also pressure dependent; Fig. S10 shows the selectivity for all experiments. The main product at 1 bar was cyclohexenol (56%) and cyclohexenone (34%), while the main product at 5 bar was cyclohexenone (51%) and cyclohexenol dropped to 44%. These results can be easily explained since cyclohexenol is an intermediate product of oxidation, which with the increase of pressure is transformed into the ketone. Furthermore, when the reaction mixture was recharged with 5 bar after the initial oxygen was consumed, the main product continued to be the ketone (64%), while one extra product was detected, 1,2-cyclohexanediol (11%) (Fig. S10). These results can be explained by assuming that the new amount of oxygen allowed the oxidation reaction to continue with the generation of the diol.

An example of a heterometallic catalyst is {[Cu0.5La2(HPDC)(PDC)2(SO4)(H2O)2]⋅H2O}n, also active in the oxidation of cyclohexene at 120 °C, under a pressure of 5 bar of oxygen. The conversion after 6 h was 70% with 60% of selectivity to ketone, with a TOF value of 61 h-1. These results are very interesting since it was the first heterometallic 3d-4f MOF used for this kind of reaction. In this work, we have been able to obtain better results with {[CuLn2(PDC)2(SO4)2(H2O)6]⋅H2O}n (LnIII: Sm, Gd, Eu) for only 1 h of the reaction, using a substrate/catalyst ratio based on copper(II) as the active species of 3200/1, the TOF values for these three catalysts being ca. 1400 h-1. The main difference between the studied heterometallic frameworks and the previously reported catalyst {[Cu0.5La2(HPDC)(PDC)2(SO4)(H2O)2]⋅H2O}n is the first coordination sphere of the copper(II) ion. While in all the herein studied {[CuLn2(PDC)2(SO4)2(H2O)6]⋅H2O}n, the first coordination sphere of copper(II) has two coordinated water molecules; in the reported {[Cu0.5La2(HPDC)(PDC)2(SO4)(H2O)2]⋅H2O}n, these are lacking. When these water molecules are lost at 120 °C in the studied catalysts producing two vacant positions, these allow the interaction of oxygen with the active metal centres, and the subsequent initiation of the catalytic cycle. This fact can be used to explain the higher conversion and the excellent TOF values for {[CuLn2(PDC)2(SO4)2(H2O)6]⋅H2O}n catalysts.

Conclusions

A family of heterometallic inorganic polymers, based on CuII and LnIII, {[CuLn2(PDC)2(SO4)2(H2O)6]⋅H2O}n (Ln: SmIII, EuIII, GdIII), has been shown to be active in the oxidation of cyclohexene, using molecular oxygen as the sole oxidant, with similar conversion results for the three catalysts. Due to the existence of labile water molecules in the first coordination sphere of the active copper(II) centres in the studied frameworks, which permits the formation of vacant sites and the corresponding interaction with molecular oxygen, the studied CuLnPDC exhibit an enhanced catalytic activity, compared to the previously reported CuLaPDC. The detection of Cu-O2 adducts by Raman spectroscopy and oxygen-centred radicals by EPR permitted us to infer the mechanism by which the oxidation reaction proceeds. On the other hand, the oxidation of cycloheptene and cyclooctene exhibited slightly lower conversions of 52% and 47%, and TOF values of 1053 and 159 h-1 at 1 and 6 hours of reaction, respectively.

Interestingly, ten B(im)4- ligands use 28 im linkers to join ten Co2+ nodes, generating a distorted GIS-cage with a pore size about 7 Å in diameter (). Similar to the traditional GIS-cage in zeolite, the distorted GIS cage in BIF-41 contains four 8-rings and six 4-rings. It is noteworthy that the 8-ring perpendicular to the c-axis is divided into two 5-rings by the ad ligand that bridges two Co2+ centers. As a result, the channel along the c-axis is partitioned by the ad ligand into an infinite number of finite segments, as well as the window size decreased from 11 × 4.5 to 3.4 × 4.5 Å (). Such partitioning does not affect the 8-ring in the other direction. So, BIF-41 also shows 1D channels along the (101) direction with a window size of about 5 × 5 Å. The pore size distribution curves calculated by Poreblazer also show that the pore-limiting diameter is 3.45 Å and the maximum pore diameter is 5.04 Å (Fig. S3, ESI). The density (T/V) expressed as the number of tetrahedral vertices per unit volume is 3.23 nm-3, larger than that of ZIF and TIF with the GIS topology in the range of 2.31-2.70 nm-3.

 BIF-41 contains structurally disordered solvent molecules in the pores. The solvent accessible volume of BIF-41 is about 35.5% of the total crystal volume as estimated by PLATON program. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that BIF-41 can remain stable up to ca. 270 °C under the N2 atmosphere (Fig. S1, ESI). The sample for gas sorption analysis was activated by immersing the as-synthesized BIF-41 in ethanol for 1 day, then the ethanol-exchanged sample was further degassed at 80 °C prior to the measurement. The purity of the sample and the crystalline framework structure were proven by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies (Fig. S2, ESI).

The gas adsorption measurements of BIF-41 were performed on a micromeritics ASAP 2010 surface area and a pore size analyzer. The N2 measurement at 77 K shows that N2 is hardly adsorbed at all (). The CO2 adsorption measurements at 273 K and 294 K show typical type I isotherms with high uptake (). The CO2 uptake values were 77.0 cm3 g-1 (3.44 mmol g-1) at 273 K and 63.5 cm3 g-1 (2.83 mmol g-1) at 294 K, which are comparable to some highly porous ZIFs. The isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) for CO2 was calculated by using the adsorption data collected at 273 K and 298 K. At zero coverage, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption for BIF-41 is 23.9 KJ mol-1 (Fig. S4, ESI). In addition, the H2 adsorption was also measured at 77 K and 87 K under 1 atm, respectively. The H2 uptake values for BIF-41 are 106.4 cm3 g-1 at 77K and 83.4 cm3 g-1 at 87 K (). These results demonstrate that BIF-41 has selective adsorption of CO2 and H2 over N2. The partitioned channels show a pore size effect preference for CO2 and H2 over N2, as CO2 and H2 have smaller kinetic diameters than N2. The unusually high selectivity can be attributed to the small cages provided by the pore space partition, which facilitate the interaction between small molecules and the channel walls.

The average surface area occupied by a single octadecyl sulfonate molecule in the ab-plane of the crystal structure of 1 amounts to 0.22 nm2. Since the  chains are interdigitated, the density of sulfonate groups in the ab-plane is only half that value (1 SO3-/0.44 nm2) corresponding to an average surface charge density σ of 2.27 SO3-/nm2.

However, on a 10 mM Ca-containing solution octadecyl sulfonate forms relatively stable monolayers, which upon compression start to collapse at a surface pressure above 40 mN m-1 (). The featureless isotherm suggests that there is no sharp phase transition at 22 °C. The first pressure increase is observed at an approximate area of 0.5 nm2 molecule-1. The average area per molecule of octadecyl sulfonate in the monolayer was estimated from extrapolating the Langmuir isotherms toward zero pressure. The value determined by averaging the isotherm data from  independent compression experiments amounts to 0.23 nm2 molecule-1 which is the same value as measured for monolayers of eicosyl sulfate spread on aqueous calcium sulfate solutions and in good agreement with the average area occupied by an octadecyl sulfonate molecule in the ab-plane of 1 ( = 0.22 nm2 molecule-1). Moreover this is close to the limiting area of non-branched amphiphilic alkanols, such as . Note however, that the latter compounds have a sterically less bulky headgroup (-OH as opposed to -SO3-).

We have examined the fluorescence properties of DMSO solutions of 2,2'-bpy, phen, im, DABCO and compounds 1-3 at room temperature, as shown in Fig. S8. The fluorescence spectra of 2,2'-bpy, im, phen and DABCO display emission peaks at 416 (λex = 342 nm), 385 nm (λex = 326 nm), 432 nm (λex = 357 nm) and 412 nm (λex = 337 nm), respectively. The fluorescence spectrum of compound 1 exhibits an emission peak at 393 nm (λex = 338 nm), which is similar to that of im in terms of position and band shape and should be assigned to the intraligand electronic transfer of im. The spectrum of compound 2 shows an emission peak at 439 nm (λex = 381 nm), which is red-shifted relative to that of 2,2'-bpy. The red shift has been regarded as due to the complexation of 2,2'-bpy with coppers in compound 2. The fluorescence spectrum of compound 3 presents an emission peak at 433 nm (λex = 371 nm) which should be assigned to the intraligand electronic transfer of phen.

Gas sorption

Gas sorption properties of the thermally activated forms of Cu-MOFs were investigated by the standard volumetric method. Despite the seemingly sufficient void spaces in all the solvent-free MOFs based on the PLATON analysis, only the activated form of Cu-MOF 2 displayed selective gas sorption ability for CO2 over N2 and H2, as shown in . Both N2 and H2 uptake amounts measured at 77 K were much smaller than the CO2 adsorption amount at 196 K. In the case of N2 adsorption, a sudden increase in the sorption amount was observed only above the gas pressure of 0.90 atm. This observation may be attributed to N2 sorption into the interparticle spaces rather than into the micropores of 2. Contrarily, the adsorption isotherm for H2 gas did not show a sudden increase up to 1 atm. The uptake amounts of CO2 for activated 2 at varying measurement temperatures were as follows: 98.5 cm3 g-1 (4.39 mmol g-1) at 196 K; 39.2 cm3 g-1 (1.75 mmol g-1) at 273 K; and 20.0 cm3 g-1 (0.89 mmol g-1) at 298 K. Interestingly, these values are slightly larger compared with the previously reported values for the thermally activated form of [Cu2(Glu)2(μ-bpa)]⋅CH3CN in which the occupied solvate molecule is CH3CN instead of water: 70.0 cm3 g-1 (3.12 mmol g-1) at 196 K; 26.4 cm3 g-1 (1.18 mmol g-1) at 273 K; and 12.7 cm3 g-1 (0.57 mmol g-1) at 298 K. The CO2 adsorption selectivity over N2 was quantitatively estimated by the initial slope method using data collected at 273 K, as shown in . The calculated CO2/N2 selectivity value was 20.9. This selectivity value is very similar to the reported value for ZIF-69, Zn(cbIm)(nIm), where cbIm is 5-chlorobenzimidazole and nIm is 2-nitroimidazole. Except for compound 2, the other three MOFs did not give meaningful sorption abilities for the three gases after thermal activation.

Antibacterial activities

The antibacterial activities of the four Cu-MOFs, 1, 2, 3, and 4, were studied via determination of their minimal bactericidal concentration (MBC) values against five strains of bacteria, including E. coli, S. Aureus, K. pneumonia, P. aeruginosa, and MRSA, which can easily be met in daily surrounding environments. While the number of colony forming units (CFUs) in the control increased more than 10-fold during incubation for 24 h at 37 °C, bactericidal percentages of the four Cu-MOFs reached 99.9% for all the bacterial strains.  

Any synergistic effects between the metal ion and organic ligands did not appear based on the measured MBC values. Although close relationships between the antibacterial activities and different structures of the Cu-MOFs were not found in our results, fortunately, the antibacterial properties of Cu-MOFs 1-4 are comparable with those of Ag NPs and Co-TDM, which are known to display very low MBC values of 10-15 μg mL-1 within a very short treatment time for the inactivation of E. coli. They were also better than those of the Zn-MOF (MBC, 4300 μg mL-1 against S. aureus and S. epidermidis), cellulose-HKUST-1, and vancomycin loaded Fe-MOF. The recently reported 1D Cu-based coordination polymer, [Cu3(py)6(μ-CH3COO)4(I3)2]n, also showed a relatively large MBC value of 2500 μg mL-1 against E. coli. The MBC values of Cu-MOFs were much lower than those of the antibacterial agent penicillin (125.00 and 500.00 μg mL-1 against E. coli and S. aureus).

Release of CuII ions from Cu-MOFs

In order to confirm the fact that the leaching of CuII ions from Cu-MOFs was not significant, MOF degradation tests were conducted in two media: deionized water and 0.9% saline solution used for the antibacterial tests at room temperature. The quantities of CuII ions released from the Cu-MOFs were monitored by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) after 6 h, 12 h, 24 h and 48 h. As shown in , the concentrations of the released CuII ions from Cu-MOF 2 and 3 increased during the initial 12 h, decreased until 24 h and then increased again. Cu-MOFs 1 and 4 released CuII ions to a maximum concentration of 29 μg mL-1 after immersion for 48 h; however, the average CuII ion concentration for MOF 4 was as low as 7.6 μg mL-1 in the test. Additionally, the release of CuII ions from Cu-MOF 2 in deionized water for 24 h was approximately 10-fold lower than that in 0.9% saline solution () and decreased to 3.5 μg mL-1 until 48 h. Although these degradation trends are similar to those previously reported, the exceptional stability of Cu-MOFs 1-4 in aqueous solution contrasts those of other unstable porous MOFs. Although the amounts of CuII ions released from the four Cu-MOFs for 24 h differ from 11 to 49 μg mL-1, all the Cu-MOFs displayed the same bactericidal abilities against the five kinds of bacteria. The amount of CuII ions released from the MBC of Cu-MOF 4 of 20 μg mL-1 was calculated to be 0.22 μg mL-1, which is too low compared with the MBC value of free CuII ions, which was 12 μg mL-1. From these results, we infer that CuII ions are not only bactericidal but the robust Cu-MOFs themselves that also actively participate in inactivating bacteria.

While the antibacterial mechanisms of metallic materials are complex and diverse, it is well known that Cu ions on metallic surfaces induce damage to bacterial membranes, resulting in cell destruction. In our study, the physical properties of the frameworks, such as the surface area, porosities, and particle size, were thought to be the more important factors that affect bacteria over the chemical properties of the constituents. Because our results indicate that Cu-MOFs cannot easily release CuII ions on their surfaces due to the hydrophobic and robust structure, Cu-based active sites on surfaces primarily make Cu-MOF crystals responsible for the excellent bactericidal property. Additionally, to confirm the fact that CuII ions could not be easily released from Cu-MOFs, the control dishes and antibacterial tested dishes were rinsed with 0.9% saline solution for E. coli, S. aureus, and P. aeruginosa. The amount of CuII ions released from Cu-MOF 2 was 0.243 μg mL-1 for E. coli, 0.036 μg mL-1 for S. aureus, and 0.079 μg mL-1 for P. aeruginosa from ICP-MS data of each solution after antibacterial tests (Table S1). These values are also negligible compared to the MBC value of free CuII ions, 12 μg mL-1.

The collapsed temperatures of the metal-doped STU-1s ranging from 370 to 410 °C under a N2 atmosphere (TGA data in Fig. S9, ESI) indicate the good thermal stability of the frameworks. The porosity of the activated metal doped STU-1s was evaluated by N2 adsorption at 77 K. As shown in , all Cu2+ and Cd2+ doped STU-1s exhibit type I nitrogen adsorption isotherms as a microporous material. The Langmuir (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller, BET) surface areas of Cu0.01-STU-1, Cu0.05-STU-1, Cu0.10-STU-1, Cu0.167-STU-1 and Cd0.6-STU-1 were calculated to be 926(624), 1320(891), 1407(948), 1070(721), 616(414) m2 g-1, respectively, which were obtained by using the data points on the adsorption branch in the P/P0 range of 0.06-0.3. Obviously, the doped metal ions affect the porosity of parent STU-1, and show an enhancement in porosity for Cu0.05-STU-1 and Cu0.10-STU-1 (STU-1, 1255(775) m2 g-1), and a reduction for Cu0.01-STU-1, Cu0.167-STU-1 and Cd0.5-STU-1. The highest adsorption volume of N2 and the BET surface area for Cu0.10-STU-1 are about 50 cm3 g-1 (at P/P0 = 0.3) and about 173 m2 g-1 (enhanced percentage: 22.3%) larger than those of parent STU-1, respectively. The low-pressure CO2 capture ability of 59.4, 79.5, 80.4, 71.0, and 48.1 cm3 g-1 at 1 bar (273 K) for Cu0.01-STU-1, Cu0.05-STU-1, Cu0.10-STU-1, Cu0.167-STU-2, and Cd0.6-STU-1 (), respectively, is in accordance with their order of BET surface areas. The highest value of CO2 uptake (80.4 cm3 g-1) for Cu0.10-STU-1 is obviously higher than that of parent STU-1 (70.2 cm3 g-1), indicating that the CO2 adsorption capacity of STU-1 can be enhanced (14.5%) by doping metal ions.

A sample of MOFs after being treated with boiling water with an unchanged PXRD pattern may not be porous as its pristine sample. The measurement of the nitrogen adsorption isotherm for the treated MOFs to evaluate the porosity is important to further determine the material stability. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms of the samples of Cu2+ and Cd2+ doped STU-1s after being soaked in boiling water for 7 days were measured. As shown in Fig. S15 (ESI), the nitrogen uptake (77 K) of Cu0.01-STU-1, Cu0.05-STU-1, Cu0.10-STU-1, and Cd0.6-STU-1 treated with boiling water is close to those of their respective pristine samples, indicating that the metal-doped STU-1s did not significantly lose their porosity and surface areas. Similar to N2 adsorption, CO2 adsorption capacities were also almost retained (only slightly dropped, Fig. S16, ESI). This property is very important for post-combustion CO2 capture from flue gas in the industrially relevant process, because the water molecules usually exist as constituents in flue gas. Furthermore, we also employed scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to explore the morphology and particle size of the pristine and metal doped STU-1 samples treated with boiling water. As shown in  and Fig. S17-S20 (ESI), the morphology and particle size of the treated samples of STU-1s are identical to those of their pristine sample, which suggest that there was no dissolution or degradation of the original phase. The experiments further manifest that the metal doped STU-1s are exceptionally water stable.

To explore the interaction between water and the pore surface of STU-1 and metal doped STU-1s, their water vapour adsorption isotherms were measured at 298 K. As shown in , the highest measured water vapour uptake was 13.48 wt% at P/P0 = 0.9 for STU-1, while those of metal doped STU-1s are obviously low, ranging from 0.43 wt% to 1.65%. The water sorption isotherms are divided into seven types (Fig. S26, ESI) to classify the hydrophilicity or hydrophobicity of the sorbent according to IUPAC. STU-1 displays a type III water sorption isotherm classified as a hydrophobic or weakly hydrophilic material; while metal doped STU-1 exhibits type VII thus judged as a strongly hydrophobic material. The water adsorption isotherm studies clearly demonstrate that the hydrophobicity of the pore surface of STU-1 was obviously enhanced after doping metal ions. The hydrophobicity prevents water from adsorbing into the pores, consequently the water stability of metal doped STU-1s was strongly enhanced.

Results and discussion

A luminescent three-dimensional MOF, [Zn2(NDC)2(bpy)]⋅Gx, 1, was synthesized solvothermally by the reaction of NDC and 4,4'-bipyridine with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DMF solvent, in a sealed autoclave at 120 °C. Single crystal structure analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in a triclinic system with P space group and consists of two Zn atoms, two molecules of NDC ligand, one molecule of 4,4'-bipyridine and disordered solvent molecules (Table S1). The Zn atoms are five coordinated with respect to four carboxylate-derived oxygen atoms from the NDC ligand and one nitrogen atom of the bipyridine ligand. The Zn-O/N bond distances are in the range of 2.0091-2.0898 Å (av. 2.0311 Å) (Table S2). The observed distances are typical for this type of coordination motif. Framework 1 is based on a paddle wheel type secondary building unit (SBU) (). This SBU is connected with the NDC ligand to form the charge neutral layer (). The other two nodes of the SBU are connected with the bpy ligand, which pillars the neutral layers. The overall structure can be viewed as bpy ligands pillaring the undulating charge-neutral [Zn2(NDC)2] layers to form a 3D network (). This network interpenetrates to result in the final structure containing a 1D channel () along the a axis. This interpenetration eliminates most of the void space in the structure. This kind of network is reported and several isostructural compounds are known. Complete evacuation of the guests was confirmed by studying the thermogravimetric analysis of 1' (guest-free referred to as 1'). Removal of guest molecules led to a distortion of the unit cell, as indicated by the shifts of the PXRD peaks (Fig. S1). N2 adsorption measurements over 1' show that the total BET surface area is 9 m2 g-1, with a pore volume of 0.03 cm3 g-1 (Fig. S2), which indicates the nonporous nature of the compound.

The fluorescent properties of 1, 1', and the NDC ligand were also investigated in the solid state at room temperature (). The excitation wavelength of 320 nm was set from the UV-Vis spectral data. The free NDC ligand exhibits emission at 461 nm and the fluorescence of as-made 1 displays a strong emission band at 450 nm.

The quantum yield for MOFs was calculated to be 0.23 through the relative method. Quinine sulfate (Qf = 0.54) was used as the standard. The emission lifetime for the compound was calculated using the time-correlated single photon counting (TCSPC) technique. The average lifetime (τav) was calculated to be 31.5 ns when the decay plot was fitted triexponentially (Table S4 and Fig. S5). The high luminescence intensity and quantum yield prompted us to consider the potential luminescence sensing properties of 1.

We have calculated the quenching constant (Kq), [Kq = Ksv/τ0, where τ0 = life time of MOFs before addition of analytes] (Table S4) and the results are presented in . The quenching constant (Kq) varies from 36.8 × 1010 M-1 S-1 to 4.9 × 1010 M-1 S-1 () and these values confirm that the interaction is predominantly collisional in nature.

For a better understanding of the fluorescence quenching mechanisms, we have carried out density of states (DOS) and band gap energy calculations for 1 (Fig. S9). The experimental band gap energy value for 1 using the Kubelka-Munk plot was found to be 2.81 eV (Fig. S10). Theoretical calculations predict that the LUMO of 1 resides on the bipyridine molecule and its value (2.00 eV) is higher than the LUMO for the analytes used (Fig. S9 and Table S5). So it will follow the same mechanism as in other reported MOFs. The result shows that quenching efficiency is in the order of NT > DNT > TNT > NB > DNB (). This order is not fully in accordance with the trend of electron deficiency.

Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed from 30 °C to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 15 °C min-1 under air flow. As compounds 1-4 have totally the same structure type, only the results of Yb3(OH)7(1,5-NDS) (4) were discussed here for clarity (for the results of compounds 1-3 see Fig. S5-S7). As shown in , compound 4 is stable up to about 351 °C and then a weight loss of 5.7% appears from 351 °C to 469 °C with an endothermic peak in the DSC curve, corresponding to the decomposition of parts of the coordinated (OH) groups. The subsequent weight loss of 21.1% in total from 469 °C to 668 °C with three exothermic peaks corresponds to the loss of organic ligands (calcd. 25.8%), and finally a bit of weight gain appears at about 699 °C, probably corresponding to a further oxidation process to generate Yb hydroxides, with the total weight loss of 25.0% (calcd. 27.3%). The two different weight loss processes from 469 °C to 668 °C may be attributed to the ligands in two different coordination types. All of these analyses are supplemented by the powder XRD pattern of compound 4 at different temperatures (). Obviously, the main structure is kept at 469 °C with two significant peaks at about 7° and 13°, and a new crystal structure of Yb hydroxides is assumed to be forming from 469 °C to 699 °C with four new peaks at about 13°, 30°, 42°, and 53°.

Photoluminescence properties

Considering the excellent photoluminescence properties of RE compounds, the solid-state luminescence properties of compounds 1-4 as well as the free 1,5-NDS ligand were investigated at room temperature. Free 1,5-NDS shows emission with maxima at 337 nm and 387 nm upon excitation at 277 nm in the solid state (Fig. S8). As shown in , strong purple emission bands are concentrated around 342 nm and 396 nm for compounds 1-4 upon excitation at 277 nm. Due to the RE ions luminescence is always presented as sharp emission peaks in the spectra; the emission peak that is similar to that of the free 1,5-NDS ligand in  can probably be attributed to intra-ligand (π-π*) emission. Compared with the emission of the free 1,5-NDS, a slight red shift of 5 nm for the high-energy emission and 9 nm for the low-energy emission was observed, which may be assigned to the coordination of the 1,5-NDS ligand with the RE ions. Comparing the four curves in  with each other, it's obvious that the peak around 396 nm for compound 3 is missed, owing to the high absorption of Er(III) ions at around 379 nm. However, the emission of the Er(III) ion is not found in the curve, which is probably because of the quenching of the densely coordinated (OH) groups around the Er(III) ions. Furthermore, as shown in , the intensity of the peak at around 396 nm is similar for compounds 1, 2, and 4, while that of the peak at around 342 nm is significantly different. That is to say, the relative intensity of the two peaks for compounds 1-4 is different. This could be a good example of RE ions tuning MOFs' fluorescence colour.

Magnetic measurements

In view of the excellent magnetic properties of RE compounds, magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range of 2-300 K. As shown in , compounds 2-4 behave paramagnetically, which is similar to the corresponding RE ions. It is noted that upon further cooling below about 25 K for compounds 2 and 3, and 10 K for compound 4, the magnetic susceptibility χmT decreases significantly and reaches 9.43 emu K mol-1, 15.87 emu K mol-1, and 4.68 emu K mol-1 respectively, implying zero-field splitting and the possibility of additional anti-ferromagnetic interaction in this temperature range, which may be attributed to the interaction between RE ions by means of the coordinated μ3-(OH) groups. Furthermore, a Curie-Weiss (C-W) fitting (Fig. S9) was also performed on the χ-1m-T data. The fitting Curie constants (C) and Weiss temperatures (θ) from the C-W fitting are listed in . Apparently, the fitting Weiss temperatures of compounds 2-4 are all negative values (-2.33 K for 2, -1.56 K for 3 and -3.8 K for 4), also suggesting the existence of anti-ferromagnetic interaction in these compounds.

Crystal structure of 5a

 analysis reveals that structure 5a crystallizes in the monoclinic space  P21/c and displays a novel 3D coordination frameworks constructed by 2D  chains and pillared Ag(IN)2 units. The asymmetric unit of 5a contains one unique La3+ ion, one Ag+ ion, two crystallographically unique IN ligands, one  ligand, and one coordinating  molecule (). The La3+ ion is ten-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from three  ligands, three oxygen atoms from two IN ligands and one  molecule. The La-O bond distances range from 2.498(4) to 2.733(4) Å. The Ag+ ion is in a trigonal configuration and defined by two  from two different IN ligands with bond distances of 2.167(5) and 2.182(5) Å and one oxygen atom from one  ligand. The Ag-O bond distance of 2.600(4) Å is comparable to those of structures 4a and 4b and other analogous complexes. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance of 3.1839(11) Å is shorter than that in the analogous heteronuclear complexes [Ln2Ag4(ina)8(H2O)10][NO3]2⋅4H2O [Ln = Sm, Eu, Dy]. The value is well below the sum of the van der Waals radii for two  atoms (3.44 Å), thus showing strong Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts. In the structure of 5a, Ag(IN)2 units act in one coordination mode () with one carboxylate coordinating to one La3+ ion via bismonodentate coordination, and another carboxylate coordinating to one La3+ ion via bisdentate chelating coordination. The  ligand acts in a chelating and bridging coordination mode with two carboxylates coordinating to three La3+ ions and one Ag+ ion ().

Thermal properties

The thermal stabilities of all complexes have been studied by  in N2 atmosphere (See ESI). The first weight losses below 210 °C for all complexes correspond to removal of the noncoordination and coordination  molecules. The second sharp weight losses above 310 °C for all complexes except compounds 5a and 5b are attributed to  of the  or  ions, while the frameworks of compounds 5a and 5b are stable up to 370 °C.  of the  anions is also evident in the  which exhibit sharp exothermic peaks at the same temperatures.

Luminescence properties

Due to the excellent luminescent properties of Tb(III) and Eu(III) ions, the photoluminescence of 1a, 2b, 2c, 3 and 8 in the solid state was investigated at room temperature. The luminescence  of these complexes were shown in , and S3-5 (see ESI). The  upon 330 nm excitation for Tb-complexes ( and S3) consist of four bands located at about 489, 545, 584 and 621 nm. The four main peaks can be attributed to the 5D4 → 7F6, 5D4 → 7F5, 5D4 → 7F4 and 5D4 → 7F3 transitions, respectively. The  for Eu-complexes ( and S4,5) excited at 396 nm exhibit characteristic transitions of Eu ions, the peaks at 594, 616, 650 and 698 nm correspond to the 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3 and 5D0 → 7F4 transition of Eu ions, respectively, which implies an efficient energy transfer from organic ligands to the metal ion (LMCT). The emission peak 5D0 → 7F1 is a magnetic dipole transition and its intensity should vary with the crystal field strength acting on the Eu(III) ion. The 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition and the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) ions decreases. Unfortunately, there was no detectable photoluminescence for other complexes at room temperature.

For 1 and 2, the magnetic properties in the form of χMTvs. T plots are shown in  and , respectively. At room temperature, the χMT values of 1 and 2 are 6.66 and 9.46 emu mol-1 K, which are much larger than the expected spin-only values (3.75 and 5.625 emu mol-1 K) for two and three magnetically isolated CoII ions (S = 3/2, g = 2), respectively (in order to investigate the Co2 unit, the calculated molecular weight for the magnetic data of 1 is 632.32). For 1, as the temperature decreases, the value of χMT slowly decreases down to a minimum value of 5.41 emu mol-1 K at 22 K, which is larger than the expected values (3.75 emu mol-1 K) of two spin-only CoII ions and indicates ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions. Upon lowering the temperature to 5 K, χMT abruptly increases to a maximum value (6.08 emu mol-1 K). Below 5 K, the χMT has a rapid linear drop, to a minimum value of 5.26 emu mol-1 K at 2 K. For 2, when lowering the temperature, the χMT value slowly decreases and reaches a minimum value of 6.07 emu mol-1 K at 12 K, which is slightly larger than the expected value (5.625 emu mol-1 K) of the spin-only Co3 unit, because of the slow quenching of orbital contribution, which indicates weak ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions of the Co3 unit. Then, χMT rises up to a maximum value of 6.73 emu mol-1 K at 2 K, further indicating weak ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions of Co3 unit. Curie-Weiss fitting [χM = C/(T - θ)] of the magnetic data over the temperature range 100-300 K for 1 and 2 results in a Curie constant C = 6.89 emu mol-1 K, Weiss constant θ = -9.39 K, and C = 10.35 emu mol-1 K, θ = -28.84 K, respectively. Notably, the negative θ values do not indicate dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between the metal centers because of strong spin-orbit coupling of CoII ions, which itself can lead to a negative θ value and a decrease of χMT at high temperature. The strength of the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction caused by spin-orbit coupling of CoII at high temperature was estimated based on . χT = Aexp(-E1/kT) + Bexp(-E2/kT)(1)

In , A + B equals the Curie constant, and E1 and E2 represent the activation energies corresponding to the spin-orbit coupling and the ferromagnetic exchange interactions, respectively. The best fit of the experimental data gives A + B = 6.97 emu mol-1 K, E1/k = -16.68 K, E2/k = 27.34 K for 1, and A + B = 10.42 emu mol-1 K, E1/k = -76.80 K, E2/k = 0.14 K for 2 (). The positive values of E2 of 1 and 2 indicate that dominant ferromagnetic interactions between CoII ions of Co2 and Co3 clusters exist in 1 and 2.

The M vs. H plots (at 2 K) for 1 and 2 are shown in . For 1, M increases quickly at very low field, reaching about 4.12 Nβ at 15 kOe, which indicates ferromagnetic interactions. In the high field region the increase of magnetization is slow, reaching 4.92 Nβ at 50 kOe, which is in agreement with the value of 6.00 Nβ anticipated for two independent CoII ions with the S = 3/2 ground state. For 2, M also increases quickly at very low field, reaching about 4.48 Nβ at 15 kOe, then increasing slowly to 6.21 Nβ per Co3 unit at 50 kOe, which is smaller than the value of 6.6 Nβ anticipated for three independent CoII with S = 3/2 ground state, but larger than those values (usually less than 4.0 Nβ) for antiferromagnetic interactions within trimeric CoII units, which further indicated weak ferromagnetic interaction in the Co3 unit and antiferromagnetic interaction between Co3 units. In 1, since the distance between the two CoII linked by L  is considerably longer (8.76 Å) compared with the intradimer Co1⋯Co1A (3.358 Å) separation, the interdimer exchange interactions can be seen further approximately as the effect of the molecular field. In addition, in 2, since the distance between the two CoII ions linked by the L  is much longer (7.82 Å) than the intratrimer Co1⋯Co2 (3.559 Å) separation, the intertrimer exchange interactions can also be seen further approximately as the effect of the molecular field. Herein, the long  only provided negligible intercluster antiferromagnetic interactions.

It is noteworthy that magnetic research for the high spin Co system is complicated and difficult because many factors, especially the strong spin-orbital coupling, can influence the magnetic behavior. For 1, the first decrease of χMT value (300-22 K) and the small negative θ value may be mainly due to the strong spin-orbital coupling of the single-ion behavior at high temperature. The abrupt χMT increase (22-5 K) can be interpreted by ferromagnetic coupling interactions within the dimeric unit, which is strong enough to compensate for the single-ion behavior resulting from the spin-orbital coupling. This can also be confirmed by the slow increase of magnetization at high fields and large magnetization values at the applied field of 5 T at 2 K. The second decrease for the χMT value (5-2 K) suggests antiferromagnetic interaction among the neighboring Co2 clusters and/or the magnetic saturation. Complex 2 is similar to complex 1 except that no maximum peak was observed at low temperature.

A highly luminescent entangled metal-organic framework based on pyridine-substituted tetraphenylethene for efficient pesticide detection

A novel pillared-layered entangled luminescent metal-organic framework [Zn2(bpdc)2(BPyTPE)] (1) (BPyTPE = (E)-1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)ethene) has been designed and constructed. The solvent-free 1 exhibits strong blue-green emission with an excellent fluorescence quantum yield of 99% and provides a facile and reversible method to sensitively and quantitatively detect trace pesticide of 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline.

Pesticides are widely used in agriculture, but their residues can cause serious damages to ecological safety, and result in hazardous impacts on human health and life quality through the food chain. Hence, the rapid and selective detection of pesticides has become one of the most pressing issues concerning human health and environmental protection. For example, 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN) is a broad-spectrum pesticide belonging to toxicity class IV. It has been extensively employed for the control of many diseases, such as wheat powdery mildew, cotton rotten bell, and fruit tree and vegetable rot. DCN degrades slowly and can persist for a long time under the environmental conditions. Currently, the common methods of DCN detection include ion mobility spectrometry, high performance liquid chromatography or other assays requiring sophisticated instruments that are expensive and complicated. To address this situation, in this contribution, we synthesize a TPE-based ligand exhibiting prominent AIE nature, and fabricate a novel pillared-layered LMOF using it as a pillar linker. The LMOF has a remarkably high fluorescence quantum yield (ΦF) of 99%, and performs outstandingly in DCN detection with a low detection limit down to 0.13 ppm.

The TPE-based ligand (E)-1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)ethene (BPyTPE) is synthesized according to the synthetic route outlined in Scheme S1 (ESI). The crude product of BPyTPE is purified by column chromatography to afford a pure target compound with a trans-conformation, which is confirmed by the single-crystal structure (). The treatment of BPyTPE with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) in a mixed solvent of N,N-dimethylacetamide and N,N-dimethylformamide yields colorless cube-like crystals of complex 1. Complex 1 belongs to a triclinic crystal system, space group P (Table S1, ESI). Each Zn2+ ion coordinates to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from different bpdc2- anions and one pyridine nitrogen atom of the BPyTPE ligand, which can be regarded as a tetragonal pyramid. The bond lengths of Zn-O/N are in the range of 2.000-2.038 Å, and the bond angles of O-Zn-O and O-Zn-N are approximately 86.380-89.714° and 95.406-105.058°, respectively. Two Zn2+ ions are bridged by four carboxylic groups to form a paddle-wheel secondary building unit (SBU) [Zn2(COO)4]. Each SBU is linked by coshared carboxylate groups of bpdc2- ligands, generating a rhombic 44 two-dimensional (2D) network with a cross-section of 22.52 × 20.09 Å2 (). Two adjacent layers are connected by BPyTPE pillar linkers with an inter-layer distance of about 21.27 Å to furnish a stable three-dimensional (3D) framework (). A three-fold interpenetration is observed for the overall structure of complex 1 (), and the pore volume of complex 1 is calculated to be 1793.3 Å3, corresponding to a void of around 33.2% per unit cell (5403.2 Å3 total). The geometrical conformation for BPyTPE in complex 1 is further investigated (Fig. S1, ESI). It is found that BPyTPE in complex 1 adopts a more twisted conformation with larger dihedral angles between aromatic moieties than BPyTPE in single crystals (Table S2, ESI). There are only very weak π-π stacking interactions between the phenyl rings from bpdc2- ions and pyridine rings from BPyTPE ligands, with the distances of 3.540 and 3.707 Å (Fig. S2, ESI), while no π-π stacking interactions are observed between the TPE units that are mainly responsible for the light emission.

Complex 1 is stable in THF or water as indicated by powder X-ray diffraction pattern (PXRD) results (Fig. S3, ESI). It can undergo solvent exchange with dichloromethane (DCM), followed by drying under vacuum at room temperature to furnish the solvent-free 1 sample. The result of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns confirms that solvent-free 1 retains the original framework without any collapsing (Fig. S3, ESI). Thermogravimetric analysis of complex 1 reveals 22% initial weight loss by heating from room temperature to 145 °C in a N2 stream, which is attributed to the loss of solvent molecules. A plateau appears between 145 and 405 °C, followed by a sharp weight loss (~53%) corresponding to the decomposition of the framework. However, there is no obvious weight change until 405 °C of solvent-free 1, indicating the solvent molecules in complex 1 have been removed completely (Fig. S4, ESI).

BPyTPE shows an absorption maximum at 335 nm in THF solution (Fig. S5, ESI), associated with the π-π* transition of the conjugated backbone. Like most TPE derivatives, BPyTPE is almost nonfluorescent in dilute THF solution because of the active intramolecular rotation. But as the aggregate formation takes place upon the addition of a large amount of water into the THF solution of BPyTPE, the emission peak at 502 nm enhances swiftly (), which is ascribed to the restriction of intramolecular rotations and thus the blocking of nonradiative decay of the excited state. These emission behaviours demonstrate the AIE nature of BPyTPE. Solvent-free 1 exhibits strong blue-green emission at 490 nm (), and complex 1 shows an intense emission peak at 498 nm, which is close to the emission of the BPyTPE aggregate. The emission of solvent-free 1 is blue-shifted by 8 nm compared to that of complex 1. This blue-shift phenomenon often appears in the reported LMOFs, which is probably due to the decreased inter-ligand coupling. Both solvent-free 1 and complex 1 have excellent ΦF values of 99% and 79%, respectively, determined using a calibrated integrating sphere, thanks to the AIE nature of the BPyTPE ligand. Both values are much higher than that of the BPyTPE solid (ΦF = 43%), owing to the greatly reduced intramolecular motion of BPyTPE when coordinated within the rigid framework. Moreover, when the turbulence of highly disordered solvent molecules is removed, the excited state energy loss is depressed to minimal, giving a remarkably high ΦF value approaching the unit of solvent-free 1. The BPyTPE solid, complex 1 and solvent-free 1 exhibit fluorescence lifetimes (τ) of 3.11, 2.85 and 2.39 ns, respectively. This tendency of shorter τ and higher ΦF may result from the immediate release of excited energy via fluorescence, which is the same as the findings of another TPE-based MOF, PCN-94.

The sensing application of solvent-free 1 in a DCM suspension (0.15 mg mL-1, Fig. S6 and Table S3, ESI) is firstly evaluated using titration experiments with different electron rich aromatics, such as toluene, m-xylene, mesitylene and aniline (Fig. S7, ESI). These tested samples can only slightly enhance the emission intensity. However, the emission of solvent-free 1 can be quenched by nitrobenzene, owing to the excited state electron transfer from the donor (LMOFs) to the acceptor (nitrobenzene guests). The quenching efficiency (QE) is estimated using the formula (I0 - I)/I0, where I0 and I are the emission intensities of solvent-free 1 before and after adding guest molecules. As shown in Fig. S8 (ESI), the emission starts to decrease upon the addition of 58 ppm nitrobenzene, and is quenched greatly at a concentration of 1800 ppm with a high quenching efficiency of 98%. It is found that the detection sensitivity of nitro aniline is much higher than those of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4,5-pentachloro-6-nitrobenzene under the same conditions (Fig. S9 and S14, ESI). When 55 ppm p-nitroaniline is dispersed into the solvent-free 1 suspension, the emission is almost totally quenched (QE = 98%) (Fig. S10, ESI). The detection limit is as low as ~4.9 × 10-2 ppm, calculated with 3σ/k (σ: standard deviation; k: slope). The higher selectivity of solvent-free 1 towards nitroaniline (Fig. S11, ESI) probably results from hydrogen bonding interactions (N-H⋯O) between the amino of guests and the oxygen of bpdc2-.

The high sensitivity and low detection limit of solvent-free 1 towards nitro aniline inspire us to develop an assay for DCN, which has never been achieved using LMOFs previously.  show the spectra of decline in emission intensity and the linear quenching range of solvent-free 1 upon the addition of DCN (Fig. S12, ESI). The strong emission of solvent-free 1 is quenched drastically, which can be observed by the naked eye (). A quantitative detection of DCN ranging from 0.94 to 16.92 ppm is established with a low detection limit of 0.13 ppm. To confirm the limit of detection, the fluorescence titration of DCN at low concentrations from 0.13 ppm to 0.80 ppm is further performed, and a linear proportion of I0/I is obtained (Fig. S13, ESI). Solvent-free 1 can be reused after centrifuging the suspension and washing with DCM several times (), without degradation in the detection performance. According to China National Food Safety Standard - Maximum Residue Limits for Pesticides in Food, the maximum residue limits for DCN are 7 ppm in fruits of nectarine and grapes and 15 ppm in vegetables of carrots. Obviously, solvent-free 1 can perform outstandingly in the detection of the fruit fungicide of DCN and is competent to fulfill the requirements. To gain insight into the mechanism for detecting DCN, the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of DCN and BPyTPE in complex 1 are calculated (Fig. S15, ESI). The excited state electron transfer from the higher LUMO of BPyTPE (-1.77 eV) to that of DCN (-2.40 eV) may occur, resulting in severe fluorescence quenching. Therefore, the photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) may be the sensing mechanism. Furthermore, hydrogen bonding interactions between complex 1 and DCN should also contribute to the good sensitivity of the detection.

In summary, we have synthesized a TPE-based ligand (BPyTPE) with a trans-conformation and prominent AIE properties. Based on BPyTPE, we have developed a novel pillared-layered LMOF (complex 1) with a three-fold interpenetration structure. Solvent-free 1 exhibits an intense blue-green emission at 498 nm with a remarkably high ΦF of 99%. The emission of solvent-free 1 can be quenched efficiently and selectively by nitroaniline. Based on solvent-free 1, we establish a reversible method to sensitively and quantitatively detect trace pesticide of DCN, with a linear range of 0.94-16.92 ppm and a low detection limit of 0.13 ppm. To the best of our knowledge, using LMOFs as a fluorescent sensor to efficiently detect DCN is very rare and the present assay method is a promising one capable of practical application. Further studies of detecting other pesticides as well as heavy metal pollutants with TPE-based LMOFs are in progress.

The characteristic emission bands of Dy(III) ions in DMA-Dy and HYD-Dy, located at 480 nm (blue), 574 nm (yellow) and 660 nm (red), correspond to the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H11/2 transitions, respectively (). An additional band observed for DMA-Dy in the near infrared (NIR) region at 750 nm corresponds to the 4F9/2 → 6H9/2 transition. Similar bands were observed previously for formamidinium dysprosium formate but for this compound the intensity of the band near 480 nm was significantly smaller than the intensity of the 660 nm band. For Dy(III) ions in inorganic hosts concentration quenching due to cross relaxation processes is often observed. The decrease of emission intensity occurs due to the depopulation of the 4F9/2 level of Dy(III) via different possible energy transfer processes: (I) 4F9/2 + 6H15/2 → 6F9/2/6H7/2 + 6F5/2, (II) 4F9/2 + 6H15/2 → 6H9/2/6F11/2 + 6F3/2 and (III) 4F9/2 + 6H15/2 → 6F5/2 + 6H7/2/6F9/2. In most inorganic matrices, luminescence from Dy(III) is strongly quenched when the concentration exceeds 3-4 mol%. The anti-anti formate-bridged Dy-Dy distances in the MOFs studied here do not differ very much from one compound to another, i.e., they range from 6.602 Å for HYD-Dy to 6.8287 Å for DMA-Dy. The Dy-Dy distances for the syn-anti connections, which are present only in HYD-Dy, vary from 5.975 to 6.627 Å. Due to long distances between Dy(III) ions the energy transfer between ions is limited and it is possible to observe emission even at very high Dy(III) concentration (up to 100%). It is interesting to note that small changes in the Dy-Dy distances lead to significant decreases of the emission intensity in HYD-Dy, that is, replacement of DMA+ cations by HYD+ cations leads to about a three-fold decrease of the emission intensity. This behavior may be caused by cross relaxation and non-radiative energy transfer between excited levels of Dy(III). The luminescence spectra also show significant differences in intensities of the particular Stark components of the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2 transition. The intensity change of the band observed at higher energy can be attributed to re-absorption of the emitted energy by neighboring Dy(III) ions. The intensity decrease of the transition from the 4F9/2 level to the lower Stark components of the ground 6H15/2 level with the increasing concentration of Dy(III) ions was previously observed by Marciniak et al. Since in our case the concentration of Dy(III) ions remains constant, the observed changes in intensity of the discussed Stark components can be attributed to shortening of the Dy-Dy distances caused by changing the organic cation in the MOF structure. For the MOFs studied here the CIE1931 chromaticity coordinates (x, y) were calculated from the emission spectra to define the emission color (). Under 350 nm excitation, the CIE1931 coordinates for HYD-Dy and DMA-Dy phosphors are (x = 0.251, y = 0.358) and (x = 0.243, y = 0.323), respectively. The obtained values show that proposed MOFs have emission close to white color (x = 0.333, y = 0.333). The desired color of emission can be adjusted by co-doping by other rare earth ions.

The kinetic of luminescence decay of the 4F9/2 state was measured for DMA-Dy and HYD-Dy at room temperature under 355 nm excitation (Fig. S5, ESI). Emission decay curves of DMA-Dy and HYD-Dy show a single exponential character that confirm a single site of Dy(III) ions and the absence of energy transfer between optically active ions. The decay curves have been fitted using the single exponential formula: I(t) = I0exp(-t/τ).(1)The experimental radiative decay time (τ) is 57 μs for DMA-Dy and 96 μs for HYD-Dy. The calculated lifetime for HYD-Dy is 435 μs (see Discussion below). These results allow us to estimate the quantum yield of HYD-Dy to be about 22.1% and suggest that nonradiative paths dominate the depopulation of the 4F9/2 excited level. It is worth noting that the lifetimes measured for fully concentrated DMA-Dy and HYD-Dy are very long compared to lifetimes observed in inorganic compounds. For instance, the lifetime of the 4F9/2 state of Dy(III) is about 5 μs for 1 mol% concentration of Dy(III) in LiLaP4O12. It is also long compared to most of the Dy(III)-based MOFs and coordination polymers, for which the lifetime is usually smaller than 13 μs (see Table S8, ESI). However, a very long lifetime of 1130 μs was reported for the [DyCd(imdc)(SO4)(H2O)3]⋅0.5H2O compound, where H3imdc = 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid. It is also worth noting that the lifetimes of DMA-Dy and HYD-Dy (57 and 96 μs, respectively) are significantly longer than the lifetime of related formamidinium dysprosium formate (2.1 μs, see Table S8, ESI). The longer lifetimes of DMA-Dy and HYD-Dy compared to the formamidinium analogue indicate that non-radiative processes are less efficient in the compounds studied here which is beneficial for their applications as luminophores.

The differences in the peak wavelengths of absorption are caused by differences in the polarizability of the ligands, leading to differences in the covalence of the rare earth sites. This behaviour is responsible for the sensitivity of Ω2 to the covalence degree of the chemical bonds between rare earth ions and their ligands. Ω4 and Ω6 can provide a lot of information about the long-range effects and the rigidity of system. The dependence of the Judd-Ofelt intensity parameters on the host composition doped with rare earth ions is of special interest because the radiative properties of rare earth ions are described by these parameters. Many studies appeared to reveal the relationships between the local structure and bonding of glasses around the rare earth ions and the spectroscopic properties of these ions due to the wide use of glasses as lasers and amplifiers. And few intensity parameters are available for rare earth complexes in hybrid organic-inorganic composite materials. Judd-Ofelt phenomenological intensity parameters Ωλ determined by a least-squares fitting approach for HYD-Dy crystal are as follows: Ω2 = 25.20 (10-20 cm-1), Ω4 = 3.93 (10-20 cm2) and Ω6 = 4.20 (10-20 cm-1). We cannot compare the Ωλ values obtained by us for HYD-Dy with data of other metal-organic compounds since, to our best knowledge, such data were not reported for Dy(III)-based MOFs. It is worth noting, however, that the spectroscopic quality factor X = Ω4/Ω6 for Dy(III) in HYD-Dy is 0.935 and this value is situated in the range of values characteristic for dysprosium compounds. One can also notice that the Ω2 parameter of HYD-Dy is very large. The extraordinarily high value of Ω2 was previously reported also for other organic-inorganic complexes such as [Eu(fod)3(phen)] (19.00 × 10-20 cm2) and [Eu(fod)3(phen-N-O] (24.50 × 10-20 cm2). This behavior was explained by the anisotropic features of the metal-ligand bonds and prominent dynamic coupling associated with the ligand ion polarizability.

Raman and IR data together with the calculated total number of IR- and Raman-active modes allowed us to propose the assignment of all observed modes to the respective motions of atoms in crystal lattices. We were also able to assign the modes of hydrazinium cations, for which vibrational studies are very scarce. Optical studies show that emission of Dy(III) ions can be observed at room temperature. The experimental radiative decay times, 57 μs for DMA-Dy and 96 μs for HYD-Dy, are very long compared to lifetimes observed in inorganic compounds and most of the Dy-based MOFs and coordination polymers. The quantum yield was estimated to be 22.1% for HYD-Dy. Although we could not estimate the quantum yield for DMA-Dy, the stronger intensity of its emission suggests a higher quantum yield of this compound compared to HYD-Dy. Unfortunately, it is difficult to discuss if the MOFs studied here have better luminescence properties than other Dy-based MOFs and coordination polymers reported in the literature since we could not find the quantum yield values for such compounds in the literature. Nevertheless, our results show that the HYD-Dy and DMA-Dy studied here have relatively strong and close to white emission.

PXRD and thermal analysis

The PXRD pattern for the microcrystalline samples of 1-6 is in good agreement with that obtained from the single crystal data, confirming the excellent phase purity (Fig. S1). TGA measurement was carried out on MOFs 1-6. As shown in Fig. S2, the six isomorphous MOFs 1-6 showed a similar weight loss process. There are three mass loss steps: the first weight losses below around 150 °C are 7.34% (calcd: 7.30%) for Pr-MOF (1), 7.15% (calcd: 7.11%) for Sm-MOF (2), 7.11% (calcd: 7.09%) for Eu-MOF (3), 6.99% (calcd: 7.04%) for Gd-MOF (4), 6.96% (calcd: 6.98%) for Dy-MOF (5), and 6.97% (calcd: 6.95%) for Ho-MOF (6), which corresponds to the loss of one lattice H2O molecule and one lattice DMF molecule; the second weight losses in the range of 150-325 °C are 17.47% (calcd: 17.49%) for Pr-MOF (1), 17.31% (calcd: 17.33%) for Sm-MOF (2), 17.24% (calcd: 17.28%) for Eu-MOF (3), 17.16% (calcd: 17.14%) for Gd-MOF (4), 16.97% (calcd: 17.00%) for Dy-MOF (5) and 16.90% (calcd: 16.93%) for Ho-MOF (6), which corresponds to the loss of four coordinated H2O and two DMF molecules and then the weight losses can be ascribed to the decomposition of the frameworks.

Magnetic properties

Thermal magnetic properties of Pr-MOF (1), Gd-MOF (4), Dy-MOF (5) and Ho-MOF (6) were measured in the range of 2-300 K under 1000 Oe and are shown in . The room temperature χT values of these MOFs and corresponding expected values are summarized in .

The χT value of Pr-MOF (1) at 300 K is 3.22 emu K mol-1, which is comparable with the value (3.20 emu K mol-1) expected for two isolated PrIII ions in the 3H4 ground states. Upon cooling, the χT values of Pr-MOF (1) decrease continuously and reach a minimum value of 0.23 emu K mol-1 at 2 K. The decrease upon cooling is mainly due to the depopulation of the excited Stark sublevels related to the ligand field, although weak antiferromagnetic interactions between PrIII ions could also make a contribution. The χT value of Gd-MOF (4) at 300 K is 16.03 emu K mol-1, which is also close to the expected spin-only values of 15.76 emu K mol-1 for two isolated GdIII ions. As the temperature is lowered, the χT values of Gd-MOF (4) remain almost constant until 6 K and then drop upon further cooling. The 1/χ vs. T plots of Gd-MOF (4) are linear in the whole temperature range, following the Curie-Weiss law with C = 16.04 emu K mol-1 and θ = -0.12 K. These features suggest that Gd-MOF (4) exhibits antiferromagnetic interactions between the neighboring GdIII ions.
