The best-fit parameter in the whole temperature range led to J = -0.032 cm-1 and g = 2.01. The negative J value confirms the occurrence of weak antiferromagnetic couplings in Gd-MOF (4).

For Dy-MOF (5) and Ho-MOF (6), the χT values at 300 K are 28.35 and 28.15 emu K mol-1, respectively, which are comparable with the expected values (). The χT values of these two Ln-MOFs gradually decrease as the temperature decreases, reaching 22.75 emu K mol-1 and 16.65 emu K mol-1, respectively, at 2 K. These magnetic behaviors may be ascribed to antiferromagnetic interactions between spin carriers and/or the thermal depopulation of the excited Stark sublevels.

The field dependence of the magnetization data of Pr-MOF (1), Gd-MOF (4), Dy-MOF (5), and Ho-MOF (6) was also investigated in the range of 0-50 kOe at 2 K (). The magnetization of Pr-MOF (1) increases linearly as the field is increased and the value is 0.94 Nβ at 50 kOe, which is much lower than the expected value (6.4 Nβ for two PrIII ions). The magnetization of Gd-MOF (4) (13.74 Nβ per two Gd ions) at 50 kOe is much lower than the saturation value, which is consistent with the antiferromagnetic nature in Gd-MOF (4). The magnetization calculated with the Brillouin function (S = 7/2) is above the experimental values of Gd-MOF (4) (, black solid line), which is consistent with the result obtained from the χT-T curves. In addition, the magnetization of Dy-MOF (5) and Ho-MOF (6) first increases rapidly and then increases smoothly. They reach 10.53 and 12.05 Nβ at 50 kOe for Dy-MOF (5) and Ho-MOF (6), respectively, which are lower than the expected value of 20 Nβ for two uncoupled DyIII ions or HoIII ions. These behaviors of the magnetization of Dy-MOF (5) and Ho-MOF (6) may be caused by anisotropy and crystal-field effects, which is similar to those observed in previous DyIII and HoIII MOFs.

Luminescence properties

The solid luminescence properties of the H3L ligand and Eu-MOF (3) were investigated at room temperature and are shown in Fig. S6. The free H3L ligand exhibits an emission maximum at 467 nm (λex = 373 nm), which is probably attributable to the π-π* or n-π* transitions. Upon excitation at 336 nm, Eu-MOF (3) displays characteristic emission bands at 590, 616, 650 and 695 nm, which are ascribed to the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of EuIII ions. The strongest emission is centered at 616 nm and corresponds to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition. Moreover, Eu-MOF (3) displays the exponential decay with a reasonable long lifetime (0.38 ms) obtained by the decay lifetime curves (Fig. S7). Considering the nitro O atoms and uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms exposed in the structures, and the excellent luminescence of Eu-MOF (3), its potential luminescence sensing towards small molecules was carefully evaluated. We investigated the luminescence properties of Eu-MOF (3) in different small molecules, including DMF, DMA, MeOH, EtOH, acetone, CH3CN, CH2Cl2, toluene, nitrobenzene (NB) and ethylenediamine (EN) (Fig. S8). The luminescence intensities are largely dependent on the small molecules, especially for EN, which shows an intense quenching effect. Meanwhile, the aqueous solvent shows the strongest emission. As a result, we choose the aqueous solvent as the dispersion medium to detect amine molecules.

In order to investigate the sensitivity of luminescence quenching effects, the luminescence spectra were recorded by gradually increasing various concentrations of EN, EA, IPA, DiPA, and TEA, respectively (). All the five alkylamines lead to luminescence quenching and the luminescence intensities are decreased gradually with increasing the concentration of the alkylamines. When the concentration of the alkylamines (EN, EA, IPA, DiPA, and TEA) is increased to 1 mM, the quenching efficiency can reach 96.3/95.8/94.7/93.6/93.3%, respectively ( and S9). The order of quenching efficiency is EN > EA > IPA > DiPA > TEA. It is noted that the quenching efficiency is defined as (I0 - I)/I0 × 100% (where I0 is the original luminescence intensity of Eu-MOF (3), while I is the luminescence intensity of Eu-MOF (3) after the addition of the analyte). To quantitatively explain the results, the quenching efficiency can be calculated by the Stern-Volmer equation: (I0/I) = KSV[A] + 1, in which KSV is the quenching constant [M-1] and [A] is the molar concentration of the alkylamines. The Stern-Volmer plots show an almost linear relationship for all the five alkylamines at low concentrations (), with the KSV values listed in , which are relatively high compared to those of the reported MOF-based sensors for sensing alkylamines (Table S8). The KSV value (5.8 × 104 M-1) of EN is slightly higher than those of the other four alkylamines. According to 3δ/k () (δ: standard error; k: slope), the detection limits are obtained ().

A p-type Ti(IV)-based metal-organic framework with visible-light photo-response

Here, we report a new Ti(IV)-based porous metal-organic framework (MOF) (NTU-9), which displayed strong absorption in the visible region with a bandgap of 1.72 eV. The electronic structure and bandgap were further investigated by DFT calculations. Photoelectrochemical studies indicated that NTU-9 is photoactive under visible light illumination (λ > 400 nm) and acts as a p-type semiconductor. The results demonstrated that Ti(IV)-based MOFs could be promising visible-light photocatalysts for energy conversion and environmental remediation.

The diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 750s UV-Vis spectrometer. As shown in , the spectrum of NTU-9 shows a broad range of absorption in the visible region from 400 nm to 750 nm with an absorption peak centered at around 520 nm. The calculated bandgap of NTU-9 from the absorption onset is about 1.72 eV. The absorption of NTU-9 was dramatically red-shifted when compared with TiO2 (3.2 eV for anatase and 3.0 for rutile), and the reported Ti(IV)-based MOF MIL-125 (3.6 eV) and its isostructure MIL-125-NH2 (2.6 eV).

To understand the electronic structure of NTU-9, the density of states (DOS) and the electronic band structure of NTU-9 were calculated using the density functional theory (DFT) in the CASTEP program. As depicted in Fig. S4-S6 (ESI), the valence band (VB) of NTU-9 between the energy level (-4.0 eV) and the Fermi level (0.0 eV) is mainly contributed from the O 2p states mixed with a small amount of C 2p states. The conduction bands (CB) above Fermi energy are mostly made up of Ti 3d states, with minor contributions from the C 2p and O 2p states. The DOS results indicate the existence of charge transfer from the organic ligand to Ti(IV) atoms in NTU-9. The dominations of VB and CB by O and Ti atoms in NTU-9 are similar to that of TiO2, whose VB is mainly formed by the overlapping of O 2p orbitals and CB is mainly constituted of the 3d states of Ti. The small contributions of p atomic orbitals of carbon to the CB in NTU-9 may alter and further reduce the band gap by changing the degree of conjugation or functional group modification in the ligands. This ‘designable' character of MOFs could lead to the synthesis of more Ti(IV)-based MOF semiconductors with visible light activity. The CB minimum (1.74 eV) and VB maximum (0 eV) are located at the same k-point in the Brillouin zone (Fig. S4, ESI). The band structure illustrates that the interband transitions of NTU-9 are direct, which may exhibit a higher photonic efficiency compared with indirect band gap semiconductors such as TiO2. The calculated energy band gap for NTU-9 is 1.74 eV, which matches the experimental data very well.

The photoelectrochemical properties of NTU-9 were studied in a three-electrode set-up.  shows the photocurrent profile of the NTU-9/FTO electrode recorded under zero-bias (two-electrode, short-circuit) conditions, indicating that the NTU-9 is active under visible light (λ > 400 nm) illumination. The repeatable cathodic (negative) photocurrent of ~60 nA cm-2 suggests that NTU-9 is a p-type semiconductor. As shown in the inset of , the NTU-9/FTO cells also showed highly repeatable photovoltage (illuminated open-circuit potential) responses of ~7 mV during the on-off cycles of illumination throughout the measurement. To further reveal the conductivity and flat-band potential of NTU-9, the Mott-Schottky measurement was performed in 0.5 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution. As shown in , the negative slope indicates p-type behaviour of NTU-9, consistent with our previous analysis. Besides the p-type behavior, the Mott-Schottky measurement gives the flat-band potential of NTU-9 at around 0.76 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The carrier concentration of NTU-9 can be estimated from the slope of the Mott-Schottky plot using Na = (2/eoεεo)[d(1/C2)/dV]-1, where eo is the electron charge, ε is the NTU-9 dielectric constant, εo is the vacuum permittivity, and Na is the acceptor density. If we take the dielectric constant of NTU-9 to be ~101 (a typical value for most of the MOFs), the estimated carrier density of NTU-9 is ~1015 cm-3.

Magnetic properties

The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibilities of compounds 1, 2 and 3 were collected under a 1 kOe field in the temperature range of 2-300 K. On the basis of the structure, 1 contains one tetranuclear cobalt(II) and two binuclear cobalt(II). The observed χmT value of 1 at 300 K is 21.12 cm3 K mol-1, which is much larger than the spin-only value of 15.00 cm3 K mol-1 for eight isolated high-spin d7 ions, indicating significant orbital contributions of the distorted octahedral Co(II) ions. The χmT value decreases slowly to 6.75 cm3 K mol-1 at about 20 K, and then decreases to 0.83 cm3 K mol-1 quickly at 2 K (), which indicates strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the Co(II) ions. The χm-1vs. T data from 20 to 300 K conform to the Curie-Weiss law to give θ = -53.65 K and C = 12.46 cm3 K mol-1.

The χmT value of 2 at 300 K is 10.49 cm3 K mol-1, which is larger than the theoretically calculated value 7.50 cm3 K mol-1 for four magnetically isolated high-spin Co(II) atoms, indicating the orbital contributions of the distorted octahedral Co(II) ions (). The χmT value smoothly decreases to 5.22 cm3 K mol-1 at 50 K, and then rapidly drops to 0.66 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The χm-1vs. T obeys the Curie-Weiss law above 50 K and gives θ = -77.17 K and C = 13.18 cm3 K mol-1 between 50 and 300 K. The big negative Weiss constant indicates strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the Co(II) ions. The χmT value of 3 at 300 K is 8.13 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly larger than the theoretical value 7.50 cm3 K mol-1 for four magnetically isolated high-spin Co(II) atoms (). The χmT value smoothly decreases to 4.50 cm3 K mol-1 at 50 K, and then rapidly drops to 0.41 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K due to the strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the Co(II) ions. The χm-1vs. T obeys the Curie-Weiss law above 50 K and gives θ = -58.97 K and C = 9.72 cm3 K mol-1.

The degradation of methylene blue

Photocatalysts have attracted much attention due to their potential applications in purifying water and air by decomposing organic pollutants. Thus, methylene blue (MB), as a model dye contaminant, was selected to evaluate the photocatalytic effectiveness in the purification of waste water. The degradation experiment of MB was tracked by spectroscopy and the results are depicted in . It was found that the degradation rates of MB are 66.3% for 1, 61.6% for 2, 60.0% for 3 and 30.2% for blank experiment after 90 min. 1-3 remain stable after photocatalytic reaction. 1-3 are good photocatalysts for the degradation of the organic dye MB.

Some CPs show good photocatalytic activities for the degradation of the organic dye MB. For example, the Ding and Hou group reported six CPs which manifest good photocatalytic activities for the degradation of methylene blue (MB) (1: 74%, 2: 41%, 3: 37%, 4: 76%, 5: 46%, 6: 75% after 160 min under UV light and in the presence of H2O2. The Zhao and Zhang group recently synthesized five CPs. Three CPs (1-3) show relatively good photocatalytic activities for the degradation of methylene blue (MB) under UV light and in the presence of H2O2. The degradation efficiency of MB is up to 97.3% after 2 hours for 1, 77.4% for 2, and 66.8% for 3.

PXRD and thermal stability

The measured and simulated PXRDs confirm the purity of 1, 2 and 3 (Fig. S7, S8 and S9, ESI). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1, 2 and 3 was performed on crystalline samples heated from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. S10, ESI). The lattice and coordinated water molecules of 1 were completely lost at 148 °C (calcd: 9.05%, found: 9.25%), and the remaining substance was stable up to 210 °C. The residue of 1 at 800 °C should be CoO (calcd: 23.17%, found: 23.13%). The lattice and coordination water molecules of 2 and 3 were completely lost at 147 and 143 °C, respectively (calcd: 9.98, found: 10.02% for 2; calcd: 17.66, found: 17.38% for 3). The networks of 2 and 3 were stable up to 253 and 244 °C, respectively. The residues of 2 and 3 at 800 °C should be CoO (calcd: 23.72%, found: 23.13% for 2; calcd: 26.70%, found: 27.62% for 3).

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility χM for a collection of small crystals of 1 was measured between 1.8 and 300 K (). The magnetic susceptibility above 15 K obeys the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constant, θ=-3.1 K, and a Curie constant, C=0.432 cm3 mol- K. The C value corresponds to g=2.15, S=1/2 for a Cu2+ ion. The negative Weiss constant indicates antiferromagnetic interaction between copper ions. χM increases as the temperature is lowered, reaching a sharp maximum at ca. 8.8 K, suggesting antiferromagnetic ordering. The Neel temperature, TN, of l was determined from the plot of d(χMT)/dTvs.T at 5.0 K, shown in the inset of . The in-phase component of the ac susceptibility (χ') is frequency independent and also shows a maximum around 8-9 K, while the out-of-phase component (χ") is zero, in accordance with antiferromagnetic ordering (Fig. S1, ESI).

The field dependence of the magnetization for 1 at different temperatures is shown in . The magnetization below TN increases very slowly with increasing field in the beginning due to antiferromagnetic ordering, it then increases more rapidly as it undergoes a transition from an antiferromagnet to a spin-flop state at a rather high transition field of around 50-70 kOe, depending on the temperature. The magnetization value at 1.88 K is only 0.16 Nβ at 70 kOe, far from the saturation value of 1.1 Nβ for one Cu2+ ion with g=2.15, again consistent with antiferromagnetic ordering. The ordering temperature TN of a 3D antiferromagnet () should be just slightly less than T(χmax). In the case of 1, the ratio of TN/T(χmax) is only 0.57, suggesting that the antiferromagnet possesses low-dimensional characters, although the connection between the double-layers in 1 through 2,5-Me2pyz could make a crucial contribution to the magnetic ordering.

An electron-donating strategy to guide the construction of MOF photocatalysts toward co-catalyst-free highly efficient photocatalytic H2 evolution

Herein, an interesting electron-donating strategy is proposed to guide the construction of novel CdS-based MOFs for co-catalyst-free photocatalytic H2 evolution in the presence of triethanolamine as the hole-scavenger. The optimally designed CdS-based MOF exhibits an exceptional H2-evolution rate of 26.1 mmol g-1 h-1 which is almost the highest rate among the reported co-catalyst-free MOF systems.

The experimental XRD pattern of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF is shown in , which matches very well with the simulated one that is obtained on the basis of single crystal structure analysis, indicating a good phase purity of the constructed MOF. Furthermore, the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF possesses good thermal and chemical stabilities (Fig. S1 and S2). The electronic structure simulations of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF were completed using density functional theory with the Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE06) hybrid functional, and the computational details are shown in the ESI. As illustrated in , the predicted band gap of the MOF is about 3.32 eV, which coincides basically with its actual absorption edge position(~388 nm for ~3.2 eV) obtained from the UV-vis absorption spectrum (). The level-off tail in the absorption spectra is believed to be due to the structural defects in the MOF. Furthermore, the projected density of states (PDOS) () shows that the valence band maximum (VBM) of the DLNU-M-CdS (H2TD) MOF is mainly composed of S 3p and N 2p orbitals while its conduction band minimum (CBM) is mainly constituted by C 2p and Cd 5s orbitals. Upon intrinsic photo-excitation of the MOF, the photoinduced electrons would transfer from the S 3p/N 2p to Cd 5s orbitals, simultaneously leaving the photoinduced holes in the S 3p/N 2p orbitals. Thus, the photo-oxidation and photo-reduction active-sites of the MOF are located on the S/N and Cd atoms, respectively. According to the crystal structure of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF and the interaction between the MOF and hole-scavenger TEOA, the photoinduced charge-carrier migration channels from the N 2p to the Cd 5s orbital in the MOF should play a key role in the improvement of photocatalytic activity for proton reduction.

The photocatalytic proton-reduction test of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF was conducted under UV-visible light irradiation with TEOA as the sacrificial hole-scavenger but without any additional co-catalyst or photo-sensitizer. Control experiments indicated that no H2 evolution occurred in the absence of either photocatalysts or light irradiation. As observed in , the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF exhibits a remarkable photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution. Furthermore, the H2-evolution amounts strongly depend on the content of the hole-scavenger TEOA, suggesting that the electron-donating process from the TEOA to the MOF serves as the leading factor for the photocatalytic proton reduction. In our case, the optimal photocatalytic activity of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF appeared in the photocatalytic system containing 15 vol% TEOA. When a higher content of TEOA was used for the photocatalytic reaction, the adsorption-desorption and diffusion behaviors of TEOA on the MOF surface may be limited due to the high viscosity of TEOA, thereby resulting in a decreased photocatalytic activity. What's more, the initial pH value for the TEOA water solution also influences the photocatalytic H2-evolution of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF (). A low pH value of the photocatalytic solution would impede the formation of double-hydrogen bonds between TEOA and the ligand of the MOF due to the protonation of the N atom in the ligand. In this case, the electron-donating process from the TEOA to the MOF was greatly weakened, which therefore led to a fast recombination of charge-carriers and a low activity of the MOF for photocatalytic H2 evolution. Moreover, a high pH value of the photocatalytic solution is also not beneficial for the H2 evolution, due to the fact that a small amount of H+ ions is supplied to the photo-reduction active-sites (Cd atoms) of the MOF. As concluded from the above results, the optimal photocatalytic solution for the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF is 15 vol% TEOA in water with the initial pH at 9. Upon UV-visible light irradiation, the MOF exhibits a good time-dependent photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of 26.1 mmol g-1 h-1 (). Notably, this H2-evolution rate is almost the highest one among the values reported for other co-catalyst-free photocatalytic systems over the MOF photocatalysts (). Moreover, the apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF reaches ~1.38% at 365 nm by using only 1 mg of the photocatalyst. This AQE is comparable to the corresponding values obtained from the co-catalyst-assisted MOF photocatalysts. Interestingly, when we used the other sacrificial hole-scavengers with different bonding abilities to the H2TD ligand during the photocatalysis, the photocatalytic activity of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF for H2 evolution was changed obviously according to the electron-donating process from the scavenger to the MOF (Fig. S3 and Table S2). These results confirm the efficiency of the electron-donating strategy proposed in our work.

To further generalize the electron-donating strategy in the design of co-catalyst-free MOF photocatalysts, another novel isomeric CdS-based MOF of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) was constructed through a similar hydrothermal process by using CdCl2⋅5/2H2O as the metal node precursor (Fig. S4-S6). According to the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) MOF belongs to the monoclinic space group P21/n (Fig. S7). As expected, this MOF also displays the co-catalyst-free photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution in the presence of the hole-scavenger TEOA upon UV-visible light irradiation (, S8 and S9). However, after optimizing the photocatalytic solution parameters, the H2-evolution rate of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) was only 6.9 mmol g-1 h-1, which is about 3.8 times lower than that of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD). The different photocatalytic activity of these two CdS-based MOFs can be attributed to their discrepant crystal and electronic structures. As evidenced by the crystal structures ( and S10) and the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) results, the content of metal Cd nodes in DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) (~12.3 wt%) is lower than that in the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) (~22.9 wt%). Meanwhile, the Cd coordination node in DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) is only bonded with one N atom from the H2TD ligand. Similarly, DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) is also a UV-light-active semiconductor with the band gap larger than that of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD), as concluded by both the theoretical calculation and experimental results (). Importantly, the two isomeric MOFs possess the same orbital constitutions for their CB and VB, implying that the electron-donating strategy is also suitable for the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) MOF toward the co-catalyst-free photocatalytic proton reduction. However, although electron donation from the hole-scavenger TEOA to the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) MOF across the formed hydrogen bond O-H⋯N can effectively hinder the charge-carrier recombination, photoinduced electron transfer from the N to Cd atoms in the MOF is unsatisfactory due to only one electron-migration channel (Cd-N) in this MOF. Please note that there are two migration channels (N-Cd-N) in the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) MOF. Based on the above results and analyses, we deduce that the Cd nodes in the two MOFs are main photo-reduction active-sites for H2 evolution. Thus, the lower photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution over the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) as compared to the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) can be ascribed to the following two reasons: (i) the low content of Cd nodes for providing photo-reduction active-sites; (ii) poor electron transfer from N to Cd atoms limits the generation of the available electrons for executing the proton reduction.

To confirm the above assumption, a series of photoinduced carrier-dynamics tests were performed on the two MOFs.  shows the measurement results of the incident-photon-to-current-conversion efficiency (IPCE) and the transient photocurrent responses (TPR). It can be seen that the IPCE curves of the two samples match well with their respective intrinsic absorption curves, indicating that the defect-induced visible-light absorptions of these samples do not contribute to the separation of charge-carriers for executing the H2 evolution. Furthermore, the maximum IPCE of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) is about 6.7% at 300 nm. This value is ~3.0 times larger than the corresponding IPCE of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) (~2.2%). Meanwhile, the transient photocurrent of the DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) (~1.12 mA) is ~3.5 higher than that of DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD)(H2O) (~0.32 mA) during several on-off cycles of irradiation by UV-visible light. Thus, we believe that the Cd nodes in the MOF act as the main supports for releasing the photoinduced electrons. And, the corresponding bonding mode between the Cd nodes and their adjacent N atoms affects the separation process of the photoinduced charge-carriers in the MOF. Please note that the above IPCE and TPR values of the two MOFs should be much smaller than their real values, because the insulating organic binder is introduced to fix the MOFs onto the electrodes during the tests.

Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structures

Single crystal X-ray structure analyses reveal that all three complexes are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit found in compounds 1-3 contains one Ln(hfac)3, three Cu(hfac)2 moieties and two NITPhPyrim radical ligands, but there are two CH2Cl2 solvent molecules for complex 1 ( and Fig. S1 and S4 in the ESI). Each LnIII ion is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms coming from three hfac ligands and two radical ligands. As is known, the eight-coordinate geometries may be mostly taken as D4d-square antiprism (SAPR), D2d-dodecahedral (DD), or C2v-bicapped trigonal prism (TPRS). Continuous shape measurements have been performed with SHAPE to evaluate the actual shape of the coordination spheres of the Ln centers for complexes 1-3 (). The results indicate that all of them are located in distorted dodecahedral environments (D2d) and the changes in the coordination environments from 1 to 3 are small. In the three complexes, the average Ln-O (nitroxide) bond distances are 2.366, 2.324 and 2.297 Å for complexes 1-3 respectively, which become shorter with an increase of the atom number of lanthanide due to lanthanide contraction. The CuII ions are located in elongated octahedral coordination environments. The equatorial plane is formed by four oxygen atoms of hfac with the average Cu-O(hfac) bonds of 1.962, 1.952 and 1.942 Å for 1-3, respectively. The apical positions are occupied by one nitrogen atom from the pyrimidine ring of one radical ligand and one oxygen atom from the other radical ligand for Cu1 and Cu2 with the average Cu-O (nitroxide) bonds of 2.506 Å for 1, 2.504 Å for 2 and 2.510 Å for 3 and Cu-N (pyrimidine) bonds of 2.301, 2.317 and 2.296 Å for 1-3, respectively, while two nitrogen atoms of two pyrimidine rings from two radicals are located in axial positions for Cu3 with the average Cu-N (pyrimidine) bonds of 2.378, 2.385 and 2.378 Å for 1-3, respectively. It is obvious to see that the axial bond lengths are significantly longer than the basal distances owing to the Jahn-Teller elongation effect. As shown in , S2 and S5, two NITPhPyrim radicals as bridged ligands link two Cu(hfac)2 units through the oxygen atoms of nitroxide groups and pyrimidine nitrogen atoms to form a [Cu2(NITPhPyrim)2] dimer ring. Each cyclic dimer binds to two Ln(hfac)3 units through its two NO groups to result in a one-dimensional chain. Finally these 1-D chains are connected to Cu(hfac)2 units through the pyrimidine nitrogen atoms of the radical ligands to lead to one two-dimensional layer, in which the NITPhPyrim radical ligand acts as a tetradentate to bridge metal ions in μ4-η1 : η1 : η1 : η1 mode. Within the two-dimensional network, the distance of Cu2⋯Cu3 is 6.440 Å for complex 1, 6.234 Å for complex 2 and 6.205 Å for complex 3. The Cu⋯Ln distance is 8.686 Å for complex 1 (Cu1⋯Tb1), 8.627 Å for complex 2 (Cu2⋯Ho1#1, #1:x, -1/2 - y, -1/2 + z) and 8.634 Å for complex 3 (Cu2⋯Yb1#2, #2:x, 3/2 - y, -1/2 + z). The 2-D heterospin layers stack parallel to one another with the shortest interlayer Cu⋯Ln separation of 9.875 Å for complex 1 (Cu1⋯Tb1#3, #3:2 - x, -1/2 + y, 1/2 - z), 10.189 Å for complex 2 (Cu1⋯Ho1#4, #4:1 - x, 1/2 + y, -1/2 - z), and 10.119 Å for complex 3 (Cu1⋯Yb1#5, #5:-x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 - z) (, S4 and S6).

Magnetic properties

Variable-temperature dc magnetic susceptibility data for compounds 1-3 were investigated in the temperature range 1.8-300 K and under an applied field of 1000 Oe (). At room temperature, the χMT values of complexes 1-3 are 14.72, 17.26 and 5.26 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are somewhat above the expected values (1: 13.70; 2: 16.02; 3: 4.52 cm3 K mol-1) for one isolated LnIII (TbIII: 7F6, S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2, C = 11.82 cm3 K mol-1; HoIII: 5I8, S = 2, L = 6, g = 5/4, C = 14.07 cm3 K mol-1; YbIII: 2F7/2, S = 1/2, L = 3, g = 8/7, C = 2.57 cm3 K mol-1) ion, two radicals (S = 1/2, C = 0.375 cm3 K mol-1) and three CuII (S = 1/2, C = 0.375 cm3 K mol-1) ions assuming that g = 2.0. Upon cooling, for 1, the χMT value remains almost constant until 90 K, and then increases more and more sharply to reach a value of 19.52 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, indicating that ferromagnetic interactions dominate in this compound. For 2, the χMT value remains almost constant as the temperature is reduced to 50 K and then decreases rapidly to reach 9.60 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K. For 3, as the temperature is lowered, the χMT value gradually decreases to 3.87 cm3 K mol-1 at 35 K and then drops down sharply to 1.63 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K. According to the crystal structure, the oxygen atoms of NO groups of NITPhPyrim radical ligands are directly coordinated to CuII ions in the apical positions, in which the magnetic orbitals of the CuII ion (dx2-y2) and the nitroxide group (π*) are orthogonal to each other, and this will result in ferromagnetic interaction. The magnetic coupling between the LnIII ion and the directly coordinated nitroxide group also suggests the presence of ferromagnetic coupling for the LnIII with 4f7-4f10 electronic configurations. The magnetic coupling between two CuII ions through the pyrimidine ring should be weak because two CuII ions are connected via axial-axial positions and the out-of-plane exchange pathway is involved. The magnetic exchange coupling between the CuII ion and the nitroxide group through phenyl and pyrimidine rings should be weak, which is expected to be ferromagnetic according to the spin-polarization mechanism (Chart S1). In addition, there exists an important antiferromagnetic coupling between two NO groups through LnIII ions. Thus ferromagnetic interactions are expected to dominate these complexes. The magnetic behaviors of the Ho and Yb complexes do not exhibit an increase of their χMT values as the T are lowered, indicating that the ferromagnetic Ln-radical contributions are weaker for these two ions and their effect on χMT is just overwhelmed by the stronger contributions of the crystal field effect as compared to Tb. The M versus H curve at 2.0 K for complexes 1-3 shows that the magnetization smoothly increases with the applied field to the values of 10.59, 11.16 and 4.92Nβ at 7 T, respectively (Fig. S7), which are much lower than the expected saturation values, indicating the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in the three complexes.

To further investigate the dynamics of magnetization, the alternating current (ac) susceptibilities have been measured for compounds 1-3. For 1, both in-phase (χ') and out-of-phase (χ'') susceptibilities show a strong frequency dependence under zero direct current (dc) field (), demonstrating the existence of magnetic relaxation behavior. Unfortunately, these data do not show the maximum of χ'' in the temperature region technically available, which can be attributed mainly to quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM). To shut down the tunneling pathway, an external magnetic field can be applied to split the degenerate levels and prompt the slow relaxation of the magnetization. Thus the ac susceptibilities of the Tb complex are measured in a 3 kOe external field. As a result, both in-phase and out-of-phase frequency-dependent signals are more visible and good peak shapes are observed. Notably, there are two relaxation phases, corresponding to the low-temperature signal region and the high-temperature signal region (). To further understand the nature of the two types of dynamics, two sets of magnetization relaxation parameters in the form of ln(τ) versus 1/T plots were analyzed by the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0exp(Δ/kBT), and the activation energies (Δ) for the magnetization reversal were estimated as Δ(1)/kB = 22.63 K with τ0(1) = 9.35 × 10-8 s for the high-temperature peak series and Δ(2)/kB = 11.89 K with τ0(2) = 1.14 × 10-7 s for the low-temperature peaks (). These obtained τ0 values are consistent with the expected characteristic relaxation time of 10-6-10-11 s for SMMs. Both thermally activated relaxation processes are attributed to the Orbach process because the two τ0 values and the two activation energies are similar.

X-ray diffraction analyses carried out on single crystals indicate that complex 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. The asymmetric unit consists of one Nit-Ph-3,5-bIm radical ligand, one Gd(hfac)3 unit, one diethyl ether solvent molecule and one coordinated water molecule. For complex 1, Nit-Ph-3,5-bIm radicals serve as bridging ligands to connect Gd(hfac)3 units into a one-dimensional chain () via their nitrogen atoms from the imidazole rings. The Gd center is coordinated by six O atoms from three didentate hfac ligands (Gd-O: 2.401(2)-2.484(2) Å), two N atoms from two imidazole rings (Gd-N: 2.537(2) and 2.586(2) Å) and one O atom from the water molecule (Gd-Ow: 2.463(2) Å). Geometry analysis of the GdIII center using SHAPE software shows that the nine-coordinate GdIII ion is located in a spherical capped square antiprism coordination sphere (C4v) (Table S3). The radical ligand separates the lanthanide ions at 12.440 Å for 1. The shortest interchain Gd⋯Gd distance is found to be 9.553 Å for 1. The NO groups of the radical ligands are free and the closest NO⋯ON distance is 3.514 Å for 1. Previous studies have shown that such a short distance might lead to important magnetic interactions. The magnitude of the magnetic coupling can be related to the separation between two NO groups, the N-O⋯N angle (α) and the dihedral angle (β) between the plane (N-O⋯O-N) and the plane (O-N-C-N-O) of the nitronyl nitroxide radicals (Chart S1). The α and β are 108.69° and 73.82° for 1.

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities for compound 1 have been measured under 1 kOe in the temperature range of 2-300 K. The resulting χMT vs. T plot is depicted in .

For complex 1, the measured χMT value at room temperature is 8.35 cm3 K mol-1, being very close to the theoretical value of 8.26 cm3 K mol-1 for one uncoupled GdIII ion (GdIII: 8S7/2, S = 7/2, L = 0, g = 2, C = 7.88 cm3 K mol-1) and one organic radical (S = 1/2). On cooling the sample, the χMT value increases continuously to reach a maximum of 9.35 cm3 K mol-1 at 4 K, and then rapidly decreases to 9.32 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. This observation suggests that the ferromagnetic interaction dominates in the present magnetic system. Based on the above structural analyses, three kinds of magnetic exchanges should be considered. One is the magnetic coupling between the Gd(III) ion and the NO group through phenyl and imidazole rings, which is expected to be very weak due to a small spin density on the N atom of imidazole. Another magnetic exchange arises from the neighboring uncoordinated NO⋯ON interaction due to the short distance (3.513 Å). However, the other two important geometric parameters related to such a magnetic coupling, α and β (α: 108.69°; β: 73.82°), significantly deviate from 90°, which suggest that the overlapping of π*-orbitals is not fully effective. Consequently, a very weak exchange interaction is envisaged. The last magnetic exchange is the magnetic coupling between the Gd and NO groups through a hydrogen bonding bridge, which should be the main pathway to transmit magnetic coupling in the present magnetic system. Accordingly, the magnetic behavior of 1 could be analyzed as a two-spin magnetic system consisting of Gd and nitroxide groups. The theoretical expression is deduced from the spin Hamiltonian H = -JSRadSGd as . Other weak magnetic couplings are introduced by using the mean-field, zJ'. (1)χM = χRadGd/[1 - (zJ'χradGd/Ng2β2)]

The optimized magnetic parameters are J = 1.76 cm-1, g = 2.02, zJ' = -0.022 cm-1. These results indicate that the magnetic interaction between the Gd and NO groups via a hydrogen bond is ferromagnetic. The observed appreciable magnetic exchange might be ascribed to the considerably short OH⋯ON distance of 2.766(3) Å.

The field dependent isothermal magnetization measurement for complex 1 was determined at 2.0 K (). As the field is increased, the experimental magnetization increases up to 8.12Nβ at 7 T for 1, which is in good agreement with the expected saturation value of 8.0Nβ. Moreover, the experimental M value is above the magnetization calculated using the Brillouin function for one non-coupled S = 7/2 and one S = 1/2 spin center at low fields, clearly supporting the N-O⋯Gd ferromagnetic exchange interaction.

This weight loss corresponds to 0.75 DMF molecules per formula unit (calc. 5.0%) and is consistent with the elemental analysis.  of the framework is observed above 300 °C. The -free framework, 1a, was obtained by heating a crystal of 1 at 200 °C for about 20 min. The crystal structure of 1a is similar to that of 1, except that the DMF and  molecules in the  channels are removed from the framework (see ESI). The integrity of the microporous framework was also confirmed by measuring the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1a, which shows sharp diffraction peaks similar to those of 1 even without  molecules (). The temperature-dependent PXRD patterns suggest the stability of the framework up to 300 °C (Fig. S4, ESI), which is consistent with the TGA result.

The host framework, 1a, was subjected to gas sorptions using CO2, H2 and N2. It was observed that 1a adsorbs CO2 and H2, but not N2 (). A steep rise was observed at relatively low pressure in the adsorption branch of CO2, this early uptake indicating the presence of permanent micropores in 1a. Calculations based on the T-method from H2 isotherm gave a pore opening of ca. 5.5 Å, consistent with the single-crystal structure analysis. The pore volume for 1a (0.056 mL g-1) measured from H2 isotherm indicates that less than a half of the available pore volume (0.120 mL g-1, calculated using PLATON) was filled at 77 K. The BET surface areas estimated from the CO2 and H2  isotherms are 210 and 90 m2 g-1, respectively (see ESI). The difference in the surface areas indicates that the effect of the framework polarity is significant. The framework host, which contains Cd2+ ions, ligated water molecules, the polar residues and the π-electrons of the , gives rise to an electric field that induces a dipole in CO2. Besides such dipole-induced dipole interactions, the quadrupole moment of CO2 (3.3-3.4 × 10-26 e.s.u.) would interact with the electric field gradient, providing a further contribution to the potential energy of . In addition, there may be some donor-acceptor affinity between the CO2 molecules and the Lewis acidic Cd2+ ions.
